description:
Food here was so good! The table habanero sauce was spicy  so a little goes a long way! 

Their Arnold Palmer was too sweet, but I diluted with water. The slow cooked pork was amazing! ($16) service 
Was great  thanks Hugo.
author: Kent B.

description:
Went for an early dinner today and ordered the Pastelon and also the vegetarian plate. Presentation:10 Flavor:6 Service:7 Location:3 
 
I usually go to Sol food in Mill Valley but decided to give this place a try and lets just say I will continue to make the drive. The plates here "look" good but lack major flavor and as far as the plates that come with beans well there are maybe 3 or 4 beans in the small cup. The lemonade was delicious but like I said if you don't know PR food then this is just fine but if you do you will be really disappointed.
author: Vee N.

description:
**This is totally comfort food for Latin American cuisine.** We absolutely loved the experience here. 

A friend and I came here for dinner on a Friday evening. I ordered the slow-roasted pork ($16.50) and a glass of the house red ($7). The red was very delicious and didn't taste like a glass of $7 wine at all. I was pleasantly surprised. 

The slow-roasted pork came with mixed greens, rice, plantains, and a dipping bean sauce. Everything was cooked with full flavor and done very well. Making this dish at home would have taken massive effort so I'm glad I got to enjoy it here. The portion was massive so be prepared to take leftovers home. 

This is great bang for the buck -- I highly recommend coming here for a casual dinner with friends looking for a hearty meal. 

Docking a star because it was pretty salty, and the plantains were really charred on the outside. Despite this, I'll be coming back for sure.
author: Julia Y.

description:
As a person with Puerto Rican heritage, I want Puerto Rican food that makes me feel at home. I went here on a Sunday for a late lunch. Lots of communal seating, but we chose a two-top. I absolutely love the decor; the beautiful bright turquoise paint on the outside and inside of the restaurant reminds me of the island, where all the buildings are painted in bright colors :) There were beautiful paintings and posters inside and a large, stunning glass pantry display with Florecitas, PR coffee, Goya goods, etc. It's an authentic, heart-warming environment. 

I ordered the pastelon (sort of a plantain meat lasagna) and my girlfriend had the bistec (looked like flank or skirt steak -- cooked about med-med well with sauteed onions). Authentic, good flavor, but everything could have been more flavorful. The red beans were the most flavorful dish. Most of what we had was on the greasy side, although much of PR food from restaurants is that way -- It is soul food after all... My abuelo adds tons of oil/lard to his cooking :) The sangria was refreshing. Didn't try the flan, but will next time! Definitely will return! Muchas Gracias, Parada 22! Viva Borinquen!!!
author: Ariana W.

description: Just as good as sol food and there was no wait whatsoever! Had the camarones a la criolla, the sauce was so good. I would frequent this place over sol food any day if I lived in the area.
author: Dakota C.

description:
When you're alone, and life is making you lonely, you can always find me at Parada 22. When I'm homesick or sad, I head straight to the Upper Haight where the smell of Puerto Rican fried chicken fills the street. The place is tiny, with exposed brick walls coinciding with bright turquoise paint. Plenty of vintage Puerto Rican ephemera and tchotchke to look at while you're waiting for your food to arrive. And while they do have the greatest hits like Mofongo, Pastelon and arroz con gandules...I find their arroz con gandules bland. Lately, I've been coming here once a month and I order the same thing...the sampler.

The Sampler $15 | Chicharron de pollo (fried chicken), yucca simmered in mojo, pernil, maduros and tostones. 

Their tostones are by far the best: so thin and crispy with none of the toughness so many other places possess. Add some of their pique and salt. But, I only got two pieces of fried chicken tonight in lieu of the usual four. Sad. But, their chicken is generously seasoned and because they cut it in chunks, the skin is extra crispy in every bite but the inside is juicy. The yuca is tender and acidic and the maduros are like little bites of custardy pudding with crispy edges. The lechon can range from dry to moist, but adding the pique helps lift it up. And of course, they give you a cup of garlicky mayoketchup for dipping. I know Ricans love that shit, but I do not.

I love this place. It's better than Sol Food. I will fight you to prove it.

They do have a bathroom for customers, it's hidden. Seating is semi-comfortable for gordas. Parking is a crap shoot.
author: Illyanna M.

description:
Puerto Rico vibes but I havent been there yet so what do I know? 

See attached photos for the mofongo de pollo marinado and the rest laying on my plate. Need I say more?

I'm bringing my family to reserve this little joint. I cant believe this place has been overlooked!

The hot sauce on the table is is delicious! Its NOT tapatio! The service was great. Super friendly waiters.

I'd come back soon for sure!
author: Alessandra E.

description:
This here is a hidden gem. Narrowly fit between two larger restaurants, Parada 22 is a tiny restaurant that serves some delicious AND affordable Puerto Rican food. Did I mention that the portions are incredibly generous too? Despite the size of the place, it's not crowded which I find is unusual given how good this place is.

The plates are all great, though you need to definitely try the pastelon, a ground beef mixture layered with plantains. Plates will usually come with rice, beans, and maybe salad or plantains. Another notable item that isn't necessarily plates is the bistec sandwich, I don't know how they cooked the bistec but it was perfection. Trust me, anything on the menu is a must try.

So what's not to love? Delicious and savory food, affordable prices, great ambiance, and no wait. That's unheard of in SF but Parada 22 provides just that.
author: Derek T.

description: Back again and this time with our son who can eat solids. Still love everything about this restaurant. My husbands home town food and he occasionally has cravings to come here. Hopefully my son will also come on his own as he gets older. My little one and was eating all the food and he's only one lol. Lively music, friendly staff, and soulful Puerto Rican food. Down side is the limited seating and wait on food because they make it so soon as the order gets in. My recommendation would be to be ready to order as soon as you get seated.
author: Jinnie L.

description:
I've honestly walked past this restaurant for years straight into Cha Cha Cha. A gf that lives near by suggested this place and I wish I came here sooner. Great food and ambience. Good for a casual date or lunch. Wouldn't suggest large party as place is small and seating is very limited (they don't take reservations).

My man just moved to SF from Miami and he loves coming here to tear up some tostones and beans and rice. Cali does good Mexican food. Miami does good Latin American cuisine.. is what it is.

So far I've tried the Bistec salad with vinaigrette or eggplant sando. But every time I come a must order is the Yuca Frita. It comes with a creamy garlic sauce *drools. The orange hot sauce on the table is great as well! 

4/5 stars as service is kinda slow and sometimes it's cash only? Merp.
author: Ashley Renee B.

description: I've been to PR and used to live in NYC where the puerto rican food slows like wine and this place is legit. They only difference, really, is price. But when you're the only show in town, you get to charge more cause of like, monopolies, and stuff.
author: Misha T.

description:
Okay. Ate here for the first time last week and loved in. I had shrimp and my friend had the plaintain lasagne thing. Both were sooo good.
Last night we had take out and i tried the fried chicken and found it was not to my liking.My hub had the steak salad and it was okay. I find th salad greens are highly wilted and very unappealing to see little own eat. Eating in the salad was fresh and green. I think the vote is, eat in not take out. 
**We also had a side of plantains and oh they are so good.  just add sour cream.
author: Bron L.

description:
Large portions - you will have enough food left over to have lunch the next day, cozy location - just a few tables really packed together, friendly staff - very attentive and kind.  The food was delicious although it seemed a bit watered down in flavor than I was expecting to experience.

This restaurant is definitely worth a pop in, but I will continue my hunt.

Parking is a bit tough to find, I didn't realize it was in The Haight district when I chose the location and so circling for 30-45mts is expected, especially on Saturdays when the weather is good!
author: Koko M.

description: This puertorican spot is bomb.com everything was delicious it's a must try and great customer service.
author: Angelina R.

description:
I got their daily special for $12 which was roasted pork, rice, and salad. It's a good portion which I enjoyed. I love places that give you a lot for the price.

The salad was really good. It was basic but good. I inhaled that.

The pork was ok. Honestly, I didn't enjoy it. It was juicy for sure but had no flavor. It was bland. I kept on adding salt and pepper and it still didn't do anything. It made me wish I would've gotten something else because I did hear good things about this place from a friend.

The venue is small so expect long waits or get there early. It's a cute place though. The decor is so comfy and makes you feel like you're eating at your Puerto Rican friend's grandma's house or something.

I would come back again to try their other dishes.
author: Jerome N.

description:
What a hidden gem.

But it's not super hidden if you pass by this area frequently; though it's narrow, it's an amazing aqua green color that makes it stand out with its quirky decor. 

It's a small space, but my group of 4 (2pm Sunday) got a table after waiting 20 min and got our food in 15 min maybe?

Wow, I'm seriously impressed by the value of this place considering it's SF! For around $12-14 you get huge portions! The plates we got came with Spanish rice, beans, a side salad and DELICIOUS plantains.

I tried the famous pastelon which is like a lasagna but with plantains layering with ground beef. It's a huge portion! Honestly, I couldn't finish, I wish I did! Usually I equate ground meats with cheap Taco Bell quality stuff, but this changed my mind! It's not one monotonous mushy texture, it's crispy, and mixed with different ingredients. LOVE. But pretty heavy.

The chicken was standard. The steak was good. The sampler plate was really cool! The fried chicken was pretty salty, and the pork very flavorful. My favorite was the fried plantain chips, super good. 

Seriously, some real bang for your buck here. Even though Mission might seem to have all the good food, this Puerto Rican spot is totally worth a visit.
author: Lilian K.

description: tasty stuff, mofongo steak was good but last time the plain steak was dry. pernil was shooo juicy.
author: Xue H.

description:
We went for lunch on a weekend and we were seated immediately.  I ordered the pulled pork, and the portion size for the amount you pay is insanely good.  My plate had piles of food on it, with a large serving of pulled pork, a hefty scoop of spanish rice, some plantains, and a large size of salad.  They all tasted pretty solid and delicious - no complaints about the meal at all.

The only negative thing I would mention is that the service here is really slow.  We had to wait around 40 minutes between the time we sat down and the time we received our food.  After receiving the check, no one came by to pick up the credit card, so we had to walk it up ourselves.  Other than these issues, this is a pretty solid place to stop by for lunch if you're in the area.
author: Tim L.

description: My husband and I went in on a Tuesday afternoon and we were seated immediately. I ordered the shrimp mofongo dish. It came with white rice, beans, salad, plantains and the mofongo stuffed with shrimp. It was AMAZING. Kudos to our waitress who knew exactly my food restrictions when I said I was pescatarian. The beans are cooked in vegetable broth with pumpkin and she suggested we get the white rice since the other option was rice with ham. The food is unbelievably flavourful and the portion was very very generous. There was also a bottle of hot sauce that was top notch. We had the vanilla flan which was a cherry on top of my lunch. The place is very clean and hygienic. I highly recommend trying it out if you haven't yet.
author: Noor M.

description:
What a great little spot! We arrived here for lunch and had about a 20 minute wait as the place is pretty small inside.

We sat on one of the side tables and wanted to see what the favourites were from the server and they were all the ones we wanted to try so that was great! We got the Pernil Asado which was amazing, had the Spanish rice and the red beans which were really tasty! The Mofongo camarones which was also good! It's like a home cooked meal and hit the spot! 

This place has a great atmosphere and charm to it and will definitely be back!
author: Steven W.

description:
We found this little gem along the Haight while thrift / vintage shopping. The place is very small, but packed with patrons. We had to wait about 20-25 minutes for a table, but the food was definitely worth the wait. 

Between three people, we shared: 

1. Arroz con Mariscos: Our paella contained layers of flavors. Each bite of saffron rice with shrimp, scallop and mussel ratio was delectable and savory. Tip:  The paella does take a while to make, so be patient. I wish the Parada 22 staff would mention this whenever ordering. 
2. Fried Plantains: Delicious and sweet. It balanced out the Arroz con Mariscos dish. 
3. Yucca with garlic and aioli: When it arrived, it didn't look like much on the plate, but the combination definitely worked. Very tasty. 
4. Half pitcher of Sangria:  Sweet and strong. Do ask for glasses of water to temper and balance all of the flavors. 

Overall, the amount of food was perfect for three people, and each dish was flavorful. Thanks for bringing delicious food to the area, Parada!
author: Nina V.

description:
Place - It is easy to find. It's on the end of the height st. Here is a small restaurant. Restaurant is filled with tables. There is tiny room btw tables. Interior is old and interesting. Many old items are on the wall. 

Taste - I ordered CHICHARRONES DE POLLO and CAMARONES A LA CRIOLLA. 

CHICHARRONES DE POLLO - it is boneless fried chicken and salad, spanish rice and banana fried. It was good. Chicken was little salty for me. Spanish rice was simple amd good. Salade sauce was sour and good. I liked banana fried. It was little hard but good to ear with sauce. 

CAMARONES A LA CRIOLLA - it is shrimp and vegie with cream sauce. It also came with rice and salade. Also fried banana was on it. Shrimp was little good. Sauce was well made. There were many shrimp and vegie!

Service and Price - Service was good and Price was reasonable.
author: Da Won L.

description: BEWARE of whomever the server/hostess/bus-girl/owner (I sure hope it isn't) with the long brown hair, Rosalina maybe? SHE IS A LIABILITY TO THE ENTIRE ESTABLISHMENT. If she is the owner, I hope you figure it out and soon! And if you are not the owner then you are SINGLE HANDEDLY TAKING MONEY OUT OF THE OWNERS POCKETS.  the levels of insanity of this woman reach new heights.  If she is working when you are there RUN DONT WAK OUT.  will never ever step foot in this place again, and it's a shame because the food is amazing. letting EVERYONE know!!! Truly shame on YOU whatever your name may be.
author: Cal B.

description:
Everything we had was awesome and good sized. The roasted pork was cooked perfectly as well as the rice. The rice is amazing. The steak salad was huge. The cilantro salad dressing was one of the best I've had. They should bottle it and sell it, that good..  The price you pay is worth it because of the portions are so big. 
Love the hot sauce the table, goes great with everything especially the pork

Note:
Try Cuban sandwich next time
author: Douglas M.

description:
Finding this place in SFO was great! Completely unexpected. I am a Boricua in Expat in the US and was surprised how much this felt like a typical fonda back in the island. An even more so, i was so proud to see this was the only restaurant in the block with a wait. That was a good omen, and a boost to my Puertorican pride. 

Once you walk in you will see memorabilia from the beginning of modern Puertorican history, the 1979 panamerican games, and a huge "chinero" (china display) full of Puertorican staple foods. Everything from salted cod to florecitas are there. Also, salsa music fills the quaint location with an island flair that only a Puertorican born and raised in the island can understand.

Make sure you open with the sampler. The pernil is jut like my aunts makes it. The tostones have oil and garlic in true Puertorican manner, and come accompanied with salsa rosa ( mayo ketchup we call it in the island). The yucca mash was dead on! This is one of my favorite foods and although it was undercooked for my preference, it was cooked by the book. The chicharron was the least authentic, but the breading flavor was there.

As entre we ordered the mofongo with pollo a la criolla. In puerto rico we would call that stuffed mofongo. The chicken was well cooked, in a creamy sauce of veggies. It came accompanied by spanish rice and white beens, but you could choose your sides. The cook on the rice was perfect, grainy, but "sticky" and with all the peppers and olives we use. That plate got a 4.5 from me. 

The second plate we ordered was chicharron with Spanish rice and kidney beans. The beans were PERFECT. They were thick and smoky, just how I like them.  This plate got a 5, i loved the rice, the beans, and the batter on the chicken. 

The ambience like I mentioned earlier was incredible and the servers, although busy, make the best they can to come say hi and check up on you. 
I highly recommend this place and would come eat here once or twice a week if I lived in the city.
author: Emmanuel T.

description: Authentic and euphoric experience.  Best Mofongo I've had, including what I had in San Juan.  Cozy and community style eating.  Be patient with the wait, the food is worth it.
author: Ryan F.

description: Forget being the best Puerto Rican  food in San Francisco.   . They are the best Hispanic Food in the 415 & 628.  Come off hours.  Cannot get in during regular schedule it is packed.   Worth the trip.  OUTSTANDING.
author: Luis O.

description: Just phenomenal!!! Came across this place by chance and oh wow!!! The service is great.. just pure magic
author: Anita S.

description:
Came here for a quick lunch on a solo sunny day spent strolling the Haight. Not too busy for a 1:30pm on a Sunday and I got a seat at the side counter immediately.
There are a couple veg options, but my pescetarian side opted for the shrimp choice on the menu - the Camarones a la Criolla which is essentially shrimp in a creamy brothy soupy sauce sweetened with bell peppers and spiced with black pepper (typically I need more of a complex spice but they do this well!) - incredibly delicious, good fresh taste, smooth creamy texture without being too heavy!
On the side you get a couple maduros aka grilled plantains (sweet, smokey, not overdone! phew!) and a little bowl of bean stew - I got the vegetarian option which was white beans and some diced veggies in a very cilantro-heavy sauce, not super compelling and could have done without it. Also comes with plain rice to sop up the creamy sauce, and then a boring un-dressed salad (think costco bag of mixed greens lol).
Washed it all down with their sweet iced tea which was the perfect amount of sweet.

Ooh pro tip: they serve an orange-colored tangy (pineapply?) hot sauce on every table - pour this into the plain rice to kick it up a bit! Pairs SO well with the maduros too!

Will def return and try some of the brunch options!
author: Farrah N.

description:
Every bite was amazing! I ordered the shrimp mofongo.  
The place is small so food will  take some time but worth the wait!
author: Izzy C.

description:
Had lunch here at noon on a Saturday and there was a decent amount of seating. I was told that this spot had authentic Puerto Rican food so I had high hopes.

I ordered the Pastelon which is ground beef layered between sweet plantains. I never had cooked plantains before but it tasted amazing. The tenderness and sweetness of the plantains paired well with the savory ground beef. I chose the red beans as a side and it was alright. I would recommend the yellow rice.

I was not a fan of the interior - it is too dark and noisy and the tables are set up awkwardly. Service was mediocre at best and the waitress was not very talkative or welcoming. Prices are reasonable and portions are pretty good. If I come back again it'll be because I was impressed with the food quality.

Food: 4.75/5
Value: 4.25/5
Service: 3/5
Overall: 4/5
author: Brian G.

description:
I've been to this place twice in one month! This spot has a cozy & homey yet lively feel! First time I came we waited about 30mins to be seated...but that was around dinner rush on a Saturday evening. Second time I came around 5pm on a Saturday and it was a much better wait time..only 5mins! The seating is very limited so be aware of that if dining w/a large party. 

The food was delicious!! I haven't had much Latin food..but from first bite I knew this was authentic! For the main plates they give you the option of white or yellow rice and the choice of red or black beans. I ordered the 'pollo encebolladao' and it was amazing!! They give a good sized piece of chicken, nicely grilled and very tasty! It came with rice & beans and a side salad. All very filling! 

Will definitely be back again! Hopefully next time I can catch their brunch!
author: Jenae K.

description:
Love love love
Place is pretty small. We actually sat right by the entrance with the curtain thing right in front of us. 
Did a short yelp review search and ordered the pork and fried chicken. Holy moly both were delicious! I tried their sangria and it was sweet but not too sweet. Loved everything except for the small space but I can't blame them- it's SF!
author: Catharine L.

description:
Came here with several friends the other day to try some Puerto Rican food.

I got the Bistec Encebollado, which is described as a marinated sirloin steak with caramelized onions. The entree also comes with choice of rice and beans, some salad, and maduros (which is fried plantains). My friends got the Chicharrones de Pollo (Fried marinated boneless chicken with salsa rosa and tostones) and the Pernil Asado (slow-roasted pork marinated with garlic and oregano). 

For my entree, I thought that the steak's flavor was nice, but it was a bit too dry for my personal preference. The rice and salsa went well with the steak, and while I'm not a big fan of the maduros, it was not overly fried to make me dislike it. Overall, my entree was pretty good and my biggest complaint would probably be the dryness of the steak. I managed to try some of the fried chicken from the Chicharrones de Pollo and slow-roasted pork from Pernil Asado, and they were both better than the steak, in my opinion. If I were to rank all three meats in order I would probably order them:
1) Chicharrones de Pollo
2) Pernil Asado
3) Bistec Encebollado


All in all, a good first-time experience with Puerto Rican food; I have no idea about the authenticity of the flavors, but I certainly didn't leave hungry!
author: Ed W.

description: Best lunch in San Francisco ! Lots of food for an affordable price. I had the pastelon - which was amazing. Delicious beef with peppers, raisins and spices inside yummy plantains. I loved the Spanish rice and beans - even the salad was great. It was hard to finish everything, but that didn't keep me from trying. This was actually my first time eating at a Puerto Rican restaurant, and I hope to find lots more in the future!
author: Katrina L.

description: Pastelon! So good here. Seriously, this is a great restaurant and you should check it out. We need more great Puerto Rican restaurants Parada 22. The Pernil Asado gets an honorable mention.
author: Jeremy B.

description:
Food is great , service is also great . We came here circa 2011/12 and since then it's our favorite spot to go for brunch or dinner when we are roaming around Haight.
If it's the first time you are here go for one of the plates, try the fried chicken or the roaste pork . Don't forget to order Sangria :) on your second try their cubano sandwich...

The inside decor has a nice vibe and I don't think they have changed anything since first time we have been here, and that's a good thing :) their price range is also reasonable considering the portion.
author: Farshid G.

description:
Food is great. 

Service is under par. 

What rubbed me the wrong way was being refused seating at the high top table in the window by the young lady at the restaurant. The table sits 4 and we were 2 people. She said these are only for parties of 4. I understand reserving the tables for larger parties but it was 3pm and we were the only guests in the restaurant. 

Would easily be a 4/5 stars if the hospitality was elevated.
author: Steve H.

description: We had a friend in LA that shared this spot once he heard we were heading to San Francisco. I reminded him that we Puerto Rican's can be a little tough on restaurants when it comes to our islands cuisine. He smiled and said if he was wrong that he would cover the meal. We arrived in San Fran and quickly checked into our hotel and then off to sight see. Needles to say we worked up an appetite. We Ubered over to Parada 22 and the minute we walked in I felt the presence of greatness, ok at least it smelled like greatness! It's was cozy just like hanging out in your tias sala. We ordered a pitcher of sangria roja and some tostones! Great start for sure. We all ordered something different and once everything arrived the silence was golden. Lucky for me they served a large enough portion to share. The pernil was melt in your mouth good and the arroz con gandules was like mami's. The locals are incredibly lucky to have this gastronomical wonderland in their hood. Que Rico!
author: Rafael R.

description:
This is always the first stop for me whenever in the Haight.  They now open for breakfast which is your typical American ailment with mimosas and coffee, but if you want the Puerto Rican goodness, that begins at 11am.  

Parada 22 is a tiny with a lofty ceiling and cultural motifs adorning the tall wall space.  "The Daily Special" has my honey and I hooked.  So we order the slow roasted pork, with rice, plantains and salad everytime.  This is the REAL breakfast of champions!  We also have a small pitcher of sangria with everytime too.  That little flat bottle of orange stuff at the table is their homemade hot sauce.  It's a refreshing light hot sauce with a nice kick of heat- not your typical heavy hot sauce.  Besides, the scrumptious, satisfying food, the staff is friendly, and accommodating.  What's not to like about this place??

It's the better restaurant on the block!  I'm always looking forward to my next visit!
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
The outside of this place is too eye catching not to check out. It's like a beautiful mermaid blue/green. The inside is pretty small but I don't think I've ever seen it terribly crowded. Full maybe, but not packed. 

I've only gone for breakfast, but would love to come back for dinner. My 2 friends and I all got their version of the breakfast burrito which came with a side of beans (red kidney i think or white vegetarian beans). 

The negative was that they screwed up both my friends orders by putting in bacon instead of chorizo and for mine they didn't put avocado in mine which I requested as one of my add-ons. And that avo extra is not cheap. Yes it showed up on the bill but I just bit my tongue and paid because they did give us a discount for messing up the order. The nice lady came back and admitted she wrote down chorizo but then communicated it to the kitchen staff incorrectly or something like that.

Anyways, shizz happens. They have bottomless mimosas I believe, so that's another great reason to come back. Food was tasty as heck too.
author: Kelly G.

description:
Whenever I'm in haight-ashbury and I need to eat something, I usually buy food to sustain myself but my expectations are pretty low---it's just not a good neighborhood for food.

So it was a pleasant surprise when we went here after bay to breakers festivities.   Everyone really enjoyed their meal and it was the perfect end to a funfilled day in the city.  I personally had the pollo criollo --- crispy grilled chicken with a creole sauce, with rice, beans, salad, and plantains for sides.  Everything was excellent.  This will definitely be my go to place to eat when I'm back in this neighborhood!
author: Monika L.

description:
We were recommended to come here by an employee of a store up the block. He said, "ooo try this bomb-ass Puerto Rican place" I was really excited. I love sweet plantains and yuca everything.

I got the vegetarian platter and I thought it was ok. It was very oily. The people I were with also felt that the meal was just ok. 

This is a really cute place and has a lot of potential. The bathroom is a little bit of an odd situation, you have to walk through the kitchen to get to it.
author: Demi K.

description: Great food, great service, lovely decor, a little cramped but that's no problem.
author: Charles K.

description:
I came here for lunch yesterday with a friend. The restaurant is extremely small- so be warned that there may be a wait if you have a big group! Two of us got seated in about 10 minutes. 

The food is seriously awesome! The portions are massive. I got the shrimp in garlic sauce and my friend got pulled pork. Both dishes came with rice, beans, salad, and plantains. The Spanish rice and black beans have ham, so opt for white rice and white beans if you don't eat it! We also tried the tostones (fried plantains) which came with a mayo based dipping sauce. Delicious as the food was, it was also on the heavier side, so I would not recommend this place if you're looking for something lighter. Still, it was delicious, and I will definitely return to try more things.
author: Ayushi A.

description:
I have coming here for the pass few years and was very impressed by the food but on Friday June 14 I asked if they can close the door because it was freezing the waiter explained that the owner wanted it open Then when I ordered my food I was extremely disappointed when  the food came, apparently they think that pepper goes on everything.  The steak with onion had so much salt and pepper I couldn't eat it. And the Tostones was the same not to forget the Yuca with onions. They put green Olives and other was watery. Now I am puerto Rican from NYC and all of the Puerto Ricans and Dominican in NYC or Puerto Rico's  restaurants I have never seen anyone put a lot of pepper on Tostones. That will be the last time I will eat there. I would rather drive to San Jose at the Habana  Cuba and Puerto Rican restaurant 
 Now that is great food
author: susan a.

description: I came back from PR recently and absolutely fell in love with the food. I found Parada on yelp and knew I had to try it. It did not disappoint. The food was so delicious. We had the caramones a la criolla,  pernil asado and sangria to drink. I would highly recommend all of the above. Portions were perfect. Service was great. Really cute atmosphere. Eat here !
author: Camille O.

description:
First time trying Puerto Rican food, and this place was just a fantastic experience, everything from the food, drinks and dessert were delicious, I got Mofongo de Camaranoes, Wife share with little girl a Piernil de Puerco, slow roasted Pork in a garlic sauce served with Spanish rice and beans both are really good, I drank Coco Rico soda different but delicious, finally we share a caramel flan....we will back soon for sure, service was really friendly and nice.

Good Latino Food!!!!
author: Mauricio A.

description: You don't find too many Puerto Rican places in sf, so when I heard about it I knew I had to try it. The wait was rather short, 15 minutes to be seated and around 20 to get our food. Waitress was nice and helpful, she pointed out the popular dishes. I ordered mofongo and fell in LOVE. I will most definitely be going back soon.
author: Kel L.

description: Love everything about Parada 22! Food just like we had on family occasions and holidays! So hard to find a good Puerto Rican restaurant in the bay! They get everything just right!!
author: MarySol M.

description:
is your chair wobbly?
good, the better to dance in your seat while you eat & convo.
and for like the 1st time ever, i wasn't the only one dancing. :p

FLAVORS are rich & bold

MUSIC is festive af, semi loud

AMBIENCE is crowded chatty. not for shy b.z.s lol

SAMPLER get it muhfuhs

VEGETARIAN / vegan options too

restaurante es muy divertido!
author: Dan B.

description:
I went for lunch today and as a puerto rican man who grew up with parents from the island, it's hard to fool me on the food. 

1. We were told they were on a wait, and to add our names to the clipboard which we did. After 5 minutes another group came (of 3) and they placed their names on the clipboard as well. A few minutes later, a group of 4 came.  Apparently, they didn't like that myself and the other croup were Puerto Rican, because they skipped over us and sat the group of 4.  So we waited. 

2. When we finally walked back in the hostess had quite an attitude, I'm sure because she was caught being messy. 

3. The food is okay people. After seeing some of these reviews I can understand why they think the food is authentic, but it isn't. Neither is the vibe. I even had to ask who in the restaurant was Puerto Rican, because although there were Latin people, they were definitely not from the islands, I'm guessing Mexican. I don't discriminate but coming from a Puerto Rican family we would have to have someone there if we owned a restaurant. 

4. The food has little to no flavor. Generally, our food is salty ( I must confess), but never lacks flavor. That could have been any rice Asian, Indian, Mexican. Sorry folks not a home town favorite or a favorite at all.
author: Daniel O.

description: The atmosphere is very friendly.  Never having had Puerto Rican food, the waitress recommended ..the ada and it did not disappoint.  Tender and flavorful plus a hearty helping resulted in me being very disappointed when i couldn't eat it all.  Absolutely recommend eating here.  Amazing.
author: Alecia M.

description:
Yum yum yum yum yum. Got the Camarones and it was delish exactly what I was expecting! Husband got the Asada and loved it also 

Just don't get the Malta beverage unless you know what it is, only downfall of my meal but 5 stars still!
author: Mary T.

description: Food was authentic and service was on point. Many so called Puerto Rican restaurants disappoint here in the Bay Area but not this one. Definitely will be a new spot for me in the future.
author: Cynthia Y.

description: Loved the food. But beware red beans and yellow rice have ham in it. Puerto Rican Cuisine at it's best. There  are only three desserts. Two kind of flans, coconut and vanilla and Mango mousse. They Do Not serve coffee. (bummer) Cafe con leche would of complete my experience.
author: Agueda R.

description: The service was amazing Thanks to our awesome waiter Jenny, I had a vegetarian breakfast sandwich and vegetarian biscuits and gravy, both were delicious. They also have bottomless mimosas for 16 bucks, for the amount of champagne they each had made every dollar worth it and Jenny was very attentive so we never had to ask for refills. 10/10
author: Bexzy V.

description: First time diner here and I personally had a tough time with what to get while looking at the different dishes on the menu. So I decided to get what most folks seemed to be ordering, the Pernil Asado. It's their slow cooked pork and it comes with rice, beans, salad and plantains. Yum! It EM was quite flavorful and one that I would consider a comfort meal. They give you a lot of meat so better have the stomach for it.
author: Chad B.

description:
I am Puertorican and I can definitely say this is NOT puertorican authentic cuisine . It may be some creole or I don't know what. But next time you have mofongo in your menu you better honor the platain famous dish back in Puerto Rico. The beans are just a mix of ham and tomate soup. I went just to get my heart broken. It may be seasoned foos but please don't call yourselves Puerto Rican food!

Ps. If you really want to experience mofongo and real habichuelas with recao go to Puerto Rico. We need the tourism now more than ever. My absolute recommendation is Casita Blanca in Santurce but any other kiosk on the street is better than this place. 

Also when I kindly tried to
Explain the waiter that my mofongo did not have any plantain he basically told me to
Shut up and that was their version. Well if you're going to culturally appropriate my foos at least apologize and take the dish.
author: Sara A.

description:
Parada 22 is great! The place is a little bit small so not ideal for big groups but the decor, staff and food are amazing!

Food wise I recommend the pastelon, with plantains and spiced beef. 
I also tried the pollo encebollado, which is good, and the plato vegetariano, but substituted to get the dark beans and yellow rice. The yuka in that dish wasn't to my liking, it's kind of soggy and not super tasty, but everything else was delicious.
Mains come with rice, beans, salad and plantains. So good!
author: Coralie S.

description:
I had the Pernil y Arroz Con Gandules. Lots of food and it was very tasty. Pernil was lean. The only thing it was missing was some cuerito!

Wife had the mofongo con camarones with yellow rice and red beans. She had better mofongo and shrimp elsewhere. 

The place decor brought me back to my Puerto Rican childhood. Boricua hasta los huesos!

Will try again the next time I visit San Francisco.
author: Alex A.

description:
If you come on the weekend for dinner you'll likely have to wait. But slip in for a weeknight dinner with no problem!!!

The STEAK SALAD is to die for!!! Affordable, delicious, lots of meat veggies and avocado! One of my favorite meals in SF!
author: Jean Marie C.

description:
Parada 22 was my first Puerto Rican food experience and goddam I REGRESARE (I will return)! 

Every bite of Parada 22's food was packed with flavor. Our party of 5 ordered: tostones, yuca fries, steak, and the chicharonnes de pollo. Of the order my favorite were the tostones and chicharonnes. Tostones were like crispy flat fries and the chicharonnes are like crispy fried chicken balls. 

I usually do not have a reason to go to the Haight, but now I do. I am so happy I tried Puerto Rican food and discovered a go-to restaurant.
author: John L.

description:
I have come here so many times and every time I am blown away. I normally get the Bistec Sandwich or the bistec, steak, plate. It comes with so much food and everything is so delicious. The flavors are amazing and perfectly cooked. 

I love the spicy vinegar sauce that is on the tables. Normally I douse my good in it. 

I would also highly recommend an order of the fried plantains as they are crunchy on the outside, soft on the inside and bursting with this caramel, charred spices flavor. 

I would recommend coming I during off times and not on a typically busy night as it's a small space and it fills up very very fast. But you wait for good food right?
author: Michael P.

description:
I'm not strict when it comes to food, so this place was great. Large portions for around $16, which is a steal considering the average meal price in SF. 

I've had the pastelon, tostones, and sangria. All are great. I've learned that the pastelon is a big and hearty serving, so come hungry. I'm full on just a side of tostones.  My favorite part of this place is the interior, it's almost disney-quality in terms of theming and story telling. 

Overall, great place.
author: Daryll G.

description: The food was great and the customer service was good too! The entrees my friend and i ordered came with salad, your choice of rice (yellow  or white), and choice of beans (red  or white). Good sized portions and reasonable price. Street parking wasn't too hard to find but the closest spots have parking meters. A block down we found free parking. We cane at a good time because we were seated immediately, but 20 minutes later there was a line out the door!
author: Jayd S.

description:
Love this place! Some of the best Puerto Rican food in the Bay Area next too Sol Food in Marin. 

I always go for the bistec (steak) combo and it comes with protein, rice and beans, salad and maduras. Always great quality, consistency and good customer service. I dine in and go here for take out orders, either way I love this place!
author: Mone J.

description:
Bad service. The waitress props open the door a foot behind where I am seated letting a cold draft in. When I ask to close it, the response is: I am talking to my customers outside... because... seated inside, I am not a customer?
Food is good.
author: Dario V.

description: I really wanted to give it a five star but the service was subpar. We came on a Friday night and thankfully no wait seated on the counter. Prices were decent $20 for Half a pitcher sangria and $17.50 for the mofongo with pretty big portion. My friend got the shrimp and I got the pernil asado mofongo. It was creamy, flavorful and if not the best I've had. Docked two stars for service- people who ordered the same time as us got their meal 20 mins before while we waited. Server also didn't offer any apology for it. Will most likely order takeout from now on. Not worth giving them 20%tip when service was poor.
author: Kai A.

description:
As far as authentic dining on haight, this is as good as it gets. The Puerto Rican twang is abundant, with wonderfully soulful dishes and generous portions. We ordered the Pernil Asado and received a quarter hog worth of braised pork. 

Our server Luke put up with us in wonderful fashion, recommending the fried chicken which we got with the sample plate. Ridiculous yum. Many delicious. Great service, warm vibe.

Will be back, now favorite spot on haight.
author: Ryan B.

description: Such a cool little restaurant and amazing food . The price point is pretty good and portions are pretty big . I've been there a few times and always had a good experience with my orders and the atmosphere. Loving the images on the walls and Latin Caribbean vibe ! Highly recommend it !
author: Zoya M.

description: We came here for lunch and I had the mofongo and the sampler plate. It was so amazing! Highly recommend and the staff was friendly as well.
author: Rachel S.

description:
LOVED: shrimp salad, sangria, vibe, its underrated because it's bead cha cha cha's, good for dates, and also work lunch, service was amazing - super friendly and accommodating folks 

EEEH: nothing!
author: Jul C.

description: Parada 22 is a wonderful spot to take visitors to The Haight! Everything is delectable, I particularly recommend the Pollo Encebollado, and add some of the delicious homemade habanero sauce they put out on each table. Such a cool atmosphere and extremely friendly service.
author: Rebecca C.

description: I am obsessed with this restaurant in the Haight. It is so cute and yummy. Lots of character but a small restaurant. Great for a solo visit or for two people. Great location in Haight.
author: Tina L.

description:
This place has lost its authentic taste and vibe. The servers don't know about puertorrican food, don't know how to explain the menu. We asked for mayo ketchup and they were like "uhhh", we asked how the chicken was prepared for the mofongo and they said "termino medio", what?! The mofongo was bland and mixed with the chicken broth, not real mofongo dude! It was more similar to mangú. 
But hey, it was ok and you can still call it Caribbean fusion.
author: Alex V.

description: We normally close at 10 but we closed early because it was kinda slow???? WTH is that?  Unbookmarked
author: David A.

description: The best restaurant for Puerto Rican food.  Very good service , very fresh and delightful atmosphere! Pork was incredible , steak very tender. Can't wait to go back to try different dishes.
author: Alena P.

description:
TL;DR Amazing food, large portions, short wait for seating! 

This place is located right next to Cha Cha Cha on Haight. I went with 4 friends for Sunday late brunch (11:30am) and we were seated along the counter. We had a chance to move to a table so we chose that option instead. The atmosphere is colorful and cozy, with people sitting pretty close to each other. There are high ceilings that are decorated with art and decor items from Puerto Rico. 

Usually my boyfriend and I will order different dishes so we can try 2 things together, but this time we unintentionally both ordered the same thing: pernil asado ($12.50) which is roasted pork served with red or white beans, salad, and some grilled plantains. It was so good that for once I was glad I didn't need to share haha. 

With the great atmosphere, reasonable prices, and delicious food, I can't wait to come back again for dinner and to try other things on the menu!
author: Barbara C.

description: Wow this place was KNOCK OUT! Total hidden gem in this neighborhood. My first time to have Puerto Rican food and it made me want to book a flight there!
author: Nick G.

description:
Amazing. I honestly don't know why I hadn't tried Puerto Rican food before! A few friends and I stopped by after an employee at one of the nearby bike rental places suggested it. Best decision of the trip. The food was amazing!

The principales are definitely the way to go - the portions are huge and they come with pretty much everything you could want, including some tasty beans, a wonderfully dressed side salad, amazingly flavorful rice, and fried plantains that I'm still dreaming about almost a week after eating them. I had the chicharrones de pollo which were just so delicious. Everything on the plate was great and paired together perfectly. I'm honestly not sure what the sauce that came with the meal was intended for, but it tasted pretty great with basically everything on the plate. I tried a bit of my friends' bistec encebollado as well as the pernil asado and both of those were just as tasty as my own. I really just can't stop raving about this place!! 

The atmosphere is really welcoming and cozy as well. The building isn't huge so it's probably not suitable for larger groups, but pretty much perfect for a small get together of two to four people.

I really can't wait to make my way back to SF just to come back to this place. Highly, highly recommend!!
author: Jane C.

description: This place is really small but the ambiance feels really authentic. The music was so on point for every song. We had the shrimp mofongo and bistec ensebollado. The plates came with rice, beans, plantains, and salad. Everything was pretty tasty but I did not really care for the salad although my partner really liked it.
author: Mariana V.

description:
When you walk in, you feel like you've stepped into a small piece of Puerto Rico (but you're still in the Haight). You are immediately consumed by pictures, music and the smell of the yummy food that you are about to consume.

Ive been many times before, and today I ordered camarones a la criolla (comes with small mixed green salad, yellow rice, red beans, and plantains). 

Camarones = shrimp for those who don't know

Great serving size, great flavor, and the shrimp was seasoned excellently. 

Additionally, they have a really good Cuban sandwiches as well (I had it on another visit). 

If you are looking for a unique latin good experience, COME HERE!
author: Attiana P.

description:
Pastelon , top fav
Camarones a la cariolla
Chicharrones de pollo
Modongo (biatec), top fav

Atmosphere: excellent, great ambiance, playful and fun
author: Mary N.

description:
Such good food! My sister and I came on a Sunday for lunch around 11:30, and it was already full of brunch-goers. I got the pernil asado, the roasted pork, and my sister got the polla a la criolla. The chicken was a lot more spiced than my pork, but the pork was delicious regardless. It was ridiculously tender.

I didn't snap a photo but the flan is incredible. It's so creamy and the perfect way to end a meal.

The price is really reasonable for the amount and quality of food you get and the sides (maduros, Spanish rice, salad, and beans) are all delicious.
author: Camille J.

description: I am born and raised in PR. I love the atmosphere and the music but the food is terrible.
author: Knickerbocker R.

description: Thoroughly enjoyed this spot! Can't believe I've missed it being in the city for so long! They have an array of dishes with rice, beans, plantains (best I've had), salad (with delicious vinaigrette), and your choice of meat! The portions are pretty large too! I had the pernil asado, and was delighted with how juicy it was.
author: Mako U.

description:
cute place with great service.
the food was healthy, fresh and good tasting? Yes I never had a moment where I'd close my eyes and say "oh my gud, this is delicious". but again the price was good and it was something I could eat and leave without feeling that I just stuff my body with unhealthy, oily, fatty garbage. 
the complain: very few vegetarian dishes and it is asked not to ask for any change/sunstitudu so as a vegetarian I can't really eat here that often which is a shame because I really liked the quality of food here.
author: Helia S.

description: We ate roasted pork and it was brilliant. The service was a little slow but the food made up for it.
author: Andrea T.

description: Awesome food, awesome service, just overall awesome- even on a busy Friday night! We got the slow cooked pork with yellow rice and everything was so so good. Will definitely be back!
author: Ruheene J.

description: The mofongo (I got the shrimp) was amazing. Flavorful rice, beans, perfectly cooked plantains (moist in middle, slight char on outside), a bit of salad, garlic shrimp. I thought the whole dish was great. Cool vibe inside the restaurant. I think the missing part would be to have a selection of cocktails available (only beer, wine, and sangria). Would definitely go again.
author: Will H.

description:
I've been searching for Puerto Rican food in San Francisco and was so happy to come across this spot! 

What I ordered:
1.) Chicharrones de pollo plate - served with mixed rice and bean, tostones, a dipping sauce and salad
The chicharrones were literally the best I ever had as were the tostones. 
The rice SUCKS - it's long grain (which is not traditionally cooked in PR) and flavorless. It tasted like there was no sofrito. The salad dressing is DELICIOUS. I can't even believe I'm raving about dressing - it was just very clean tasting and flavorful. The dipping sauce for the tostones were OK - it didn't really add much. 

2.) Plato vegetariano- served with white rice and beans, maduros, yuca, and salad. 
The maduros were excellent as were the white beans. The yuca was pretty good but could have been cooked a little longer. Salad was great with the dressing.
The white rice was WAY BETTER than the mixed rice but the above still stands.

The pros:
Great spot, very nicely decorated, good music, nice service.

The cons:
Limited menu (where are the pastelillos, alcapurrias, guisados etc?), REALLY bad rice. Most of the products contain pork.

Overall - I'm eager to try the rest of the menu (aside from the rice). I'll definitely be back for the tostones, chicharrones, maduros, and that delicious salad!
author: Angel R.

description:
While in San Francisco for a business trip, I decided to order from this restaurant for delivery to my hotel. I ordered through the delivery site Caviar and the process was super easy. I'm a huge fan of Latin/Puerto Rican food, and happen to be having a craving, so I decided to order the Bistec Encebollado with some Maduros on the side. Back home, I'm used to eating super authentic Puerto Rican food, and the food from this restaurant just didn't cut it. 

When I received my order it did not come with utensils or napkins, which was pretty annoying and the food was pretty cold by the time it got to me, despite the fact that it didn't really take that long to get delivered. The steak was season well and cooked through, but the meat was so tough it was pretty impossible to chew through and it took a while to consume each bite. The yellow rice that came with it was overly seasoned and also very crunchy. The maduros were mushy and overcooked, they typically should have a crispy outside and a more tender inside. I also had a side of beans that came with it. When I went to take a bite of the beans I got a huge chuck of fat in my mouth. Needless to say, I was definitely turned off. 

Definitely would not order from here again.
author: Victoria T.

description: My favorite latino spot in san francisco! The tostones, the pernil, the sangria! Dios Mio! The ambiance and decor transports me to Puerto Rico! Me encanta! As a Caribbean living in the bay this is closest I feel to "home"
author: Natalie M.

description: Yumminess!  The atmosphere was great, people were great and food was delishhhhh. Totally coming back here. I had the bistec sandwich and he had a shrimp plate. The smell was phenomenal and definitely hit the spot with our taste buds.  Highly recommend!!
author: Me V.

description: Sooo good! Huge portions and (not that I would know but...) tastes authentic! Love that it has a hole in the wall feel :) Service is really friendly, too, which is always the cherry on top.
author: Caroline R.

description: Excellent food! Good portions too! left with lunch for the next day. Yucca fries were perfect. Pork excellent.
author: Nicholas B.

description: Great place for Puerto Rican food!  The atmosphere is chill, and very comfortable.  You can sit and enjoy your meal and savor all the flavors.  I LOVED the food!  The tostones were on point and reminded me of my late grandmother's.  I had the chicharrones de pollo with arroz con gandules and my girlfriend had the camarones...OH MAN!!! We left those plates empty!  Service was fast, definitely friendly and always checking on us to see how everything was...I forgot her name but she def gets props!  If you're visiting SF do check this spot out!!
author: Anthony C.

description:
Very Good!

I got the Mofongo with chicken and it was really tasty. Be forewarned: the portions are pretty big so one could easily get two meals out of this.

Service was pretty fast though the place is kind of small and it filled up quickly. If you go on a weekend for dinner I recommend getting there a little early.
author: Marco E.

description:
This place is ALRIGHT. I've had it a few times and all I get is the sampler. I'm Puerto Rican and know about authentic Puerto Rican food and it's NOT here. Arroz con gandules they do not have, the mofongo has to many onions NOT the right mofongo! They don't have that much PUERTO RICAN plates. I'd say this place is pretty basic.. 

On the plus side, the sangria is REALLY good and the pollo.. but other than that.. nothing really catches my eye here anymore.. I'd rather have Sol Food..
author: Dasha F.

description: I LOVE this place. Amazing food, amazing sangria, amazing service. I've been coming here for years and it never disappoints.
author: Gladys C.

description: The decor and ambiance at this place is great! Who doesn't love a place where you can dance in your seat while you eat your food and drink your sangria (it was amazing)?! We the Pollo Encebollado and the Chicharrones de Pollo, with a side of Yuca Al Mojo, and of course a half pitcher of sangria. The food was amazing- Latin(x) comfort food. We had both dishes with Spanish rice, and at first with red beans. I didn't know the red beans had pork (ham), and we don't eat pork, but our server was understanding and swapped them out for white beans. Although we live in the Bay Area , coming to the city takes a lot of mental preparation, and the right mood to come into the hustle and bustle of it, but we would visit Parada 22 again in a heart beat.
author: Iliana D.

description: A cute little Puerto Rican restaurant on upper Haight, authentic food, homemade sangria, large menu, large portions, friendly service, good prices. What more could you ask for? You know I had try the  the sangria :)  it was good. I had the arroz amarillo, OMG I loved it! Full of flavor. A great lunch or dinner spot.
author: Karen R.

description: Love this place,  always have.  This is my go to spot for authentic Puerto Rican food.  I love their fried chicken it's sooo good.  My man always gets the mofongo and he loves it.  The place is small and can get crowded so it feels congested in there but the food and service is wonderful.
author: Lennie G.

description: Been here three times already, great food, good atmosphere. The place is pretty small so there will be a somewhat long wait time during peak hours.
author: Leslie L.

description:
Loved this charming little spot in Haight Ashbury! We stopped here for a filling but casual lunch before exploring Golden Gate Park. 

Most people in my group opted for the main plates which come with many sides. The meats were all tender and juicy and seasoned perfectly and the plantains were deliciously sweet. 

Seating at the restaurant is pretty tight so I don't recommend coming with more than a couple of people. My group of five was wedged into the corner near the entrance.
author: Carleigh R.

description:
so my bf and I went here to eat Puerto Rican food. my god i dont know why they have 4 stars ? im really confuse. because seriously their food is not good at all 100 percent taste weird and nasty. I'm not puerto rican but im surrounded of puerto rican people and been eating puerto rican food so i know what really taste like. specially my bf is puerto rican his mom cook waaaaay better. so btw if you guys need new chef i can maybe hook you up lol. cause seriously you guys need to kick the mexican chef in the kitchen. they just ruining the puerto rican food. or just serve mexican food not puerto rican. its so upsetting. also learn how to make mofongo smh. maybe people who eats here dont kno what Puerto rican food taste like. 

so sad theres no really good Puerto Rican food here in the city. 

Dont waste your money here. you will just regret it. ewww
author: Lara J.

description: I am so looking forward to going back to P22. I will be heading up north this coming weekend and I can't wait to eat there again. I will be the one wearing my PR shirt and hat stuffing my face with tears in my eyes. I highly recommend this place. This is my Nor Cal spot. See you then.
author: Gilbert D.

description: Highly recommend this restaurant. The decor is lovely, the staff is friendly, and the food is amazing. I had the layered plantain dish which was incredible with the flan which was really good too. Great small spot in the Haight
author: Leyla G.

description: Stopped in after a long drive and was not disappointed! The atmosphere is super fun and the staff were incredibly friendly! Fairly small place that easily felt cramped, but so worth it!
author: Samantha C.

description:
This place charmed me left and right!

We came on a week night, Tuesday during normal dinner rush and didn't have to wait.  The line never got too long during our stay either.  I'm sure this place gets slammed on normal nights.  However if you want a special treat without the crazy come early week!  

We sat at the side bar height area with 4 of us and had that front window corner all to ourselves.  The waitress was delightful and helpful with all of the menu options.  And if you follow me in any way you know I'm a sucker for a menu that gets to the point.  I've said it before "Do a few things well."  They strike an amazing balance between options and simplicity.  Not a 4 options menu but not 400.

Apps are a great way to start here.  Get your taste buds rolling with some sippers and dippers.
The food comes out pretty quick and hot off the grill.
We had a good sampling of a couple of things so let me walk you through some of them:
-Plantain Chips and Yuka to start.  Simple and great dips and sauces to smother in.  Came out quick so we could order without any hangry folks in our party.  Smart work Parada.
-I got the Cubano which was classic and a nice balance of flavors with salty goodness. I needed the dipping sauce that came with the yuka but it made it the perfect combo for me.  Not too big of a meal with a perfect side salad to cleanse the pallet.
-Pernil Asado, the pork was a big win.  Perfectly cooked meat with a small side.  Simple but elegent dish.
-Pastelon was like an amazing lasagna layer creation of goodies.  Heavy and a big serving but full of thoughtful flavor combinations.
-Arroz con Mariscos, the winner of the night.  A giant seafood platter rice dish of magic.  Could easily feed two but really took the cake with flavor, color, presentation and authenticity.  All around a big win.  

This place was warm, welcoming, humid and thick with great smells and vibrancy for a cultural food you want to experience!  Make it a date or small group night.  But either way, enjoy this local small business as they have a lot to offer in a small space.

I believe they have rotating desserts but we took advantage of being in the charming area we were and walked over to The Ice Cream Bar which is open late.  So make a full evening out of this experience and enjoy the Haight.
author: Brooks M.

description: Really good, reasonably priced Puerto Rican food, which can be hard to find in San Francisco! My boyfriend is Puerto Rican and grew up on the island, so he is always looking for a good spot for a taste of home. He loved his bistec encebollado and my shrimo mofongo was out of this world. I got Spanish rice, but I think the arroz blanco y habichuelas (white rice and kidney beans) are a better and more authentic choice.
author: Sarah B.

description:
I was SOOO excited to find this place being that I'm Dominican (very similar cuisine and you can't find Dominican food in the bay).  

I've been here a few times and I always get the chicharrones de pollo with tostones.  It's honestly delicious and I definitely recommend it.  I will give a tip -- ask for ketchup, it's great with tostones and it's how Dominicans eat them.  The platanos maduros are delicious -- definitely try those as well.  Tostones are savory plantains and and platano maduros are sweet.  

I also always get a pitcher or a half pitcher of sangria -- honestly not the best but it gets the job done.

I love the decor of the place, more because it makes me feel at home and it's hard to find that Caribbean style on the west coast.  

I should mention, as a person who grew up with Puerto Ricans and has been a few times (and as a Dominican) -- the food is not 100% authentic... But it's as close as I have been able to find out here -- definitely give it a try!
author: Michelle S.

description: Love coming to this place for brunch on the weekends. Vegetarian paradise! Portions are giant and prices are cheap. Their vegetarian biscuits and gravy are so damn good. Egg dishes are also delicious and they have soyrizo which is a vegetarian staple to make food taste meaty and spicy. Interior is adorably decorated and staff is super. Great place
author: Keely A.

description:
Homestyle restaurant....usually packed. Come with flexible open mind. Food is exceptional!! Fried chicken just ok....,but, The PORK is Wonderful! ! ! Authentic Puerto Rican food....wonderful flavors. 
Rice is addictive....always order extra. Beans ...only place I'd actually eat...they are soooo tasty. 

Service is relaxed. ..and yet. ..one person cooking & one person serving. ..for a place regularly packed....is quite impressive. And orders come out pretty quickly.
Really can't say enough good things about this neighborhood gem.  Love it.
author: Sharine d.

description: This little hole in the wall was a very pleasant treat for us. My husband lived in Puerto Rico but being from Idaho we rarely get ethnic food. Someone told us about Cha Cha Chas but I am glad we came here instead. My favorite is always bifstek and tostones. The highlights for me were the rice and beans however. I'm not usually a huge fan but these were GOOD!  My husband and I shared and the portions were very generous for that.
author: Erin E.

description:
Great food. Neighborhood gem. Small place with big flavors. 
I had the Pastelon-reminded me of a lasagna, but so much more flavor.

Great service.

Good facilities. A little small.

Good ambiance. I love the decor.
author: Jean S.

description:
I've had my share of authentic Puerto Rican food at several different restaurants around the country. The only dilemma is that they're tougher to come across than you might think. Especially in California where this state is literally flooded with Mexican restaurants. Well rest assured, if you happen to be in San Francisco, particularly in the Haight, I would definitely check out "Parada 22".

Located directly in the heart of the Haight-Ashbury neighborhood (between Shrader and Stanyan St's.), "Parada 22" is a tiny little building with a mint green exterior. In fact, you wouldn't even notice it if you're walking by quickly. And the inside is as small as you might expect with only 10 tables for dining. I had come here with my lady and our two friends on a Sunday evening around 7:00pm. Fortunately, there was an open table available as we were seated quickly. But I must warn you, because of the size of this restaurant, you may expect a very lengthy wait before you are seated.

Since we are on the subject of the interior, you will find many Puerto Rican artifacts, pictures, and memorabilia that focus on their culture and heritage. I particularly liked how the owner focused on her roots by making you feel as if you're dining at an authentic restaurant in Puerto Rico. And because of the diminutive size, you feel much more cozy. Do keep in mind that you might be dining very close to strangers so don't let that deter you from eating here.

Once seated, the waitress took our orders in a very timely manner. In fact, the waitress not only waited on her customers but also was the hostess AND server. I was impressed as she helped every customer in the entire restaurant. As I glanced at the menu, I decided on ordering the "Classic Cubano" sandwich (for $11.50). This consisted of roasted pork, smoked ham, pickles, Dijon mustard, and Swiss cheese on a soft roll. It also included a side of mixed baby greens. As a side, I opted for their "Habichuelas Blancas" (for $5.00). This was braised kidney beans slow cooked in a chunky smoked ham sofrito with green olives. And to wash it down was a simple Coca-Cola in a bottle.

Our meals come in in just 10 short minutes which was amazing considering how busy it was. My "Classic Cubano" sandwich was made perfectly; the bread had great consistency and texture while the pork/ham blend added a unique flavor that is not found in your traditional sandwich. The beans also tasted creamy while the ham added a nice seasoned taste to my appetizer. My friend ordered their "Camarones A La Criolla" which was sauteed shrimp; this tasted exceptional as well as her side of cooked plantains. I could tell that they keep the cooking as homemade as they possibly could.

Overall, I would highly recommend dining at "Parada 22". Aside for it being a wee bit on the small side and portions are a tad bit high for the amount of food you get, this is a great little spot that would wow locals and tourists alike. I would like to come back here on a future visit to try a different dish on their extensive menu. And they do have very generous hours as they're open Monday-Friday from 11:30am-10pm and Saturday-Sunday from 10am-10pm; respectively. Great Puerto Rican food with a excellent service and a fun dining experience!
author: Donovan H.

description: Great sized portions at reasonable prices. I got the pork Mofongo and shared a pitcher of sangria. The Mofongo came with a generous amount of rice, a small sofrito side (tasted like small pieces of hot dog in a light salsa/sauce), and best of all, some sweet plantains. I couldn't finish the meal but still went in to try the coconut flan dessert. The flan was on the lighter side, and not extremely sweet (not necessarily a bad thing). Overall the food was enjoyable and I liked the Puerto Rican style decor and the communal seating. One thing about the seating: the table was quite wide, so with just me and one other person it felt a little distant from each other. That was just a small shortcoming of an overall great experience
author: Michael S.

description: Best spot in the city love the food , the sangria is amazing and the staff is super friendly particular Yeni she's awesome and efficient I definitely recommend this place !!
author: Louie H.

description:
First time, I think it's worth the visit. 
I came during late lunch so only one employee, he was great. I loved the plantains
author: Toni F.

description:
Holy shit.  This place is so good.

Am in San Francisco visiting a friend and we were walking around super hungry looking for a place to eat.  My boyfriend had tried (and liked) Cha Cha Cha's which is right next door so we thought it would be fun to try something totally new.  I am so glad we did.

This place is amazing.  We each ordered something different.  My friend got bistec, I got the pork, and my boyfriend got pastelon.  Y'all.  This shit was all so good.  SO.  GOOD.  It's got me looking up "Best Pastelon in Los Angeles" and it's really not looking like there's anything like it anywhere.  I think I'll just have to keep coming back here to get my fix.  You won't be disappointed!  Each dish came with rice, beans, a side salad, and fried plantains at a very reasonable price.  I'm telling you, this was so good.  Everything super delicious.  I highly recommend!!!
author: Jordan B.

description:
Wonderful food in a quaint and unique area of the city-- if you're in the Haight, I'd suggest stopping by for a bite. I had never had Puerto Rican food before, but expected something similar to Cajun/Caribbean. The restaurant has a friendly and conversational ambience, great for catching up with an old friend, as I was there for. Service was quick and casual. 

Both of us ordered the Mofongo de Camarones-- at $16.50, the price was a bit steep, but for the amount that comes and our satisfaction with the meal, it was well worth it. The mashed green plantains and smoked ham sofrito were both well-seasoned, as was the side of rice. The camarones a la criolla had a taste similar to shrimp etouffee-- packed full of vibrant, tomato-y flavor, and a perfect complement to the rice and plantains. Despite the large quantity, the food wasn't too heavy and we left the restaurant feel full but not in a plantain/rice-induced coma. I'll definitely be returning in the future.
author: Sharath R.

description:
In my opinion this is hands down one of the best Puerto Rican restaurants in the Bay Area. 
Naturally, being Puerto Rican I'm always very skeptical of my PR food because it's important to me, but they did the job of satisfying this boricua. 
I ordered Chicharrones de Pollo (fried chicken) which was boneless, and came with salsa rosa (a pink sauce), and tostones (fried bananas/plantains). 
The chicken was perfect. That's it. 
Tostones: Just how I like mine. Crispy. Just amazing. 
Dip both in the salsa rosa trust me. 
I've been here a few times so I've tried all of their rices and all of them are good. They do their PR white rice just like home. And that's what this place is like... home. It doesn't try to hard to be different and fancy, it's like I'm eating my Grandma's food (sorry but no place is ever going to compare to her cooking). 
10/10 place in the Haight, SF. A small space, so expect to wait when the place is poppin' and don't come with a large party. 
Pricing: I mean it's not bad... it's San Francisco c'mon. 
Muchas gracias Parada 22!
author: Francis A.

description: First time trying Puertorrican food and it was amazing! That guy who helped us was really nice and friendly. This is my new spot every time I will visit SFco.
author: Rosmery A.

description:
Went here on a Friday night around 9pm. No wait. I ordered the Pollo A La Criolla with rice, beans, small salad & maduros. Food came in less than 20 minutes. This was the best meal i've had in a while. The chicken was DELICIOUS especially coupled with their hearty smoked ham sofrito. The rice & beans had so much flavor. The salad was also delicious (amazing dressing). And the manduros were warm and cooked perfectly. Sangria was delicious too! :) 

ALSO - this was ONLY $15

crazy

5/5
author: Matt N.

description:
It's the fair prices and welcoming service that stand out to me. 

My favorite time to come here is for brunch. My roommates and I have been coming for years and the hostest always recognized us and welcomes us.  There's hardly a wait over 15 minutes and can accommodate large groups well (yes you read that correctly).

Expect filling meals with a Puerto Rican twist. 

The real hidden gem here is their bottomless. It's inexpensive and damn they do not hold back. It's served pitcher style at your table. Just when you think you're overstaying your welcome they bring out ANOTHER picher without asking. 

Parada should steal the slogan "when you're here you're family"
author: Rachel W.

description:
First time trying Puerto Rican food. This was recommended to me from a friend. It's a tiny place, but really cool. Makes you feel like you could be in the exact same restaurant somewhere in Puerto Rico. It's simple food that is done really well. 

If you do not eat pork or seafood (like myself) then the options here are very limited for you. The dishes are heavy with pork here. I'm not a vegetarian by any means, yet there were still only about 3 dishes I could choose from. Just so you know...

I got the biftec encebollado and really liked it. Done very well and I really liked the plantains on the side. Great portion size as well, and it feels like very wholesome food, unpretentious food very reasonably priced! The mofongo looks awesome but I couldn't get it because of the shrimp. Staff was really friendly and our food came out rather quickly. I could definitely see myself coming back here. The only thing I would skip is the sangria.
author: Thielson D.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants to go to in San Francisco. All of their dishes are cooked perfectly, especially their pork. The pork is always soft and full of flavor, I always leave satisfied!
author: Josue G.

description: My lady and I were told to wait outside for 5 minutes presumably to get a table. Four minutes into waiting another couple walks in and is seated immediately.  I'm not happy.
author: Everett J.

description: Great Puerto Rican cuisine in Upper Haight neighborhood. The serving size is also huge.
author: Manny Y.

description: Are here with my pals and had an excellent meal. I recommend the Sampler!! You really get to try everything.
author: Gabrielle M.

description:
Yum!  Got the mofongo de Camerones and it was delicious! The mashed green plantain was really interesting the shrimp were tasty and the sauce was really rich. It came with rice, beans, salad and grilled plantains. VERY filling. I couldn't finish it. 

My friend got pastelon, and she liked it as well. Also a huge plate of food. She also said the sangria was good - not too sweet. 

It's really small, so don't come with a big party. No reservations. It was crowded on Wednesday night at 8pm. 

Staff was nice. 

It was really quick. Like so quick that they clearly have pre-prepared the food, but it still tastes really fresh and not reheated or anything. No negative points for this in my book, just good time management.
author: Sarah C.

description:
I went to this place on a Friday night with my best friend, who's Puerto Rican. I've visited and cooked with her quite a few times so I knew that this place had to meet some high standards if it was going to impress both of us. 

This restaurant is a quaint and intimate joint located on Haight St. Puerto Rican relics, posters, and souvenirs adorn this eclectically decorated spot. The staff was friendly and was available to answer any questions we had on the menu. We ordered and shared a half pitcher of sangria, the Sampler, and the Biftec Encebollado.

Within a few minutes of ordering, they brought us the sangria(which you DEFINITELY have to get!) and before we finished our first glass, our food was on the table. I immediately grabbed for the tostones and boy were they AMAZING. They were perfectly fried and when paired with the sauce they were heavenly. We're both still dying to know what they put in their mayo-ketchup (salsa rosa) dipping sauce to make it so tasty--we basically dipped everything in that sauce. The rest of the Puerto Rican fare did not disappoint! The steak portion was generous, so it was perfect to split with another person. The meat was tender and beautifully seasoned. My friend's highlight of the meal was the maduros, since she is a sucker for all things plantain. Overall, this is an incredible dining experience that transports you to Puerto Rico with its unique flavors.

My Puerto Rican friend and I definitely give this place a thumbs up in approval for its authenticity, reasonable pricing, and cozy vibe. We're now curious to try Cha Cha Cha too...
author: Emily G.

description: Nothing satisfies cravings after a day full of live music and the gathering of friends far and near with some authentic Puerto Rican food.  Luckily I just happened to be with my only Puerto Rican friends who was kind enough to explain to me the names of all the items.  All from how it's prepared, the origin and even how to pronounce it in their native tongue.  Believe me, my tongue was so happy, it was salsa dancing.  Thank you to my dear friends for treating me to a wonderful dining experience.  It was delicious.
author: Alex A.

description:
I know it's easy to give a place 5 stars when you have really enjoyed the experience however, I am really going bonkers over Parrada 22 !  We happened to be spending the afternoon  (Sunday) in the Haight and we were having drinks at the Milk bar when our bartender recommended this place. It's a small place and they were busy but we were seated in 5 minutes.
 We each ordered a cold beer which came out in less than a minute along with a carafe of cool lemon water.
 We were given time to look over the menu and decided on Arroz gandules, Pernil pork, Mofongo, Chicarron chicken, Tostones and Platanos!  
 Our food was out piping hot in about 910 mins and we did not have to ask for a thing seen as our server, Danai, saw to our every wish and need !
