The best Pernil juicy and sweet,  the Arroz was perfect as was EVERYTHING else ! What an amazing experience  !  Our check with drinks was $38 !  Oh My GAWD!
author: MMA E.

description:
Gotta give it up to Parada 22, came here once with friends wile waiting for a table at Cha Cha Cha , The food critic of the bunch recommended this spot instead of waiting, best decision.. I grew up in the Caribbean so I know how good Puerto Rican should taste like, parada 22 has a very authentic sabor and presentation, definitely recommend this spot all the time..  

4 starts only because the spot is so small.. but really it's  a 5..
author: Carlos G.

description: This was my first time here, came with a friend while in town for the weekend. If the wife and I ever had the chance to get away this place would be at the top of the list for food. This place is pretty small and I wouldn't recommend it if you had small children or babies as almost all the tables are two tops and one large shared or family table. We showed up at 11:30ish foe lunch and got the only other open table. Service was good or server was friendly, she seemed genuinely in a good mood and was able to answer our questions about the menu. I ordered the marinated roasted pork (sorry i do not remember the name of the dish). The pork was very good and really juicy, and what i will order on my next visit. The rice was flavorful and must have been cooked in a broth or stock and didn't dilute the overall meal like plain white rice can sometimes do. The white beans, not my thing. They were cooked with peppers or a green chili or some kind and not a flavor i personally enjoy. The salad had a nice and light but tasty dressing and the fried plantains were subtle sweetness that were a great finish to the meal
author: Chris m.

description:
Everything about this place is GREAT!!! Small quant establishment and the food was DELICIOUS! On a level 10+... I am a very picky eater and I know what I like! 
I ordered the Camarones A La Criolla and a side of Tostones with a cream dipping sauce! This dinner gave me life and was cooked to PERFECTION! The Sangria was one of the BEST that I have ever had! The Pastelon, Pernil Asado, Yuka Al Mojo and Maduros was also a 10+ FLAVORFUL! 
THE staff was FRIENDLY and ATTENTIVE... Also the music was good! I HIGHLY RECOMMEND this establishment for some home cooked Puerto Rican  food with all the FLAVOR and FLAIR!!! 
Parada 22 is a gem
author: Toni S.

description: The first time I ate at Parada 22 I thought it was good but not terribly memorable.  I remember that my beans were really good,  and that my pork was good,  but lacking something.  This time around I have gained a new appreciation.  The beans were still really good and there's 's two versions,  a white bean/cilantro vegetarian stew and a kidney bean/ham chili. The mofongo was excellent both in texture and seasoning. Portion sizes are filling  and fairly priced.  My only knocks are the size of the restaurant, it's extremely tight,  and the take out packaging.  They ought to separate the salad from the main dish.  All it does is wilt and get dressing on an otherwise standout meal.
author: Eric M.

description: I had the Pollo Encebollado and my wife had the Pollo sandwhich.  The food was awesome!  Being a transplant from the east coast where you can find more Puerto Rican cuisine I have to say this was soooo good.  It wasn't the same as mi abuela but it was on par. I didn't leave a grain of rice on my plate. Great flavor, atmosphere (salsa music blasting) and the server was super polite and nice!  I highly recommend coming here. The chicken was delicious!
author: Anthony C.

description:
Decent place. Worker was amazing. Great guy. Ambiance was nice. Not sure about the meat locker hanging plastic strips but I wasn't going to judge. Most people in our party  of 9 got the pork. Needs more salt and almost everyone went looking for a sauce to put on it. 

I ordered the bistec encebolado, the steak. Needs to be thinner cut, pounded more, marinated more, or something to make it softer. When the main dish is the last thing on the plate, you know it needs work.  Rice and beans are great. Maduros (sweet plantains) are tasty. Spicy orange sauce is tasty, perfect to spice up the rice or meat. 

Last issue... was looking forward to a Cuban coffee or equivalent afterwards. Asked for colada, was told they had American coffee. Expecting a tasty Cuban coffee and getting some pot that rivaled old 7-11 coffee was disappointing.
author: Jesse A.

description: Everything seems delicious and it can be hard to make a decision on getting the one or two things on the menu to eat. Here's my pro-tip contribution to you: get the Maduro and Pastelon with a side of Rice with pigeon pea. That's all you really need. But really, you can't go wrong with anything from here. Come early, be ready to get cozy up into this tiny little joint and gorge on them sweet plantains. Pastelon to me is a puerto rican version of gluten free lasagna made of thinly sliced sweet plantain, layered with ground meat and snow pea. Like all other dinner plates on the menu, this also comes with their regular rice, bean, and salad, but to elevate your experience, definitely get the rice with pigeon pea on the side-so good.
author: Taffany H.

description:
On Haight St, there are two popular restaurants to get Cuban/Latin American food: Parada 22 and Cha Cha Cha. The cool thing is they're next to each other. And I believe that they're also sibling restaurants too. And best part is that each one has its own unique flavor and atmosphere. Cha Cha Cha has like a Rain Forest setting, whereas Parada 22 looks more industrial and intimate. 

Given the long line at Cha Cha Cha, we decided to check out Parada 22. Parking was plentiful because the restaurants were located in a residential area, and so we didn't have to fight for a spot. Coming on a Saturday evening, we expected a long line but were seated in about 20 minutes.

First thing you'll notice is that the price is perfect. This restaurant is affordable even though Parada 22 has a bunch of pretty well known and popular dishes that can be pricey (Bistec especially). We got two orders of the steak (Bistec) with a side of plantains (Tostones). 

Food came out pretty quickly. We ran into a problem with the Bistec and it seemed like the waitress who was serving us thought we got ONE order of the steak, and so we started with one steak plate and plantains. First off the Tostones was AMAZING. Even though fried plantains are so simple, the mayo sauce they gave us was a perfect compliment to make our appetizer APPETIZING. 

But we came for the steak and that's what we were betting our money on. For about $15, our steak plate was pretty big for what we were paying. The meat was cooked medium, and although we wished it was cooked a bit rarer, it was tender and paired well with a side of beans and with some onions. What the dish was lacking was some mushrooms and more caramelized onions. 

The second steak plate took a lot longer to come out, and as a result we kind of lost our appetite for it. And thus, that piece of steak tasted not quite as great as the first one. But it was probably because of our lack of appetite from waiting.

Overall, I had a great experience at Parada 22 with my friend. The wait wasn't that long, the food was decent, and the price was perfect.

Eat well and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description: Just when I think they've done it, they do it again. The last time I was here, I ordered my usual, the camarones a la criolla, which I am NEVER disappointed with. But right after ordering, I saw they added a cubano emparedado to the menu! Not sure how long it's been there, but if there is anything I love, it's a Cubano sandwich. Today, we went back- today I finally ordered the Cubano... simply amazing. Sure, is it a classic Cubano? No. But it is definitely delicious. They add that garlic aioli stuff they usually send along with tostones on the sandwich, the pernil is super tender and tasty, and the perfect cheese... so happy. Was sad I couldn't finish it all, I was so full after half and sneaking some of my friend's yuca- but happy to say it's come home with me and I will be enjoying the rest later!
author: Angelic S.

description: I've been coming here for about 4 years now, I travel from Stockton just to come here to enjoy the amazing food & the culture setting. My absolute favorite restaurant in the city !
author: Ashley G.

description:
I LOVE LOVE LOVE their mofongo w/ shrimp dish. There's plenty to share for two (unless you're a hungry, hungry hippo, or maybe just a normal food eater I guess) and their maduros (fried sweet plantains) are SO GOOD. I could probably eat a plate full of those. 

Parking can get tough, but trust me, it's totally worth coming here. Most orders come w/ the maduros, your choice of white/red beans, white/spanish rice, and salad. I'm usually not impressed when it comes to salads that are included w/ dishes, but their salad DRESSING is amazing. There's a little jar of the stuff at each table, but watch out--this stuff is spicy! It's kinda tart and pleasant at first, but it builds up! 

I've only been here for dinner and it's a nice, chill spot. If you're here with a group of friends, grab a couple of beers and relax!
author: Christine L.

description:
Great food-ordered the pernil asado, friend ordered the Pastelon. Both were delicious, and the servings were huge(especially for SF standards!) We came over on a weekday, and although they were packed (no lines but completely full), they allowed us to get seated first while waiting for one more person. They also have vegetarian options too. 
Will come again!
author: Kelly S.

description: Omg!!! True Puerto Rican food.  Service was excellent.  Sangria was authentic.  I had the pork dinner with black beans and rice with plantains and an additional side of peas and rice.  Hubby had the sautéed prawns dinner in an awesome sauce.  Only bad thing is the place is really small.  Seating is tight.  But worth it.  I was truly impressed.
author: Pam P.

description:
Just the plain flan alone deserves five stars: it pure heaven, worth the calories! They offer a coconut flan but the waitress said that the plain flan is a must-try.

I got the sampler platter and enjoyed it a lot despite horking it down because I was ravenous :).  Huge portions here enough for leftovers. 

But the flan....the flan!! It was creamy, silky and dense in texture, buttery and egg-y in the best way with a beautiful browned layer on the bottom, soaked in the caramel glaze that was sheer perfection.  That bottom browned layer made it like having a dessert within a dessert: Every spoonful was a dream, then you got to eat that brown layer at the end, with a smoky flavor and chewy texture. I finished all of it, and also the caramel sauce on the plate, that is how good it was! No leftover flan! 

The interior is really cute, a tiny place with lots of character, exactly my kind of scene. They have a bar with stools on the side for those dining solo or on the go, and warm wood tables for those who have time to linger. 

Definitely will be back, next time with friends! Also, lots of friendly folk who come here and randomly walk up and talk to you; conversation centers on the food and how good it is.  Definitely recommended.
author: Joyce M.

description: The best food around. Try the tostones (made to perfection) heck everything is good here even the music!!! first time? Try starting w sampler plate and a glass of sangria. Be back there soon!
author: R B.

description: Pernil, Pernil , Pernil. Sooooo good. The price is right and the maduros and arroz were very good as well. I like the entrance and vibe of this place as well. The service was good  too.
author: Rod M.

description: Our second visit to SF and our second stop at Parada 22!  We've had the sampler, the pernil, and the cubano!!  ALL delicious!!!   My husband is happy to be eating like he was home!!
author: Cristi S.

description:
Amazing! Highly recommended!
I try to go there every 2 or 3 months. Definitely, you have to try their food if you are in SF.
author: Sergio R.

description:
Ideal for sangria-induced drunchies! Parada 22 is right next door to Haight Street's legendary Cha Cha Cha latin bar, so you can grab a pitcher of sangria there, then head next door for a more affordable, and verrrrry filling plate of Puerto Rican specialties at Parada. 

This is the kind of authentic eatery every neighborhood needs. The menu is legit, full of yuca, tostones, maduros, smoked ham, braised beans, and garlicky sauces. Just the kind of starchy, fatty grub your belly craves after a night of drinking OR just a day of existing. Prices aren't dirt cheap, but the portions are well worth the $10-16 range. Dinner + tip for $25 pp is tough to do in this city! 

The fast & friendly service, flavorful dishes, plus bright turquoise walls and artsy decor make Parada a truly pleasant spot to feast.
author: Nique F.

description:
I hardly ever make it to the Upper Haight. It just gets a little too crowded for me. Besides I was a near-toddler in the Summer of Love so what did I know of LSD and free love? Sorry to burst your bubble but nothing is free. Before I have a psychedelic hot flash, I should tell you about this casual Puerto Rican spot. It's on the same block as the longer-standing Cha Cha Cha but probably gets a lot of the spillover crowd since they cover geographically the same type of food. Parada 22, however, has a homier vibe focused on dishes you'd probably get at Sunday supper in San Juan. Stews and sauteed meats are the specialties here. The menu features nine entrees, five sandwiches (including a Cubano, of course), five salads and several side dishes (photo: http://bit.ly/1BPAaom).

That appealed to me since I am always up for comfort food no matter what the culture. I thought I'd have trouble finding a seat as a solitary diner, but as luck would have it, a small table opened up just as I entered the compact Caribbean-style premises. My eyes locked on the $12 Pernil Asado, a big hunk of fall-off-the-bone roasted pork marinated with garlic, oregano and their housemade sofrito (photo: http://bit.ly/1drI37O). It was honestly like having a half a pot roast to myself, and the bottle of seasoned dressing on the table brought a nice spike of flavor (photo: http://bit.ly/1RKlSYb). It came with a cup of their Habichuelas Coloradas, a hearty broth of red beans, a chunky smoked ham sofrito, green olives and a bevy of spices.

Also on the plate was a scoop of Arroz Amarillo, a Spanish-style rice with green olives, sweet peppers and smoked ham. I liked how they used the same ingredients in different ways on the same plate. There were some mixed greens and their Maduros, the buttery-tasting sweet plantains pan sauteed (photo: http://bit.ly/1RKlN6L). It was all quite tasty in a comfortable way that made you feel you were at some roadside cafe run by your no-nonsense aunt if you happen to be related to Ricky Martin and livin' la vida loca. In fact, I was feeling so much at home that I ordered the $5.50 Coconut Flan for a sweet treat (photo: http://bit.ly/1GUJFBS). It was a significant helping with toasted coconut shredded on top like a crown. Definitely a find for comfort food with a Caribbean accent.

FOOD - 4 stars...comfortable Puerto Rican comfort food prepared like you were at someone's home
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...a bit of a tight fit here but find a space if you can
SERVICE - 3.5 stars...quietly authoritative
TOTAL - 4 stars...maybe I should come to the Upper Haight more often
author: Ed U.

description: Feeling skeptical about Puerto Rican food on the west coast I decided to go ahead and try it out.  I will say that the main difference in food here compared to Rican food in NYC and Puerto Rico is that they are light handed on the salt.  I prefer my Rican food salty like I had it on the island.  That being said, my roasted pork was so tender, juicy and full of garlic flavor.  4 stars only because the beans tasted like nothing and there was only 1 waitress.
author: Michael H.

description: Very good, very tasty food. The seating area is a bit tight but well worth it!  Portions are all good sizes.
author: Bob S.

description: Oh my stars-so good! My boyfriend was in OR for work and has been sending me pics of his food. Id never tried Puerto Rican food before but the pics looked so good! So i ordered the fried plantains and the dish that was like a grojnd beef or pork layered between plantains like lasagne. It was out of this world. The meat had raisins and olives in it and was perfectly seasoned, and i think im addicted to the plantains. Im actually debating going back tomorrow night, lol. So glad i found this place-i want to go back and try more stuff ASAP. Definitely recommended.
author: Mer L.

description:
Authentic. Food is rich and full of so much flavor! 

If you are in a party of more than 4, this may not be the best choice since it's small and there are limited tables, however, great place. I was very impressed!
author: Jay D.

description:
Service alone was crap-
One girl behind the counter on her cell phone, not helping anyone out.
Other girl sat my party of 2 on the counter top but cleared other people out of their tables to seat other parties of 2. We sat and waited for about 10 minutes, while we were being ignored by the server walking back and forth behind us, and the other girl on her cell phone. 
Can't say anything about the food that we didn't get to try- but definitely won't be since we can't even get decent service here.
author: Tika O.

description: Heard good things about this place, unfortunately,  I was not impressed. I ordered the Bistec Encebollado, which had a good flavor, but was cold. I also had the white rice and red beans with a side of tostones. The white rice had no flavor,  estaba soso. Beans were good as were the tostones. I asked for mojito for the tostones,  but they only had the mayo ketchup dipping sauce. I was hoping for a nice Puerto Rican restaurant in the city, guess I will keep searching. My parents are from Puerto Rico and I was sent to Puerto Rico every summer so I know good Puerto Rican food. I will say it is 10 better than Frutilandia, I went there several years ago and it was just awful. I must say the service was good at Parafa 22.
author: Edwin R.

description:
I LOVE this place. I've had a difficult time finding good Puerto Rican food in the city. Honestly, the tostones here are better than the ones at Sol Food in San Rafael... yes, I said it.

Unfortunately, I do have to dock 1 star because it's usually super difficult to call in an order. I have seen them in person just ignoring the phone as it rings and rings. The restaurant really was not crowded when they did this... so I have a difficult time understanding why they choose to ignore customers.
author: Nicole D.

description: Just go. The food is incredible, the help is friendly, and they have reasonable prices. Like others have said, no frills, you may share a table, but so what  enjoy the festive atmosphere. I bring out of towners here not because Puerto Rican food is somehow local to SF, but because it is such a great and fun experience.  Pork is killer, and I love any dish with plantains.
author: E F.

description:
Yum! Tasty Puerto Rican food! The shopfront itself is pretty small but it's a cost space. I came here with a friend on a weeknight and there was plenty of room and no line.

The lemonade is good and tangy without being overpoweringly sweet. I also got the pastelon with Spanish rice and sweet plantains and it was delicious! The sweet plantains were cut into chunks and fried so the edges were crispy and caremlizes, yum! My only complaint is that I was full but kept wanting to eat more because it was that tasty.

Service was okay; I feel like it could have been a bit more attentive. When we sat down the table wasn't wiped and when our food came out there weren't enough knives in the silverware can on the table. Not huge deal breakers or anything to be fair, but they were still little bumps in my experience.

I'd still come here again though without a second thought.
author: Jo L.

description:
After seeing tons of people in the place, I finally decided to check out the hype...... and I was very disappointed. Not only the food was just ok, they also stole my credit card information here and tried to ring up hundreds of dollars in charges!!! and I am sure it was here as this was the only place I used that card in weeks (I get 3x dinning points on it, so it is only used for this purpose alone!!). I instantly got a bad feeling when they took too long with my card for payment in an empty restaurant. 

Avoid this place like the plague, or be sure to pay with cash.......
author: Juan B.

description: I enjoyed the Plato vegetariano and it was so yummy! It had yuca, rice, fried plaintains, beans and some greens.. really satisfying. And my boyfriend had the pernil, arroz con gandules, yuca, and greens. Our food came out pretty quick and everything tasted delicious. The only thing is that it's sooo small inside you feel so crammed and you hear everyone's conversations. Lol I'm not a fan of that but it's still a great spot :)
author: Kayla M.

description: I really liked this place. I wasn't sure what to get or how different Puerto Rican food was compared to my usual Mexican-fare. I went safe and got the pollo a la criolla for lunch. Everything on my plate was exceptional (some of my greens got a bit soggy from the chicken juices) My total was only $13 and I got two meals out of it. Next time will have to try the roast pork! This place is unique, local, and not expensive and their food is full of flavor, why not try it?!
author: Gabriella M.

description: Amazing food, reasonably priced, fantastic service. We found this little gem on our way to Golden Gate Park. Everything was so delicious and the portion size was more that we could eat.
author: Morten V.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE.

1 - Entrees. Pernil Asado, the roasted pork entree, is so good. I have gotten it every time I have been here because its just so good. Opt for the spanish rice, it comes with olives inside and its really good. Red beans are better than white beans so id go for that option too!

2- Sandwiches. My friend swears by their cubano (with added avocado for $1). It looks so good and I definitely want to try that next.

3- Appetizers. If you love plantains, go for the Maduros over the Tostones. The Tostones are more specific to this restaurant, but I think the Maduros complement the food much better.

4- Interior. Love the decor and good lighting, feels like you are on vacation.

5- Service is quick and awesome, the boys here know whats up. 

Another thing I love is that the put lemon and cucumber in their water and the sweet tea and lemonde are both very good too!
author: Kimia M.

description:
A thousand thank you's to the staff and chefs in this kitchen.

I took my dad here this weekend for a belated birthday meal. I already knew the food was amazing but felt compelled to tell him. We were seated right away and served quickly. We both had the steak and yucca with a half pitcher of sangria on the side. 

To be honest, I think he was expecting mediocre latin american cuisine which is common in the bay area. We're both Puerto Rican and were blown away. He literally said, "This tastes like the food my grandmother used to make". We were silent for a long time. The food was that good. Seriously. 

Thank you for making his birthday delicious. The sangria was ON POINT.

Amazing
author: Brittany G.

description: The pork pernil is always good, perfect comfort food you can count on. The hot sauce could be hotter for my tastes, but the food is always outstanding!
author: Andy B.

description: This place is absolutely amazing. I'm used to eating home made Hispanic food so I can get a big judgmental when eating out but WOW. I highly recommend this restaurant. Your taste buds will enjoy every bit of Latin flavors.
author: Valentina H.

description: Service can be occasionally a bit slow here, so not the place to go when rushing, but it's supremely worth the wait!
author: Jeremy R.

description: Pretty good Porto Rican food, they have a small place but nice ambiance!! Food is delicious!!
author: Halina F.

description: I am absolutely livid. Paid for a 20 dollar Uber only to be told that they "close at 830", despite the website/yelp saying they close at 10. I arrived at around 9 o'clock expecting to buy quick apps after a long flight. I was so excited to finally have some Latin Caribbean food on the west coast only to find out that they treat you just how they do on the east coast... on their own time.
author: Elena D.

description: This place is amazing! Ambiance, the food, customer service  I will be coming back on every trip to SF. The price is great, food is amazingly flavorful.
author: Patricia J.

description: This place is so tiny, yet so comfortable. It holds 40 people and that's how many people were there on Tuesday evening. It was packed! It's authentic Puerto Rican. Try it! It's so yummmmm!
author: Sherie R.

description: Our meal at Parada 22 was amazing! I had the fried chicken. The chicken was tender and juicy. The sangria was also great. Not too sweet. Exactly what we needed after our Land's End hike.
author: Bryant E.

description: Soooo fire! Everything was so delicious and very inexpensive for the quality and quantity you get. Def hit this place up
author: Thomas H.

description:
I was extremely excited to stumble upon this restaurant during my SF visit! I live in LA and there is one okay Puerto Rican restaurant. 

Service was attentive and polite. The food is very authentic and cooked fresh. I ordered the Chicharon de pollo which is Puerto Rican fried chicken. Very crispy and tender flavorful chicken. I highly recommend this dish. It was served with fresh hot tostones which are flattened twice fried plantains. The yellow rice (Moro) was also very tasty. My only mini complaint was the amount of beans I got. I'm use to a ton of beans at other Puerto Rican establishments but it was a decent amount. I also ordered a Malta which is a soft non alcoholic malt beverage that not every can appreciate. It was a brand I was unfamiliar with but tasted just like Malta Goya. 

Parking wasn't too bad, it was a busy Sunday afternoon and I was able to find street parking. I highly recommend this restaurant, it's small inside but definitely a delight. !!!!
author: Jordan M.

description: Dance level loud music, food is good though, small eating area. Probably good for 3+ folks looking to shout at each other over the loud music. Do not recommend for couples or singles
author: Fuzzy J.

description: Amazing Cuban Food. The staff was friendly and attentive. Great music and atmosphere. We ordered the Cubano Sandwich with Avocado & Bistec Sandwich, with sides of rice and beans, and of course baked plantains. This place rocks.
author: Anthony R.

description: The most authentic Puerto Rican Cuisine I've had outside of PR itself. As soon as we walked in the decor and music told us this was the real deal. The food is amazing, perfect pork and plantains. The mofongo is off the hook. Efficient and friendly wait staff. We want to go back before we leave town and we're only here a few days. We're rolling out the door heavier and happier!
author: K W.

description: This was an amazing restaurant. The food was excellent, service was great and the portions are more than enough to keep you full for the rest of the day. Will definitely make this a frequent stop when we are in town
author: Mirna C.

description: Pleasantly surprised! The food was delicious. The place was very intimate and "homey".
author: Yissel R.

description:
If you're a fan of Sol Food in the North Bay then Parada 22 will definitely make your tastebuds boogie. The get down - hip roll - kind of boogie, where you close your eyes and just lose yourself in explosions of flavor.

Parada 22 is fantastic. It's intimate size makes it a little difficult for groups and they don't take reservations - but being that they're still fairly under the radar  - if you arrive early in the evening or are patient - manifesting a table shouldn't be a problem.

Everything about Parada 22 is low key and accessible. They only carry one white and one red wine, they serve their wine in normal water glasses, and the descriptions of their food are straightforward.  I appreciate places like this. There's no pretension and all of the energy from the staff is directed into the food - which is both made and served with genuine love.

The majority of tables here are made for two people - so being a group of 4 we sat at a communal table. Our server was the sole waiter for the warmly lit room and he was exceptionally kind and helpful. He answered any questions that we had and he was quick to bring out all of our dishes. 

We ordered the sampler plate to start the evening, as well as a pitcher of their sangria. The sampler plate is phenomenal and the perfect portion size for a group. It came with Pernil asado (roasted marinated pork leg with garlic, oregano & base sofrito ), chicharron de pollo (fried marinated boneless chicken with salsa rosa), maduros (fried ripened sweet plantains), yuca al mojo (cassava root with onions, garlic & olive oil mojo) and tostones (pressed fried green plantains with salsa rosa). We devoured the whole plate in a matter of minutes. The sweet plantains melted on the tongue, the fried chicken was some of the best I've had in San Francisco, and the pork was absolutely sensational and was the stand-out of the evening. 

For my main meal I had the Pastelon  - which is sweet plantains layered with spiced ground beef. It reminded me of the homemade Sheperd's Pie that my Welsh grandmother used to make - with a Caribbean twist. The sweet plantains complemented the spiced beef well and the seasoned yellow rice was buttery and dreamy with it's beautiful intermingling of sweet peppers, green olives, spices & smoked ham.

In addition to the Pastelon, our table tried the - Camarones a la Criolla -  sauteed shrimp in a fresh tomato, onions & sweet peppers cream sauce and the eggplant sandwich, which came with jack cheese and a creamy cilantro-garlic dressing. Everyone thoroughly enjoyed their meals.

For fantastic authentic home-style Puerto Rican food - you don't need to drive over the bridge - Parada 22 is a sure thing boogie.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
It's okay here. So the skinny (and you are not after you eat here):  the red beans are amazing. Yellow or white rice fantastic.  Platanos maduro  (ripe and sweet) or tostones (green and crispy like thick potato chips) spot on. Ambiance is very good (salsa music piped in). Service very good as well. 

The bad?  My chicken was dry and flavor lacking. The over salted carmelized onions did not hide that fact. He got the pollo criollo with ham...was also disappointing.  Dry chicken that I didn't finish or like very much.  And let's face it: it is hard to disappoint me on some chicken.  

Sangria was also very good and we would probably come back...not with an "oh! My goodness; we must come back here!" attitude but with a "hmmm; maybe order something different next time," perspective.  

This place could be a bigger, better part of Puerto Rico in the Haight.  And I am always an optimist.  There!
author: Darby W.

description:
Came to the city to sight see.  And wanting to try something different.  So why not Puerto Rican food?

Decorated with PR historical pictures.  Possible family photos.

Small diner, but plenty of room.  Open kitchen, always nice in my book.

Wife and I shared the marinated chicken plate.  With side of yuca.  The chicken was cooked and seasoned perfectly.  The sautéed onions were delicious.  Salad and dressing were delicious too.  We got their yellow rice.  Fantastic blend of seasoning with smokey pork chunks and hidden olives.

Yuca are served boiled.  With a wonderful combination of garlic, butter and onios and some other ingredients I don't remember.

So if you are in the city and want to try something new or have had Puerto Rican food before, I highly recommend this place.  It's near Haight and Ashbury.
author: Sam V.

description:
Amazing first experience at this little Cuban food paradise.
I had the pork with yellow rice and red beans.
They leave the salad dressing on the table.

The salad dressing was similar to Puerto Rica  sauces I have had. Vinegar, chili, garlic to start.
It was AMAZING!
The service was fantastic. The young man was working the entire floor in every aspect of foh.
Was able to shake my empty corona and he promptly brought me another without saying a word.
Fantastic food. Excellent service. Beer was the perfect level of chilled.
The dinning room is small but I don't think a lot of people linger the seating is a bit cramped.
author: Nathan B.

description:
Great! The pernil (roast pork) plate with rice, beans, plantains, and salad was sooooo good! The pork was marinated and cooked to perfection, and well, so was everything else! Even the salad was delicious!

The restaurant is small and really cute too! I would definitely come back and try more.
author: Jen B.

description:
Oh god I've been dreaming of this place every night since I've had dinner here. Came here on a Saturday night and ended up with a forty minute wait. Its very staggered though and I saw many couples and groups of four walk in without having to wait at all so you might get lucky! They don't take reservations so its first come first serve.

Its loud, its hot, and the food is so hearty and filling you're going to wish you had more room to finish everything. I read a random review mentioning how heavy the food is here and when I got my dish, I didn't believe it but half way through I had the very horrifying thought that they actually gave too many shrimpies but I powered through. I had the Camarones entree with the cream sauce, red beans, and spanish rice. You have to get the Spanish rice! It has green olives! Even the side salad had the best dressing. 

Service is super nice. The two male waiters act like they've known you forever. Only complaint is we never got water refills and had to remind them twice before getting some. We noticed all the other tables had pitchers of water though so maybe they're not used to refilling water. Make sure you try the housemade salsa as well! They're in jars on random tables so you have to ask for it incase you end up in a table without one.
author: Tiffany V.

description: The best Puerto Rican place in the city. The food is very authentic and the service is quite fast. The servers are friendly and they have good music. The cost of food is also reasonable. Highly recommend it! Try it out if you haven't yet!
author: Calebe D.

description: Everything was delicious and tasted authentic! The beans were so good and the tostones and yuca with the sauce was to die for! Love Rican food!
author: Yanex E.

description: Food is excellent, the ambience makes you forget you are in SF. The service was wonderful. Sangria is sweeter than I would like but all in all an awesome night out
author: Nandini S.

description:
Pollo encebollado - crisp greens, delectable plantains, tasty Spanish rice, warm beans, caramelized onions - oh, but the chicken. The chicken was sharp. The chicken interrupted every train of thought I had, from the first bite and the last. The chicken peeled apart like there was a god. 

In short, get the pollo encebollado. 

Service was fast and pleasant. My friend reported that the bathroom was cute, so go check it out.
author: Connie L.

description: Hands down best puerto rican food I ever tried. The food is so flavorful and my favorite dish is the pernil asado. SO YUMMY!
author: Miani P.

description:
One word...Mofongo!  

Theirs is a different take on what I am used to but it was delicious nonetheless.  The place is small, almost reminding you of eating in your parent's dinning room.  The music was blaring and the decor was cool.  Being in the "Haight" added to the auro as well.

Delicious through and through!
author: Gene D.

description:
Parada 22 is my current favorite restaurant. Located in one of San Francisco's coolest areas, Haight Ashbury, Parada 22 is a must visit. The cute tropical-inspired interior and their authentic Puerto Rican menu are just great. 

I tried the Pollo A La Criolla and the Mofongo dish - both were amazing. We washed it all down with a pitcher of their homemade sangria and trust me, the half pitcher is more than enough!
author: Aletta B.

description: This place was amazing! We followed the yelp review and decided to come here and wasn't disappointed...service by Hugo was amazing, he gave us great recommendations! We had a little bit of everything, but we all agreed the chicharrones de pollo was the best! Great food, great service, def our new fav place!
author: Deborah J.

description: My sister and I were hanging out at the Haight and it was dinner time and our cousin Jimmy told us about this Puerto Rican restaurant that's popular but kind of crowded and that was an understatement but it wasn't so bad..We were seated within 5 minutes..Loved the colorful decor.. alot of art, soft lighting, and great Puerto Rican music playing.. I ordered a traditional dish called mufango pernil asado (roasted pork) with plantains salad red beans and yellow rice and there was a bottle of spicy habanero or scotch bonnet sauce on the table..The service was prompt and courteous.. I was told the word mufango is where the word "funk" comes from..And yes this place is truly funky.. I will definitely come back..
author: Daisy C.

description: Came here to eat lunch for my Mother in Law's birthday and had mixed feelings. To start with the good: The food we got was delicious. The red rice was amazing!! Meat was good quality, and portions were big. My only complaint was with the service. First, I asked if they could make a quesadilla even though it's not on the menu but they have tortillas and cheese. He said he couldn't ask the kitchen to make that. Mmmkkkaaayyy. So I ordered bread with melted cheese (for my kid) and they forgot it. They brought all the food, and 10 min went by and NADA, no grilled cheese. Husband asked them what happened and server said "Sorry, we were just busy with online orders." and that they would get on it. Long story short, they never made it and my kid was left hungry. I think there is room for improvement in the customer service department. Also, the establishment is kind of small, not good for large groups or very handicap accessible. Overall, I would come back if in the city for a date night without the kids and ample amounts of time to wait.
author: Carmen A.

description:
The place is very small but very good. The pork was cooked to perfection and tasted just like it did back when we were on holiday. 
The chicken was also good. 

It's only a bit strange that you walk past the kitchen (no wall in between) when you go to the restroom. 
That didn't make me feel too good. 

The food, as I said, was really good!
author: Kathrin H.

description:
Adjacent to the more popular, though less cozy tapas bar Cha Cha Cha, Parada 22 serves Puerto Rican home-style food in a tinier, yet more intimate setting. Undoubtedly, there are similarities between the two neighboring restaurants in terms of cuisine, and that's because they have the same owner/founder.

To get the most bang for your buck at Parada 22, I recommend the main dishes, each of which consists of a protein, served with rice (choice of Spanish or white), beans (choice of red or white), salad, and maduros. These dishes are offered during both lunch and dinner, with same sized portion for both, but lunch prices are around $2 to $3 less than dinner.

The pernil asado (roasted pork) is slightly smoky and very moist, and the fork-tender texture is phenomenal. The pollo a la criolla (chicken and smoked ham sofrito) is very moist and juicy as well; the white meat chicken is grilled nicely and marinated well; the ham sofrito adds a lot of savoriness and saltiness. The chicharrones de pollo (deep-fried marinated boneless chicken) has a very crispy, but not too oily batter. The chicken, both dark and white meat, is very moist. Instead of being served with the usual sweet plantains, this dish has tostones (green plantains) instead. The delicious pairing of the salty fried tostones with the creamy, sweet and tangy salsa rosa is perfect.

The restaurant staff is friendly, and service is quick. The home-style comfort food and ambiance is a very different change from Cha Cha Cha. So, bring a large group for tapas next door, but bring a date to Parada 22.
author: Priscilla W.

description: Visited this restaurant based on Yelp reviews. Food was awesome and service was friendly. I had some dish with a "creamy" sauce and it was very tasty. Good portions for the price. Only downside is that seating is tight.
author: R S.

description: Great quality Puerto Rican food on the Haight street route. Every time I've visited it's for to-go only and bring it back home & it stays hot. There is usually seating available if you want to sit in or grab & enjoy in the park. The dishes are fairly large portions with beans & rice complimenting the entrees rather than an after thought. Savory & delicious. Recommended to friends who are now fans as well. For two an entree & app is enough food without breaking the bank.
author: S K.

description: This place was really good. All of us thoroughly enjoyed our meal in our server was very friendly as well.
author: Hal S.

description: Awesome Cuban style dishes, cozy environment with family style tables or your own. Friendly staff and good food, what else can you ask?
author: Jason B.

description: Its located in the Haight, so there is never any parking, and the restaurant itself is always pretty crowded--but that's because its so good. Best Puerto Rican food in the city! I love the Pastelon- delicioso!
author: Ana G.

description: Always stopping ground for delicious PR food highly recommended I live in San Jose area whenever I'm in the city I'm there!!
author: Jacob E.

description:
I had high hopes for Parada 22 since Sol Food is one of my ultimate favorite spots and I've heard such great things about them. The restaurant is an itty bitty little cozy spot located next to the popular Cha Cha Cha's. We were lucky that we came on a slower day without any wait at all.

Between the three of us, we ordered:

- 1 pitcher of sangria: Delicious and sweet, as sangria should be!
- Pollo a La Criolla (Marinated boneless chicken sautéed with a hearty smoked ham sofrito): Not bad, but not on Sol Food level.
- Pernil Asado (Roasted pork marinated with garlic, oregano & base sofrito): This was my favorite dish of the night even though my girlfriends felt otherwise.
- Mofongo De Camarones (Mashed green plantains with smoked ham-mixed veggie sofrito & camarones a la criolla): Not bad. The mashed green plantains were really interesting and a great alternative to mashed potatoes!

Overall I think Parada 22 is decent. Unfortunately, my taste buds have spoiled by the deliciousness at Sol Food, so I was unable to give Parada 22 a fair try. If you're looking for Sol Food in SF, I'd recommend look else where. However, I'll be back to give the sandwiches a try!
author: Tiffany U.

description: Huge portions, everything we ordered was outstanding! The only complaint I have is that I only ordered one glass of sangria! They only have space for about 45 diners so this is not a place for a group. You have to walk through the kitchen to go to the bathroom, a bit odd. No complaints about the food or the portion sizes. Delicioso!!
author: Julie H.

description: This is a great little hideaway on Haight street. I vacationed in Puerto Rico a few years ago, and the decor, music and menu took me right back to Old San Juan. Portions were tasty, filling and inexpensive. Great cozy, casual spot for authentic Puerto Rican food.
author: Sara F.

description: Hi my name is Ashley and i am born and raised in Puerto Rico now I'm a resident in Nevada. I was on a getaway to San Francisco and thought it would be special to take my boyfriend on his first time tasting of Puerto Rican food. I read up on restaurants who would apply to what i was looking for and this is the only authentic Puerto Rican restaurant in San Francisco. Venue: very cool and authentic. Staff: very friendly and professional, food: was not good, menu options don't have much selection and for-sure authenticity is not there. I was told you ran out of mofongo and this was the only thing i look forward to. Yuca was not good at all, it had no flavor. "Carne frita" was actually fried chicken. The tostónes were great and the pernil was ok. The rice was also good. That's all. You had no authentic alcohol options, nor desserts. I was disappointed. But overall it was ok i don't want to say is horrible. If you never tried Puerto Rican food and you've been here this is not entirely it. There is amazing food from our country, coming here made me miss my own cooking as well as my mother's. Step it up guys !
author: Ashley R.

description: Such an authentic restaurant. Really love them. Plus tostonas were amazing, the steak and chicken was absolutely great. Their Moho is one of a kind because They have yuca in it. I would definitely recommend coming here especially because the music is A1  and so are the wall decorations.
author: Alexandra F.

description: Went on a Tuesday night,  and it was pretty empty,  but our wait staff was decently attentive and the food was great. We got the mofongo and house salad.  The mofongo tasted a bit different than how I remembered it in PR, but it was still really good. Would recommend to a friend... in fact I already have.
author: Lizzy W.

description: Was in the city and wanted to try something new so I yelped and came across this little spot. It had a nice atmosphere. The food ordered didn't take long to make. The food was amazing. I got the vegetarian dish which came with rice, beans, plantains and potatoes and a good portion size. The staff was very nice as well. Loved the music they were playing.
author: Nadia A.

description:
Omg.. soooooooo good!!!! My boyfriend and I came here Friday evening around 830 and had the best experience. Sangria is perfect! The pork is freaking amazing!!

We ordered the sampler plate and everything was soo tasteful and the honey mustard sauce was bomb! Not to mention the habanero sauce they have on the tables tastes good with anything! I got the steak salad and it was mouth watering. There is a small wait but of course you'll get that anywhere on a weekend night. We personally think it's better then the Sol food restaurant up north, which is also popular, but that's our opinion haha. This place is unbelievably good and glad to have found a great Puerto Rican in the area!  It made us feel like we weren't in America for a few hours! :)
author: Monica L.

description: I loved my authentic Puerto Rican food. The first time I came here it was just ok, but then I decided to try it again for my birthday this year and it was great!! Will be back
author: Luna R.

description:
A great, authentic Puerto Rican meal, and reasonably priced. Went here as a group of three on a Saturday night. Had to wait about 20 minutes for a table, and the place is small so waited outside. 

Service staff were friendly. I'm gluten free, and they were able to answer questions and help me right away with contamination and other issues. Couldn't have the plantains because of the shared oil, but staff were aware and had other options to direct me to for dinner. The plates of food were pretty large, so we ordered two mains and a side dish and shared it between the three of us. I didn't get to eat the Pastelon, but it looked delicious and the others really loved it. The beans were amazing, and like we were back in our families' home in Puerto Rico for a meal.

I shared the yucca side dish and the slow cooked pork. Amazing. So good it melts in your mouth. Worth the wait, the cost, the small space. Bonus factor that it is gf friendly and I was okay eating here as a celiac.
author: S L.

description:
I was utterly disappointed with my visit to this so called Puerto Rican restaurant. The most upsetting aspect is that it claims to be something that it is not. Any Puerto Rican or Cuban restaurant should at least offer pastelitos/empanadas as an appetizer. Anyhow, I let that go and decided to give it a chance.

To begin with, the sangria was served in a tiny cup and is not worth the price at all. Secondly, it was warm and the cup had no ice. However, my boyfriend's lemonade was good.

My boyfriend ordered the pollo encebollado with white rice and he seemed to enjoy it. But still, how could a so called Puerto Rican restaurant only offer two tostones on the side?

The dishes I ordered were an insult to Puerto Rican food! My mofongo with cerdo resembled hash instead of an actual mofongo. The reviewer that called it mangu was being quite generous. This "mofongo" did not have the crunchy tower shape that I appreciate. Also, I was hoping to have crispy pieces of pernil in that so called mofongo, but of course- they were non existent. Additionally, I ordered a side of arroz con gandules. The texture was awful. It was extremely mushy! 

I understand that none of this is the waitresses' fault, but she noticed that I hardly ate my food. She could have at least offered to not charge me for the arroz con gandules.

To conclude, I felt compelled to write this review because I felt that this food insults Puerto Rican culture. I come from and live in a community that has excellent Puerto Rican, Dominican, and Caribbean food. I suggest that the owner should advertise this place as Latin fusion... Perhaps that is a stretch as well.
author: Maria V.

description:
Wow... Just wow! This is a must go for amazing food! 

Pros: everything from the amazing food to the awesome and friendly servers. I had their pork entree that the melt literally melted off the bone. The plantains are yummy along with many of their entrees. They seriously represent Puerto Rican food super well! Pair it with a Mexican coke and you are golden! Also the price is reasonable for the amazing-ness you get!

Cons: there isn't any a/c so it could get a little warm in the summer but the food is so worth it!
author: Timothy Y.

description:
I took my BF here for his birthday lunch back in August. It's been a little over a year since the last time we are here ... not much has changed, the food is still on point. 

I ordered 2 plates while the BF settled for his usual Mofongo. 
1. Pastelon - Puerto Rican version of a lasagne using sweet plantains as the pasta, sofrito based sauce with ground beef. I love this dish and reminds me of the little hole in the wall in downtown San Juan, PR - El Jibarito! 
2. Pollo ala Criolla - marinated boneless chicken covered in Criolla. I love Criolla but I was hoping for the tomato based Criolla! 

 All plates come with arroz, salad (I love the salad dressing too so long as you a vinegar based dressing) and habichuelas! I love the beans so much I had to take some to go! The portions are huge and price point is very reasonable. 

I just wish this restaurant was located in the East Bay because I would be here at least 2x a week. 

This place is so 10x better than Cha Cha Cha next door.
author: Ela M.

description:
I was in san Francisco for a few hours and decided to look for a Puerto Rican restaurant. Among the few featured on Yelp, this one stands out. Its not far from downtown, just roughly ten minutes driving. They don't offer parking, for what you have to pay a meter parking of $2 per hour, Which its not bad taking into consideration you are in SF! 

The place looks very nice and authentic, it has posters related to the Puerto Rican culture which made me feel at home! 

They need to hire better waitresses and staff, they were NOT nice nor welcoming and she didn't seemed to know the menu at all. 

I ordered the mofongo relleno de camarones and it was delicious! Although... Not as authentic as they claim, but still very tasty and I loved it. It was weird the mofongo came with rice and beans, that is not how we eat mofongo with shrimp in PR. 

The portions were very generous, so its worth the price! If I find myself in SF again I think I would cone again.
author: Alba C.

description:
This place is amazing. I moved to San Francisco in January, after living in Puerto Rico for 25 years (my whole life) and it is such a nice feeling to have a place I know I can go into and have food just like my grandma makes it. It never fails to be great and just the Puertorrican fix I need to get me going.

Why four stars? The music. Every time I go they have a horrible music selection and sometimes it's too loud. The best salsa music comes from Puerto Rico! I wish they would play more salsa music and forget about their current music selection which is just plain awful.
author: Yamel F.

description: The best! It's my favorite place in the city!! I always get the mofongo or the chicharon de pollo.. with yellow rice and the beans with pork.. I love the plantains and it's super cozy in there! I think the food is great and the service is always super quick! Great place to eat! Only street parking DO NOT PARK AT MCDONALDS!! We almost got towed!
author: Leticia L.

description: My favorite restaurant! The food is really good and so is the service. My family and I are frequent visitors but in our recent visits my mom pointed something out that she was not happy about. Customers having dogs in the restaurant and having them drink water from glasses we use as customers isn't cool. The second time a woman had her dog in her bag and had it licking the fork. Staff, you know damn well you see it happening. White people, we all love dogs but please stop!
author: Sean A.

description:
The generous, indulgent, yet balanced food at Parada 22 was a perfect comma without the coma on my "treat yo self" day. The price is decent, the ambiance is fun, and the portions leave you very happy.

Jenga'd at the very edge of Haight-Ashbury and sandwiched between art-scribbled streets, this restaurant is a little warp into Puerto Rico. The walls are plastered with Spanish headlines and there's faint music in the background to wiggle your tush in your already wiggling table.

I ordered the juicy pulled pork plate that came with fried plantains, meaty beans, and a modest little salad of course. Each table has a bottle of house-made jalapeño (?) infused sauce we both doused our food with. This is my first taste of PR, and I will say I feel we got an authentic experience. With two people working the whole space and un-intrusive service, this restaurant is all about the food. It's an casual & intimate setting with high ceilings. Planning for my next fix!
author: Olivier K.

description: Personally the food needs improvement. The muduros we cold, stale. The shrimp was cold. The beans and rice needed more seasoning. To each is own. I would not return.
author: Gabriela C.

description: Pretty good food in this smallish restaurant joint. 3.5 stars. It was my first time having Puerto Rican food. I ordered the mofongo and chose the camarones (shrimp). It was an interesting dish. The garlic flavor of the shrimps mixture with the red rice were strong flavor combinations almost overwhelming each other. I tired some of my friends pernil (roasted pork) and that was tender and very good.
author: Ali F.

description: Great food, great place, as puertorrican I can tell, San Francisco have an authentic puertorrican food place. I will back
author: Angel R.

description: So last night was my second visit in a little over a month since I moved out here to San Francisco. The food is really good and being a Boricua from Brooklyn finding a spot with my peoples food out here made me happy. Last night they didn't have arroz con gandules which was a little disappointing because that is what I was looking forward to. However el arroz con red beans was good. El  pernil was also on point. So far, I have enjoyed the food here and would recommend this place to anyone who wants Puerto Rican food. Now I hope the owner or manager of this restaurant reads this because I would like to request that the flag hanging above from ceiling in center of the place be fixed. It is dangling in a way that looks like it was just thrown up there. I have gone there twice within a month and no one has corrected that. We Puerto Ricans feel VERY strongly about our flag, being that not long ago we would be arrested for flying our flag, the way it looks now is not pleasing. So if that can be corrected it would be greatly appreciated. Hey and if you need a new one let me know. Thanks!
author: Manny V.

description: I agree with another review below. Credit card got cloned in this place. They took unusually long for processing the payment. Avoid this place at all costs if you don't want to sponsor the staff's 2 am Walmart shopping spree for shoes! :(
author: J S.

description:
Came here on Saturday with a party of 5 and the wait was about 30 minutes. 

Judging from yelp pictures, it seemed like the Pernil Asado (roasted pork marinated with garlic, oregano & base sofrito) was the most popular so that was what I ordered. The pork was very tender and soft - you can break up the meat simply by scraping it with your fork! The yellow hot sauce that was at every table added a nice kick to the meat. 

My boyfriend and I shared the Camarones salad (shrimp salad). The creamy garlic cilantro sauce was what gravitated me towards it and my boyfriend loves shrimp salads in general. The shrimp was cooked perfectly and the dressing did not disappoint. 

I will definitly come back here again to try other things on their menu.
author: Michelle T.

description: Cool little place. Food and vibe was outstanding. Definitely a hidden gem.   The sangria was excellent as well.
author: Leo S.

description:
What a delight! If you are looking for authentic Puerto Rican cuisine, this is your place. Based on other people's reviews, this place seems to be packed. I came here around 6:15pm on a weekday and there was no wait for a table of two. The decor is beautiful with tropical colored walls, warm wood tables, and light bulbs fixtures dangling from the ceiling. 

I'm not sure you can go wrong with your order here. I ordered the pollo encebollado with mexican rice and red beans (red beans have pork; white beans are vegetarian). I was blown away by the plantains - the may have been some of the best plantains I've had for a very long time. Overall, fantastic sides and the portions were large. I had difficulty finishing my plate. My friend ordered the Pollo a La Criolla and that was just as delicious. I would recommend both dishes.
author: Nicole J.

description: It is good place for lunch when hung out . Great Maxican style grill and happy music.
author: Irene Y.

description:
Super tasty food. Small place, very crowded.
Great service.
The tostones are a must have! ( green smashed fried plantains)
The sangria was good and overall we had a great experience.
If you want good, inexpensive food, good service in a casual environment, this is the place to go!
author: Junior V.

description: My husband and I decided we would come here and try the food because of all the excellent reviews.. let me tell you this I was so disappointed! In my opinion it was not worth the 55 dollars that I spent on top of the tip we gave to the server for the horrible service. Our food came to us after a long wait the rice and beans that came with the plate was awesome however everything else was horrible. We found plastic on our spoon that was touching the arroz  con grandules ( aka mush from the microwave)when we told the server he just swapped out the spoon and went about his way. The server also failed to mention to us about the happy hour specials. when a group of girls came in that sat next us he decided to go through the whole introduction and recommendations. Which he failed to mention to us. Honestly, I would have rather gone to cha cha cha next door but, we decided to try this overhyped place.We did not hear any signs that there's actual cooking going on in the kitchen just the ringing of the microwave. Fail
author: Linda N.

description:
Had to call twice to place my order but boy was it worth it.

Tucked next to the ever-popular Cha Cha Cha, it's very easy to overlook it, as I have, despite walking past it nearly everyday for 4 years.

Ended up getting the Camarones a la Criolla--shrimp in a yummy cream sauce with lots of caramelized onions. Came with their yellow rice, beans, plantains, and a side salad. Decided to venture over to Golden Gate Park for a little lunch al fresco, and it was lovely.

Everything on my plate (well, tin foil bowl thing) was awesome. I could eat a bowl of the rice on it's own. The beans were savory and filling. The plantains had a luscious texture, like if a baked sweet potato and a canned peach had a baby. The salad was the perfect light, acidic thing to break up the otherwise rich food (not that I'm complaining about how rich the food was).

A warning for vegetarians/pescatarians: pay attention to what's in the sides. The rice and the beans both have ham in them, which I didn't know until I got them. A closer look at the "sides" on their menu will tell you what I cavalierly overlooked.
author: Julien I.

description:
Wow, very flavorful and hearty food!  I came here last night (Sat) at 6:30pm and snagged one of the last tables.  

I ordered the Pastelon ($15) which came with rice (Spanish or white), beans (red=with pork or white=without), salad, and 2 pieces of fried plantains.  The Pastelon was served like a piece of lasagna - sliced plantains acting as the pasta, and a ground beef filling.  The plantains were perfectly cooked, the seasoning was spot on, and if you wanted it spicy you could add some of their homemade habanero hot sauce.  My only criticism is the ground beef was sort of tough, but that was such a minor point relative to the incredible flavor of the dish overall.  

My next favorite item was the Spanish rice - so flavorful and so vibrant from the saffron.  I saved this side dish for last, I liked it so much!  The fried plantains were also great - nice and crispy on the edges.  The red beans were also tasty and the salad was well-dressed.  There really were no flaws.  

My friend thoroughly enjoyed his Pernil Asado ($15.50) as well and especially enjoyed the pork with the house habanro sauce.  I have never seen a white person clean up a plate that well!
author: Beatrice W.

description: Walked in with my girlfriend and waited to be seated.  It's a small place with a few open tables, wasn't bustling or anything.  There's a Wait to be Seated sign so we linger by the door.  Nobody came to seat us, and after a minute or so we noticed the cooks were just staring at us.  The staff was aware of us but intentionally refusing to seat us.  Very awkward moment there tonight.
author: Drew B.

description: Delicious and authentic Puerto Rican food.  At first I was concerned about not seeing empanadas, alcapurrias and pasteles on the menu, but they do have mofongo!  I ordered the mofongo with shrimp and it was amazing.
author: Camille T.

description:
This place is supurb.  Good atmosphere.  Delicious food.  Moderate pricing especially for the quality of food.   

I had the Mofongo de Camarones (prawns]. Spectacular!   For dessert,  Flan.  Delicious.

The place is clean and quiet.   It's designed decently well.   But it's all about the food.   And this place did not disappoint.   

I will be back again.
author: Miguel C.

description:
This place is amazing! I've been to Puerto Rico and after coming here, it just took me back! I had the mofongo and let me tell you it was super flavorful! I had it with the red beans and Spanish rice and I would totally recommend it that way should you get this delicious dish! 

I am totally coming back here.
author: Loreto D.

description: Talk about a small place with a big punch!  This little shop is just exploding with personality and character.  One of the top two places we visited all week!  In the Haight Street area of San Fran, this little café had great friendly hard working service, amazing diverse options for breakfast and lunch, and just a great vibe throughout.  We couldn't decide between all of their great options, show we shared several! Chorizo and Eggs, the amazing Pernil Asado, Pancakes, Eggs and Toast, and their Fresh Lemonade!  Honestly everything was really incredible.  The Pernil Asado was just busting with flavor and the Chorizo and Eggs was perfectly prepared.  The staff teams up to help everyone and each other.  Just a chill vibe that makes everyone relaxed and in a great mood.  I would love to eat their every weekend.  Thank you Hugo and team for a great brunch. If you have to wait a few minutes for one of their few tables - please be patient and do it.  It was worth it.
author: Jeff M.

description: I was craving Puerto Rican food and the options in the Bay are minimal to none so stopped here and got the Pollo a la criolla with white beans and spanish rice.  The flavors are incredible and are so reminiscent of an authentic home cooked PR meal.  The rice and chicken were full of flavor.  The salad had a nice light dressing and the sweet plantains were cooked just right.  So happy this place is here, I will gladly drive the 1+ hour from San Jose to get my grub on.
author: Tracy R.

description:
Excellent food which is inspired by the kitchen of Peru, from the simply things like the Rice and the beans to the more advanced stuff like the lasagne like beef dish and the chicken was everything just extremely tasty!

P.S. The Sangria is quite good and strong too!
author: Martin H.

description:
Had been to Puerto Rico and been always craving to have some authentic Puerto Rican food in the mainland. Found this after biking trip in GG park. Not very authentic Puerto Rican but very tasty. For example they only have 1 mofongo dish surprisingly.

I got the #1 on the menu which is minced beef layered with plantains. This reminds me of a Colombian empanadas that I had before. Very tasty and serving size is huge. Came with salad, plantains, and Spanish rice. All very delish
author: Ruxin H.

description: Excellent pulled pork! Spanish rice was also good, it all tasted like a home cooked meal. Restaurant was packed, but service was a little slow.
author: Michael D.

description: Came here for my birthday. Ordered the sampler as my meal because I wanted to try everything. It was ok. The best was the pernil. This place is tiny, so don't come with a large group. Service is a little slow, but the were always moving. I'd recommend getting just the pernil.
author: Lisa T.

description:
YUM! Being in SF, there's not too many Puerto Rican restaurants, at least they're not as prevalent as Mexican food.

SOOOOOOO gooddddddddddddddd. I went here like 6 weeks ago but I can still remember the texture and flavor albeit I didn't remember the name of what I ordered until I went on their site and looked at the pictures again..

I had the Mofongo de Camarones, which is pretty much mashed green plantains & shrimp. Mofongo is like .. amazing chunky mashed potatoes taken to another level and the shrimp is super flavorful and perfect with it!

The place is pretty small and there was only one waitress at the time I went (a weeknight).. she was pretty slow and was nowhere to be seen for like 5 minutes when I tried to pay my check and literally stood at the counter to wait for her.. which is the only reason why I'm docking one star.
author: Emily C.

description: I'm home, crowded, uncomfortable and loving it. Best home cooking from PR in Bay, just need more space, which keeps me from the last star. Pastelon was OMG, can't get this good except Moms house in PR.
author: Lance S.

description:
After spending an entire Tuesday frolicking in the city and its beautiful sights, I knew I wanted to end the day here. With the bf being half Puerto Rican and hasn't had authentic Puerto Rican food in who knows how long, this visit would be a special treat for him.

And indeed it was.

Instantly, we were taken away by the sounds of salsa and reggaeton (by artists the bf knew by name). We loved the cozy feel of the restaurant with Puerto Rican flags, artwork, pictures and even pantry items adorning its walls. We went during a perfect time - around 6pm on a Tuesday since parking was easy to find and we were seated right away.

The Puerto Rican dining experience was brand new to me. We ordered the sampler plate and devoured the tostones, chicharrones de pollo, roasted pork, and yucca. I marveled at the bottle of homemade hot sauce on the table (the bf saying his grandma would put a bunch of chili peppers and vinegar and other spices and let it sit). This hot sauce is so bomb, I ended up pouring it all over my food. So delicious. He ended up having the roasted pork, me the chicharrones de pollo. Everything we ate was just perfection. 

A week after our visit, we're still talking about our meal here and how we were craving tostones. We'll be back again one day Parada 22.
author: Grace L.

description:
I used to live by this place, and we would go there all the time.

Everything is amazing - especially the Pernil! 
And their homemade salsa is to die for. I would buy that and put it on everything except that it wouldn't even last me the day. 

The only problem is that it's a little hard to get a table because it's tiny inside, but the decoration is adorable - pictures of what I assume are someone's Puerto Rican grandparents, and little knick-knacks from old Puerto Rico. It's the definition of "hole in the wall."
author: Nadine G.

description: Stopped in for brunch on Easter waiting for the record store to open. Everything was great -- food, service, atmosphere. I wish I could come back to try the Puerto Rican comfort food for lunch or dinner. Maybe next trip!
author: Mike M.

description: Pernil - good, bistec - good, plantains - hella good. Those plantains and the house spicy sauce are probably the only reasons I'd come back here. Everything else is basically alright, but not spectacular. Decent prices, at least.
author: Ruobin W.

description:
If you have read any of my previous reviews for Latin food places, you are well aware that I have a true addiction to Cuban sandwiches. I have been known to hop in my car on a moments notice and trek 40 miles in each direction to satisfy my childhood obsession of these succulent pork on pork masterpieces. 

If I go more than a couple of weeks without one of these things I tend to breakout in cold sweats and feverishly start plotting a way for me to escape my daily responsibilities to get to one of my favorite places to calm my withdrawal symptoms.  Last night was a perfect example of this exact scenario, I had been craving one for a good week or so and the time had come to get my fix. So it was a toss up for me, do I go to the well known restaurant on the corner that I know also has this amazing 'wich on it's menu or do I slip into it's little cousin's (no true relation from what I understand, but you know how it is) establishment to stop the shakes? 

After doing a virtual coin flip, Ro Sham Bo and Eeny, meeny, miny, moe, I decided on the latter and stepped in and placed an order for the Classic Cubano (Roasted pork, smoked ham, mustard, pickles and swiss cheese) and a side of Habichuelas Coloradas (Red Kidney beans with smoked ham sofrito and green olives). Took it to the house and waited until that signal went from my gut to my brain. As I opened the to go container I got a whiff and I turned into Pookie and felt like I wanted to hop on a BMX bike and ride all the back across town to make away with the entire stash of these things, damn well knowing ICE-T would be on my ass the entire way back. 

Leaving all New Jack City references aside, this was spot-on what I was looking for and it will now be my go to spot in the city until a new heir apparent has been found. 

Salud!
author: Josh H.

description:
First time having Puerto Rican food, and the food was absolutely delicious! Came here for lunch w/ no wait, & I decided to order to order the Pollo Encebollado (marinated boneless chicken sautéed w/ caramalized onions) w/ a side of red beans, yellow rice, salad & maduros. The chicken was soo tender & flavorful along w/ the caramelized onions. The salad was refreshing. The red beans which also had pieces of pork were delicious. For the rice, I'm not a huge rice person, but these were amazing - creamy texture w/pieces of olives..drooling! The whole plate had amazing flavors & all complimented each other so well.

*We didn't get our maduros until the end b/c they had forgotten a couple of times, but the waitress was very kind & gave us a few extra pieces for having to remind them abt our maduros.

Overall, really great first experience & def recommend trying !
author: Trina N.

description: My wife's family is from Puerto Rico and there's no restaurants in the area where we live while visiting SF we found this place and it taste just like grandma's food! I am extremely happy that we found this place and have somewhere to come now when we come to San Francisco to eat off the hook for we can film!
author: Ryan S.

description: One shouldn't even dare think of visiting the Haight without having some of Parada's homestyle Puerto Rican fare. One foot into the tall minty green building and you're instantly transported to a small neighborhood in San Juan. Get ready for the juiciest of pollo a la criollas which was sautéed boneless chicken with ham and tomatoes or the pernil asado (roasted pork). Both meats we tried were excellent, but I preferred the chicken. All meals come with fried only once plantains, your choice of spanish or white rice (go for spanish!), a small salad, and red or white beans. The portions were spot on. It is definitely a hearty meal but unlike the typical vigorous meal where you feel the need to unbutton or else you'd pop. it was a happy, warm, please-let-me-stay-forever kind of feeling you get from a home cooked meal or a hug from your grandmother. Or both.
author: Shirley L.

description: Small, fun, good Puerto Rican fare.  Looking forward to trying more on the menu.  Definitely will return
author: Chris B.

description:
I went to Puerto Rico last year and I was craving for Puerto Rican food. I saw my friend posted a pic from Parada 22 on Instagram and got curious. Thanks to my curiosity, my boyfriend and I have found the best Puerto Rican food in town! 

The taste just felt like home (I'm not Puerto Rican but some of the latin dishes can be similar to filipino dishes). I ordered the sampler which consist of chicaronnes el pollo, roasted pork, tostones, yucca, and veggies. Super yummy. 

I would definitely come back when I crave for Puerto Rican food
author: Jennifer B.

description: Great food... My first time eating Puerto Rican food and I'm hooked.. I wonder if San Jose has any of this... waiters were friendly and fast... they answered all my questions.. and the environment was just very chill.. definitely recommend to anyone...
author: Lucy R.

description:
Miles better than neighboring Cha Cha Cha and I'm convinced the $8 Sampler platter is the best happy hour deal in the city. 

Everything here is spot on, authentic Puerto Rican cuisine. And if you don't know what that tastes like, come here anyways - the food will objectively blow your mind. One of my favorite meals I've had in SF.

Highlights were: tostones (get these now!), pastelon, pernil asado. They also make an incredibly tasty flan.
author: Andres B.

description: Where do I begin?  Incredible food, service, and authentic experience!   Food tasted fresh and came out steaming hot.  It's always packed, which is a clear sign that the food is fantastic.
author: Savannah P.

description: As server myself, i was highly impressed!! Super great food and super great service. Thank you Masson!!
author: Melissa L.

description: Can't speak for the rest of the menu but the Classic Cubano is worth blowing my rent money on
author: Dara R.

description:
What I ate: Biftec encebollado with arroz amarillo, habichuelas blancas, and maduros; camarones ensalada
Visit date: October 12, 2012
First time? Yes.

Every bite was followed by an "ooooh yeaaa." When we were full, we were a little sad that we couldn't eat more. What can you do?

The camarones salad: sauteed shrimp in a creamy garlic cilantro sauce. So good. I love saucy foods, so salad definitely makes the cut. The added fresh avocados AND pickled onions make this dish hard to beat. 

The biftec encebollado: sirloin steak served with caramelized onions, Spanish rice, white beans, and plantains. In my mind I wanted the Filipino version -- "bistek" -- which has tender steaks and caramelized onions. This meat tasted like...beef, nothing special. It was also a bit overwhelming -- parts were chewy and there was a lot of it. I loved the onions, though. They went so well with the Spanish rice and white beans. The maduros, we saved for our dessert. They were perfect bites of fried goodness. 

Try the hot sauce on the table. SPICY YUMMIES! I drenched the meat in it and it gave it moisture and bit more flavor. 

Give me a bowl of their caramelized onions, Spanish rice, and house hot sauce and I'm a very happy girl. Initiate happy food dance. Since this visit, I have sent a few friends over; I'm eager to return.
author: Erin G.

description: Absolutely amazing! Favorite restaurant is Sol Food in Marin and this is pretty close I would highly recommend.
author: Brooke K.

description:
I love this place!! SO GOOD!! The first time I went to Parada 22 was actually the one on Valencia. My friend and I were out for girls night and so happened to pass by. Unfortunately, that one is now closed. So I started going to this location. The place is much smaller than the one on Valencia but it does not bother me. My go to meal is the pollo encebollado with a side of tostones. The dish comes with rice (I choose spanish), beans (I choose the one with pork), maduros, and salad. The dressing they have for the salad is really good but a little spicy. I recommend trying a little before drenching your salad.  My boyfriend and I always get the pitcher of sangria to share. He drinks a lot so we get the large one. The food is really good, chicken nicely seasoned, tender, and juicy, the onions are sauteed and give a nice crunch to each bite. I am used to sour creme for the tostones. However, they use a different kind of sauce, almost like thousand island but better. It goes well with the tostones and maduros. I usually get an extra sauce because my bf hogs it. 

The service is great. They are pretty attentive of you. They make sure you have everything you need at the table and refill when necessary. Quality of food is great and fresh. Definitely will be returning for the 15746168 time!
author: Gabrielle C.

description: Although it's a little cozy, the atmosphere is one of friendliness. There's so much energy that you'll likely dance off your meal while dining. The food's fantastic. Really nice people, good food.  Clean, fast service and preparation, tasty, interesting.
author: Oscar R.

description: Fun place to eat and really good food. I recommend the appetizer sampler plate to start. The pork dish is absolutely wonderful!  The chicken on the sampler plate is outstanding also.
author: Kristi A.

description:
My favorite place in the Haight.
