Only knock is my fellow Caucasians that work here never answer phone for take out ( 3 times now) no matter how busy. Very curious as to why.
author: Thomas M.

description:
Delicious Puerto Rican food in Haight-Ashbury neighborhood of San Francisco!

This is my first Puerto Rican food, so I can't comment on authenticity. Fresh salad greens, everything tasty (including the sangria). Trying the shrimp main course with creamy tomato based sauce - fantastic taste, both thumbs up!
author: Kenneth B.

description: I freaking love this place. It is located right next to a cha cha chaslightly which serves similar cuisine but the ambience at parada is way more intimate and has awesome decor, in my opinion. The food is always fantastic - my favorite plate for now is the pastelon! So delicious and filling...also love that the plates come with rice, beans, maduros, salad, etc. Sangria is also wonderful.
author: Samantha A.

description: Consistency is key! I I have been coming here for about 6 years and its always DELICIOUS! mofongo and sangria
author: Macy P.

description: Really good food! It's a small cozy place. I had the roasted pork, but wished I had gone for the chicken. There was a lot of pork leftover.  The salad looks really good. Next time, I want to try the chicken salad or one of their sandwiches. Yum!
author: Julia W.

description: I love parada! Quick service and food as well. Get the pork, totopos and maybe an extra order of those kidney beans!!
author: Erronious M.

description:
My boyfriend and I just finished watching the movie, "Chef." We had the biggest craving for Cubano's afterwards. Searched on Yelp to see where we could get Cubano's in the city. Parada 22 it is.

Got there. Waited 15 minutes. 

Ordered the Cubano and the appetizer sampler. The Cubano was good, but it wasn't amazeballz. It was good enough to satisfy our cravings though :P. Of all the items in the appetizer sampler, the maduros (sweet plantains) hit the spot. If anything, I'd come back here just for that.

Sangria - get it. How are you going to come to a place that offers sangria's and not have some at your table?
author: Denise K.

description: The roast pork was very tender.  The beans were quite flavorful.  A good size plate with salad and rice, pork, and the yummy plaintains.  The size of the restaurant is quite small.  Definitely get there early to enjoy the light and the quietness inside.  They have the best water with lime and orange.   The shrimp dish was filled with peeled shrimps.  I got so full, couldn't fit in the coconut flan, darn!
author: Helen L.

description: Best PR food in Bay Area, flavor like home.  Small location so get there early for seating.  Sangria was strong and good.
author: Michelle J.

description: Amazing!! Was traveling with my cousin who is from Puerto Rico and who had been craving food from home and we stopped here.  It was some of the best PuertoRican food I've ever had! The waitress was really nice and the restaurant itself is very cute and clean.  The only down was it took some time for the food to come out, but extremely worth it!
author: Yarah L.

description: Tasty food and great service. A nice stop after a walk in the park nearby. Would return for sure.
author: Nick R.

description:
The shrimp mofongo is great; comes with a nice variety of stuff on the plate (sweet plantains, salad, beans, rice, and the mofongo).

Minus one star because their prices on the menu posted in the window are super outdated. Once inside, the menu shows most items at $2-3 more. Kind of an annoying bait and switch almost.
author: Linus W.

description: This is a good place to eat. It was recommended by some friends and I was not disappointed. The food was great! Minor setback: it is a bit small!
author: Guillaume G.

description: So surprised I haven't been here yet. Went for the first time Friday night and came right back for dinner Sunday night. If you go early, around 6, there is usually no wait. The food is DELICIOUS! I think it's even better than Sol food in Marin.
author: Skye W.

description: As soon as you walk in you hear the salsa playing and aroma of great Puerto Rican  food! The food had so much flavor and was delicious!! Reminded me of my aunts cooking back in Puerto Rico! I literally wanted to order everything on the menu so I ordered a sampler with a side of rice and beans and I was in heaven!! Would def come back again. 5 stars in my book for sure!
author: vanessa f.

description: My wife and I were out for a walk on Sunday when someone recommended this Puerto Rican restaurant for breakfast. Perfect choice. The huevos rancheros were excellently seasoned and excitedly different from traditional Mexican food. Staff was friendly and atmosphere was old school SF. If you eat here, you must try the fried Yucca appetizer, you won't be disappointed.
author: Todd W.

description: Yummy Puerto Rican food!! The yucca platter and shrimp platter were top notch. Although I'm not a big fan of yucca, I absolutely loved the way it was prepared here with the flavorful sauce. The fried plantains were delicious too - I wish they gave me more than 2 pieces of it though. Prices aren't atrocious and portions sizes are good.
author: Sharanya A.

description: I highly recommend this restaurant for some high quality Puerto Rican food! I loved this place on my very first visit and enjoyed the Latino music that they had that day!
author: William H.

description: Came in right after lunch crowd...no fuss. I enjoyed the personal attention and eclectic decor. The box TV was playing nostalgic HeMan cartoons. The food was great! I had the perfectly prepared pastolon with Spanish rice,  beans, maduro, and salad. Needless to say I left very happy.
author: cory h.

description:
Dear Parada 22, 

I've eaten at the restaurant several dozen times, but I am now an ex-customer.  I have put up with the absolutely terrible service at both dinner and brunch because I really love the food.  But I just can't do it again unless you can get your act straight.  I want you to know that I have been a regular.  I am recognized by the staff.  And it has taken a LOT of very bad service to bring me to the point of posting this rant to Yelp.  But I'm done.  The service is intolerable.

Let me be specific:  the wait staff is friendly, but they are some combination of overworked, underpaid, or undertrained because they don't pay any attention to the customers:

1.  No one pays attention when people walk in the door.  I mean, I see that they notice me.  It's a very small room, and I'm the only customer who's standing up, and 2 minutes have passed by.  Am I insane here?  I should not have to walk up to the counter and ask for a table as if I'm the first person that ever entered a restaurant.  One time I waited 5 minutes while the server chatted with a cook, only to be told that a private party was coming soon so no tables would be available for a couple hours.  Are you kidding me?  How hard is it to put a sign up?  Or to just acknowledge me when I walk in?  

2.  After taking my order, no one ever any pays attention to me for the rest of the meal.  At dinner, my water is never refilled, and at brunch, my coffee is never refilled.  Several times now, I've eaten an entire meal - which takes at least 40 minutes - and not been offered a single refill.  Come on!  This is just serving 101.  Circulate with the coffee pot every now and then.  The worst is when I'm offered my first refill as the check is delivered.  Seriously?  Too little, too late.

3.  No one ever notices when I'm ready for the check.  It's really not hard to notice when my napkin is crumpled next to my empty plate.  And I'm talking ten minutes later.  The whole restaurant has less than 10 tables.  Yet, almost every time, I need to flag down the server to ask for the bill.

4.  Here's what really kills me:  I don't just sit there, I make direct eye contact with the servers.  I see that they see me.  And yet they don't come over!  It's incredibly frustrating and just baffling.  When I want the check, I actually have to tug at the server as they pass by or call out loud to them.  

Just so you know, I have always tipped well, and I'm polite.  I know that when several different servers give this terrible service, the problem has to be the management.  I'm sad that I have to give up eating your tasty food.  Let me know if you ever get your act together.
author: Trip B.

description:
I don't know how many touristy people would end up here, but it's definitely a nice, hidden gem that locals know about. I had the pollo sandwich and my boyfriend had the pernil asado. In case you don't know, pernil is like a marinated, shredded, Puerto Rican pork dish. My boyfriend is from South America, and he liked it a lot.

We ordered an extra side of fried plantains because they were very good and only two came with his meal, but be careful. It is a big order, and you will definitely want someone to share them with.

It seems like very authenticate cuisine!
author: Nadia H.

description:
Okay, we came here because of a GROUPON for early dinner. There were two other table seated and so when we walked in and only saw tables meant for 4 people and up and a 2/3 seater all the way in the back towards the cash register, I was a bit uneasy.  Not because the tables were all the way in the back but because we got to pick one out of the two. The one in front of the cash register.. was LITERALLY in front of the cash register. How awkward is that? The second option (which we opted for) sat two but one seat was facing an ugly wall (the table was up against the wall in a corner) and the other seat was facing the counter which had a small display of beverages. I seriously felt like I was sitting in time out.

I couldn't understand why we only had these two options and I asked the waitress/cashier if I could switch. She said no because they might have a "rush". She did offer a couple times afterwards after she saw me pouting and complaining under my breath and looking super unhappy but being stubborn I refused to move just because I wasn't going to switch back to that seat after a "rush" comes in.

food was absolutely delicious. I don't even care to talk about it in this review just because of the horrible service I got that night. 

The place is just dirty and the bathroom is all the way in the very back past the kitchen which I swear a health inspector should probably go see it. I dont even know how sanitary that place is but whatevs.

What made me even more upset was two guys came in and she let them sit at the table that seated 8-10 people. what the heck. I'm not a diva or a princess or anything but this was seriously upsetting that we weren't considered as a priority or even customers for that matter. She never filled our glasses of water but filled theirs and waited on them hand and foot.

Service sucked. Go next door to Cha Cha Cha!
author: Lauren K.

description:
There is an epidemic in Norther California.  It's a food-based epidemic.  Suddenly, it seems like people can taste price!  Everywhere you go, 5 and 4 star Yelp reviews for moderately expensive restaurants that favor presentation and ambience over food quality.  So many restaurants out here lack flavor, and yet people seem to ignore it when conducting a review.   I almost daily read 4 star reviews that say "The food was a bit under-seasoned, but service was good."  When did we all forget about food quality and flavor?

Luckily Parada 22 delivers big taste and big value!  Its moderately priced, offers great portion sizes, and punches you right in your taste buds with delightful flavors.  Dinner for my wife and I, along with a pitcher of sangria was only $50.  That kind of price is rare in these parts, and we were fortunate to have stumbled upon it!  I had the Biftec Encebollado and my wife had the Camarones a La Criolla.  We both agreed that it was by far the best food we had in the SF area up to that date.  I'm definitely looking forward to returning soon!
author: Jon F.

description: Very cozy hole in the wall type of place. I had the pulled pork, which came with yellow rice (contained green olives), beans, and salad with dressing. The pork had a good amount of fat on it, to add to the savoriness. There was actually a lot of pork left when I was nearing the end. Not enough rice and salad to really complement the serving size of the pork, but I'm not complaining. Overall, pretty delicious and homely. But not spectacular enough to warrant 4 stars for the price.
author: Toni T.

description: I had the mofongo with camarones, it was delicious. The plate comes with rice and beans, which were real good. They served a lot of food, the prices are also very good.  I had puertorican food in many other restaurants, this one is one of the best outside of Puerto Rico.
author: Jesus D.

description: Seattle is lacking great food like this. The closest thing we can get is probably Paseo's. Anyways, the food is delicious along with the sangria that is tasty and very potent. Service was good, as our server was very attentive at always keeping our sangria and water glasses full. I'll be back next time I'm in San Fran. I strongly recommend this place.
author: Lisa U.

description:
I really like their food. But I'm a vegetarian, and I always order the vegetarian plate. The last time I ordered a delivery, when I was about to finish eating I noticed little tiny pieces of meat, which I'm guessing they used it to season the beans or something. 
You can't call it vegetarian if you're gonna season it with meat. I felt betrayed because I've always trusted them that the dish I was ordering was vegetarian. I'd love to hear from Parada 22 on this situation.
author: Juan B.

description:
This used to be my own private little gem until word got around as to how good this place is. Tiny little restaurant. Even at late hours of the night there can be a long wait for a table. However, the food is worth the wait!

Upon sitting, they bring a huge pitcher of citrus water to the table. Love it! Love citrus water and hate asking for refills of it. Wish more restaurants caught onto how valuable the water pitcher concept is. 

I always get the same thing: Camarones dinner plate. Comes with your choice of Spanish or white rice. I prefer the Spanish rice. Also comes with beans, leafy salad and sweet plantains. God I really love this place. It's so good!! Have tried other entrees like the Biftec and Pastelon but the Camarones are my favorite. They're sautéed with veggies in a light cream sauce. 

The sweet plantains are so good I usually order extra. And the Yuca is good too. Very authentic food. Would come here more if the seating was more comfortable.
author: Rosalyn W.

description:
Probably the BEST food I had the entire Labor Day weekend that I had spent in San Francisco. Their roasted pork is just so melt-in-your-mouth delicious, that I couldn't stop eating. 

The sampler is a good choice if you want to try a lot of different foods. Everything on that plate was just so tasty! I really enjoyed eating the sauce that they give you with pretty much everything. 

But the pork entree is definitely something you should try. My favorite dish we shared was the pork sandwich.

This place is super cute, and I'd probably go here every time I go to visit SF.
author: Jen N.

description: comida criolla! Just straight forward Good Puerto Rican comfort food!! The rice... The beans.... Oh so good!
author: Mariangelli C.

description:
I am giving this place three stars because of the service.

First of all, I like the food here. There's a lot of it and it's good. I got the "Chicharrones de Pollo-fried marinated boneless chicken with salsa rosa & tostones." I absolutely loved the tostones with it and the chicken was delicious. I feel like you can't go wrong with deep fried chicken, I also like the sauce with it - it reminds of a mayo-based, honey mustard type of sauce. 

The salad on the side is exceptionally good too. The vegetables are fresh and the dressing is tangy and good. Delicious! 

This place is really small, so it can get pretty busy. The wait staff is a little too chill for me. They aren't always attentive and they are a little slow with getting things right. 

Also, I like the hot sauce on the table. Adding it on to everything gives it a little kick. It's habanero spicy sauce or something along those lines. It's not very spicy if you put a little but if you put a lot, you might feel it. Just remember to spread it everywhere and you're not taking a big bite of just sauce!
author: Margaret L.

description: This place is amazing! The fried plantains were so delicious. They were salty and sweet! Cute place with nice ambiance. Located on hait street...
author: Melissa E.

description:
Very happy to find a place that serves Puerto Rican food in bay area. It's worth a 45 miles from my home.
We have ordered Chicharrones De Pollo and Mofongo. All the items in the plate are fresh, flavorful and of unique taste. The fried chicken was made just perfect, along with rice, beans, salads, tostones and plantains. Mofongo is also great, and goes very well with the shrimp.
author: Subhra B.

description:
Superb Puerto Rican food, the best I have had away from the island. I've been to PR maybe 25  times over many years, its a lovely part of the US, has amazing exotic experiences yet as a part of the US you can just hop on a plane any time you want and enjoy an amazing vacation full of cultures, sights, sounds and best of all, their food. The food on the island is saturated with flavor and textures that are so satisfying and different that I always try to eat my way through the island. If you want a sampling of that island experience right now, then you must come to Parada 22, the food transports me back to the many well enjoyed visits and the many wonderful meals I have enjoyed there.

Today I ordered the sampler because after staring at the menu for a long time, I knew that I wanted to try absolutely everything but I'll just have to keep coming back, so I went for the sampler plate to begin with.

"The Sampler" features:
Pernil Asado rost pork shoulder marinated with garlic, oregano and traditional Sofrito
Chicharrón de Pollo fried boneless chicken with salsa rosa
Maduros Ripe sweet cooked plantains
Yuca el Mojo is cassava root with onions garlic and olive oil
Tostones traditional fried and pressed green plantains with salsa roja

Mind blown! It was all so good that it truly felt like I was back on the island. The flavor are authentic and rich. If you have not tried it before all I can say is that its like creole only better.

My companion ordered the Camarones A La Criolla, sautéed shrimp in a fresh tomato sauce, onion and sweet pepper cream sauce which were so good.

Dessert was the coconut flan and drinks were iced sweet tea and lemonade.

Service was excellent, the waitress answered all our questions, was very patient with our indecision and quickly brought our plates with a smile. We gave her an extra nice tip.

We enjoyed the meal so much that we then ordered two more dinners to go, the Arroz Amarillo and Habichuelas Coloradas are island staples which we enjoyed so much that although they come with the plates we ordered extra sides so we would have plenty to enjoy back at home.

Our take out order consisted of:

Mofongo De Camarones contining mashed green plantains with smoked ham, mixed veggie sofrito and camarones a la corolla (see above)

Pastelon which is made of sweet plantains layered with picadillo (spiced ground beef with olives raisins peppers and onions

Arroz Amarillo spanish rice with sweet peppers, green olives, spices and smoked ham

Habichuelas Coloradas Braised kidney beans in a chunky smoked-ham-sofrito with green olives

We enjoyed these dishes for dinner tonight, at home, and each was yummy and satisfying.

The floor profiles of Puerto Rico are unique, and Parada 22 really delivers on those flavors. Its a tiny humble place with Puerto Rican memorabilia dating back to 1898 covering all the walls. Its a quaint place that would be as good for tae night as it would be for family night. If I worked nearby I would stop by here for lunch every day, they also have sandwiches with late flavor profiles, that I intend to check out in the future (I was serious when I said I'm going to try everything on the menu).

Please do try this humble place, it will give yo a feel for who Puerto Rican mamas take good care of their families.
author: Bob L.

description:
After living in Marin for 4 years, I am a strong advocate for Sol Food. With that being said, I was hesitant to try a new Puerto Rican place because nothing could live up to sol foods expectations. 

My boyfriend and I decided to try out Parada 22 after seeing it on the way to flywheel coffee awhile back. We went for lunch, and the decor is very homey--similar to sol food. Lime green walls with black and white pictures. Bf ordered the Bifstec sandwich with avocado ($10.50) and I ordered the mofongo y camarones ($12). I almost always order the camarones criollos at sol food so I figured I should try them here. The mofongo came with camarones criollos so I ordered it with Spanish rice, spring salad and red beans--AMAZING. The shrimp had more of a garlic butter sauce rather than the tomatoey garlic sauce that I'm used to. Everything was amazing. The Spanish rice had chunks of chorizo and the mofongo had a really smooth texture. The steak in the Bifstec sandwich was well seasoned and thicker than I was used to, and it came with a spring salad. Their table sauce was a little creamier than sol foods but pretty good and tangy. I will definitely be back. Everything was uhhhhhhmazing. Definitely a shorter drive and NO WAIT compared to sol food. It's not sol food, but it satisfies my sol food craving.
author: Vivian C.

description: The food was delicious!  We had shrimp and pork and the pork was everyone's favorite.  Rice and beans are good, also.  Only complaint is that we waited about an hour - the restaurant is tiny.  But it's worth it.  Interior is very cute and very small.
author: Jennifer C.

description: It's okay. Sangria, maduros, and pernil were on point. The yellow rice was meh. Try the sampler to get a taste of everything.
author: Toni R.

description:
So I passed by this place almost every time I'm on Haight Street, which is half of the week. Im so glad my friend finally drag me here for lunch. 
We got in right at Happy Hour so needless to say, we were most definitely happy.
- A sampler plate for $6. What? All the deliciousness for $6. Roast prok, fried chicken, fried plantein, everything was on point.
- I think you probably hear enough about the Spanish rice but i guarantee you the rumor is right: the Spanish rice is GOOD! 
- We also had the sauteed shrimp (sorry i can't remember its Spanish name, i tried, i just cant) and it was so good i finished the whole plate before my friend could even taste it. I felt so bad but it felt so good :)
author: Alan T.

description:
I LOVE PLANTAINS.  That being said, the side of plantains, funny enough, were the highlight of my plate. Don't get me wrong. I got pollo plate and the chicken was good. I just like plantains more.  

Next time I'm just going to order a giant plate of plantains. Yum.
author: Sinan W.

description: We had a very tasty meal for a great price. We split a plate and drank sangria it was awesome! Very very delicious, we are highly satisfied.
author: Leila S.

description:
I walked down here with my coworker for lunch on a Friday and there were only 2 other people inside so no wait at this time! The waiter was really nice and attentive and everything on the menu sounded so good. I was debating between the Pastalon and the Chicharron de Pollo. The Pastalon (basically a plantain lasagna) sounded so interesting, but I chose the latter because I'm not a big fan of olives and raisins. And I'm glad I did! The fried chicken was so tender, perfectly crispy, and so full of flavor especially with the dipping sauce. The plate also comes with rice (get the Spanish!), beans (red or white), greens, and 2 plantain chips. Everything on that plate was delicious! I would definitely order it again. 

The portions are also a lot bigger than I expected. My coworker ordered the Biftec Encebollado and loved it too. He almost couldn't finish it because it comes with so much beef! We also ordered Yuca to share as an appetizer and it was amazing. I loved the warm, soft texture and it tasted like a sweet potato, but better! We were both so full and satisfied after and had to power through the food coma back at work, but it was worth it. The only thing I didn't like about this place was the gross clear vertical blinds you have to walk through to get in and out, but that won't deter me from coming back! Maybe I'll be adventurous and try the Pastalon next time.
author: Stephanie G.

description:
One of the rare Puerto Rican places in the bay area. This place is so freakin adorable inside. They collected and brought out all kinds of things from New York and Puerto Rico, coffee, cookies, pictures, etc. Really adds a nice touch. So onto the food... I am Puerto Rican so I can judge pretty accurately and the food was really authentic, like my mommas. I ordered the penil (pork) and it was amazing and full of flavor and it came with rice and beans and platanos maduros (sweet plantains). BOMB! And guess what GF'ers???? All this food was naturally GLUTEN-FREE!!! Whoot Whoot! 

#GLUTEN-FREE
author: Natalie L.

description:
I love Puerto Rican food.  I am not going to say that I am some kind of Puerto Rican / Caribbean culinary genius, but I have had a LOT of food from the region, as I live in New York and have lived in Miami dating a Puerto Rican for let's just say a really long time.

I think this place hits the spot, thus I would recommend it.  But I cannot say that it is without its imperfections :-)  

Lets start with the GREAT parts.
- The Pastelon really nails it.  Think of a Puerto Rican flavor profile crossed with a lasagna.  ($14)  I wanted MORE though... 
- Pernil ($14) was VERY well seasoned and VERY good .  Think of succulent roast pork with caribbean flavors (likely sofrito).  Delicious.
- Tostones and side Mayo-Ketchup style sauce was very tasty.
- Side salads on each plate were very tasty and a good complement to the PRican foods which are full of oil
- The white rice was cooked to perfection (with a little bit of oil).  I love the way PRican rice is made... similar but tastes different from South and East Asian varieties.

Least liked:
- Sangria was mieh.  Really mieh.  We drank it, but were unhappy with it.
- The Mofongo con Camorones ($14.50)  was very liked but was missing a lot of the mashed plantains component, which we asked for and got more of.  I loved this dish, but want to put here so people know that when they order the Mofongo to ensure they get enough of the plantains.

Excellent service (very attentive) and very friendly.  Will come back.
author: Andrew S.

description: The food here is amazing. I don't have anything bad to say at all about this place. Huge huge, tasty well seasoned food. I loveee plaintains and everything they make. The service was quick to us, we arrived around 4:30pm. The seating area is a bit tight but I personally don't mind it as long as the food is good. I hope they keep up the terrific quality. I will definately be returning in the near future. They do have beer and wine, not sure if they had hard liquor or not, we didn't check. Give it a try you won't be disappointed.
author: Christina C.

description:
Stopped up here midroute during the "morning" (maybe by 11 AM?) of Bay to Breakers this year for a Puerto Rican-style brunch. I remember having the Chorizo and Eggs, which was actually quite a large serving. Probably too much sour cream, but chorizo can win me over any day. I think we had mimosas to drink, though I know they also make sangria.

It was getting a little crowded inside, but I'm glad we arrived when we did -- by noon, it was packed and there was a line. Likely in part for B2B, but FYI. Was nice to walk just one block over to Golden Gate Park next.
author: Garett T.

description:
I was strolling about with 5 friends on Haight Street when lunch time arrived and that we started looking for a good spot. I ordered Chicharrones De Pollo. Other friends ordered the same and others ordered Camarones A La Criolla. 
I've never tasted Puerto Rican food before and it was very very good. The Spanish rice and fried chicken were perfect. We all devoured our dishes. 
There are not a lot of seats and tables and we were packed at a high table close to the storefront window but it was ok.
author: Mag D.

description:
Parada 22 is a great neighborhood restaurant. It's small and cozy, but the dining area is open and not cramped with tables. The high slatted ceilings make it seem even bigger than it is and together with the way the place is decorated and one full brick wall, the ambience is comfortable and totally inviting. The service was very friendly, helpful and quick. If you're not sure what to get, ask, and you will be rewarded.

The pollo encebellado (marinated boneless chicken sauteed with caramelized onions) was tender and juicy and came with your choice of Spanish or white rice* and white or red beans. The Spanish rice and small bin of red beans were also both well flavored and a good complement to the chicken smothered in tasty onions. A salad is also thrown on the plate with three maduros so you really get a full meal with a lot of different things to sample in one order. The chicharrones de pollo (fried marinated boneless chicken with salsa rosa & tostones) were also excellent, friend but tender on the inside and came with the same options except you get two tostones instead of three maduros.

The value is great and the food backs it up. Whatever you are doing in the area, Parada 22 is a nice spot to pop into to get a quick, tasty, authentic meal. Top it off with some flan and then get on your way.
________________
*Why you would choose white rice over Spanish rice at a place like this I'm not really sure.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
Casual, and on the tiny side; something to keep in mind.

Parada 22 is named for one of Puerto Rico's treasures, the Centro de Belles Artes which, apparently, resides famously on bus stop 22 in the balmy streets of old San Juan. Aaah, Google, thanks.

As you enter the diminutive cafe, you'll notice a large black & white photo mural over the kitchen. This nostalgic scene sets the stage for the "P.R." dining experience you're about to enjoy.

We ordered plantains and a few other dishes we were familiar with. When our food arrived, we were pleasantly surprised at the flavors and color. While our servers changed during our meal and the second person was less attentive, we still enjoyed our meal immensely. Parada 22 easily topped our previous "go-to" Puerto Rican restaurant, the wildly popular Sol Food in San Rafael.

If you're new to Puerto Rican food, you'll find the savory flavors and textures easy to enjoy and satisfyingly filling. If you're already a fan of this Caribbean cuisine, you''ll likely enjoy the richness of the flavors and might even have discovered a new gem. In either case, you'll find great casual fare in this delightful little cafe.

And, unlike Sol Food, you're not likely to wait in a line stretching down the block!
author: John H.

description:
Thursday, 8:15PM

Quickie:
+ Food quality
+ Friendly staff
- Hygiene
- Slow turnaround
- Space
+ Menu variety

And then...?


**********
Stuffed my face in:

1. Camarones a la criolla: sautéed shrimp in a fresh tomato, onion and pepper cream sauce
     + Cream sauce buffered the sautéed salt. 
2. Pernil asado: roasted pork, marinated with garlic, oregano base sofrito
     - Overwhelming vegetal pork flavor. 
3. Tostones
     + Salsa prevents plantains from being too dry. 

Constructive comment:
*Source ingredients
author: Chuck N.

description: Stopped into Parada 22 to have some authentic Puerto Rican fare during our visit to the Haight-Ashbury neighborhood.  It was a bit cramped inside and the person behind me couldn't back his chair out without hitting mine... Had to move our table to get in and out. The atmosphere was nice though as was the staff. Wife ordered the Mofongo de Camerones, I ordered the Biftec sandwich. The flavors were there with my sandwich,but the steak was so tough you couldn't really eat it like a sandwich. Every bite would pull the whole thing apart because it wouldn't tear. Finally ended up cutting it up. Wife enjoyed hers and the mash was quite good. Her Sangria was also nice. Overall an enjoyable experience, despite the tough steak and cramped seating.
author: Ben G.

description: Food and service... AWESOME! Great staff in and out of the kitchen. You can taste the love that goes into this food. Well done all at Parada 22. I will return.
author: Guy C.

description: Definitely stop at 22. This hot spot represents puerto rican culture with style. With fast service excellent food and a well curated decor visualizing the everyday latin house hold, Parada 22 feels like home and tastes of its comforts. A must try. Don't forget to ask for the mayo ketchup.
author: Chris L.

description:
Something is not fresh with their food...
Mofongo + Pastelon tasted like they were made days in advance, frozen then reheated. We've made better tostones at home. Asado seemed decent. Don't know why they get such high ratings. Disappointed.
author: s t.

description:
best Puerto Rican Food in the bay area!!!! 
My bf is from puerto rico and nothing beats homemade food of course but this place is absolutely amazing if i had more start i'd give it 10!!!
author: Maria H.

description:
I had my first date with my novio here. Danay was our server and she was a delight. Love her!

First of all... they serve sweet tea and that melts my little southern heart. I love not having to explain to a Yankee server why it's different than having to dissolve a packet of sugar in cold tea. The food is great and the space is awesome. Large portions too.

We had;

Chicharrones de Pollo. I add hot sauce because I live for heat.
Pastelon. Delicious.
Sampler with the Yuca al Mojo. I'll order it again.

The food had an authentic, warm, home-cooked feel. Nothing over the top or fancy, just like a dinner at my x-novio's mothers house in old San Juan. Try the sangria too!
author: Thomas Nathan S.

description:
THIS REVIEW IS FOR DELIVERY.

I ordered through grub-hub and when my food came it was cold.  Waited almost 2 hours for it and when you wait that long/it comes to you cold, it just is annoying.  Had to reheat it in the microwave which I wasn't too stoked about.
Also, I ordered a steak dish and chicken came.

Get yourself together for deliveries if you're going to do them, because I'm sure it's delicious food when it comes in a timely matter and is still hot....
author: Chantel B.

description:
I enjoyed coming across a Puerto Rican restaurant in SF. I had the plato vegetariano and my friend had the Pollo Encebollado.  I was happy with my dish. Lots of flavor, and fully satisfying, which isn't always the case with veg dishes. Usually veg. dishes consist of lots of salads, pasta, or a stir-fry concoction. The main part of the vegetarian plate was the yuca, which was different in a good way. It definitely felt substantial. The salad had too much dressing, but the mofongo was was yummy, and the white beans were really good. Nothing was overwhelmingly delicious, but it was great food nonetheless. My friend had the same response to her plate, "it's okay, pretty good."

I don't know that I would ever go out of my way to go to this place again, and probably wouldn't recommend it unless someone  asked specially for puerto rican food.
author: N S.

description: Nice home style set up. Had pollo encebollado  with white beans and yellow rice. Loved the baked plantains.
author: Samir T.

description:
Puerto Rican food is amazing and a must-try for anyone who's never had it. I pretty much always enjoy what I eat as long as the chef sticks to classic dishes with classic ingredients. Parada 22 kicks up a notch by offering that rare, truly homemade feel that many mom 'n' pop restaurants claim to have, but few actually do.

I got the Pernil Asado and my friend got the Biftec sandwich. The Pernil Asado was like a treasure trove of culinary delights served on one plate. I couldn't make up my mind what to eat next and wanted to have everything in my mouth at once: the fluffy rice, the juicy meat, the starchy plantains....ahhh, thinking about it is making me drool right now! My friend's sandwich was tasty, but it was no contest which I preferred. 

I docked a star because the woman who was our server was kind of a sourpuss.
author: Josephine L.

description:
Pretty good though overall the meat was on the dryer side. Spot is colorful, has lots of personality, and is a good casual place to grab a flavorful and casual meal. Bloomspot deal of $30 for $15 helped out as it wasn't too pricey to begin with. 

* Service
There was ONE server running the whole place and she remained stress free and always pleasant. Eg: we needed a table for three and there were only two tops available with maybe a 30 minute wait. One couple was at a table that we noticed could fold out for three and we offered to ask the couple if they could possibly move to one of the two tops but the server gladly asked them for us. 

* PERNIL ASADO - 3.5 stars
(roasted pork, marinated with garlic, oregano base sofrito. $12)
Good savory meat, great flavor and spicing. Based on other review the meat on this dish should be so tender and succulent that it just falls apart under your fork. While it wasn't quite close to that, I still enjoyed the meat (while it was cooking I kept smelling something amazing and asking what it was- it was this pork every time). Came with greens, plantains, choice of rice, choice of beans.

* CHICHARRON DE POLLO - 3.5 stars
(breaded and fried chicken thighs served with tostones and salsa rosa dipping sauce. $10.50)
Very similar review to the pork - flavorful, and the breading on this one was good, but the meat could be more tender. I'd say the flavor was more poignant and unique on the pork. Came with tostones, greens, choice of rice, choice of beans.

* ARROZ DE AMARILLO - 2 stars
(Spanish rice. $4)
Plain, not much flavor, only addition to rice grains was I believe peas. Texture was fine as far as spanish rice goes.

* Rice special - 3.5 stars
Not sure on name but this was much more interesting with lots of veggies and pork and good savory flavoe.

* HABICHUELAS COLORADAS - 1.5 stars
(homemade red beans in sofrito base sauce. $3.5)
Strange sauce with weird flavor, and the beans were overcooked and too starchy.

* HABICHUELAS BLANCAS - 3 stars
(homemade white beans in sofrito base with potato, carrot, and calabaza (vegan). $4)
Much better than the red beans, liked the flavor and texture.

* MADUROS - 3.5 stars
(ripen sweet plantains. $4.50)
Really nice, moist / soft / sweet.

* TOSTONES - 2 stars
(traditional fried and salted green plaintains, served with salsa rosa dipping sauce. $4)
Tasted dry, stale, and was overly salted. 

* FLAN (plain) - 4 stars
Great custard-like texture, good balance of being firm yet our spoons sunk right in.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
The bf is Puerto Rican so we get excited when we see a Puerto Rican restaurant with rave reviews. I guess no different than when I see Chinese restaurant reviews and the comments are more than just about their crab rangoons and general tso chicken.

The service was great. Very hospitable, friendly, and reasonably chatty. The atmosphere was solid.The food was unfortunately not.

We ordered the sample platter and the mofongo. The food was really greasy. The meat was fatty. The yuca was drenched in oil. But the most disappointing part was the lack of authenticity. The mofongo has this odd creamy sauce, which doesn't normally accompany mofongo. In fact, the sauce overpowered everything and ruined the dish for us. Arroz con gandules is a staple in PR and it wasn't on the menu. Their Spanish rice might be their equivalent but I didn't find many pigeon peas in there....and there was ham in it which was different. The only thing we liked was their maduros and tostones. But you really can't go wrong with fried bananas.

I would come back for bottomless mimosas but the bf is using his veto card. Sorry Parada 22. We wanted to love you. We love you staff, just not your food.
author: Ivy T.

description:
I was thinking.... 

 In Hot Tub Time Machine they traveled back to 1986 and wanted to act like they invented twitter and viagra. So he combined the words Twitter and Viagra to be Twitagra..

I like Yelp.  I like Mofongo. So if I traveled back in time, I'd act like I invented Yelp and Mofongo.  Yelp and Mofongo combined  can be Yelpongo.  How can you not like saying Yelpongo??

Which brings me to Parada 22.  

The Goal:  Eat Mofongo and any other Puerto Rican dishes I can get my hands on.  Here's what I ordered:

Sampler Platter:  it's nice to be able to try a little bit of everything.  Problem for me was that nothing really tasted that great.  The yucca, tostanes, maduros, and Chicharron was average at best.

Pastalone:  A little better than the Sampler. A cross between meatloaf and lasagna, but instead of pasta it's plantain.

Mofongo:  by far the best dish and one of the better Monfongos I've eaten.  Tasty and moist, mixed with the sofrito and shrimp.  At Parada 22, it's all about the Mofongo.

An A-ok spot for Puerto Rican Cuisine.  If you go, definitely order the Mofongo.  Or if I find my time machine, it may change in history to Yelpongo...
author: Michael L.

description:
My girlfriend and I wanted to take my sister's family out to dinner and it was a good opportunity to try something new.  I found a deal online for Parada 22, and learning that it was Puerto Rican food similar to that of Sol Food, I needed to give it a try.  It was located in the Haight and not only is it a little shady, but the parking is terrible.  When we finally did find parking, we head in for some grub.

We started off with a big pitcher of their sangria so we could warm up a bit from the cold outside.  I ordered the pollo a la criolla which was covered in a sofrito sauce.  It was very tasty but the portion size was tiny.  The rest of the table enjoyed the pernil asada (roasted pork) and mofongo.  I really enjoyed the mofongo and the pork was nice and tender.  Both had larger portions than my chicken for about the same price.  Overall we enjoyed the meal, but for a meal we expected to be pretty cheap the price tag for the whole thing was a surprise and the total bill (including $20 discount/tax/tip) was $70.  At least we managed to catch a nice buzz by the time we headed out.

Parada 22 is no Sol Food, but it's nice to have something sort of similar in the city.  It's a little more expensive per dish and I like the plantains at Sol better, but the sangria here packs a nice punch.  Service was really good too and even when we used the coupon we got a nice smile.  I'd be down to try it again on occasion.

Food: 8/10

Service: 7/10

Price: $$

Atmosphere: 8/10
author: Joe M.

description:
Parada 22 is a gem of puerto rican food nestled in the outskirts of the hustling haight ashbury area. 

Seating is limited and space is pretty small overall but the food is so good. 

I love their biftec encebollado and camarones a la criolla. The dishes will come with Spanish rice, red beans, salad and plantains. I literally am writing this review surrounded by tons of fresh fall off the bone BBQ but all I want to do is throw this bomb meat at the wall and scurry my ass over to Parada. Mouth watering.
author: Lauren Y.

description: I had no idea where to grab a quick lunch in the Haight, but you yelpers did not steer me wrong! I got a window seat and the friendly waitress gave me some recommendations and I had a fabulous melt-in-your-mouth roast pork lunch with deliciously sweet fried plantains, Spanish rice and pinto beans. Yum-ha! I had more than enough left over pork and rice for another meal! Great food, great price, and great service!
author: Thalia F.

description: Very genuine places with fantastic big amounts of tasty varied plates. Totally recommended after a golden gate visit!
author: Natalia D.

description: OH EM GEE... after deciding that I wasn't going to drive over the GG bridge for some Puerto Rican food, we landed here instead and there are absolutely NO regrets. NONE. Service was great but most importantly, food was bomb. I had the chiccharon de pollo (I am coming back here tomorrow) and my buddy had the mofongo. Each piece of chicken was perfectly seasoned to taste. I got to the point where I was too full to finish but I couldn't stop eating. Halleljuah for great food. We grubbed, and demolished the coconut flan. Seating is super tight but we did not care....we sat ourselves after less than 5 minutes. Enough ranting...want some really good PR'n food? This is your spot
author: T A.

description: I've must have walked by this place dozens of times, but never actually noticed its a restaurant. Really easy to miss. I'm so glad a friend I was with pointed it out. We stopped in her for an early dinner. We were greeted by a pretty young woman, she gave us excellent customer service and even chatted with us a bit. The food was yummy. I had the pollo encebollado, chicken with onions, my dish also came with beans some fried plantains and a spring mix salad. I will definitely be returning.
author: Mary V.

description:
The food here is delicious. Every dish looks clean and well played, not to mention the flavors are the best. I also like how they serve water on a jar with lemons it gives it a very good taste. The place is cozy and neat. 
I only had one issue...it was service. I've been here two times and in both occasions one of the waitresses/cashier was a bit rude. She seemed annoyed when I was asking questions about happy hour and prices, also when my order was ready she just walked up to me with the bag (I ordered to go) and didn't even look at me or said anything. Just a suggestion be nice. Till next time
author: Carlos T.

description:
I really really want to give this place 5 stars. But they don't make cafe con leche!!! :( Was shocked when the first time coming here, asking for it, and the lady didn't know what it was. Everything else is great. Reminds me of home (NYC).

Otherwise, the food is really good. Really really good. It's one of the few places where I'll eat rice because the food is so tasty. (Despite my Asian blood, this body doesn't like rice.)
author: Kiai K.

description:
Not being a local, I had been craving this cuisine for awhile. Came up to San Francisco for a day trip and used yelp to find Parada 22 after visiting the Legion of Honor nearby. Parada22 has limited seating, but we arrived and we're seated promptly. Portions were proportionate to prices. Parking can be a pain in the butt to find, but circle enough and eventually you'll get lucky. 

We had Pollo a la Criolla and Pernil Asado. We also shared a half pitcher of Sangria. We left feeling satisfied and impressed. This will be one of my go-to places in the Haight/Ashbury district.
author: Stephanie G.

description:
Tiny place, but delicious food!

Came here for my last meal in San Fran before being dropped off at the airport and decided to go with the fish salad which was filling and really good.

My friend all seemed to enjoy their meat dishes as well.

Would prolly be back if I'm craving PR food!
author: Dominique F.

description:
Good food, great prices.

I went with 4 other people so I was able to try a little of everything.

I liked the chicharron de pollo (fried chicken) and biftec encebollado (sauteed steak). 

The pernil asado (roast pork) was dry and lacked flavor. The pastalone (like beef lasagna but w/plantains instead of pasta) did not work for me. Maybe it's an acquired taste issue?

All their plates are around $11 and it comes with a side of rice, beans, tostones/maduros and salad. I don't eat beans but everyone else at the table raved about the red beans. The tostones and maduros were good. The spanish rice was ok. I preferred their white rice.

They serve Cha Cha Cha's sangria. I like my drinks sweet so for me I would have liked it a little sweeter.

The rum cake was ok. The flan was rich and dense.

Service was good.

It's a really small restaurant. I wouldn't suggest going in a group like we did.

Overall it was good, not great. Four stars.
author: Andy W.

description: Wow- best meal I had while in San Francisco. Do yourself a favor, order the Mofungo, you will not be disappointed. I loved my meal, loved the plantains and the side salad that comes with the dish. The atmosphere was lovely and the service was excellent!
author: Jillian R.

description: Ok, we were just meandering and came  across.  Conflicted on where to eat we yelped.  Let me juuuuust say..... the portions here are enormous and amazing. We had the Pastelon. It's a concoction of sweet plantains layered with picadillo which is spiced ground beef and pork with olives, raisins, peppers and onion.. it is like a giant Puerto Rican lasagna. It came with some rice some beans and a salad and some plantains. It was more than enough for two people. Additionally we got the half pitcher of the sangria. We ended up giving sangria away because it was way too much for us to drink and we're the people giving away booze. All the dishes around us looked fantastic. The place was packed, it's small and well worth it.  The service and music is great as well.
author: Dustin W.

description: We were a party of 4 in a restaurant seating 23. . So, obviously tiny! Even though their goal would be quick turnover, no one was rushed and wait staff spent time answering questions. Quick service, cordial and clean. 3 of the 4 ordered the roasted pork....AMAZING...4th ordered sampler plate due to indecision,  everything was good, unless  you compared the roasted  pork entree meat to the sampletr same pork...NOT...the sampler meat was dry and not at all the unctious option served in the entree....yucca made up for it tho...to die for
author: Dianna L.

description: Fantastic food, cute little place, and great music to eat with. I had the vegetarian plate and it was fantastic. The rice was seasoned well, the beans were amazing, plantains were so tasty, and the salsa they have at the table is to die for. Water was even classed up with some lemon and cucumber which was refreshing. Make sure you get here for dinner early as the place will fill up fast. Definitely will be coming back here.
author: Adrian L.

description:
This is a little restaurant that is almost hidden in plain sight. But man, what a treat!

Onion steak, spanish rice, plantains and salad with garlic/cilantro dressing for a total tab of twelve bucks.  Awesome!
author: David K.

description: My girlfriend is Puerto Rican, and so she wanted to eat here. Great little place in the Haight area, friendly staff and superb food. If you're looking for good Puerto Rican food, this is the joint!
author: Stoph M.

description: Love this place! Great portion size and great staff! Wait was fast! I think this place gets unrated because it's by cha cha cha, but I have to say this place is way better if you're looking for Hispanic food.
author: Perry A.

description: Puerto Rican in SF!  Yaahooo!!  After a long day in the city, had to come check this place out for dinner.  Was not disappointed!!  We ordered 1/2 pitcher of sangria, roasted pork, rice & beans and tostones.  Food was fresh and served hot.  Portion sizes were bigger than average.  If I'm ever back in SF, I'll be back!!  Very authentic taste.
author: Heidi P.

description: Love love love love it!!!!!!!!!! Food is yummy sangria is too! Very limited seating but who cares if you have to wait it's sooooo worth it!
author: Rebecca M.

description:
I went there for lunch today and I had a great experience. My friend had the Pernil Asado, which i had in the past and  it was delish.
This time i tried the Pastelon, which is sort of lasagna but instead of pasta they use sweet plantains......SO DELICIOUS!

i am definitely coming back.
author: Gabriel G.

description:
The food in this family-run Puerto Rican restaurant is authentically Puerto Rican and incontestably delicious! 

We've been several times and we've tried several dishes. We gladly recommend the Pastelón, Camarones a la Criolla, Biftec Encebollado, and Mofongo de Camarones. If you have the appetite for a side dish, have some Tostones, as well. The white beans and the Spanish rice are also great accompaniments. We've seen, but never tried, the Ensaladas and they are huge and look fresh and delicious with a large quantity of beef, chicken, or shrimp on the side. Easily a complete meal. 

The ambience is casual, the walls lined with photos and other memorabilia from Puerto Rico, Caribbean music playing in the background. 

Delicious food, affordable prices, and a fun place to eat. Definitely worth a visit!
author: David K.

description: The shrimp mofongo should be illegal.  It's incredible.
author: Emma H.

description: This was the first time I had ever had Puerto Rican food and it was awesome!!! Everything was so flavorful and delicious. I would love to try every single item on the menu. I thought the prices were good and liked the atmosphere. And bottomless mimosas for $12!
author: Melissa P.

description:
Such. Good. Food. And a great deal!

I got the mofongo de camarones, pretty late at night (~9:00 pm?), and it was amazing.  I could have used a little more shrimp, but what was on the plate was fantastic.  The red beans had a bacon-y flavor... Don't know if it's from actual bacon or not, but it was tasty! Especially when all mixed up with those delicious mashed plantains and spanish rice. Yum.  I skipped the salad, just because I was so full.

The ambience of the restaurant is absolutely adorable--it's teeny tiny but the decor is completely charming.  We shared the family table with some other people, which was no problem at all.

Oh-- we also got the $25 pitcher of sangria, and honestly even between five of us we had trouble finishing it!  It was strong and there was a whole lot of it.  It also jumped up the price of our dinners by quite a lot.  So next time, we'd probably get the 1/2 pitcher and save some bucks!

If I get the chance, there definitely will be a next time!
author: Allison M.

description:
Parada 22 has been excellent every time of come. Pork, Steak, and Eggplant sandwich have all been wonderful. Don't miss the fried plantains and the sangria is a big hit every time with my guests. 

Try, better than Cha Cha Cha next door.
author: Zac O.

description:
Parking on Haight may make anyone succumb to pulling their hair out.  Only thing keeping one from doing so is the steering wheel, or else they'd crash and hit some pedestrians in the process (duh).  I don't venture down Haight much.  My little sister, on the other hand, has more oft frequented the area than me.  Thinking she had some pointers to where to park, I asked if there were any secret spots.  "Just drive around the side streets off Haight".  Thanks little sis, high five for the big help.   

I forgot where I parked exactly.  It was a few blocks away from the restaurant, and yes, it was one of those side streets off Haight.  I guess she deserves a real high five rather than the sarcastic one.  Looking at Parada 22 compared to the Goliath of a restaurant next door, Cha Cha Cha, anyone could easily sweep it to the side as another boring little restaurant.      

Their take on Puerto Rican contemporary rural charm enchants the restaurant.  We sat near the kitchen and could hear the traffic inside.  Oh the smell of Puerto Rico in the air...never mind...it was the server coming with our food.

OUR ORDER:

*Pernil Asado - Holy Cow!  I mean Holy Pig!  Pork isn't my first desired meat, but they really hit it out of the park with this dish.  Blindly picking the first dish on the menu worked out.  Lightly jabbing my fork into the moist meat, a nugget of astonishment had presented itself.  Coming right off the bone the pork held a lot of flavor.  The described spices and ingredients from the menu were noticeably infused.  Too bad you can't ask for seconds.  Poor pig, happy me, the life cycle continues.    
  
*Biftec Encebollado - Biftec means steak?  "Holy cow" would have been more appropriate here, yet I liked mine more.  Bun orders steak almost everywhere; her thought process goes a little like this.  When in doubt pick the steak.  On top of the steak were caramelized onions.  Easy going dish emitted an easy reaction from Bun, "This is really yummy."  Absolutely correct is she, as Yoda would put it. 

Both plates came with rice, beans, AND a plantain dessert.  Not to be outdone by their entrée centerpiece, the rice and beans were absolutely delicious.  They got other items with a range of sandwiches.  As a novice to Puerto Rican comfort cooking, judging authenticity is obviously not my strong suit.  Nonetheless, the main thing is this.  If this is what authentic Puerto Rican food is like, I'm a fan.
author: Arnold T.

description:
Cool spot that offers authentic Latin food for a good value. Came here after having my eye on this place for some time. The place is hard to spot as it is very small next to cha cha cha, just keep a look out for its green storefront. Once inside the place is awesome, cool Cuban and Latin decorations inside which gives it an authentic vibe of being in a family kitchen.
I came here for lunch so I'm not sure if the dinner is a bit different but there were no appetizers on the menu which I was throw off by, that's usually an essential for me but I decided to put it off and got a glass of sangria instead. It is very similar to cha cha chas, fruit in glass and chilled, tasty overall but not one of the best I have had. 
I decided to get the pork plate with yellow rice and white beans. The plate also came with a side salad and plantains but we did not end up getting our plantains till we finished our meal which was an upset. The pork was very good, tender and seasoned well with good spices. The yellow rice and beans also complimented the pork and made it a very filling meal for the small portion that it was. Overall I had a good experience here and recommend it for a good authentic Latin meal.
author: Josue V.

description:
I love this place. It reminds me of home in the Caribbean: red beans, rice, plantains, delicious meat entree and flan coco for dessert! 

I would eat it every day, if I could, but it's not in my 'hood and parking can be hard in that area. But we make do!
author: Anna G.

description: Loved the classic cuban sandwich, garlic shrimp salad, and tostones! Cute interior though it's a little cramped. Quick service and great spot for a nice lunch.
author: Jamie B.

description: Had this a while back, I remember the mofongo and their hot sauces being delicious.
author: Matthew P.

description: Definitely the best puertorican food that I have tasted in California, the arroz con habichuelas rojas , pernil y tostones was the bomb!!!
author: Christian T.

description:
Amazing Latin American food with generous portions, affordable options, and friendly service! Love!

My friends and I popped into the small restaurant on Sunday at 11 AM to avoid the lunch crowd, and avoid the noon lunch crowd we did. We were seated at the long table in the back near the kitchen, with only one other couple at the table near the entrance. The waiter was prompt with handing us our menus and our pitcher of lovely spa water chock-full of lemon and lime slices. We didn't realize that lunch started at 11:30 AM (brunch starts at 9 AM), but the waiter said that the only dish that was still in the works was the Mofongo.

After some deliberation, we decided to go family style and order 4 plates among 5 girls. The waiter was incredibly patient as we jumped around with our choices, and he was kind enough to bring out 5 clean plates so that we could more easily share the food.

We ordered:

POLLO A LA CRIOLLA: marinated boneless chicken sauteed with a hearty smoked ham sofrito [$9]
- http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/parada-22-san-francisco?select=erlTWYMCrpOJpBIT5yqT0Q#1uteoAZUnZ6eGncsW4eYKQ
- Unlike the pork and the steak, this dish emphasized the paired flavors of the salty sofrito and the tangy chicken. The chicken was tender and juicy, while the sofrito was well-stewed but a bit salty. This was a favorite!

PERNIL ASADO: roasted marinated pork leg with garlic, oregano & baswe sofrito [$10]
- http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/parada-22-san-francisco?select=erlTWYMCrpOJpBIT5yqT0Q#oXsiZGIX-tGuQZnsLuzBkA
- This entree, along with the sirloin steak, was a dish that highlighted the meat over the seasoning. They gave us a huge portion of pork, although it was a bit dry and bland, especially in comparison to the other meat entrees.

BIFTEC ENCEBOLLADO: marinated sirloin steak sauteed with caramelized onions [$11]
- http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/parada-22-san-francisco?select=erlTWYMCrpOJpBIT5yqT0Q#nPJnNbB3xSknOPsueyOZHw
- The steak really was the highlight with its smoky undertone and hearty chew. This was another favorite!

SAMPLER: pernil asado, chicharron de pollo, maduros, yuca al mojo & tostones [$11]
- http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/parada-22-san-francisco?select=erlTWYMCrpOJpBIT5yqT0Q#mJZMnOJBmO5jIFUlOjdWMw
- The chicharron de pollo was two pieces of fried marinated boneless chicken. At first we didn't think that they would be anything special, but all of us enjoyed it a lot! Yes, it is fried chicken, but the chicken is rich and juicy and its breaded coating is crunchy and not-too-salty. With the salsa rosa, it was perfect!
- Maduros. I love them. Whenever I go to a Latin American restaurant, I have to have them. These beautiful fried ripened sweet plantains were absolutely scrumptious, like taking bites into soft carmelized banana chunks.
- The yuca al mojo was cassava root with onions, garlic, and olive oil. I mistook them for plaintain chips, but they had a bolder taste that was much enjoyed.
- The tostones were traditional pressed fried green plantains. It looked as if they were stewed with onions. They're very different from the maduros, as most of the flavor comes from the plaintains themselves. I didn't enjoy the taste as much, although I liked the texture. I think I was supposed to dip it into the salsa rosa though...

All entrees aside from the sampler came with a side of salad (with delicious dressing), side of maduros (love love love!), and choices of either white rice or Spanish rice and white beans or red beans. We chose the Spanish rice and red beans for all 3 dishes (thank you Yelpers!), and we couldn't have been happier with our choices! The red beans were cooked with ham and vegetables, giving it variety and flavor.

At $11.30 per person, tip and tax included, Parada 22 is delicious AND affordable. I would come back for the maduros, the Pollo a la Criolla for pairing of chicken and sofrito, and the Biftec Encebollado for the steak itself. Can't wait!
author: Adele F.

description: Great restaurant!! I ordered the Pastelon and it was freakin delicious. The red beans melted in your mouth, yellow rice was seasoned perfectly and my main dish was perfect. Our waiter Stefan the Cutie was very helpful and kind. The place is small and has a cozy cultural atmosphere. You have to use the bathroom next door at cha cha cha's...its that small. I will return for sure.
author: Brittney D.

description: To say I love this place would be an understatement. The food is incredible (highlights: fried chicken, pollo encebollado, maduros, and of course, the sangria). Super nice staff, seriously the best. This is my neighborhood *spot*. The mains come with rice, beans, salad, and protein (so balanced!). I love the ambiance of this place and also often take it to go (tip: leftovers the next morn w/ a fried egg is -- yes). Enjoy!! You won't be sorry.
author: snowhappy P.

description:
The Chicharrones de Pollo is el uno. 

Also, don't leave without having their dessert: coconut flan! Was skeptical about it at first but the coconut was perfectly hinted & didn't overpower the original flanness of the flan.
author: Thy N.

description: OMG I'm so glad that I found a good Puerto Rican restaurant in the city. The atmosphere and building reminds me of Puerto Rico and the food brings me back to my Abuelita's cooking. The tostones were some of the best I've ever had.
author: Erin S.

description: Pernil asado, pollo encebollado y tostones were my favorite dishes. Very good customer service. This place is kids friendly, but don't accept reservation. Waiting was fast. Only 20mins.
author: Mila N.

description: Oh my goodness. Where do I even begin? I came here with a few friends who were raving about this place. I walked in and was surprised by the cozy interior. There's about 6 tables and a small bar area against the wall to sit at. We had to wait about 10 minutes for a table since it was full but we were quickly seated after that. Our server was friendly and quickly took our order. I ordered the chicharrones de pollo and oh my goodness it was delicious. My plate came with rice, beans, a small salad, and fried plantains. I devoured absolutely everything on my plate along with the Mexican coke I ordered. I think I found my new favorite place to visit when I am in the city.
author: Karina M.

description: Parada 22 is probably the closest to home taste of Puerto Rico in the bay area offering flavor packed dishes you would expect from Puerto Rican cuisine. Ordered a Cubano and my friend went for the biftec encebollado. We both shared an order of tostones with "salsa roja" which in reality is just mayo ketchup-a renown seasoned mayonnaise and ketchup condiment served with fried snacks in Puerto Rico such as alcapurrias and pastelios. I was quite surprised they had mayo ketchup as I requested it before at another Puerto Rican restaurant only to be given a blank expression. The pique was also very good. Everything was jam packed with flavor and prepared with heart. Great clean and organized restaurant with a friendly atmosphere. Was hoping to find a tripleta on the menu but nonetheless everything was good and I had a great experience.
author: Cedric J.

description:
I had a most enjoyable lunch at this joint yesterday!  I came here on my own at around 1pm and it was still quite busy.  Luckily, I was able to secure a table anyway.  When I saw that Pernil Asado was on the menu, I knew right away what I was in for.  And the roasted pork was everything I hoped for, and then some!!  The meat was sooo tender, packed with flavor and plentiful.  It came with either white or Spanish rice.  I chose Spanish rice, mixed with green olives and ham. I was also given a choice of either red or white beans.  I chose red after the waiter said that it'll be the more flavorful side dish.  Halfway through, I was already full.  The rest served as my dinner tonight. 

Yup, Parada 22, you and I will have a most satisfying friendship together...
author: Yvette F.

description: I have never ordered anything but the CUBANO because I cannot believe there could be anything more delicious on this menu. I'm an aficionado.  If you know of a restaurant that serves a Cuban Sandwich as good or better than this, I'd be shocked. Every ingredient is generously represented.  A big portion of roast pork, thick planks of pickle... It is a fat, juicy, mustard-y, pickle-y sour, crunchy crusty, pork-y tender, cheese-y gooey, slice of heaven. The salad side has has just the right amount of vinaigrette and even though I wish I could have tostones sub in instead, the salad is gobbled up. The big bottle of hot "sauce" spikes up the sammy as much as you do or don't like. Wish I could offer you a picture, but as soon as I touched it, the juice was running down my hands (a four napkin event) and there was no way to stop and grab the camera. BTW,  I saw a sandwich board inside that says they're the Boogaloo pop-up breakfast joint. So if you miss that restaurant, check it out here.
author: Nini M.

description: Came here because cha cha cha's next door was closed and what a pleasant surprise the food was so good and authentic tasting it was like I was at someone's house. Glad it was my first try with Puerto Rican food actually can't wait to come back
author: Theresia B.

description:
We stopped here for a light lunch, so we ordered the sampler for two people. It includes: carne frita (fried pork chunks), chicharrones de pollo (fried breaded chicken pieces), maduros (fried ripe plantains), yuca al mojo & tostones. Everything was delicious. Both meats were so tender...and the tostones, the best I've tried in a long time, other than the ones we make at home; so we asked for an extra order of tostones.

My husband ordered a red wine sangria. It's not the kind of sangria I'm used to, which is sweet & fruity, this was more like wine, but still good.

Beware, finding parking in the area could be rough (we parked in a nearby parking metered spot). They have lots of Puerto Rican decorations and mementos, and the place is tiny, I think it can sit about 25 people.

I found the customer service to be a little slow even when the place wasn't packed. The server didn't do any rounds to our table to see if everything was Ok, so we had to keep an eye on him and call him when we needed something.  Definitely an area to improve.
author: Jossie L.

description:
Sooo happy there's a Puerto Rican restaurant here! I love Sol Food as much as the next girl but that's literally the only reason I have to go to Marin. Parada 22 is perfectly situated. You have your height shops, you have whole foods...and now you can stop for a delicious Puerto Rican meal. I'm a fan. 

I had the bistec encebollado with rice and beans. Their rice is delicious. I also loved their hot sauce. I also tried the flan which was unreal. 

The restaurant is adorable. They did an excellent job with the design and decoration. Truly felt like a little piece of San Juan.
author: Karina A.

description:
The restaurant is pretty small, but the food is good and large in portion.

The dinner meals come with rice, beans, maduros, and salad. The sampler is also a huge meal by itself.

Staff here are also friendly.
author: Katrina L.

description: Great food. The place is small so not good for big groups but great staff,music, and vibe will be back
author: Danny T.

description:
Love.It!  I know that I have a wonderful life when I can get some great Puerto Rican food.  It was a covert mission on a Sunday evening... hubby was out watching the game, son was at his friend's house and I took off to the city to get some food.  

Yes, I will drive a country mile to get something tasty - - Mofongo de Camarones, a side of maduros, and Sangria.  My Sunday evening transformed into a Blissful evening!!! 

Parking sucks!  BUT, SO WHAT!  I will park 2 miles away and walk there.  I ain't scurred LOL.
author: Shonda D.

description: Good place for Puerto Rican food. Cute interior. A little small, so it gets crowded. The mofongo and pernil are terrific. And I can't forget the plantains! So, so good. One of the better restaurants in the Haight.
author: Ryan Y.

description: San Francisco... the golden gate, the old tramways, the up-and-down hills... and the hippie neighborhood ! In the middle of the eclectic and the "let's make a revolution but next week" area, you will find a cosy cantina full of colors and flavors.  Painted walls, great decoration with a ton of vintage items, cans, bottles, provisions, old pictures and everything in between, but with one common thing : Puerto Rico and the hispanic culture.  A cool menu full of sunshine, but my heart really goes to the Pastelon, a dish with sweet plantains layered with ground beef with olives, raisins, and peppers... OMG ! Yeah, it might sounds like a puerto rican version of the moussaka, but one thing is sure, it really feels like a great comfort food coming from the island, the kind of you expect to have on sunday in a local family, and that's great. Pretty unique too, so far the only place in the world where I've seen it on the menu. So Haight-Ashburry is worth a visit anytime you're in SF almost only for the Pastelon from Parada 22.  On top of it, friendly service and good music too.  So have a parada at 1805 Haight Street whenever you're around, you'll still have the chance to buy a vintage hat or hippie pants afterwards, the belly full of flavors and a smile on your satisfied face...
author: Xavier P.

description: Cute ambiance and decent price, but ok food. Areas for improvement: 1) dish was supposed to come with plantains - it only came with two veryyy small pieces. 2) it gets too drafty when the door opens and closes. 3) and they only had cold drinks...I wanted to order hot tea because it was a chilly night and they couldn't even do hot water...I've never been to a restaurant where they don't have hot water...
author: Jan Z.

description:
I was looking for somewhere to eat with my friend after walking around haight and saw this place pop up on yelp. It had been compared to Sol in San Rafael so I thought this would be worth a try. 

The aesthetics are very similar to Sol except cozier. Went on late Saturday afternoon and it wasn't completely full. Way better than having to sit at a table with strangers or facing the wall like Sol. 
 
We ended up getting the chicharrones del pollo and the steak. Both were yummy but I must say the friend chicken was a little better. The rice, beans, salad, and plantains were all good. I finished my plate clean! 

Everything about this place was perfect for a chill lunch. Good service, good food, and good music.
author: Adriana R.

description:
Spent a Sunday in the neighborhood. Usually I go to ChaChaCha, however
they were not serving at the hour I was starving.
I was in the mood for the classic Cubana sandwich. Yummy, on target
with the food in Miami in Little Havana. Mexican Coke yea. Comes with green 
Salad. The plantains were excellent. Everything I saw coming out of the
Kitchen looked fantastic. I must return to try the pernil asado and Mofongo.

Small place, a bit crowded, yet no one seemed to mind. Latin music
jamming in the place. Afterwards a trip to Amoeba was in order and I
picked up some great stuff. Definitely will be back to try some other
Goodies. You won't be disappointed.
Cash or credit cards accepted. Service was very good
author: Michelle L.

description:
My boyfriend and I were looking for a Puerto Rican place similar to sol food in the north bay. This place had similar menu items and others that made them distinct, along with decent prices $10-12 a plate. 

I had the pollo encelbollado and my boyfriend had the pollo a la criolla. Both were super good with lots of flavor, especially the pollo a la criolla. 

The place was not too crowded for a Sunday around 1:30 despite their limited seating. Will definitely return!
author: Samantha C.

description: This place is tiny...but thanks to Foodspotting for introducing me to this place; otherwise, I may not have ever discovered it.  The food was really good so my family and I will definitely be back for more...
author: Rose A.

description: We loved this place. Rarely do we find Puerto Rican food!!! It was amazing. We both got the pernil asada (pork), Spanish yellow rice, and red beans. We also got the tostonas & yucca :) both simply amazing. Great flavor. Great service. Cute little place. If was a perfect find after a long day exploring the city.
author: Dawn T.

description: If you want real puertorrican food you have to visit Parada 22! The food is absolutely delicious and the service is excelent! Love it!
author: Roselly T.

description:
This food so good I'll shoot someone if they ate my plate
This food so good I wanna shoot myself in the head because my brain can't fathom
This food so good I wanna have sex on the table with my date 
I would eat this food off the ground outside in the TL
This food so good I almost bought the restaurant
This food so good I'll cry at my next meal
This food so good it makes cha cha cha look like Mcdonals
This food so good 
This food so good I almost gave them my paycheck
This food so good they should close it down
This food so good id eat the compost
author: Aharon H.

description: Amazing food!! Can't leave SF without stopping here ! There often is a wait  for a table,  but you will not be disappointed ... totally  worth it!
author: Deanna N.

description: Great place for a little taste of back home. The decor is awesome, service is good, and the food is excellent. Haven't had a bad meal there yet. Favorite is the pastelon. Pernil and chicharron de pollo are also up there.
author: Nestor G.

description: The best Puerto Rican food of ever. I wish we had one in Seattle! Muah, P-22, you guys are the awesome.
author: Kristine A.

description:
Great food, the meat is well done but i wanted it medium rare. The food leaves you full but not stuffed.  The prices are right and the location is good.
  
I thought the plaintains were a little raw.

Overall pretty good!!
author: Toby I.

description:
After hearing the ridiculous hour plus wait at the popular Cuban place next door, step right over to Parada 22, take a seat, and order a beer or sangria for the shorter ten minute wait.  There's a certain charm to this homestyle Puerto Rican restaurant - classic jars and cans, old photos on the walls, the open kitchen, and quaint community tables.  It's small, so some big groups got split up.  Either that, or the other tables were holding out on us when strangers were passing pitchers of sangria between tables.

Of course, we started with a $12 half pitcher of sangria of our own.  Light on the ice, and heavy on the sangria, although there wasn't much fruit except for lemons.

We split the Sampler of pernil asado, chicharron de pollo, maduros, yuca al mojo, and tostones.  The stars were obviously the plantains - one pan-fried and the other deep-fried.  The chicken and pork were the same as the entrees, and sadly, I didn't get to try the chicken.  The cassava root was soft, gooey, and delicious.  For $11, the Sampler would have made for a great main course by itself.

The $12.50 Pernil Asado was a super tender chunk of roasted pork leg with garlic, oregano, and base sofrito.  The pork was tender and delicious, although it started tasting too salty about halfway through, so be forewarned.  (I would suggest getting the Sampler to try the pork and ordering a different entree.)  All entrees were accompanied with a small salad, maduros, red or black beans, and Spanish rice.  The pan-fried plantains and Spanish rice were particularly delicious, and well worth the visit alone... along with the sangria, of course.
author: Kevin W.

description:
If you're not in a mood for tapas next door, this place is a great alternative for reasonable priced entrees.  Haven't disappointed yet...

I've tried:

Pernil Asado - very good
Pollo Encebollado - one of my favs
Cubano sandwich - yummy
Sangria - good

also, get their Spanish rice with their combo plates.

beautiful day? take-out, pick up some drinks, picnic blanket and head inside the park.
author: Leland H.

description: Ordered the Cubano to go and it was Amazing! The salad it came with was well dressed also. The Service was quick and polite. I would definitely try this place again!
author: Jake V.
