description: This place was really really delicious. I've only had Puerto Rican food once before and to be honest I'm a pretty picky eater. I had the pork with garlic and rice and it was amazing. The place is so small but has a really friendly vibe. My friend and I shared a half-pitcher of amazing sangria (some places in San Francisco would have called this a full pitcher and charged us double for it - so great deal there!) and we also shared a plate of the fried plantains. Man oh man, those were yummy. Service was great, food was great, drinks were great, 5 stars all around for me.
author: Jenna K.

description: They had me at plaintains, main dishes were good and portions were large. Seating was limited but spaced out enough. Overall good experience for boriqua comida :D
author: Krit X.

description: Service was very good but the food is very bland and the atmosphere was very plain and dry. No Latin music, might has well been an uptight tech meeting inside. Not live and not be ounce of Puerto Rican culture. As far as the food.. The roasted park was so bland and dry with no spice or flavor.. Obvious for the crowd... Go next door to cha cha where the atmosphere and food is night and day even though the same owner, but the food is Cuban and much more authentic.
author: Zac B.

description: This is the WORST customer service ive ever experienced since my ten years of living in the United States. On August 27, 2017 my friend and I decided to visit Parada 22 for a early dinner(my third visit). With much enthusiasm we went and asked to be seated at a table and was told by the waitress our wait time would be approximately 10-15 minutes. That's no problem and quite frankly an easy wait for Parada22. My friend and i watched as tables became empty, one in particular sits 4(the table by the window) we thought she would offer that table to us since it was the first table that became empty. A couple and son walks in and she gives them that table, fine no biggy! So we finally get a table and upon her arrival we decided to put our orders in immediately (Sampler plate and 2 chicharrones) since we were starving by them. I just want to mention that this was probably one of the least busy ive seen Parada 22, our appetizer took a long time, and when it finally arrived we were super excited and ready to sample, assuming our meal would come out a bit after. So we are eating our appetizer and my friend ask for additional side of sweet plantains. I notice a while after the plantains arrive but our main dish is still not here. We realize its been close to an hour that we've been here so i call over our waitress and ask her when will our food arrive. Her response, "i just put in, i thought you guys were waiting until you ate your appetizer" We were so confuse and puzzled we didnt say much! I didnt know you wait until someone finish eating their appetizer to put in an order for the main dish. Our food finally arrives and evem though we are super upset we decide to dig in. Complaining underneath our breath we notice a african American male walk im and gets seated not paying much attention to him. A few minutes later a couple walks in and gets seated in the same table, l didn't here what the couple asked, but her response, ' i dont know where he went." The young man walks in looking puzzled since he had already put in his order. Im not sure what was said but i saw him walk over to another table. Holding his head down, he kept looking back at his table and out the window. I felt so uncomfortable, sad and hurt. I was so upset, she has totally ruined our day, we are about to call management and report our experience.  I will never return, i can't believe in 2017 racism is still alive and well!!! She didnt give us her name but shes a Blondie, medium-built with tattoos. We also called to ask for the manager and she hung up the phone on me!!!!!!!!!
author: Kimberlee W.

description:
Date & Time:  Saturday April 17, 2010 @ 2:30pm
Location:  Next to Cha Cha Cha
Dining Companion:  The Husband
Scene:  Cool Mix of Hot 20-Somethings Girls in Boho Tops & Guys in Baseball Caps & Shades Alongside Aging Hippies
Vibe:  Lively
Decor:  Whimsical & Fun.  White Shelves Filled w/ Imported Carribean Products. Lime Green, Teal & Exposed Brick Walls.  Picnic Style Communal Tables
Service:  Ridiculously Good-Looking & Charming Young Guys
Imbibe:  Refresco de Mango & Lemonade
Devour:  Pernl Asado(Pork Leg), Camarones a la Criolla(Shrimp), Maduros(Plantains), Bizcocho de Ron(Rum Cake)
Total:  $38.71
author: Genevieve Y.

description: I have to say this is the best puerto rican restaurant in the Bay Area. I prefer Parada 22 over Sol Food.  The place is small and Fridays and Saturday nights there can be a wait. The pastelon and chicharrones de pollo are my favorite dishes here. Portions are good and service is friendly.
author: Mildred R.

description: Wow, wow, wow, what a great meal! A group of us were hungry and looking for a place to eat dinner on Haight, and someone suggested we try out Parada 22. The restaurant is quaint and cozy, with interesting and fun decor. The food is FANTASTIC. Having lived in Miami for a year, I was excited to see such a great selection of Cuban food on their menu. I ordered the pastelon and ate every bite off my plate. My friends ordered the mofongo, the chicharrones, and the Cuban sandwich and everyone was more than happy with their order. And they have 21st Amendment beer which went really well with our dinner. Service is fast and efficient, and our server was attentive even though the place was full. I will definitely go back!!
author: Regina L.

description:
Absolutely delicious!  I had the chicken and caramelised onions dish $11.50. It also came with rice (choice of white or yellow), beans (choice again between kidney and ..... sorry forgot), deep fried banana and salad. I was full. 

Service was friendly.  Once I ordered meal I had it in about 5min.

I will be going back again.
author: Kristine B.

description:
Out on another food adventure with @JaRue2011 using our G*PON deal that turned out to have some TASTY Puerto Rican eats with our 1st time visit to Parada 22 in SF.

Saturday 4/28/12
8pm-ish
Unmetered Street Parking
Approx 10-min Wait for 2ppl

G*PON: Purchased $10 Deal for value up to $20 eats.

LOCATION: On intersection of Haight St & Shrader St. Yes, next door to Cha Cha Cha. Street parking, lots of foot traffic with the many other restaurants & shops on this strip. We lucked out finding parking just half a block up soon as we got there; didn't drive around long at all, but might be different story for other nights.

CUST SVC: Friendly & thorough service from the moment you walk in to the moment you get ready to leave with the 2ppl covering the floor! Food prepared & brought out in a reasonable time frame for all sitting patrons. Keep up the great service! 

RESTAURANT: In agreeance with other Yelpers, yes the place is small, but stays full. Walk through entrance doors, heavy rubber drapes (that keep the breeze to a min w/ ppl walking in & out) & immediately come to a dinning tables that likely have sitting patrons. Waiter/Waitress will signal you from where ever they're standing to let you know they see you, come over (or signal) to inquire how many #ppl in our party & take your name. Have to walk through their kitchen to use bthrm. Seems friendly for babies/kids, parties 2-4ppl, ppl various shapes/sizes; could be handicap/wheelchair friendly, but may be a hassle during heavy eating times. True bottom line, don't let the small space keep you away from trying them out!  

** Top of Menu http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TlBFKt2N2eSEBpN-UZmDBw?select=LbplwcgFBjrbRHoL5EV3Ww#xmq300hW8aqLcJymKPGeaA
** Plates Menu http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TlBFKt2N2eSEBpN-UZmDBw?select=LbplwcgFBjrbRHoL5EV3Ww#ghjU3RYtJ6UYUC13cXEVSw
** Sides Menu http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TlBFKt2N2eSEBpN-UZmDBw?select=LbplwcgFBjrbRHoL5EV3Ww#crF1I4bWkXH577yIjtlVZw

EATS: Such a delicious experience! BF-J & I both opted for the side of Arroz Amarillo, which was a tasty choice! Red beans cooked perfectly w/ sweet peppers, green olives, & smoked ham; really well seasoned side dish. The Maduros (sauteed plantains) were cooked & lightly seasoned; a suttle sweet compliment to each savory bite. BOTH entree dishes we sampled get our recommendation. 

$2 Lemonade & $2 Sweet Tea http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TlBFKt2N2eSEBpN-UZmDBw?select=LbplwcgFBjrbRHoL5EV3Ww#tKSvUSdJCTZJqk-3yn2NIA
** Nothing uniquely great, but good. 

$13 Camarones/Shrimp A La Criolla http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TlBFKt2N2eSEBpN-UZmDBw?select=LbplwcgFBjrbRHoL5EV3Ww#xZUZn-8NFJyxlKSoKCK1xg
** O-M-G GOOD! I absolutely loved the creme sauce on the shrimp. Next visit, I'll definitely try the upgrade version...Monfongo de Camarones.

$12 Pollo/Chicken Encebollado http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TlBFKt2N2eSEBpN-UZmDBw?select=LbplwcgFBjrbRHoL5EV3Ww#F2IQHuF6yYPDtb8dr_wy-A
** BF enjoyed this nicely seasoned chicken w/ caramelized onions. He left his plate so clean like nothing was ever brought out to him. 

FINAL TAB: Total bill for 2ppl came to $31.45, but using $10 G*PON Deal for $20 value we just came out extra $11.45 http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TlBFKt2N2eSEBpN-UZmDBw?select=LbplwcgFBjrbRHoL5EV3Ww#RNpXxL-dPQTTuTs_skQdgw This was another tasty new adventure for BF-J & I http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TlBFKt2N2eSEBpN-UZmDBw?select=LbplwcgFBjrbRHoL5EV3Ww#ibKdExJSr0FCcR3w25-uLQ We're looking fwd to coming back here & won't mind waiting to be seated for their delicious Puerto Rican dishes!
author: Mary J.

description: The food was great and reasonably priced! The tostones come with a delicious mayo sauce. It's a really cool spot!
author: Ana D.

description:
The food here: awesome, Puerto Rican goodness.. but our service was lacking and in a small spot like this it is kind of hard to forget your customers. 

Five of us walked in after B2B, and were seated at their largest table in the middle of the restaurant. Very accommodating. Beautiful photography and artwork decorated the walls and the homemade hot sauce on the table prepared me for the goods to come.. We all ordered quickly and were served up some delicious sangria while we waited..

I ordered the chicharrones de pollo with white beans and Spanish rice. The chicken was crispy and flavorful, a tad dry but the beans and hot sauce made up for it. Flattened and fried platanos served on the side with a dipping sauce.. deliciousness! 

I just about finished my plate when I noticed that one of our buddies at the table had not even been served yet! Damn, I must have been hungry and forgot about my manners.. we were all eating and he was sadly sitting watching us.. when we were all about done with our food, the server brought his dish out, not even a "sorry dude" or "kitchen messed up", nothing. We asked for it to go and bounced. 

Too bad, because the food here is so good! I wanted to give this spot 5 stars all the way, but truthfully it is not cool to serve the whole table and leave out one hungry person.. to stare and drool.
author: Sara F.

description: Very under staffed but great flavored food! Bathrrom is filled with customer drawings and food is pretty great.
author: Ashana D.

description:
Excellent (and I assume authentic) Puerto Rican food in the Haight. The service was friendly and laid-back and the space is really charming.  The  plates are reasonable sized, but not huge but prices aren't either, so I walked away with my belly and wallet pleasantly full.

Don't love walking through the kitchen to get to the bathroom, but what can you do?

Well worth a stop, hell, well worth a MUNI trip!
author: Chris C.

description:
This place was exactly what I was looking for in a casual dinner restaurant. Seating wasn't the best, but the ambiance and service was perfect for a Sunday dinner with someone special.

This was my first time eating at this restaurant and overall a great experience. The steak and plantains where perfect, the only suggestion/ criticism I have is for the pork, which was really tender, but a little too salty for my palate.
author: Eric M.

description: Great if you had a big lunch and want something small. Perfect for sharing, too! All around a great Tapas place.
author: Katie P.

description: Even though I'm pescatarian I still loved this place! The shrimp was incredible and the plantains were delicious!
author: Jackie N.

description: I LOVE! I cannot express how much I love this place! being Puerto Rican this food makes me feel at home! BORICUA HASTA LOS HUESOS
author: Anna L.

description:
I used to go to Sofrito on Fruitvale from opening day until they closed. I was afraid I would never find good Puerto Rican food in the bay but thank God Almighty that I discovered Parada 22

It's totally worth the drive from Oakland for some bomb arroz con habichuelas and some delectable maduros. They have great breakfast brunch lunch everything. It's a quaint little restaurant with cool pictures hung up everywhere. 

Nothing will ever replace my beloved Sofrito, but this place is amazing and I am very glad to have found it. Food and service are amazing.
author: Clarice W.

description:
What a delicious spot! The boyfriend randomly declared that he wanted to try out Parada for a weekend lunch, and a quick glace at the menu was all I needed to get on board. Parada is a tiny spot-- I can only imagine how crazy it must be during peak hours. I think we came right at the end of brunch peak (1pm on Saturday) so we only had to wait 5-10 minutes for a table (although there was room for us to sit along the bar when we arrived.)

The service was very attentive from the get-go, which is always a plus. The two of us ordered a 1/2 pitcher of Sangria, which was a LOT for us. Seriously, it was a great portion for the the 1/2 pitcher. They didn't fill it with ice or too much fruit, so we actually received a good amount of sangria to enjoy. 

In terms of food-- you have to get the plantains. Despite the fact that most dishes come with a few fried plantains, we ordered another side, because who doesn't love them? They were crispy and warm and sweet-- just like my grandmother used to make. 

We were there during brunch, so I got their version of huevos rancheros, which came smothered in salsa, over perfectly runny poached eggs. I also got white beans (which is the veggie option) and rice, which made for an overly satisfying meal (but we still finished off the side order of plantains..) My boyfriend had the popular mofongo, which was a heaping plate full of yummy things that I don't eat-- but he enjoyed.

I definitely will be back for more-- it might be one of my new (to me) favorites!
author: Bryan B.

description:
I was really blown away by Parada 22. I came with a friend to use a Groupon I'd purchased on a whim, expecting decent food at a decent price (it's on Haight, so I figured it could be a tourist trap, but still worth a shot). But no, it was delicious. It was by far the happiest Spanish-infused meal I could've hoped for. The place itself is really nice and unassuming too, quiet and on the smaller side.

The only nasty surprise is this: there's tiny bits of pig (ham, bacon, what have you) in freaking everything. But if you're mostly meat-less (and in this case, pig-less) and hungry like me, you'll eat around it, no problem. It's worth it.

The beans are good, the plantains are good (sweet or savory, however you get them on the side), and the fried chicken is fantastic. Even better, there's lots of everything. Our waitress was really nice too, checking up on us with water and extra silverware.

Also, I hear they now have brunch on weekends. And let's be honest - you'll probably see me there.
author: Jiordan C.

description:
Best thing on Upper Haight besides Amoeba's is this charming Puerto Rican restaurant. The flavors of the dishes, along with the cultural details of the interior (and peep the exterior!) give you a sensory experience. I devoured the chicharrones de pollo con tostones, a savory dish. And for desert, I had the coconut leche flan which was the perfect caramelized treat to top off a great dinner. Service was fast, food was cooked perfectly, and the staff was welcoming. 

I totally recommend skipping Cha Cha Cha's for this spot. It is definitely worth trekking through the Haight to satisfy your umami buds. I left feeling like yelling, "Puerto Rico!! Uh Ohhhhh!"
author: Cel C.

description: Absolutely delicious. Was drawn to it by the Boogaloos Brunch pop up, but ended up ordering off the Parada 22 menu. I ordered the Slow Roasted Pernil and it was soooo tender and juicy. The Spanish rice was very flavorful, maduros cooked perfectly. Also my friend's breakfast burrito looked on point. I'll be back...soon.
author: Max K.

description: Lives up to the rating! Great service and simple menu that does not disappoint. Add to that the reasonable prices and this place hits the mark.
author: Garrett E.

description:
One of my friends have tried this place on multiple occasions and cannot stop raving about the shrimp entree and she is right ! Within our party of 5 people, we tried the main entire with marinaded pork, beef, shrimp and marinaded chicken with the ham !?? 
Tips ;

Order Spanish rice!!!!!!! (5/5) it goes perfectly with any protein. Also, the white rice alternative seems very mundane and come on you can have it at home!! Try something new!!

Order enterees! All very good!!!!! They come with rice and salad, portions are quite generous !!!

Appetizers : 

-get the plantains. The sauce makes it so delicious!!!!

-forget the potato one.  ( small size and lacks a little flavor )

Order the shrimp, beef or pork. 
-Shrimp is creamy and perfectly cooked
-Beef is tender and seasoned ( a bit smaller portion )
-Pork was light, very appropriate for someone looking for a dish not too heavy on seasoning

Drinks: 

Sangria half pitcher is good for 3 people, don't get greedy and order the big one, it's a lot bigger than it looks.  

Ps the restaurant is  small so you will regret it if you look intoxicated..trust me everyone will  see.

Cons: marinaded chicken -very super  salty and I would recommend against it 2/5)

Great staff and food. Will definitely recommend to anyone who wants something new.
author: Sue T.

description:
AMAZING. Big portions, affordable prices. Casual feel. Delicious, authentic experience. I couldn't speak more highly of this place.

Plus, I got pretty crunk off their sangria. Top contender, with cha cha cha (neighbor) for most alcoholic sangria pitcher in the city.

I LOVE YOU PARADA 22
author: Katie P.

description: I hate to revise my review for Parada 22 and lower it, but I am surprised and disappointed that they won't make vegetarian mofongo at all.  I asked the waiter if they can make it, and he said no.  He told me it has to be made with pork, and what I think he means is that mofongo always has to have pork, or else it will not be mofongo.  But he is wrong.  You can absolutely make mofongo without pork. You just use oil and garlic.  So many restaurants in Puerto Rico make it without pork to begin with, and that is also how my family makes it.  I wish they would make it that way at Parada 22.  Otherwise, the place is great.
author: Mister M.

description:
Really good Porto Rican food! Plates are big and it's very tasty. 
The place is small and cute, with warm atmosphere, liked it :)
author: Laurie M.

description:
This place is amazing. We tried a sampler and got a bunch of their most
popular plates and shared everything, so I got to try a lot of different things... it's all so so good. The pork was ridiculously tender, the plantains (savory and sweet alike) we're so addicting. Every thing I tried was mouthwatering, down to the sangria and coconut flan. This place is a must of you're lookin for good food in the Haight. However, it's a popular place and the seating is really limited. It's not a good place to go with a group (we made that mistake), but they also have takeout I believe, so you can snag that for a lot of people.
author: Tatiana F.

description: The white beans and Spanish rice are to die for! Love the chicken as well, fried and baked/marinated. Love the art and decor as well.
author: Ashley N.

description: Oh my gosh! The food here was so delicious!!! Came for the first time earlier today for lunch to meet friends for my bday. The vibe, the music, and food brought me back to my childhood days (raised by my puerto rican father). I would highly recommend this place and will be returning to try the pernil since I chose the mofongo this time around. Yummmmmmmy
author: Manuel R.

description: I start this off by stating that I am a native Puerto Rican born on the island. I am pretty critical when it comes to PR food. EXCELLENT!!! FOODGASM! I don't think I have had better food in Puerto Rico. A definite must try, I am sad that I live in LA and don't have this place in my hood. I will be here every time I come to SF.
author: Carlos B.

description: Food was amazing. I ordered the Mofongo De Camarones, and cleaned my plate.  I'm usually picky about other's rice, but ate every last grain.  The seating area is a bit small.  Staff isn't very talkative, but the food speaks for itself.  The flan was excellent as well.  My only regret is that I didn't get a pitcher of sangria like other tables, but I was too hungry to care.  It's metered parking and it took a few turns around the block before we found a spot right out front.  But it was worth it!
author: Jasmin U.

description: For the amount their prices have gone up, they could at least afford to pick up the phone for call-in orders, or check their order ahead! Just called 10 times with a busy signal for 30 minutes straight, and it's not the first time. They've also previously forgotten our order ahead orders (a few times), so we've had to wait another 20 minutes hungry and cold. Finding more reasons not to come back.
author: Liz L.

description:
I've been coming to Parada 22 since I moved to CA in 2010. Being from Puerto Rico myself, this is one of the top places I've found all over California for authentic and delicious Puerto Rican food! I've had a few dishes, including the pernil asado, pastelon, sandwich Cubano, and pretty much all of the sides. There's not an item on the menu I have tried that they haven't done well. 

The space is small, but comfortable. Service is never a problem here either.

Always a favorite :)
author: Ruby L.

description:
I have been to SO many places in this City and this world for that matter, but the food here is the top of it all with exception of maybe a couple place that I have been in Belgium and Miami. 

The food is exceptional. Light, perfect flavor. The Sangria is a perfect blend of dry and fruitful, yet not overly sweet! The Carnitas are light and unreal flavorful.  The Cubanitas, are the most flavorful that I have had ANYWHERE. 

Denay is a a fantastic waitress that will provide excellent guidance, and ensures that everyone in this small restaurant are well looked after. 

Overall, it's a cozy feel, with a relaxing yet somewhat energized presence that makes one wish they could call it their regular joint.
author: Gabe D.

description:
Super yummy and afforable too! I was in SF for a conference and since my brother lives in town I wanted to meet him for dinner one night too. He had just taken a trip to Puerto Rico over the summer and lives close to the Haight so he suggested meeting at Parada 22. I had to take the Muni from the FiDi, but the stop was a short walk to the restaurant. We were seated right away at about 6:30 on a Monday night, but the place is fairly small so you might expect a wait on the weekends. 

My brother got the Chicharrones De Pollo, which is one of his favorites and I wanted to try the shrimp Mofongo since it was new to me. Both came with beans, rice, a green salad and your choice of sweet or crispy plaintains. Mofongo is sort of a plaintain mash with various types of meat and/or veggies mixed in. My shrimp were pretty tasty, but the plaintain mash itself had a few too many bell peppers for my taste. The salad, beans and rice were all very very good. If you can handle it try some of the hot sauce on the table, but beware it has quite the kick. It really jazzed up my beans and rice. My favorite part of my plate were the sweet plantains. My brother really recommends the chicken in the future and I would love to come back and try it. 

He and I also split a half carrafe of sangria and it was absolutely perfect. Not too sweet but with a smooth finish. We both really enjoyed it, espcially with the spicy food. Some of the best sangria I have had in a while. Service was good, even though it was basically just one guy running the whole show. I went to use the restroom and you have to walk through the kitchen and it looked like there were just two guys there that night. I was impressed at all they did. Our bill came to less than $40 before tip, which is downright amazing for the quality of food and being right on Haight. I definitely need to take my husband back here the next time we are in the city sans kids.
author: Lisa H.

description: First walking in I expected it to be bigger but it only sits about 30 people.  Besides that this place is BOMB! The decor is fun and the music is nice, it isn't that annoying Mexican music.  Now the food. Omg it is amazing!!!! My fiance is Puerto Rican and they have his approval.  Perfect portions to if you finish the plate, which I did, you don't real like you're going to explode.  It is hearty food that tastes like home cooking.  You can see the chef cheffing it up in the kitchen.  The sweet tea is good.  Next time I want to try their sangria.  I wish we had a place like this in Sac. I will go to Frisco just for this place.
author: Rachael P.

description: after reading some reviews, I understand that it can be difficult and frustrating if the restaurant is busy. However, if you have the patience or can come back when its less crowded, the food is fantastic! mofongo con camarones is my go-to and I always recommend it to first-timers. The restaurant is not really well-suited for groups larger than four or children in prams/strollers.
author: Torrpedo T.

description:
My Puerto Rican friends swear by this hidden treat in the Haight, so since Parada 22 already secured their street cred, I figured I'd give them a shot.

First off, the dining area is small. Not a bad thing at all, I prefer a place where the cooks have the time to focus on your food, and it really preserves that eating-over-at-a-friend's-house feel. Their sangria is very smooth, like 'you don't know how much you've had until you stand up and the room spins' smooth. Their mofongo is excellent (and it's fun to say...mofongo!) and their pork is slide off the bone tasty. Their dinner plates are massive and will please even the largest appetites. Pecking eaters will likely have lunch for the next day.

Finally, the staff really treats the place like it's their family kitchen and you're a guest. They were always quick to the table, checked on us often, and made sure we felt welcome. Parada 22 is tucked away a bit, so amongst all the other fanfare on Haight you might not know it's there, but if you don't, you're missing out.
author: Kevin B.

description: Awesome service, awesome food. The ambiance here is great! Super tiny place, but people are usually in and out pretty quick. One of the times I was here with a friend we got lost in our conversation, hardly touched our meals, and ended up talking for over 4 hrs...the staff were completely understanding and accommodating. We love how it's a judgment free zone here.
author: Rebecca J.

description:
How does this place not have five stars?  

I live two blocks from here in the Haight and believe this is the best dinner in the neighborhood, bar none.  Most of the food in the Haight is... well... it's kind of scroungy, whatever that means.  Really low quality.  Parada is totally not like that and is also affordable -   ~$14 or so for an awesome four course meal with everything tasting awesome.  I would eat at this place every week - in fact I may start doing so.
author: John A.

description:
Visited this place on Saturday - my hubby's Puerto Rican, and while we cook many of the native dishes (and go "home" to eat the same!), there are a few we haven't mastered (or tried to cook).  So when we saw mofongo on the menu we thought "hurrah!".

Small, but cozy, we weren't greeted immediately but found space at the counter - then, eventually saw a table opening up so ran over to it!  It's always fun to go to a restaurant to find out almost no-one on the staff is FROM the region (we asked - only the chef is, they told us!).  We ordered the pastelon (think Puerto Rican lasagna - made w/ sweet plantains in lieu of noodles, and their spices in the meat!) and, of course, the mofongo, along w/ a 1/2 pitcher of sangria.

Sangria was KILLER - 1/2 more than enough for two in terms of strength!  But there must have been an ice shortage for both it, and our water.  

Pastelon: receives an A from the hubby (and me.
Mofongo: we've had it MANY, many, many times in the island, at all sorts of places - but never with a cream-based sauce like this one had.  Normally, its "shell" holds together until you forcibly cut it - this one crumbled.  Taste was good, just not the "traditional" mofongo we were looking for.
The other tests:
Rice - a bit oily for us, but not out of line.
Beans - my hubby does them better ;-)
Other - even tho' BOTH of our dishes were based on plantains, we had extra sides of sweet plantains served alongside - bit of an overkill, but done well!

Given the difficulty finding parking and the "good but not great", probably won't go there again.
author: Marie O.

description: Food is great but everything is a hassle. They refuse to split up the bill and give you a pen to do the math. At these prices you would think they would be nicer about getting money out of you.
author: B.c. C.

description: I really love this place! Such good food for a reasonable price, and great atmosphere for a fun casual dinner. Reminds me a lot of Sol Food up north - also worth trying!
author: Rachel W.

description:
If you are looking to taste Puertorrican food cooked by the flare of Grandma, you are in the correct spot. A small an charming little restaurant next to Cha, Cha, Cha. The decoration took me right to some happy memories of my Island and I immediately felt my proud Boricua heart engaging with the ambiance. Not only what I had for lunch was amazing but the music they played; old Trio and Salsa Gorda was just what I needed. I order the Pastelon de Amarillo and oh boy was I happy surprised about how it reminded me of my Moms own recipe. When I start talking to the sweet waitress and she found out I was from Puerto Rico, she immediately brought to my table yuca al mojo and aguacate ;).. my husband ordered a Cubano sandwich and although it had a more refine taste to it.. the pernil was cooked to perfection...  

For dessert flan de coco and rum cake is a must try.. The only reason I'm not giving this wonderful place 4 starts is because they did not have any COFFEE.. really? after an amazing carb meal and sweets you are telling me no cafe con leche??? o cortadito? shame! but as per the waitress they do serve coffee during the weekend. I hope is brewed in an old black sock like grandmas used to do back in the day ;)

And yes my last feedback is that apparently is the same owner as Cha, Cha, Cha... ;)

Bay Area this is a must try and yes the price is just right for the amount of food you get..

And to the owner of the restaurant you can hold the veggies when you serve.. we Latinos can careless about them when we have a piece of Lechon/Pernil on our plate ;)
author: Las Comadres I.

description:
Definitely better food than Cha Cha Cha next door. Huge portions for a decent price and delicious!! To start off with, me and some coworkers had the Sampler Plate. It has the pernil asado (roast pork), chicharrones de pollo (fried chicken), maduros, tostones, and cassava which were all starchy and savory. I highly recommend getting this one! The ranch-y sauce they serve with it is delicious, and it's a great way to try all of their hit items. The pernil asado was really good and tender, the chicharrones were okay.

For drinks, I would skip the lemonade or sweet tea. My coworker said the lemonade was way too sweet and my sweet tea wasn't that great either.

For my entree, I had the pollo a la criolla which is a chicken dish with a ham saucey stirfry thing on top. It was delicious! I love how they grilled the chicken perfectly so it had that great grill-y flavor while still remaining its tenderness. I got it with the spanish rice and red beans (which are kidney beans with ham). I would recommend getting the white beans with this dish, because the red bean sauce tastes very similiar to the ham sofrito and they are both a tad too salty when eaten together. My coworkers had the pollo encebollado and it looks AMAZING! Definitely getting either that or the pernil asado next time.
author: Christina L.

description: Yummy Puerto Rican food, but I just wish they would expand the place because it is VERY tiny. It was super packed the day my friends and I went, and I was so suffocated that I almost fainted. Will have to get this delivered next time for sure!
author: Sovanarath C.

description: This place is cute and affordable. I took the roasted pork with rice. The whole meal was cooked to perfection ! I enjoyed every bit ! They cooked it really fast too. I would definitely come back again and try another dish ! Yummy
author: Marian P.

description: We went there for lunch on a Sunday afternoon. It was busy but not overwhelming. The service was friendly and we shared a long table with a few other people. I ordered the sampler, the plantains are delightful and pernil was ok. It wasn't as juicy and tender as I expected. The fried chicken was quite good and juicy. Overall pretty good.
author: Lily T.

description: Since i've moved back from the east coast, I've only been able to find this place that satisfies my cuban/DR/PR fix.  I always order the pastelon as I'm a fan of maduro.  This does it for me.  Flan is satisfactory but every time I've had it, the bottom always seems to be a little bit hard.  Overall a great add to this city's food options.
author: Spencer Q.

description:
My friend & I decided to try a new place, first hit on Yelp that neither one of us had tried on Haight Street happened to be Parada22. So we went, not knowing what we were to expect.

It was both our first time trying Puerto Rican food & we both enjoyed it. 

The decor is cozy and homey. The server was very friendly and the food was delicious. Add a pitcher of Sangria to your meal and you have a great evening. 

We ordered the Vegetarian plate which comes with Yuca, Plantains & White beans. The Yuca & Plantains were amazing. The salad that comes with is was tasty as well, and I'm just not a white bean fan, but the white beans were ok as well (my friend really liked the beans). The rice was super tasty. 

Count on me for coming back! :-)
author: Helen D.

description: Great, authentic PR food (Mofongo!) with a laid back, casual atmosphere and friendly staff. Very good chicharones. Would recommend for low cost, casual good food.
author: Edmondo R.

description: Can't say enough good things about this place.  As fun and festive as ever-so-popular Cha Cha Cha is next door, I'd choose this place first.  Parada 22 still has the fun, colorful, Latin vibe and the food is authentic and outstanding.  The restaurant is small, so don't come starving-to-death at a busy mealtime, because you might be waiting a bit.  The pork plate is delicious, but then again I haven't had anything here that is less than enjoyable.  Seriously, come here.  I really don't understand why more people in the city don't know about this place when I bring it up.  This is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  It's affordable, too!  Which is always a plus.
author: Kristen F.

description:
i'll tell you the truth: i wanted to go to cha cha cha but their kitchen was closed between lunch and dinner and this was next door, the menu looked great, and my friend and i wanted to try some puerto riccan food. im glad we stopped in! 

i was told the top 3 items on the menu: pastelon, pollo a la criolla, and pernil asado were the most popular. i opted with the pollo a la criolla bc i saw someone else had ordered and it looked and tasted delicious. i'm always afriad that chicken will be cooked dry but this one was juicy! i had leftovers that i heated up today and it was still good! i got it with red beans and yellow rice, both super flavorful. 

i went to PR just in march a couple months ago and to me, this restaurant was better than some of the food i had there lol don't forget to try their sauce if you like a bit more flavor and spice!
author: Jen S.

description:
Most people pass up this hidden gem because Cha Cha Cha is right next to it, but both times I've been here the girl and I both licked our plates clean!  

The place is a bit small, but given it's not as popular as the restaurant next door, I've never had to wait for too long.  

Try the Mofongo de Camarones ($13ish).  The shrimp are plentiful and plump, and the mofongo is BOMB.  Think of a chunkier, kicked up version of mashed potatoes.  The dish also comes with fried plantains, seasoned rice, and a small salad.  It's not the prettiest looking dish, to be honest, but it's packed with flavor.
author: Ronald T.

description: OMG, yum!! It's so good. I went be myself the first time and vowed to go back. Me and my husband and our toddler, took out grandpa for his birthday. We all got the steak plate. The dishes were clean.
author: Jennifer W.

description: Easily my favorite restaurant in the Haight-Ashbury neighborhood! Menu standouts are the slow roasted pork (pernil asado) and the fried chicken (chincharrones de pollo). Sorry if I spelled those wrong! The sangria is also really good. I've never gotten anything less than a great meal here. I actually think it's better than Sol Food which is saying a lot! Can't recommend this place enough.
author: Sara S.

description:
Being Puerto Rican and a foodie, I have to say this place has great food with a modern twist of its traditional dishes.
The sampler platter is a great way to try a taste of what to expect. The beans are very flavorful, just like grandmas home cooking.
Sangria is great here.

Why, only 2 stars?
 Well this place has the worst service ever.  The wait staff was just hanging around talking amongst each other, back towards the dining area, drinking coffee, hugging up on each other. Very unprofessional mannerism going on. Every person that came in had to wait for a long time to order. I looked on every persons face who came in how frustrated they were. I had to ask for my water 3 times before I got it. One server went to go sit down with some friends and that was the only time I seen one of them to be attentive but to her own friends.
If it wasn't for the great food and my morals, I would have walked out.

I suggest take out!
author: Ness C.

description:
Next time Cha Cha Cha line gets too long -- just go next door!!  Food is equally savory but much cheaper, and the venue more intimate for better conversations.

Scoutmob brought me to Parada 22 for my first Puerto Rican cuisine experience (btw, 50% off your bill, but expires 10/2 so act fast).  So yum.

I'm big on being able to sample varoius dishes, so really appreciate the color and variety in all of their entrees.  

I ordered the Mofongo ($11.5) per the waitress' recommendation -- no regrets there!!  It's basically the Camarones a la Criolla dish but over mashed green plaintains.  The shrimps had the best texture and was perfectly flavored in a citrus cream sauce...and there were lots of them.  Plate also came with Spanish Rice, White Beans (in soup form), a salad, AND fried plantains.  Perfect meal on a plate.

Oh - don't forget their sangria.  I won't.
author: Kendra W.

description: Loved, loved the food. Giving it 4/5 stars because the restaurant is Puerto Rican, but the rice is missing pigeon peas and there is no Cola Champagne! Great ambiance, and great for a group of 2-4 people.
author: Herald A.

description:
FOOD:

Generous portions, meat is cooked super well. each plate comes with a salad, beans, rice, and usually plantains. This is comfort food, nothing bourgy here. 

Not a huge fan of the hot sauce, it lacks that slow heat you want, and tastes like it was cut with Orange Crush. 

ENVIRONMENT/OTHER:

Prices are perfect. It can get a little busy sometimes, and there's not really a lot of room to wait inside, so if it's gross out, you may be stuck waiting outside the front door which is no good.
author: Patrick T.

description:
Thanks Parada 22 for the terrific Cubano Sammy tonight.  I did something in try not to do which is come in at the end of the night and order while the kitchen is cleaning.  

They host told me they were closed but I pushed for a sandwich and they made it happen.  Thanks so much!!! 
Made my night.  And it was delicious.
author: ari b.

description:
Simple, small place with attentive service.  The space is a bit chilly though.

PERNIL ASADO - roasted pork, marinated with garlic, oregano base sofrito - wish I went w/my 1st choice - the shrimp, because I pictured a stew like dish.  Instead there were hunks of pork pieces but some had great seasoning & flavor & some were dry & flavorless.

CAMARONES A LA CRIOLLA - sautéed shrimp in a fresh tomato, onion and pepper cream sauce - so glad my friend ordered this so I was able to taste it.  Definite winner.

Each dinner came with sides:
ARROZ DE AMARILLO - Spanish rice - A-ok

HABICHUELAS BLANCAS - homemade white beans in sofrito base with potato, carrot, and calabaza (vegan) - not a veggie or vegan but damn they were tasty!

MADUROS - ripen sweet plantains - 2 pieces.  Luv those plantains!

VERDE ORGANICA - green organic.  A-ok greens.

A couple next to us ordered the CHICHARRON DE POLLO - breaded and fried chicken thighs served with tostones and salsa rosa dipping sauce - wow it smelled & looked yummy!  Another visit.
author: Kim S.

description:
I was brought here by surprise by my husband. He knows I'm not always fond of trying new places so instead of asking where I wanted to go, he just told me we were going here. I knew I couldn't fight it. :) 

 I got the Plato Vegetariano -
Yuca, maduros, habichuelas blancas, and tossed greens. 
It took me awhile to decide because all of the menu looked great. However, having eaten Puerto Rican food before, I was always astounded by the ability the cuisine has to make root vegetables and all veggie dishes delicious; I knew it'd be a good bet to go with the vegetarian dish. In fact, it was Puerto Rican food that introduced me to the variety of root vegetables out there, and I have to say that I love them all. Also, I opted for the veggie beans as a side with the salad. 

My husband got the  Pernil Asado - Roasted pork leg marinated with garlic, oregano, and sofrito base. He opted for the non-veggie beans.

I LOVED mine and he LOVED his, although we both agreed the vegetarian beans were a little more to both of our liking. I'm not a huge pork fan so while his was great, it wasn't my taste, but he absolutely adored it. 

I can't wait to go back!
author: Julie W.

description:
This could be Haight Street's best kept secret!  

8pm on a Friday night, and there's hoards of people in line for Cha Cha Cha, my partner and I walk into Parada 22 and absolutely no wait - score!  We ordered (to share): 
Camarones a la Criolla 
Pernil
Coconut Flan
Half Pitcher of sangria.

Camarones are out of this world delicious, I was practically licking every last drop of the sauce of the plate.  Pernil was just alright, but the sides of spanish rice and red beans were still delicious.  Coconut flan - very good. Oh and the sangria -- you could taste the alcohol (in a very very good way) and a quarter of a pitcher later I was stumbling home! 

$46 later were well-fed, happy, and drunk, without a dent in our pocketbooks.  This place has a similar price point to their next door neighbor, but the food is leaps and bounds better!
author: Andrea P.

description: It was super good! Better than I expected! I ordered sautéed shrimp. I got it to go and the sauce kinda spilled but the bag was thick enough so it wouldn't leak out. Everything was super! Very satisfied.
author: Karen Q.

description: Eh. The usual bland shit you get. It's like a fucking hit or miss with these places but I would rather not eat here. Why? People are rude. On your man-period much? I mean if you're going to produce "okay" food be at least a little polite or have a little ventilation in your place. So yeah. Wasted my time at a restaurant that fucking does not know how to salt their food. GOD. *rolls eyes* :)
author: Dominique S.

description:
I LOVE Sol Food, as many of the other yelpers seem to too, but this place is a good alternative. 

I came with a couple of friends a little before 6, which is happy hour, $18 for a pitcher of sangria and $6 for their appetizer platter! 

After 6, it got SUPER crowded and I was so glad we arrived early. 

Food took a little while, but it was one server and only a couple of cooks in the back, so understandable. 

I ordered the shrimp that everyone talks about, not sure if I would order again but it was good. The rice...amazing, red beans, pretty good, and salad decent. All in all a good experience and would def come back. 

OH, yeah, the tea and lemonade was not as good as Sol Foods, not worth it.
author: Alison N.

description: I've only been to the Sol Food located in Mill Valley and I like the camarones & maduros here better.
author: Som S.

description:
This is a very solid addition to the Haight restaurant selection. First of all, I'm a sucker any time there are sweet plantains. Secondly, we had a great selection of non-alcoholic drinks, including coconut soda and coca cola with cane sugar (the only kind worth drinking, in my opinion). 

I think this place actually has a lot of potential, and the only reason I give it four stars instead of five is the lack of a "standout" dish. The food is solid, but there was no amazing dish that makes me run to come back. There was no shortage of fried options. If lived nearby, this would likely become a regular spot, but not for now.

The staff was also very friendly and full of humor, and the ambiance was right for a fun Friday night out.
author: Mike G.

description:
A very pleasant surprise! Like an unmarked gift box with unknown contents that you sweat about hoping you can pull off a happy face even if you didn't like it.....

It's a tiny place next to cha cha chas and if you've ever been there you know that the wait can be insane on most Friday and Saturday nights and the bar packed to the brim! And who can blame them - the food and the sangria are good!! Well it was pretty late around 830pm on a Saturday when we arrived and it was one of those nights after a really long busy day that's about to be followed by another busy day and one of us was gearing up for her first nike women's half marathon!  So we really didn't have an hour or more to wait for a table followed by another long wait for food so.... We ended up here because the wait was only 15-20 minutes long. 

The service wasn't too bad, although the greeting part was a little lacking but overall the waiter was very attentive once we were seated and getting situated. He offered good recommendations to my friend when she asked and the portions are actually pretty big! The sangria here was also delicious and strong! We each ordered something different - roasted pork, chicken, a fat steak and camarones (a la criolla, that was my order and I loved it! The fried plantain that came with the dish went amazingly well with every bite!).  Everything was made to perfection - textures of the meat/shrimp, seasonings, flavours... It was all there! I was very impressed. And the price was all very reasonable!
author: Mercy D.

description:
I was pretty disappointed by the food here. In general, there was too little garlic and too much salt, which is a bad combination. The pernil asado had areas that were far too fatty, and those which weren't were dry and tough. The sofrito in the pollo a la Criolla really didn't come together, at least partially because the peppers were not chopped finely enough. The yellow rice was notably bland and the habichuelas coloradas also suffered from the sofrito. The cuban sandwich was actually the worst I've had - a lackluster roll with dull ham, the same dry tough roasted pork, and not much else going on. The ingredients aren't premium and there's nothing bringing everything together. 

I will say that the tostones, while a bit nontraditional, were my favorite of all the ones I've tried, and the maduros were good too. The chicharrones de pollo did not have traditional Puerto Rican flavoring, but they were pretty tasty. So if you find yourself here, I would recommend ordering among those items. But I would even more strongly recommend going to El Nuevo Fruitilandia for Puerto Rican & Cuban food in San Francisco.
author: Lisa K.

description: Recently went to New York for the PR Festival and I was introduce to this dish called Pastelon while I was out there and it was out this world when it came to my taste buds. So on a Sunday afternoon my girls said she wanted to try this place Called Parada 22 in SF. And on the menu was the great dish I had in NYC so you know I order it and it was bomb dot com. Also recommend the Shrimp MoFongo :0
author: Napoleon A.

description:
We decided to check this place out this past wknd, 4th of july. Pretty small space, their are stools along one wall and community style seating. Luckily, my friends & I were able to get the corner table.
I wanted my tostones fix, so I order the cubano wit tostones versus the salad. Yum, the sandwich is a lot smaller than usual cubanos but not a problem bc u end up pretty stuff. The salad is just a plain mixed green salad.
My friend got the pollo   Which came with a side of rice (Spanish or white),beans & maduros (sweet plaintains).
For the area, the prices are fair. Not sure why it's right next to cha cha cha's since they serve somewhat of the same style food. But the food is really good n I was happy to get my fix. Next time I go back, I'm getting the sampler bc I eyed the table nxt to us and it was pretty decent portions wit a taste of everything.
author: francis c.

description:
It's slightly short from a 4-star in my book. I don't have much exposure to Puerto Rican/Cuban/Latin American food so the review is based own individual preference rather than judgment of authenticity.

Service can almost get five. For some reason both the servers we had were new to the job, still, they managed to do a great job. The restaurant itself is quite small, a few slightly longer table plus a few more regular tables. Avoid busy hours if you don't want to wait. We sat at the kid's corner, with crayons on the table. 

Coconut Flan -- 5++ STARS -- If you love coconut and/or flan, you must try this. If you don't, try this and it might change your mind about either coconut or flan. The flan had great consistency, smooth and creamy, but not overbearingly thick. The bottom was a thin layer of shredded coconut. Really really sweet but so gooood. 

Camarones a la Criolla -- 4 STARS -- The dish tasted great, but I cannot say there's anything special about it. I liked the fried banana though :) I think there should be more sauce that come with the shrimp, which goes great with the coconut-flavored rice. Order the white bean instead of the kidney bean, much more flavorful and not too sticky. Also came with a salad. 

Chicharrones de Pollo -- 3 STARS -- I didn't try the boneless chicken, but according to my friend, the chicken was way to try that she had to dip in the sauce to swallow it. Again, loved the friend plantain.

In short, worth the money because I had the Groupon and would totally come back to try more dessert!
author: Maggie L.

description:
The greens, the plantains and the beans... were grubbin.

The pernil was just okay to me.  I may be too used to my own ..so don't let me discourage you from trying it.

I like the small feel this restaurant had but the food didn't taste like Grandma's cooking.  Don't mind this spoiled Puerto Rican, it was still good eats and I would come again :)
author: Lisa A.

description: Can't believe the chief that cooked the chicken plate is the same guy that made the steak sandwich. Chicken plate was fantastic, perfectly cooked, and delicious. The steak sandwich was overcooked, lacked flavor, and a bad cut of meat. But what really sucked was the service. The waitress was not friendly at all. Don't understand why it's so highly rated. Would not recommend.
author: Mitch W.

description:
This place is affordable and yummy! A Latin American friend recommended this to me and of course, I trusted her judgement.

I came with a friend on a Saturday night and it wasn't packed, thumbs up. :) She got the Pernil Asado, which was Roasted pork leg marinated with garlic, oregano, and sofrito base. The pork was tender and soft, while being full of flavor. It came with a good portion of rice, beans, and platanos!

I, on the other hand, got the Chicharrnes De Pollo which were Fried marinated boneless chicken with salsa rosa and tostones. WHO DOESNT LOVE FRIED CHICKEN?... I definitely love it. I do wish that my dish came with platanos instead of fried.... chips? I'm not really sure what they were.

Regardless, each dish was a good filling portion for one at a reasonable price of ~$15 for dinner. Who can complain. I'm definitely coming back to try what else is on the menu.
author: Joyce M.

description:
My friends who live in Haight-Ashbury introduced me to this gem of a restaurant in their neighborhood.

I'll have you know I was only offered marijuana three times while walking down the street.

The restaurant itself is small so you'll have to wait during lunch and dinner. Because of this, they might seat you next to strangers. I hate everyone so I barely want to be out let alone sit next to people I don't know. Alas, I understand they are optimizing the limited space they have to work with.

Loved the plantains. Loved them!! Can I have more please?

I loved my boyfriend's dish, the plantain lasanga (pastelon), and my boyfriend loved my dish, the camarones a la criolla. We ended up switching plates, but I could have eaten either and left just as happy.

Always opt for the Spanish rice!

We all loved the $15 pitcher of sangria. Aw yis getting crunk midday then napping until 8PM. Living the good life my friends.
author: Trang H.

description:
Your mouth's BLISSFEST.  

Forewarning before I dive into the goodness:  They have an unbelievable ant infestation out in the dining area on the walls and counters.  It was horrifying but EVEN THAT WON'T DETER ME from this heavenly food!  (However, note to management-please do something about the ants!)

I ordered the Camarones a la Criolla.  This dish included a refreshing salad, fried plantains (tasted like sweet potatoes, but better!), red beans (which include ham and veggies), a side of tasty spanish rice and the main treat was the shrimp/veggie medley with the most savory, addicting white sauce you can imagine.  

Wash it down with their perfect, just-sweet-enough Sangria and you will have one happy belly.  

Proactive and pleasant service, as well.  Parada 22 makes The Haight far more desirable.  It's worth the street harassment, I promise.
author: Ashley W.

description: Fantastic! Love the space; small, colorful, friendly. Biftec is cooked and seasoned perfectly. I've been thinking about this place since I tried it for the first time over a month ago. Highly recommended.
author: Miranda H.

description: Best cubano in town, seriously business, woke up craving it the same way I crave al pastor california style super burritos; get a half pitcher of sangria to pair with it, you won't be disappointed. Havana another.
author: jacob m.

description:
I've been wanting to have Puerto Rican food for years and it was nice to finally have it in San Francisco.

I had the Pernil, which was a nice portion of roasted pork.  It arrived with plantains, beans, Spanish rice and a small salad.  They server good portions here and I left very satisfied.  Depending on which portion of pork you end up getting, it could be very well seasoned or slightly under-seasoned.  The service was attentive and the décor was casual, but fun.

The next time I'm in the Haight, I'd definitely come back here.
author: Ken G.

description:
My friends and I initially wanted to try Cha Cha Cha, but after waiting for more than an hour I decided to yelp nearby restaurants. I came across Parada 22 which is conveniently next door with high ratings and available seats. We did not regret the restaurant switch at all. 

The restaurant is small but homey and a lot easier to talk to your friends without screaming or trying to filter what your friends say through all the loud chatters like at Cha Cha Cha. The waiters are very nice and polite...and by the way...they also work for Cha Cha Cha because Parada 22 is owned by the same owner. The guys are very helpful answering any questions we have and make jokes along with us. We asked them for their recommendations, and they recommended Mofongo De Camarones, sampler, and Pernil Asado. The dishes were delicious, and the meat was not dry at all. I love the plantains there; super good. 

I will definitely return, and thanks Yelpers for not letting me down on this one.
author: Jen T.

description: Im sitting here now...once i step outside i just wont do it...sooooo i have been here before no disappointments with the food its really good...TODAY it was good too i got the chicharron de pollo which is fried pieces of boneless chicken and white rice with white beans...i don't know the waitress name no name tag sher service sucked and she was flirting with the cook which its cool but do that when its not busy...shit do it when im not eating idc but anywho will i be back no not soon good food shout out to THE CHEF 4 stars for the clean area and the cook!
author: Yolanda G.

description:
Yum!
Mofongo and Sangria was realllllly good.
Service is great. I don't want to overkill you on this but, the service was so friendly and the food was so good. 
The restaurant it self is small but has character.
Parking in the Castro.. Always challenging. Oh well, get over it and eat some good food.
author: Lauren E.

description: Small restaurant, but food was delicious. The sangria was great!!! We had the classic cubano, mofongo de camarones, and the sampler. All very good. Their water was infused with cucumber snd lemon slices. It was very busy! We found street parking which was a plus. Unfortunately you will see many drug dealers, drug users and a zoo outside the window, but hey, you are at the Haight!!!
author: Jackie H.

description: The most authentic Puerto Rican food my husband an I have had since returning from Puerto Rico. A small intimate place to bring friends for some good sangria and food! My escape when I want to reminisce about hot humid nights in Viejo San Juan , PR!!!! Takes me back. Do me a favor and if its your first time, have the Tostones, Lechon asado and Mofongo! cant go wrong with these main staples Puetorriquenos!
author: Christina M.

description: The chicken with onions came on this big beautiful plate with Spanish rice, beans, salad and the best plantains I've had outside Latin America. Plus, there are these homemade bottles of orange sauce on the table that's spicy and delicious. Go for the Spanish rice over white! A perfect find for a meal before or after exploring the park.
author: Kathleen C.

description:
Definitely still a solid 4 stars.

They've upped their game. While still remaining oh-so-wonderfully-chill.

Red beans: more so a delicious concoction of a few beans with awesome amounts of tomatoes, peppers, onions, and potatoes. It's pretty much a dish in and of itself.

Spanish rice: no longer just a slightly sad looking yellow-colored rice. Now, it's filled to the brim with ham and pimento-stuffed olives. definitely tasty.

Pernil asado: super yum yums. the slightly under-seasoned and relatively dry chunks of pork have been replaced with wonderfully seasoned and deliciously tender chunks of ms. piggy. i like. a lot.

And they discount the scoutmob on alcohol. Really, how could it get much better?
author: Monica C.

description:
This is a great place for a casual meal if you're hungry and want some real flavor. My brother and I hit up Parada 22 on a Saturday for lunch, and had the pernil (pork) and the camarones a la criolla (shrimp).

The best part about the dishes is that they each come with rice and beans, plantains, and a little salad (along with whatever you ordered). So you end up with a little bit of everything, and everything is delicious. The pernil was well-prepared and moist, and the camarones were delicious, in their creamy tomato sauce. Would have been nice to have a few more shrimp, or larger ones, but isn't that always the case?

We finished with the flan (the plain one), which was good, but not amazing. My only complaint was that the service was a little slow; one woman was handling all the customers, and although the place is small, it wasn't very full. All-in-all, though, a great place for a great meal.
author: Andrew M.

description:
My friend from was feeling nostalgic for Puerto Rican food and remembered he had heard of Parada 22; so off we went!
Its a casual cute little place and I had never had Puerto Rican food so I was excited, especially since I was going to have someone tell me how authentic it was compared to his family's cooking. 
We had Arroz Amarillo, Tostones, Biftec Encebollado (for him), and I got the chicken version, we got a few more things that I can't remember...which is now where I mention we also got the sangria.
He said it was mostly authentic and I liked the flavors as well as he did. The chicken was moist and tender, arroz/rice I admit could have been better, great flavor but it was a little too firm for my like. Biftec/steak with caramelized onions was tasty and reminded me of my mom's version. The sangria was decent and I wouldn't decline a glass there but do fancy Cha Cha Cha's a little more than I do this one.
I would come back here for sure
author: Eff B.

description: You can get Mofongo with pernil (pork) if you don't want shrimp! Super yummy, authentic Puerto Rican food in SF. The Spanish rice was a bit bland & they need to play low music, it was too quiet & you could here every word said in the tiny place. THUMBS UP regardless! Great little find.
author: B K.

description: Delicious! Chicharrones de pollo were perfect-lightly fried and juicy. White rice and white beans (yes) were perfectly cooked and flavorful. The salad was dressed  lightly in a nice vinagrette.  Sangria was a nice complement-neither too tart nor sweet. Sabor at a great price-point. Good portions of quality food prepared right!
author: Andrea S.

description: I got takeout with a friend but this place was really good. We got the pollo encebollado and the biftec sandwich. We also added an extra side of the fried plantains. Highly recommend if you're in the area!
author: Ivy C.

description: Love it. The classic sandwiches are the best in the city. It was recommended to me as "the most authentic" in the city. I don't know about that, but they are fantastic. If I had a suggestion, it would be that they should have chifles as well as tostones.
author: Philip M.

description:
100% from PR, so a little spoiled. Pernil asado was very good!
White rice and beans were good.
I love mofongo and it's the reason I came. You don't boil mofongo, you FRY IT. Well, here they boil it, so FAIL for me. Too dry and weird looking.

Nice little place and good PR ambiance.
author: Fabia G.

description: We celebrated a birthday dinner here. We had to wait longer then 30 minutes. Restaurant is quite small. If you don't mind waiting outside of the Haight area (weirdos) potheads walking around and trying to talk to you. Then, this place may be for you. All seven of us in our party was a bit skeptical that it got 4 stars on yelp. It is worth the 4 stars. First, we started off with 2 pitchers of sangria and samplers. The samplers pork, chicken, yucca, corn croquettes were so tasty. Dip it into the sauce or add their hot sauce, it's sizzling. The meals came with beans (red or white), salad, rice (spanish or white) and yucca. I was able to try the biftec encebollado and mofongo de camarones for entrees. They were both quite delicious. For dessert, the flan was one of the best I've ever had. Wow!
author: Jennifer G.H. W.

description: Love the food and the environment here. There's sometimes a wait, but usually I'm able to come right in and sit down. One of my go to spots in the Haight.
author: Scott H.

description:
For those who just want a summary: great food, but atrocious, lazy, disinterested service from wait staff that should consider getting a job that does not require paying attention to anyone but themselves..  for example, a professional masturbator or mirror checker.

This place is tough for me to recommend for one simple reason. The staff at Parada 22 are a bunch of slackers who would rather talk to one another all day instead of doing their job. Instead of being attentive, they chat, they lounge, they check their phones - anything other than taking your order, giving you more water, getting your bill to you.  Long story short: they really don't want to do their jobs. On the other hand, the food is pretty good, so if you are willing to deal with incompetent, angsty, unprofessional wait staff who think that working in the Upper Haight means that subpar service is acceptable, then by all means, check out Parada 22 but just be sure to be vocal about your needs and to penalize via lack of tip accordingly.
author: Jan S.

description:
Sol Food has a serious contender-- Parada has better chicken (tasty, juicy, marinated and cooked just right) and almost as-good maduros (plantains).

Pleasant service.
author: Inigo M.

description:
At work, we ordered Parada 22 from trycaviar so I can't speak to ambiance or service. What I can speak to do is the food and it's great! 

While I grew up in Maine (my dad's family is there), my mom's family is from Rio Piedras and Trujillo Alto (in or near San Juan, Puerto Rico), so I ate a lot rice and beans, tostones, roast pork, yellow rice and flan. 

The Pernil Asado was awesome. Tender, juicy, flavorful, and pure gold. It reminded me of my grandmother's garlicky roast pork. I also liked both the maduros and the tostones--both perfect versions of sweet and green plantains. I liked the yellow rice, but I was hoping it would be more dry, have pigeon peas (arroz con gandules) and have a little pegao (the crispy rice from the bottom of the pan)--maybe I can ask for the latter when I go to the restaurant.

While I occasionally cook Puerto Rican food at home, I definitely plan to bring my wife and daughters here for the comfort food I grew up eating. Hopefully they serve flan too.
author: John S.

description: We came here after a running club meeting and I was blown away. Why wasn't this place on my radar?! I had the pork with Spanish rice and red beans. The pork was flavorful, the rice wasn't too mushy and the beans were the best I've ever had. This place is a must visit for anyone that likes Latin food! Can't wait to come back.
author: Alice W.

description: Very cute interior, kind staff and absolutely amazing food. I recommend this place to all my friends  and wish I was there right now having a plate of Pollo a La Criolla....... soo good....
author: Amy H.

description:
Food was "rich," oversalted mush.  

$15 half-pitcher of red sangria was great though.

The waitress we had wasn't much of a waitress. 

The space is tiny, all the tables are small, and there are not that many tables.  Don't come with a big group.
author: John B.

description:
Caramelized confusion.

Knew I wanted to come back. Thought it was for the sandwich. Reading my first yelp turns out it was for a dinner plate.

Had the sandwich again. More caramelized onions than before. Chicken just as good. Small side of greens. Reasonable $8. But an unfortunate undisclosed sauce.

So much for asking for and getting everything dry.

Perhaps fate is returning once again to try the chicken as it's own dish. There would be less confusion this way.
author: Jason B.

description:
I am a local Latin American customer who requires good food, service and environment to stick around. I found my kitchen home in Parada 22 a year ago when I moved to Haight; the food is undoubtedly delicious, and I will always recommend to go there. The music and the service is another aspect that makes this place special, I can always listen real latin music, and when I get there I know my husband can speak English and I can speak my Spanish. 

Yesterday, I went back to my lovely Parada 22 to celebrate, and the great latin music that gives caracter to this place was replaced by "Dance and Electronic music". Not enough my favorite server Carlos was not there, and somebody there told me he is not working there anymore, which made us think that the place is losing it's original caracter with these changes. 

This is a comment in the name of him, because Carlos had the capacity to make my family and friends feel at home, he knows what I want, he always keeps a friendly smile with everyone, and he is always respectful. This place was not the same extraordinary place yesterday, and I am standing up because we miss him and we know he keeps this place real and original; not like being just in another restaurant in San Francisco.
author: Marisol B.

description: Excellent food but the service was absolutely horrible ! The two female waitresses were very grumpy and rude ! They did not come by our table once to ask if we needed anything else.
author: Alyssa M.

description:
Incredible, totally authentic Carribean food. Knew this place was legit when I saw tostones (fried green plantains) on the menu, as well as yucca, which they make covered in a delicious garlic sauce with onions. 

The appetizer plate is my favorite so I don't have to pick or deal with filler rice and beans (sacrilege for a Dominican girl, but no one makes rice and beans like my mom, so I don't bother with any place else). 

It's a tiny spot, but their take out business is quick. A lovely stop on not-so-lovely Haight Street.
author: Maria D.

description:
extremely some nice folks working here. we got here around 730 for dinner and snagged the last table. we waited on our friend for about 30 minutes but they were so accommodating with us just hanging out there. 

the three of us ordered some very delicious food. i got the bisteak entree, while the hubs got the pork and our friend got the chicken. the entrees came with side salad, protein, spanish rice, and red beans. everything was spectacular! meat was cooked perfectly, and all the sides went with it nicely. for dessert, we got to try their flan and it was authentic. my husband is a flan fanatic and he gave a big thumbs up.

the sangrias were made well here. they don't add ice which i can greatly appreciate! no filler  and no dilution.
author: Qui C.

description: This is a good find for Puerto Rican style cuisine. I ate the pernil plate which was generous in the pernil portions. Well seasoned and moist. The Spanish rice that came with it was adequate and a reasonable size portion. The serving of beans was small in size, sadly because they tasted great. The maduros (fried ripe plantain) were ok and sadly we got two small pieces. I ordered tostones (fried green plantains) as a side for for $7. Good portion and well prepared, BUT they season with salt and pepper. Not a fan of this yelper. Overall I would go back. PS: consider having Picadillo a a dish, it's a PR staple.
author: Luis C.

description:
Was referred to this place by a bar acquaintance that knew I was into Caribbean/Cuban food.  Been looking for a good Cuban sandwich in the area for the longest time and finally had a chance to pop into here for a quick lunch the other day.

The girl (waiterperson sounds too formal since she was so nice and sweet) working the tables and register was so nice and although the place is small and charming, I went at an off-hour and had the most pleasant lunch there. Ordered the Cuban sandwich and I was really happy when it came out.  Per their menu, it is the Cubano Clasico - roasted pork, smoked ham, pickles, dijon mustard & swiss cheese (9.50).  I did order mine without the dijon mustard as I'm not into dijon and although I could be wrong, thought it might be more authentic without it.

I discovered the sandwich on arrival to be so nicely made with fresh bread and excellent ingredients...finally, a place that looks and tastes authentic!  The roast pork and ham was very nicely done and it really hit the spot, exactly what I was looking for.  As always, more is better and the sandwich was so good that I wished it were bigger, but for what it was, it did just fine.  I'll take quality over quantity every time.

Their water pitcher had lemons in it which I thought was a nice touch...in a cute neighborhood place like this, it means that someone really cares.  Had a nice lunch and when I left, I felt far happier and a lot more relaxed than when I first arrived.  To me, that is truly the sign of a good lunch and a satisfied customer.

Have a couple leads on another Cuban sandwich in San Rafael, but since I have a lot of great friends in the Haight, that will have to be set aside for another day.  So happy to have discovered this little gem in the Haight. :)
author: Roy N.

description: Cute little place.  Cubano Clasico Sandwich the best in town.
author: Gary B.

description: Wow, can't say I've ever had food like this before. I got the Pernil Asado with Spanish Rice, and red beans, while my friend got the Pollo a la Criolla. They came with amazing plantains on the side, which was something I've never experienced with lunch before. They were slightly crispy and very sweet, it was awesome. The salad had a light refreshing vinagrette. The roasted pork itself was extremely tender and flavorful, and I split it between me and my friend. His chicken had an awesome texture and the ham that came with it was delicious. I would totally come back here.
author: Matthew K.

description: No, you don't have to cater to vegetarians, but when you're located in the Haight?  Anyway, just came back from 2 wonderful weeks all over PR. Not a bad meal anywhere.  Mofongo, paella, kidney beans, yellow rice... all vegetarian.  We couldn't be happier.  La Madre Patria could teach Parada 22 about the true, inclusive spirit of Boricuas, especially at the dinner table.
author: Will M.

description:
I'm Puerto Rican and I can tell you their mofongo is one of the best I've had. Our waitress was also so super nice and perky. The space was clean and vibrant and inviting. The pork was tender and yummy. The prices were right. And the owner is a Boriqua! And a successful one at that!

Get some pasteles and pastelon on your menu!
author: Andrew K.

description:
Yum!  Teeny place with difficult parking.  My husband I came on a Saturday night around 7 and waited less than 10 minutes.  The service was great and food arrived very fast.

He had the Pastelon and ate every bite.  I had the mofongo and had to force myself to save half to eat for lunch the next day.  (Not the huge, butterflied shrimp I had on my mofongo in Puerto Rico but this was half the price!). We both had the red beans and Spanish rice.  We shared the coconut flan for dessert.  It was more gelatiny than custardy but I am not a flan expert.  It tasted great.

We would definitely come back.
author: Vicki D.

description: Delicious food, great place and decorations, quick service, somewhat pricey but overall good!
author: Marissa B.

description:
Biftek Sandwich. YUM!
Pastelon. Delectable!

I am so glad we came here on a recommendation of a friend. 
We would return here to try more of the dishes.

Parking sucks, though.
author: Riza T.

description: Small locale but big on taste!  Had the sampler appetizer, pork was somewhat bland but all other items-tostones with sauce (yummy), Maduros, marinated fried chicken and yucca were ALL delicious.  My mother in law who is not an adventurous diner tasted the yucca and was really enjoying under the guise of potatoes-lol.  The marinated chicken and onions, shrimp and onions both awesome choices, white rice or Spanish rice.  The red beans were a surprise hit! My whole family enjoyed the meal including my 11 and 14 year old kids who were skeptics.  Great value, not good for parties over 8 people.  Great puertorican cuisine!
author: Mona M.

description:
Very disappointing visit today. Showed up, there were two tables that just needed bussing, so I put up my name on the waiting list. Waited around for five minutes, when a couple walks in and gets offered the first table that had just been cleared up. Not even two minutes later, a second couple walks in and they are seated on the second table. Left on an empty stomach.

I've enjoyed the food here on previous visits, so I'm very disappointed that after making the trip down to the Haight, I was so blatantly ignored.
author: Hector R.

description:
I want to rate them higher because the Sangria is UH-MAZ-ING and the food is REALLY good! But the service was awful.

Put in for a table and were content to wait...got a wait time of 15-20 mins, mentioned the idea of getting a drink and a menu. Staff totally ignored us. Wait time ended up being 45 mins at least. Service was extraordinarily slow and most staff just hung out by the registers. A table had a check sitting in front of them waiting to be paid for 15 mins. which was irritating to those of us waiting. 

Finally got a table. Some guys came in and were content to wait at the spot we sat in and we handed menus and got their drink orders taken....um, oooook?

The food was amazing! Maduros were some of the best I've had as were the tostones (I'm in love with plantains and I'm picky about them...these rocked!). Roomie also got a free birthday flan. Sooo yummy!

Celiacs/Gluten Intolerant- Wait staff were a bit worrisome when I inquired about what did not have wheat or gluten. I got some blank stares when I mentioned the word gluten. Luckily Puerto Rican cuisine doesn't use a lot of wheat and the menu was really descriptive about what each dish consisted of. I got the vegetarian dish and did alright with it. I feel like I was just lucky. I was worried because the servers seemed unfamiliar with ingredients in the dishes.
author: Lily K.

description: Found this place on Yelp and loved it! Camarones a la criolla is delicious. The fried banana gives a subtle sweet taste. I will definitely go back soon.
author: Roberta T.

description: Went there with my family for lunch on a Thursday after a visit to Twin Peaks. Luckily we found street parking. It is a small restaurant with glimpses of Puerto Rican life portrayed on its walls. We ordered Pernil Asado, Chicharonnes de Pollo, Pastelon and Classic Cubano. The quantity of food was excellent. The pork was soft and delicious. The red beans had a gentle blend of spices which left me lingering for more. I finished off my son's red beans as well. The fried plantains were nice.
