The Arugula salad had a nice dressing. The limonada was a touch too sweet but I liked it. Overall it was good experience. If we're in the neighborhood we shall go there again.
author: Somnath M.

description:
Came here the other night with one of my best friends -- we're both big foodies and love trying new places to eat. 

We wanted to order an appetizer of some sort, but there really weren't any appetizer options, so we decided to just order two entrees and share.

We ordered the biftec sandwich and the camarones a la criolla (shrimp!). The shrimp honestly was AWESOME. The sauce was out of this world, and I couldn't get enough of it. The sandwich was good too, but the meat was definitely overcooked, and I wish there had been more of the sauce on the sandwich. The shrimp was the shining star of this meal.

The proportions were not huge -- I left the meal not hungry, but also not full. For the price, they were reasonable, but I think I'm used to the cheap, huge portions I've been spoiled by in San Francisco.

Overall, I think this is a good lunch restaurant, but I don't think it was quite enough for dinner. I won't be back for dinner, but it's a great place to grab lunch for a glass of sangria and a sandwich.
author: Erica W.

description: Very authentic flavor and quick service. I will be going back for more! I highly recommend the Pernil Asado, very tender pork shoulder. The rice and beans was delicious.
author: Marlon F.

description: THE BEST PUERTO RICAN FOOD IN SAN FRANCISCO. Demasiado delicioso. The taste of the mofongo just awesome, mixed with the steak and you get an amazing plate. The price super reasonable, and the attention ex excelente
author: Carito R.

description: Hands down my favorite place to eat. Its in my neighborhood, consistently great. Tastes just like home (Panama). I almost dont want to write the review because I dont want it to get more popular and full than it already is. Seating is limited and not great but who cared about being huddled in a corner near a drafty door when the food is this good.
author: Stella D.

description: Really unique and good :), I'd definitely come back when I'm in the mood for something Latin, but different than the norm. It's all about the sweet bananas yo, the flan.
author: Bahar A.

description:
How does this place have any less than 5 stars? I wish I lived closer to the Haight, otherwise I'd be back every week. I went on a Tuesday night, and there was a 15 minute wait, which wasn't so bad. The restaurant is fairly small, but there are stools to sit on to wait. 

The food... so amazing. Everything was cooked to perfection. And I've never had better plantains. It's also fairly reasonably priced for the amount of food you get. I got the steak and carmelized onions plate for $13 and it came with Spanish rice (amazing), beans and plantains. We finished our meal with the caramel flan which was equally amazing. 

In addition, there was only one waiter serving all of the tables that night and he was great. Super friendly and also very efficient. I will definitely be back, and highly recommend coming here if you're in the area!
author: Alice W.

description:
Amazing!!! Everything was delicious and tasted like it tastes back home! We had the biftek encebollado, pastelon, tostones, yuca, and coconut flan. 

So excited to have found a tasty Latin place in the bay!
author: Meir M.

description: Everything this place dishes out is amazingly delicious. I buy their home made hot sauce regularly because it is liquid love. I love there yucca and the sampler plate. Kisses to the chef/s.
author: Mel M.

description: Really liked this place, had a bodega like feel to it and homely styled cooking.  I got the pulled pork with plantains and red beans.  The food was simple but had lots of flavor.  It was surprising how good the food was because of how simple it was.  The only complaint was that seating is very limited because of how small the place was but otherwise a must try for Puerto Rican food fans.
author: James F.

description: Decent food at best. The place is small and very uncomfortable. The service was good,  very nice ladies taking your order. The pernil was missing the crusty skin and could have been more tender. It felt as if the place was for tourists and not what my mama used to make. Probably better to skip this joint and fine some more authentic.
author: John S.

description: Great Morongo and grandson of founders runs the place with Puerto Rican hospitality and pride. Small place but if you like comics Puerto riquena with some fusion thrown in - you have to stop by.
author: A A.

description: Came here to pick up food. Was given a 2:00pm pick up time. It is now 2:25pm and Ive been here since 1:50pm and was just told another 15-20minute wait. Mind you, they told me the same thing at 2:00pm. Was told they were really busy today, but theres no excuse for it taking over 45 minutes for food. What made it worse is twice I stood there about 5 minutes before anyone acknowledged I was there. I will never come here.
author: Tiara E.

description:
Quick and friendly service, strong sangria, delicious food.  

Coming here was a good choice
author: Tanner C.

description: This is the best Puerto Rican food I have ever had. I lived in Puerto Rico for a while several years ago. This is hands down amazing. Delish bottomless mimosas, tasty well flavored dishes served in the perfect portion sizes! Camarones a la criolla is the best!
author: Jasmin R.

description: This is a great spot in the Haight -- small, cozy and serving up some seriously delicious Puerto Rican fare. Our group of 8 shared entrees - we dug into two kinds of fried plantains and an array of pork and chicken dishes, which came with beans and rice. The meal was incredibly filling. We were comatose afterwards and had to go directly home (worth it),  so definitely consider sharing. We ordered the sangria, sweet, fruity and perfect with the fare. They were pretty packed on a Saturday night, but accommodated our huge group. We went to the bar next door, had drinks and shot pool - not a bad wait at all. So glad we got in here because Cha Cha Cha had an hour wait (just next door). Staff were very friendly and everything reasonably priced.
author: Melody K.

description: Came here bc the line at cha cha cha was too long. I got the pernil asado which was a hit on yelp. I'll admit. The pork was plain. The Spanish rice, red beans and sangria were great tho. It's a little pricey for me tho.
author: Zoe S.

description: What a surprise. Knocked my socks off! A great variety of food comes on the plate. The plantains are perfectly prepared. Great service, too. Small space and they make it work. this is kind of random, but they have a really cool front facade. Amazing spot.
author: Victory J.

description:
BEST PUERTO RICAN FOOD!

So we went to Puerto Rico and tried the foods there.  All the food tasted salty so I was hesitate to eat here because of that reason. I am so happy to report 
that it was very tasty and not salty. I tried 4 different entrees and some sides and they were all delicious. They had there own homemade water. They put lemon and cucumber in it to enhance the taste. The service was ok. They had a high chair. 
This is a small restaurant and they play loud music.
author: Ada Y.

description:
I reviewed it before but I'm increasing it to 5 stars. One of my new favorite restaurants. I can't remember the last time I ate somewhere and thought "wow, I'm really glad I ate here".

Fried chicken is sooo good.
author: Linh H.

description:
Great food. Love the Cuban sandwich.
And a cultural lesson for y'all: http://i.ytimg.com/vi/vl61-s1OuNQ/hqdefault.jpg
author: Tom C.

description: I was born and raised in Puerto Rico. .. so let's stay with that.  The food here is better than the food my grandmother makes. .. Talk about a taste of home.  Super authentic dinner menu... brunch is a bit of a cop out though.
author: Max R.

description: Super cute place for lunch.  Wish I read some Yelp reviews before ordering.  Got the steak and it was really tough.  Rice and beans were yummy though.  Left here full, but craving Back-a-Yard (awesome restaurant in Menlo Park).
author: Jenny L.

description: Place is totally awesome. Rolled in here while visiting the neighborhood. Food is killer. I grabbed the fried chicken and it was amaze balls. My friends had the Cuban sandwich and said it was best they ever had. CHECK IT OUT!!!!  Love it
author: Jeff C.

description: My new go-to spot. The steak salad is superb. You can also order the pork as a salad even though it's not on the menu - and get the garlic cilantro dressing as a sub for the vinaigrette. I also suggest the Spanish rice and red beans.
author: Jeff M.

description: On a streak of bad luck with this place last 2 visits. Food is great but service needs some work. 1st visit they forgot to include all of my items in my to go order & I didn't realize until I got home. 2nd visit I called to order for a pickup & was put on hold for 6 minutes. I could hear the worker talking in the background & laughing. So I hang up & go order in person. The restaurant is empty so they weren't too busy to finish my phone call. Then when I check my bank statement the following day, they charged me twice for an item. I call them for a refund & the woman who answered told me someone wrote in a $8 tip!?!?! Wow! Workers are outright stealing here! Still eating the food but will be paying in cash from now on.
author: Victoria L.

description: This place was incredible.  Really great service and nice atmosphere.  I had the roasted pork shoulder with red beans, Spanish rice, plantains, and a salad for less than 10$.  The pork was so tender you could cut it with the side of your fork.  I would definitely recommend giving this place at least two to three chances at first glance.
author: Ben D.

description: We actually settled for Parada 22 after another nearby restaurant was too full, and boy were we glad we stumbled upon it. Absolutely delicious food, cozy and intimate setting, and the friendliest staff. We were a larger group and took up most of the space, but they let us hang out well after closing and even came by with a complimentary pitcher of sangria. Great atmosphere and would highly recommend to out of town guests.
author: Rachel D.

description: I was walking down Haight St by myself after a not-so-great day looking for a good place to eat. Parada 22 seemed very popular, lively and cute, so I checked the Yelp reviews and went in. The staff was so kind and welcoming, and I decided to order the Pollo a la Criolla and a glass of sangria. It was all fabulous and put me in a great mood. When the bill came and I pointed out that they had not charged me for the sangria, the waitress (or was it the proprietor?) refused my offer to pay for it and said, "Next time." I live in New York, but next time I'm in San Francisco, I'm definitely coming back. Wonderful experience all around.
author: Ken M.

description: I came here for dinner on Saturday for the first time. I had the pastelon and it was absolutely delicious!  Everyone else at my table loved their dish. The food is very flavorful. Didn't disappoint and I will definitely be returning!
author: Jess Y R.

description:
For as busy as upper haight is as a neighborhood, it doesn't have many good food options. Initially a lot of people pointed me towards Cha Cha Cha which I've always found to be the definition of "just fine." 

Well I'm so glad someone finally pointed me to this smaller, tastier neighbor. It's very small but I've never had much of a wait, and the space still feels fairly open. Inside it's got a generally inviting, laid back vibe, good for conversation and meeting with friends.

The food is definitely what keeps me coming back. The flavors are great and everything is simple but tasty. The Spanish rice and red beans that come with every entree are always just what I want. It doesn't hurt that the sangria is delicious too.

Last time I even tried the flan and was pleasantly surprised by how good it was. Hard to beat a place with good food, good vibes, good dessert.
author: Molly O.

description:
VEGETARIANS BEWARE

Today I tried Parada 22, Boogaloos pop up on Haight. I will not be going back. If you are vegetarian be carful, if you are vegan, don't bother. I LOVE Boogaloos and am always happy to go there because they offer a wide assortment of options for me and all my veg and meat eating friends. So when I ordered they Desyuno Tipico (a fav. from Boogaloos) I expected my normal wonderful plantain cake. It came as fried plantains, but hey what the hell. Half way through I found a pork cube in my beans. I asked the waitress (who it must have been like her first day because she was totally clueless.) she directed another waiter over who informed me: 'oh ya, we list that it has pork on the lunch menu, but not breakfast' WTF!!!!! I - a Jewish Vegetarian was served beans with pork, it was not listed on the menu, and no one mentioned it when I ordered. I have not eaten pork ever in my life. 

Also they do not serve any milk alternative and when a friend asked what was vegan on the menu the above mentioned waitress pointed out the Vegan Soyrizo and Eggs. Eggs. Hmm. Then shrugged and said "I guess you can tell I'm not Vegan.'

For reals people. You are in San Francisco. On Haight Street. Get it together. 

NEVER AGAIN.
author: A. W.

description:
Yeah so a few months ago I am trying to find a good spanish restaurant and an Asian friend of mine tells me about this place called Parada 22 in San Francisco, CA.  He tells me that it is the best most amazing Latin Food he has ever tasted and travels all the way from Vacaville just to eat there whenever he gets the need for Latin Food.  I live in Elk Grove, CA and the trip to SF is at least 1 hour and 15 minutes on good day, and you know what, Parada 22 is worth every mile, every minute, dealing with every idiot on the drive there, and all the traffic crossing the Bay Bridge at 3 on a weekend afternoon!!!

You want to know what Puerto Rican food is all about, Parada 22 is the last stop you ever need to make unless your actually in Puerto Rico or anywhere in the Bronx or Brooklyn New York.

You feel the Puerto Rican culture as soon as you look around the restaurant from the flags on the wall, to the famous yellow cans of Cafe Bustelo, to the authenticate Puerto Rican chef.  It made me feel like I was back in New York with their style and it made me feel like I was back in Puerto Rico with their taste.  

The menu is full of authentice Puerto Rican dishes and you can't go wrong with either one.  I orderd the Pernil with rice and beans in addition to four orders of Tostones.  Yup four orders!!!  Have just one and you will not be done!  The price is great and the service is just as good.

If I had one complaint about Parada 22 it would be that the dining room is not big enough.  You actually have to share a long table in some areas however, it does create a cozy home feeling and you can make new friends that way.  I didn't have a problem with it but I can see where others may. 

Parada 22 is what us Boriqua's are all about!!!!
author: David L.

description: I've been here a few times.  The food is really good and it comes out fast.  I plan on trying everything on the menu.  Seating is limited,  best to go with small groups.
author: P A.

description: Excellent food,delicious and authentic Puerto Rican food. Had the best Plantolon. The steak and onions were amazing. The pulled pork dish was out of this world. And the Sangria hit the spot. What a great place to eat authentic Hispanic food. Loved every dish we ordered. I'm definitely coming back. The seating area is limited but we had no problem getting seated at 8 pm for dinner.
author: Shelly P.

description: The pastelon is delicious, I will be going back for that at least! Service was nice and attentive even on a busy Friday night. The place is small and cute with character.
author: Kris F.

description:
THANK YOU YELPERS!!!  I never would have found this spot without you!!!  We were looking for a quick meal before a concert in SF, but GOOD food, because a trip to SF has to be worth it food-wise.  
The food was fantastic, and the prices extremely reasonable.  The pork was melt-in-your-mouth tender, the Spanish Rice was perfect.  Their salad (with what I imagine is a house dressing) was just do good and the perfect complement to the heavier food.  Oh, and my entree came with fried bananas, which was basically a prerequisite when I chose my entree.  This was a taste of my grandma's kitchen in the middle of Haight!
author: Jennifer P.

description: Order the vegetarian plate, which consists of yuca, fried plaintain, and white beans. It's comforting, hearty, and filling. SF food without the SF prices!
author: Sharon L.

description:
I'm more of a Jet than a Shark, but after living in NYC I can definitely appreciate some good Puerto Rican food.  The compostable plates and friendly staff with normal sized posteriors didn't seem that authentic though.  I agree with other Yelpers that the tostones are sorely missed.  However, on a coast where there is too much Mexican food it is nice to see a Puerto Rican outpost.

Chicharrón de Pollo: That's Puerto Rican for Fried Chicken!  Could use some extra breading/crispness compared to it's light shell.  The meat though was nice and juicy.

Pernil Asado: A few slices of pork roast with a hearty bit of tasty fat attached to each piece.  Very tender meat and melt away fat.  Texture was spot on, but not as spice infused as pernil asado I've had in NYC and Miami.

Arroz de Amarillo: Was very Goya-esqe.  Yellow in color, though didn't particularly scream saffron so much as food coloring.  Some veggie bits.  More exciting than white rice at least...

Habichuelas Coloradas: Surprisingly flavorful red beans in a stew base.  Enough spices going on not to miss the pork lard.  Might have been the highlight of the meal.

Habichuelas Blancas: White beans in a stew base, not nearly as exciting as the red beans.  A tad bland.

Yuca al Mojo: Boiled, not fried, yuca.  The creamy onion mojo sauce worked very well to flavor the otherwise bland boiled tuber.  And to think, I almost didn't order this because it wasn't fried!

Maduras: Came with the main dish along with rice & beans as any good Puerto Rican plate should have.  Sweet, though a little oily.

Rum Cake: Reminiscent of Italian rum cakes.  Light yellow cake layers with a very creamy rum custard in between.  Was a little pissed that they tried to charge $4 when the posted wall menu and take away menus stated $3.  On the positive side, the cashier conceded to respecting the advertised price despite what her register said.
author: Adam B.

description: Delicious. I've only been in the bay area for about a month. I recently moved here from NYC and this reminds me of home. The food and music are great. The sampler is everything I need when I miss home. Coming here again... and again.
author: Christopher M.

description: Straight from the island!  Their Mofongo with shrimp is delicious. The homemade hot sauce is not too hot and is very flavorful.
author: R M.

description:
Overwhelming deliciousness. 

This place is a nice cozy niche in SF. The servers there are so sweet and attentive. Sangria was awesome and all of the foods I tried were outstanding...especially flan!
author: Mel B.

description: This place kills it!  Food is amazing and portion size so big.  We will be back to try more things on the menu.  We had three entrees - pork, steak, and fried chicken.  All served with a variety of side dishes and side salads.  Deep hardy favor - felt like we were cooked a home cooked meal. A little divey on the atmosphere but super friendly staff.  Great place and we'll be back soon
author: Matt B.

description: The Pernil Asado is my favorite. Juicy pork and the flavors are spot on! I've been here a number of times and it has never disappointed me! Definitely one of my favorite places in The Haight!
author: Illi F.

description: So delicious! Stop by on a Sunday evening with my boyfriend wasn't overly crowded but had a good amount of people inside. The lady greeted us and was really nice. We ordered our food and it came out rather quickly. After the first bite I was in heaven! So delicious, the pork was so tender! Everything on the plate was incredible.
author: Jay L.

description: I came here by recommendation and was sorely disappointed by the complete lack of service. After waiting at the table for an excessive amount of time with no word from our server,  my dad had to get up And ask if we would be helped. Their response was that they'd have to see when someone would be able to handle our table. Was the food good? I'll never know and I'll never return to find out.
author: Lorraine T.

description:
Went there for lunch and it was wonderful!  I had the PASTELON - Sweet plantains layered with picadillo (spiced ground beef with olives, raisins, peppers and onions) and my friend had the CAMARONES A LA CRIOLLA (Sautéed shrimp in a fresh tomato, onion & sweet pepper cream sauce).  We both loved our dishes.  We got the spanish rice which had a nice flavor. I had the red beans and loved them.   I like how they added a small salad too with not too much dressing so it didn't take over the other wonderful flavors of the dish. 

Honestly, I had planned on putting half aside to eat later because for lunch, this was a lot of food but dang, I ate the whole thing!  My friend had the coconut flan for dessert & it was delicious as well.  Overall, a great value for the quality & amount of food you are getting. 

Very friendly staff and neat decor.  I like the choice of tables from high to regular.  The only reason I'm not giving it a 5 star is that it took a while to be served & get the check. They were very busy & there were only 2 women working.  They did a wonderful job & weren't ruffled at all.  I'll definitely be back!  What a great find!
author: Donna W.

description:
I am so hesitant to post this review because I want to keep Parada 22 all to myself! I don't want anybody to know just how amazingly delicious their food is!!!

Ok well the cat's out of the bag. I loooove Puerto Rican food and have been looking for a good place in the city. We drove all the way to San Rafael for Sol Food a couple of months back just to satisfy our need, but we don't want to to drive that far all the time. So happy Parada 22 is in the Haight, closer to where we live. 

First off, the place is so cute! It's small-ish. Maybe 10 tables? And a bar table along the wall for maybe 10 people, if one of the tables isn't free. As fas as I can tell everyone who worked there were Puerto Rican so yay points for authenticity. 

Food- we ordered the Sides Sampler (Pernil asado, chicharrón de pollo, maduros, yuca al mojo & tostones).. wowsers wowoweee everything was sooo good!!! Probably one of the best tostones ever. The pernil asado was like magic, so tender and melted in my mouth. The chicharron de pollo  was dang good. Of course I love maduros, and the yuca al mojo not only looked homestyle, it tasted like it too. You need to get this dish.. we shared it as appetizer, but you can prob make a meal out of it. For my main dish I had the Mofongo de Camarones (mashed plantains and shrimp).. another great tasting dish. It comes with either red or white beans, white or spanish rice, maduros and some leafy greens. My partner ordered the Pastelon, which is like  lasagna but made with sweet plantains. We have been searching for this dish all around the world LOL.. it's one of my favorite ever. And their version is excellent. A must try! Again it comes with beans, rice, maduros, and greens.

We arrived later for lunch and was lucky to be able to grab a table. There was a steady stream of customers while we were there so they get busy. No surprise here.. we'll be back.

PS.. just read some of the Yelpers and comment on service. We didn't have any problem with ours; it was fast friendly and efficient.
author: Vol T.

description: When I'm missing Puerto Rican food and there isn't time to make it at home, I like Parada 22. It's the best you can get in the bay area, the flavors are very close to the home cooked flavors of my Puerto Rican family. Order the pernil with the red beans and Mofongo. Delicious! It's a bonus that they have the homemade hot sauce at the tables, try the pique.
author: Jackie G.

description: Everything we had was the best! The flan was killer ... If your looking for killer Puerto Rican food.. This is the place!
author: Matt B.

description:
Scoutmob! 50% off dinner. Why not try right?
It was delicious! We had 3 plates of different kind of meats. One with steak, one with grilled chicken and a sampler plate. All were huge and yummy! All the meat was tender and not dry at all, which is a major PLUS! All the plates had plantains (those big sweet bananas) , salad and some kind of potato thing. My favorite thing I ate and will be goin back for more is the steak, and the fried chicken! the chicken was delicious from the flavor to the fact that it was boneless. 
All three plates came out to be only $19 with the discount! ALthough the discount will be expired soon, I would definitely come back and pay full price. 
FYI- the place is a bit small so don't come in big groups! You will wait forever!
author: Linda N.

description:
I'm dissapointed that it took me so long to eat here. It's a great addition to the neighborhood for sure. We went for Saturday late lunch and I fell in love instantly.

We spilt a pitcher of sangria. We ordered the chicharrones de pollo (amazingly tasty fried chicken) and the camarones in a cream sauce. The plates were filled with all kinds of goodes - rice, yummy white beans, salad, fried plantains.  All of it was awesome.

Ready to go back there again already!
author: Mac M.

description: Food was pretty good and worth comming here. I had the chicken salad and it was a nice and light meal. One of the best spots on Upper Haight St.
author: Heather W.

description: Came here for a friend's birthday dinner.  We were a group of about 14 people, and the staff was very accommodating to our large party, especially given the relative small size of their restaurant.  The biftec encebollado was flavorful and served with a side of beans.  I appreciated that the side was in a separate bowl from the meat.  The staff was super cool and took my friend next door for a birthday shot.  I'm sure they made her evening a memorable one!
author: Christina G.

description: Place is awesome second time here great service I would definitely come here again this place closes early around 10 but we got here at 9 and they still gave us service super awesome waitress this is definitely one of the best spots in San Francisco
author: elvis G.

description:
The food is great but the service needs work. 

The food especially the camarones was so incredibly good but the service was not that great. The waitress made a mistake on my order, the sangria was warm, I had to wave down the waitress to order and pay at the end. The worst part was when the waitress said she would go next door and tell me when there was an open table, which she said would be open in 20mins. An hour later, she never came and when I went to check the restaurant there were 3 tables open and a row of bar seats empty.
author: Michelle L.

description: In the tiny space formerly known as "all the burrito you can handle" (or Chabella's), is a gem with a quirky manager who is a lot of fun. The savory veggie plate was excellent and the sandwiches are a perfect meal. Add a Negro Modela or a sangria and you are good to go. It reminded us of some favorite little places in The East Village.
author: Helen K.

description:
The best in Puerto Rican cuisine in the city of San Francisco, for sure! The ambiance is great on Haight street and the food is always good. The servers are always great and the food is great. Usually get the Biftec Encebollado (steak with seasoned onions) which comes with a delicious salad, yellow rice, and white or red beans (I prefer the red which comes with diced ham). They serve Citrus Water.

My ONE complant: Why don't they serve Cafe Bustelo?! They have it as decoration. Sangria is great but people go nuts for coffee here. They should be sharing in the Cafe Bustelo flavor.

Overall, a great spot!
author: Austin P.

description:
Me and some friends stumbled upon this when cha cha's next door had a long wait. Small little place with a great atmosphere. limited menu, but AMAZING food. One of my friends with me that day is from Puerto Rico so we thought to put the food to the test. it passed with flying colors. 

I had the cuban sandwich and plantains, my friends an assortment of pork, cassava root salad and a chicken dish. All were absolutely delish! Ill definitely be frequenting this place more in the future.

Oh, and the prices are totally reasonable! not too often can you get a great meal for a deal.
author: Carlynn A.

description: Hands down, best pork I have ever had. Service was great and it seems like every time I get to this place I'm part of the last group to fill it up! Quick turn around on orders and it's worth it.
author: Grant B.

description:
Man oh man, that cook does wonders with simple ingredients, a grill press and a whole lot of Cuban soul! Parada 22 is not just one of the hundreds of nooks on Haight street. Specializing in Cuban staples, they don't use grease to make flavor, but a mix of marination, fresh meats and simple grilling to make tasty treats.

The space is small but a huge lofted ceiling gives an airy and light vibe. Cuban music is in the air and a dramatic photo mural accents one wall, while a pantry filled with old-school Cuban condiments coats the other. Someone thought about this space. The lawn style chairs weren't the most comfortable, but used the space to it's max. A small and exposed kitchen whipped up an amazing Cuban grilled chicken sand which with avocado and sauteed onions (pressed, of course) and a side of the boiled Yuca was amazing. My friend got a side of grilled plantains (a personal favorite), a bean soup, so filled with flavored chunks of meat and veggies, it was almost a meal in of it's self. The chicken was juicy, the spices subtle and on point, and the waitress, all smiles!

This place is a little gem!! I'd like to try some of their more complex entrees, but as lunch goes...this place was a hit!
author: Cameron B.

description:
A nice hole in the wall restaurant with friendly service and a nice, comfortable atmosphere. We went on a groupon and otherwise we would never have known about this little place.

I recommend the sampler for first timers as you get a bit of yucca, fried chicken, roasted pork, plantain, and this mashed, crispy, fried plantain. You can order a side of rice and beans as well. My favorite was the fried chicken, which I plan to get next time for sure. For dessert you MUST get the flan. It is AMAZING!

As for accessibility they've a small entry and slightly steep ramp. It wasn't so easy to get in and once inside don't expect to make many 360s. Maybe a well maneuvered 180 here and there. Their tables don't really let you pull up comfortably either but the larger table may work. Not for multiple wheelchair riders unless you're tiny. The food is great though, so order takeout. 

I definitely want to go back for more!
author: Kat W.

description:
Nice little gem in the Upper Haight. Good for a date or meeting with a friend.

The place is snuggled between Cha Cha Cha and some other building. Seating is limited, but doesn't feel cramped with the high ceilings. I've seen lines during their weekend brunch.

The Pernil Asado dish was amazing. I'm not usually a big fan of pork, but the meat was tender and juicy. 

They also have a good deal for the sampler platter. $6 during their happy hour.
author: Czar Y.

description:
Living in San Francisco I have learned two things; keys in a jacket pocket sound like loose change, and Parada 22 has the best sandwiches and sangria of all time. 

After my first bite of the Cubano Clasico I felt as if God had taken every kind, unnoticed deed I had ever done and turned it into the most delicious sandwich so that I could actually taste selflessness.   Holy exquisite melding of flavors!  There is the option to add avocado if you would like to, and while I do add avocado to almost everything, I suggest not doing it.  Why would you want to mess with perfection? However, you must get at least a half pitcher of Sangria. I have roughly the tolerance of a six foot 235 lb. man, and half a pitcher between 2 or even 3 people is more than enough.  It's strong and it's delectable.
 
I usually wander in at around 9pm on a Friday night and the place is always slammed.  It's already a cozy building, but filled to capacity, you're definitely making some new best friends or at least brushing shoulders, elbows, and knees with strangers.   Which is all the better because I like it when my dinner experience has that element of convergence.  

I always run into the same two women working the register and running the food, who are both amazing.  Last time I ended up waiting around 10 minutes for a table, a modest price to pay for sandwich ecstasy, and they brought my friend and me a glass of sangria, and even remembered me from a previous visit.  

The ambiance is charming; warm lighting, a cabinet filled with pictures and keepsakes from Puerto Rico, and the sounds of laughter and happy people enjoying their food.   

Parada 22 is absolutely stellar, and you would be remiss to not go and savor a meal here.
author: Kimberly L.

description:
We (my husband and I) came here a couple weeks ago on our quest to try 52 new places in 52 weeks. 

Why would you go to Cha Cha Cha if you could come here?! I honestly don't get it.
The portions were large and the beers were cold and you don't have to wait an HOUR for a table.

Also- I just found this out this week. Boogaloo's items are on their brunch menu :)
author: Melissa N.

description:
We tried this restaurant the last time we were in San Francisco and we were very, very satisfied.  The pictures on Yelp simply don't do it justice - while small, the decor is very pleasant and we were happy to get a table near the front windows.  Both entrees we had were excellent - well seasoned and delicious.  Portions are large and prices are quite reasonable.  Service is friendly.  

Highly recommended, will definitely return.
author: Randy R.

description: Sol food is by far the best puerto rican place in the bay, but when I can't trek up to Marin, Parada 22 is the place to go to. They have the main staples of puerto rican cuisine, and their pasteleon dish is my favorite. Postmates now delivers through them but their delivery charge is insane- $30+ just for delivery! Hoping they partner with door dash soon.
author: M M.

description:
Came here for dinner around 7:40pm Friday and it was pretty packed. Did not get a great first impression because it was hard to get anyone to notice you or seat you. We did not get any service until we walked up to the very front  and tried to talk to one of the waitresses. The waitresses were friendly, but not very attentive. This place has a homey atmosphere, with wooden tables/chairs and a lot of wall art...but I didn't really notice the decor until later because i was too caught up in trying to get the waitresses to notice ust. 

The food was good (though not mind blowing). I had the biftek (grilled steak) dish. The entree came with salad, rice (spanish or white rice), plantains (fried & sweet), beans (red beans that are cooked with ham OR white beans-vegetarian choice). The plate is 13 dollars. My friends had the pork leg and fried chicken..those were pretty good/flavorful compared to my beef. 

Out of everything in the plate, I like the plantains the most. It was warm,  crispy, and sweet...so good! Salad was fresh, the rice and beans were fine. They cooked their beans with vegetables/ham so it was probably better than beans you get elsewhere. However, the rice and beans I don't find anything too special about them in terms of taste...they were moist...so guess that part was good. The beef was a little tough, it was juicy enough...but tough. Tasted good with the onions on top,.but can't say it's awesome (it was a little on the bland side). Put the hot sauce on your steak!

One thing I like about the place is that they give you a pitcher of water with fresh orange/lime in it, it was great. My friend loved the water. 

After we were done, it took a while to get our check (a lot of waiting around and waitresses not noticing you at this place...). By the time we're done (around 8:30pm?) there was a 15-20 min wait for people who are coming in. 

Overall, good experience, but not awesome. Good dining atmosphere, but slow/inattentive service. Probably not a place for big groups because of the wait unless you come early (the place is small). Need to try their sangria next time.
author: Whitney W.

description:
Parada 22 no me decepciono. Soy borikua y les digo q  este pequeno lugar es FANTASTICO.   Tipica comida borikua.  
The mofongo con camarones.  Is superb. Amd i had the most tipical chicharrones de pollo con tostones y arroz con habichuelas blancas were perfect. 
Kristee attenion was excellent. A PR gem in SF 
Luved it
Rafa
author: Rafael R.

description: Parada 22 is phenomenal!  The place is small, so you may have to wait for a table or even share a long table with someone, but it is totally worth it.  I brought my folks here when they were visiting from out of town and now they want to go every time they are visiting SF.  The pork (pernil asado) is one of their popular and best dishes, but you should also try the Camarones a la criolla.  If this spot was closer to me, I'd be eating there all the time.
author: Lexi B.

description:
So. Damn. Good. Everything is homemade, super-fresh and super good. Tastes like your mom is in the kitchen, if your mom is Puerto Rican and an amazing cook. The red beans have so much flavor, I don't know why they are so much better than everyone else's red beans-- but they are. I get them all the time to go, just to keep them around. I'm addicted.

Another mystery- why are their fried plantains so good, too? I've never liked ordering plantains much because they're always greasy. But these aren't! They're perfectly cooked. 

Also, the owner is cool and friendly and takes really good care of you. She really cares about the food and the experience you're having, and it shows. Food this great at prices this cheap-- what's not to love?

Oh- and the fantastic BRUNCH is the best-kept secret in SF food. There, I let it out. You're welcome.
author: Mary B.

description: So happy to find a place my finicky Cuban husband enjoys! We started with the appetizer sampler, the pork was tender moist perfection, and the chicken was crisp and the maduras and tostones done right and hot. I had the best Cuban sandwich that I've tried outside of Florida. Most places in California leave out the roast pork, and make a glorified ham sandwich. Parada 22 does the real deal. We enjoyed the laid back ambiance and the friendly service. (far better then the noise and waits at Cha, Cha Cha's next door) We can't wait to go back!
author: Fleur R.

description: Always good food and great service.  Miss some of the soft drinks they used to have. Great place to enjoy with good company.
author: Carlos G.

description: Awesome Latin ambience and the food is perfect in every aspect. If you end your meal with a Caramel Flan you will be closer to heaven than you ever were! I'm definitely coming back!
author: Marc M.

description:
There are many foods I miss in SF like decent bagels, pastrami, and decent Puerto Rican food is pretty high on the list.

Like many places in San Francisco this place will satisfy your desire for the food without delivering exceptional food.

The food here is pretty basic and straight forward and not bad but it a pale imitation to the average Puerto Rican food you can find in NYC.

I've tried most of the menu and it's all pretty standard Puerto Rican inspired food, Some of it is better than others. The maduros aren't that good. The rice is good and considering how important the rice is that's a good thing. The Mofongo may not be your auntie's but it's not bad.

It's a small place and a bit on the cold side when I've been there. There weren't many vegetarian choices.  The prices are higher than they would be in NYC but in keeping with the prices in SF.
author: DeathandFood H.

description: No words can live up to the reality. Sweetest/cutest servers and AMAZING food. The coconut flan omg. Wilson was the best waiter! Go!
author: Missy B.

description:
The San Francisco restaurant scene is over-saturated. That is an understatement. I lived in SF for two years before I started to realize which restaurants I liked and which I didn't. And it really wasn't until I'd eaten at Parada 22 a few times before I realized: this was one of my favorite restaurants in the city.

Unassuming. Full but never too busy. High-end but not fancy or too expensive. If anything, Parada 22 is under-hyped, which in the city of San Francisco, is an almost unheardof development.

The best things at Parada 22 are the sides that come with every dish. Both the red and white beans are amazing. So are the rice and plantains. When half your plate is guaranteed to taste great, it's easier to try new things on the menu. (My favorite main dishes have all been chicken, but others have disagreed with me there.)
author: Zachary M.

description:
Having just moved to SF less than a year ago, I feel like there will never be enough time to try all the places that I want to eat.  

This place was good, but it was nothing spectacular.  Parking is difficult to find, although that's the case anywhere in the city.  The place is small, less than 15 tables, making the seating close to the door VERY cold.  

Prices were pretty standard.
author: Suzi F.

description: Friendly staff. Service is great. Plantains delicious.
author: John B.

description:
I have been to Puerto Rico, eaten on the side of the road, at fancy resorts, local strongholds and even braved the hole in the wall establishments there during my stay...I don't get scared easily and when it comes to dining in foreign countries, I never shy away from doing as the locals do. So I can say with confidence that my palate is pretty refined when it comes to Puerto Rican food. 

After having discovered Sol Food in San Rafael and remembered why I love Puerto Rican food, I have been on the hunt for a PR joint in SF that can rise to the occasion and battle Sol Food. Thanks to Living Social, I was introduced to Parada 22. 

Mind you, I usually mark places who get in on these coupon deals as struggling or a new place looking to get publicity and new customers. Thankfully, Parada 22 is new and did not fall into the struggling category (The established joints who need the living social's or groupon's of the world are almost always struggling due to SHIT service and even more clueless management who cannot for the life of them figure out how to fix the flow of the shit experience they offer- just sayin).

The waitress was so nice and very knowledgeable about the cuisine and menu, never spouting word for word explanations of the dishes or ingredients committed to memory from the menu. 

The food and service was better than expected and could even rival Sol Food. Because of this, I go back to this spot all the time and am happy to pay full price- I cannot say this has been the same experience I have had with other Coupon Deals. Now, when I go back, the waitresses remember me and even suggest new takes on dishes I have been ordering or a couple changes/additions they make to certain dishes etc. I love that personal feel...and when you are eating in a place that is as small as Parada 22, it is even more fitting when you feel like you know the peeps running the joint. I have tried everthing on the menu and everything is delicious...ok, all the meat options. I don't do veggie. 

The only reason they got 4/5 stars is because I long for Sol Foods pink beans and sauce in the bottle. Other than that, Parada a great place for a tasty meal at a decent price point.
author: Lucia V.

description: Been here several times.  Never been disappointed.  The food is great.  The service is thoughtful and kind.   The vibe is upbeat!   I'll definitely be back!
author: Charles H.

description:
I visited on a Saturday evening and the service was horrible. It was apparent that the employee neglecting me hated his/her job and would rather if the restaurant was empty all night so he/she could talk to her/his boyfriend. 

The food was good and I may be back in a few months as I assume this employee will have moved on, until then I'll wait for the tides to change.
author: Justin S.

description: I had the most wonderful lunch here.  Some sort of steak something or other.  The waitress was pleasant and helpful in helping me decide between the side dishes.  All I know is that the steak melted in my mouth and I was in heaven.  The only problem with this restaurant is that the menu is filled with good things and it is frustrating trying to narrow it down!
author: Vickie B.

description:
Out in the city on a date night with the BF we decided to try Parada 22
we both love Sol Food in San Rafael so why not Puerto Rican on a Friday?  We walked in and the place had a very cozy , I'm not using cozy lightly, feel it's no bigger than my living room but packed minus one open bar stool.  We waited a few minutes and a table opened up and we snagged it. The staff was very welcoming and attentive. 

I'm doing the vegan thing so I wasn't able to try the camarones but the BF loved that and the pollo salad and my veggie plate was yummy.  Plantanos (MY FAV), fresh green salad, check, I was disappointed that the spanish rice has pork in it so I had to settle for white rice (ick) but I enjoyed my meal. The little cup of habichuela blancas YUMMMMMMMMMO, I wish there was more of that and less of the yuca (potato (root) and onion dish).
author: Cianni E.

description:
This place is great! Really cool decor on the walls and the food is amazing!! I had the Pernil Asado and Tostones and it was really delectable. The pork fell of the bone so easily you could go in with a spoon and not struggle, the rice and beans was seasoned perfectly and just needed a splash of their house hot sauce ( the recipe of which I was unsuccessful at getting out of the super sweet waitress) They have a top notch selection of beers and a few other cool non alcoholic drinks.

All in all a great spot to grab some good food and drinks.
author: Tiffany K.

description: Came here on the first day that it opened and was digging the decor of randomness. Perfect for a spot in the middle of good ol' Haight Street! Though Puerto Rican, served Cuban pork and beans and a side of salad was decent enough, but I've never craved another sitting since...
author: Kaori T.

description:
Mmm, deliciously carmelized fried plantains. Need I say more?

Sunday evening, 5:15 p.m.. We ordered 4 dinner plates (which come with plenty of extras) for 3 hungry adults and 3 kids plus we drank 1 beer for each adult + 1 side order of extra plantains (because I have no self control when it comes to fried plantains) = $71 before tip. After dinner, we adults were each full but we just barely cleaned our plates. My vegetarian plate was tasty and my kid's fried chicken plate was extra hot (temperature wise) and extremely juicy. Because I don't choose to eat pork, I appreciated having our waitress tell us that we had a choice on the rice and beans between the pork rice and beans side and the non-pork choices.

I can't speak directly to the authenticity of whether the food was strictly Puerto Rican or not, because I've never been there. But having spent time eating more than my fair share of beans, rice and fried plantains in Spanish Harlem while I lived in New York City, I can definitely say this satisfied my craving for Caribbean-style food.

I will say that by the time we finished eating, the salivating folks waiting for a table were ready to snatch up ours. I can imagine they get very busy here!

Delicious food, coloring pages for the kids, attentive wait staff. I will definitely be back!
author: Susan L.

description: Those tostones knocked my calcetines off!!!
author: Ken W.

description:
I think it's about time I wrote a review for Parada 22. Puerto Rican food in San Francisco? Since moving to the Bay, I haze my boyfriend into trekking to Sol in San Rafael for my Borinquen fix. 

The first time I chanced a taste here, my skepticism could have flooded the tiny space twice over. Months later, I've gone here at least once every two weeks since moving to the Upper Haight and while your average neighborhood go-to spot is usually hit-or-miss, I can't stress how satisfying this food is here and you get your money's worth. I've sampled a pretty diverse range of their offerings including the Pernil Asado and Biftec Encebollado. The Camarones a la Criolla is so delicious! The mofongo is kick ass; packed with flavor. The spanish rice is the way to go. I also love the maduros; they are made exactly how I'd want them. The tostones are great; the dipping sauce is truly something special. 

I've never waited longer than 10 minutes for seating and I have gotten my noms on within an additional 15min every time. Still, I'd suggest avoiding this place 8p onwards on a Saturday. It's literally a hole-in-the-wall, however cute, so it can get cramped on a busy night. Good luck with a group at any time. There are only two or three larger tables so 4 or 5 folks might best be your max. Overall, the service is above average; they have even gone as far as to remember my name and are quite friendly and accommodating. 

Why four stars and not five? Every once in a while, something seems to be missing in the seasoning department. Usually when I've ordered for takeout. Not sure what that's about; completely remedied by the hot sauce in my cupboard though.
author: Aushlee C.

description:
HOLY MOLY. 

My first Puerto Rican food and I was definitely not disappointed.

The place is very small and crowded that's why I took a star down, but otherwise it would've been a 5!!! The tables were so close together that it felt like I was in a conversation with the group/s next to me. It was a bit uncomfortable because I constantly had to move my chair for someone, and I had to be aware that I'm giving the person behind me enough space for his chair, etc etc.

Moving on.. 
I honestly thought I would be disappointed, but I underestimated them.
I had the Biftec Encebollado with spanish rice instead of white and it came with beans, salad and maduros. PERFECTION. The salad was fresh, maduros were delicious and the spanish rice with the biftec were a scrumptious match. Everything was perfect. I didn't eat the beans though but I'm sure it would've been good as well. 
I was also able to try the Pollo a la Criolla from a friend's order, and guess what I'm going to order next time?

We left the place in shock cause we never had food THAT good and a bit sad, cause we finished our plates so fast and we wanted more. 

I recommended them to all my friends and if you are reading this review and wants to try and/or loves puerto rican food, get off your butt and head there now!
author: Dee Y.

description:
Got to know of this place through a groupon deal and now i am a fan! Why didnt we ever see this place while waiting in the frustrating line of cha cha cha?? Cha cha cha we go for sangria and cajun shrimp one in a while, but Parada22 is for the regular hearty home meal !!

I like this place for its simplicity and character. Interesting pictures on the walls. Its a small place with few tables, but service is quick. 

Each dish comes with rice,beans, plantains, and a little salad, so a great way to taste everything! The bean gravy is the best i ever had till date!!

I love my CHICHARRON DE POLLO! Its a plateful with 4-5 pieces of fried chicken, and everything else that comes along. 

Now I see no reason of going to the over hyped cha cha cha when there's this place with great food just next door!  I love such surprise discoveries - Calls for revisit!
author: Payal B.

description:
So after searching for a good Puerto Rican restaurant in the bay area I came across Parada 22 and let me tell this is the place to eat! came for dinner and we sat right down, Our server Kareen was excellent greated as soon as we walked in great customer service. 

We ordered the shrimp mofongo with Spanish rice and the pernil was not disappointed brought back memories of when I used to go visit family back at the island. Sangria is pretty good and of course I had to order my coco rico. 

I will defiantly be coming back again.
author: Artie T.

description:
I've probably passed by this place more than a handful of times during my treks down Haight Street, but for some reason never noticed it before- maybe it's trying to rush pass all the homeless/druggies/etc panhandling outside amoeba that I don't really notice any of those small stores on the block.

I must say that of all places I'm happy I discovered via ScoutMob, this would be it!

MOFONGOOO.  If you've never had it, I suggest you do (I popped my mofongo cherry here).  It's an explosion of flavors, best party ever in your mouth.  AND the prices are amazing for all the food you get.  

This place would definitely be at the top of my list of where to take an out-of-towner that doesn't want to spend too much $$$, wants something different, and likes good food.
author: Clarissa P.

description:
Excellente!
Good job with the restaurant guys! Im from Puerto Rico and so far this is the best puertorrican food I've tried in the Bay Area by far. Prices are really reasonable, the music is great, authentic PR music. The decoration of the place is also superb. Keep the good work and I wish you only the best.
author: Pedro R.

description:
This place is just amazing!

I love the environment, the service, and of course the food!!

I have been there like 5 times already and each of the meals I have got were memorable.  Words are not enough to describe the Latin American flavor.

By the way, music is also great!

My recommended dishes are mofongo (if you like seafood), vegetarian dish (beans are awesome), and flan for dessert.

Enjoy :)
author: Mr. M D.

description:
Delicious! Worth the trip/wait.  The Mofongo with Camarones is a must-have and a shoe-in for best dishes in town. Service was attentive and gracious. Cool under pressure as the place got packed and a line formed outside.
For those who know puerto rican food well I would suggest going with the white beans instead of the red. They tasted much more like the ones you would find in the island.
The maduros (sweet plantains) and tostones were cooked to perfection.
author: Karem P.

description:
A few months ago I moved into the Cole Valley neighborhood and started sampling the nearby restaurants.

By the second month I was fixated on Parada 22, specifically their fried chicken and their shrimp in cream sauce. It got pretty over the top for a stretch. My friend complained about a weeklong stretch where I IMed him precisely once a day with only the words "parada 22?" I began to obsess about regular status and it was one of the greatest days in my life when I no longer had to request my choice of red beans and spanish rice for the sides.

The fried chicken and the shrimp dishes are pretty much perfect products of a meal. I think I have basically alternated between them, favoring the shrimp, and probably had them literally dozens of times over the past few months. It feels confessional admitting it. I eat there alone a lot which helps mask my problem with my friends. My only worry is that I will burn out on these dishes, so recently I've been trying to pace myself but it's tough.

Writing this review is making me hungry.
author: Phillip R.

description: Came here on a whim after walking down Haight street. Checked and saw 4-stars on Yelp so we walked in. Ordered pretty quickly and didn't wait very long for the food. I can honestly say even if we had to wait the food it would be well worth it! My friends and I all ordered different items and each one of us was really happy! I had the Chicharrones de Pollo, we also had the Bistec Encebollado, Tostones and cleared every plate!!! Definitely something to try if you're in the area or even if you aren't!
author: Kori-ann K.

description:
I had the salad with marinated chicken, a side of spanish rice and maduros.

The salad and chicken were all tasty. Spanish rice was pretty authentic too. 

Maduros weren't very good. But when I informed the super friendly lady waitress, she took it off the bill. That's dope and it'll have me come back.

Coming from a girl who lived in Brooklyn and had access to West Indian, Caribbean and Puerto Rican food all the time, its a little pricy.
author: Valerie F.

description:
I had dinner there again tonight. Even better than the first time. I think I'm falling in love.

Ordered the sweet tea. Downed that shit before the food was even ready. And also stole some from my sister. Yep that good. 

Ordered the sauteed shrimp with the sweet pepper cream sauce. To die for. I ate every single thing on my plate. The salad, the red beans (ohmygawd the beans, and I hate beans) and the Spanish rice. Downed it in 5 mins. Not exaggerating. 
 Ordered the coconut flan, very sweet but melty like butta. Yammy! Haven't been so satisfied by a meal in a while. This place is a keeper.
author: Tutti C.

description: Delicious, filling food with lots of variety and great service in a charming restaurant.  We had an early, peaceful dinner with mofongo de camarones, a biftec sandwich and fresh squeezed lemonade.
author: Esther R.

description: Excelent restaurant. This is what Puerto Rican food really taste like. Highly recommended.
author: Dennis M.

description:
aY INFIERNO Sí (that's "oh hell yes!" in a literal Spanish translation)

Mofongo here is better than Sol Food in San Rafael and I thought they were 5 star quality.  

Both types of their plantains are quite solid here.  Spanish rice is packed with green olives, dishes are tasty but  can be heavy so don't get overly ambitious ordering.  

Food is authentic, nothing seems Americanized.   That said, there were lots of Latin folk here enjoying a Sunday dinner together, that's always a good sign :)

Thankfully, although a Sunday eve after the nuttiness of Outsidelands, it wasn't packed when we got there.  Out waitress said we had just missed the madness & thank God for that.  I'm not into waiting much.  We probably would have thought because the food proved to be worth it.  And I'm sure we would have a glass of sangria in hand if we did wait.

for those who care: One of the owners is no stranger to great restaurants (cha cha cha, boogaloos, the corner), and they've done this one just right. 

Highly recommended from the dormant Boriqua in me.
author: Athena S.

description: The "almost" daily special of pork, rice and eggs is so good.  Add the sweet and chewy plantains and it is one of my favorite meals.  The staff is nice.  Be aware, it is a small place so it can feel a bit crowded.  Best food in upper Haight.
author: Jim B.

description: My Puerto Rican wife took me there for our anniversary!  Great food, small portions but very filling!
author: Roger O.

description: Mediocre, decent food.  Nothing too special.  But bomb ass rice and beans!!
author: Nancy S.

description:
Ironically I just returned from Puerto Rico and my first meal back in SF was from Parada 22. My goodness -- I can honestly say this was up to par, if not better, than most of the food I had over there during my stay in San Juan.

I had the pleasure of trying many different types of Mofongo over there in Puerto Rico so I had to see what Parada 22 had to offer with their version. It looked very different than most I had tried in San Juan but the flavor here was off the charts! We also tried the spicey beef layered with sweet plantain. This was actually the first thing I ate in San Juan and I was not impressed at all. But Parada 22 made me rethink my thoughts and this is truly a brilliant culinary creaction.

For an appetizer we odered the tostones -- crunchy and sweet that was complimented by a wonderful dipping sauce. And after our amazing meal, we couldn't pass up the coconut flan. I'm not a fan of coconut, but this was a might tasy treat.

Can't wait to visit again to attack the rest of their menu :)
author: Sara K.

description:
WOW!

as a full blooded born Puerto Rican, gotta say, this place was having a taste of home!

I came here today and had the sampler appetizer platter: chicharones de pollo (amazing), pernil asado (a little tough, but savory taste..), tostones maduros y frito (veryyyyyyyy nice) and yucca al mojo (very good!)

and also split a Cuban sammich, which was sooo good! Staff was super friendly and everything was very well priced!
author: Carlos C.

description: A place to indulge in delicious Latin American comfort food.
author: Ernesto J.

description: We had a great experience at this place. It is small, but they accomodated a party of eight almost last minute. The staff was polite and got all of our orders correct. The food was excellent, I expected the appetizer to be a little bigger, but the serving size of the main dishes more than made up for this. Almost everyone got the Pernil Asado (marinated pork), which was excellent- not too many pieces of fat. The wife got the pastelon (think Puerto Rican lasagna using plantain and picadillo). This too was excellent, I may need to get this next time. I will definetly be back to try the other dishes, and for more of their Sangria.
author: Pachuco C.

description:
I've been to this restaurant three times!! I love the food--especially the avocado and yuca salad!!
It makes me happy, as the food they serve reminds me of peaceful times growing up in PR. There is also a little bit of a California fusion going which I definitelly approve of (btw--i am puertorrican) so I know Caribbean food. Thank you so much for this restaurant!! I love it!!
author: Minerva F.

description: I just finished dinner for my birthday and it was a terrific experience! Our server was super sweet and helped my friends out with ordering since it was our first time here. The sangrias are delicious and much better than the sangrias next door at Cha Cha Cha! The food was delicious and perfect for splitting between two ladies. The food was a bit salty, but all around very yummy--especially the Spanish rice! I had the steak with carmelized onions and it was so good! I dined with 4 people and we split two flans and they were delicious. There was a candle on one and the entire restaurant sang (loudly and cheerfully) happy birthday to me. Both flans were on the house which was a nice surprise. It was a great dinner and this is a great place!
author: Allison S.

description:
I've been to 2 Puerto Rican restaurants in the Bay Area and this is my 2nd favorite. (#1 is Sol Cafe in San Rafael.) Every dish I've had at Parada has been very good, or as my Borriqua boyfriend would say, "muy criolla". The Biftec Encebollado (grilled steak with onions), Pastelon (sweet plantains with ground beef), Pollo a la Criolla (chicken with ham sofrito), Pernil Asado (roasted pork leg) have all been excellent. The sides of white or red beans and mixed greens are delicious as well. Order a side of tostones (fried green plantains) to share with a pitcher of sangria, and taste some authentic Puerto Rican dishes.

Either for weekend brunch or weekday dinner, this is a casual, neighborhood place to go.
author: Susan H.

description:
Let me explain the awesome customer service here at this restaurant. We walked in to the half full restaurant and were greeted and seated immediately.  The gentleman who was serving us was also serving the rest of the restaurant. My friend so badly wanted to try Chicharrones de Pollo but my friend absolutely HATES cilantro and since most of the items on the menu are marinated in cilatro, it was hard for him to get it with out. The server kindly found out every angle in which my friend would be happy without cilantro. Talk about going above and beyond!!  As for me, I had the shrimp dish and it was just fantastic.

Great job guys!
author: Ezequiel R.

description: Great food..  closes in the bay area to Puerto rican food . . Great flavor in small space .. got the biftec sirlion..
author: Miguel P.

description:
Went her with a friend for lunch.

The portions were really generous and the food was delicious.

I got a dish that was ground beef layered between fried plantains (called postalon or something).

My friend got the Mofongo.

Both dishes were delicious and were accompanied by rice, beans, and salad.

Will definitely come back here,  I think I like it better than Sol Food in San Rafael.

2 entrees and 2 soft drinks was ~$27 - great value.
author: Joseph H.

description:
I read ahead and was prepared for a wait. After a short wait, we were seated and after another wait I began to wonder if we were ever going to get menus. It was packed and there was one waitress for the entire place-- but once that was done, it was all goodness.

We saw that the people next to us were sharing some sangria so we decided to go for that. After glancing at the prices, I began to have second thoughts. It was over $20 for a pitcher of sangria so we opted for the half-pitcher ($12). When it came to the table we were surprised to find a full small-size pitcher of sangria. I had seen the smaller pitcher at other tables and thought this was the size of a full-pitcher. I'm glad we went with the half because for two people it was plenty, it was good, and it was STRONG.   

Foodwise- Yes, yes, and YES!! We split a Pernil Asado (roasted pork) and something from the specials menu that was beef layered with plantains. Both came with salad, rice (we opted for Spanish rice), and beans (red beans for us omnivores. White beans available for vegetarians). The pernil asado came also came with plantains. Both dishes were fantastic, with the special beef-plantain-layered thing holding a slight edge.

My assessment: The food bears a mysterious lip-smacking I-can't-believe-I-ate-a-whole-plate --ness (You can't stop eating!) that reminds me of the Caribbean but without the humidity.

In short: Have some patience, get the sangria, trust the specials, and enjoy the Caribbean without the humidity
author: Loli L.

description: This Puerto Rican restaurant is great good food and service they really want to make you're dinning experience the best !
author: Alex A.

description: The food was excellent, I had the pork and my wife the onion steak both of he very flavorful. Not only the meats tasted well, the rise (yellow), plantains and the side of tostones were delicious. I will definitely repeat in the future.
author: Manuel P.

description:
Date night! I ordered the Camarones a la Criolla which was basically shrimp sauteed in a fresh tomato, onion, and sweet pepper creamy white sauce...i'm in love. 

The only downfall is that the rice was not cooked to perfection, but the taste of the food overshadowed that small disappointment. 

They give you a choice of red beans (cooked with ham) or white (vegetarian). I got the white beans and they were ohhh soo good, there were chunks of potato and what not, I would've ate them with just rice alone and been happy.

My husband enjoyed his "bistec" meal also. Everything came out in about 10 minutes which is always nice when you're starving..Sweet tea, not that great, not that sweet. My dish was still so good, that I have to give it four stars, it would be wrong not to. Sooooo this concludes my review, in the words of The Terminator , "I'LL BE BACK".
author: Brandi W.

description: Adorable little hole in the wall Puerto Rican restaurant with authentic decor. Prices were very reasonable, friendly waitstaff, and the food was delicious and well-portioned. No complaints and excellent first Puerto Rican food experience.
author: Keren S.

description: What a great experience! Cute restaurant on Haight St... apparently it has been around for a while! I'm so glad my sis scored a sweet livingsocial coupon and hit me up for lunch at this place. Our waitress was very friendly, and made fantastic recommendations. We ordered the Mofongo (green plaintans mashed with sofrito served with camarones a la criolla) and the Pastelon (sweet plaintains layered with picadillo). Wow was I impressed with these dishes, both so unique and exploding with flavor. Parada 22 definitely got me hooked on Puerto Rican food.
author: Elaine N.

description: Food is pretty good but I hope they reconsider charging ~$12 for the vegetarian plate when it's 80% disgusting flavorless yuca. Eeew. Just take the bus up to San Rafael and hit up Sol Food instead...
author: Hannah B.

description:
We were really happy here, loving the cramped, too-small atmosphere, great soundtrack, etc. 

Great: Chicharrones pollo. A bittoo salty, but otherwise the most flavorful fried chicken ever. 

Good: Pork. Just cooked pork shoulder, no seasoning. Too much connective tissue to work around. This dish really should have been better. 

Great sides: Salad, both kinds of plantains, Spanish rice, beans. 

Sangria was very good, not too sweet. Great coconut flan.
author: Todd H.

description:
I've come here twice using Scoutmob, and I've left happy both times.  I haven't had Puerto Rican food much, and this restaurant in the Haight is a bit far away, but it is definitely worth a stop.  They serve quality food at affordable prices.

If you're not sure what you want, I recommend starting with the Sampler Platter, which comes with both the sweet and salty plantains, yucca, pernil asado, chicharron, and a mixed green salad.  It is a good amount of food for $11.  I liked all of the individual items that were included.  My only complaint would be that the pernil asado can be a bit dry, but the meat's flavor was very good.  The chicarron was crispy, garlicky, and delicious.  And I loved the sweet plantains, but I think it would be hard to mess those up.

Of the entrees, I've tried the sauteed steak, the mofongo, and a sauteed chicken special in a tomato sauce.  Each entree comes with a mixed green salad, a choice of white or red beans, white or spanish rice,and the sweet plantains. The portions are definitely very big.  For $11 or so, I think that the steak is a great deal.  It was cooked well and the texture and flavor were both excellent.  The mofongo (mashed green plantains and shrimp) was different from anything I've had before, and while it was good, I thought that it was a bit heavy because it was so starchy.  Finally, the chicken entree was savory, but extremely salty, so I wouldn't order that again.  Of the beans, the white one tastes like a salsa/soup whereas the red one tastes like a chili (I prefer the white).  The salad is good and the spanish rice balances out the meal.

Service was mixed.  It was good the first time I went, but they didn't really come over to check up on us or refill our water on my second visit (different waitress).  Overall though, this restaurant serves good food at decent prices.  With the scoutmob coupon of 50% off, it was definitely a steal!
author: Tyler C.

description:
Until Parada 22, I was unaware that Puerto Rician restaurants existed.  This place is fantastic, great food and great prices.  Even better, they marked everything on the menu that was vegan, and helped me with my selection.

I came here with my friend and we split the veggie plate, and the two plantain appetizers.  Everything was amazing.  The veggie dish had some yuca dish, plantain, salad, rice, white bean dish.  It was delicious, and more then enough for both of us.  

My favorite thing here was the fried plantain appetizer, it was amazing, and I couldn't even tell it was made from plantain, it was like a huge french fry...so freaking good. 

The place is pretty small, but we didn't' have an issue getting a seat at around 830. If you have a larger party though, it could be a problem.  The service was great, and everyone working was friendly.

The best part our bill was only $22, and I left feeling more then full.

Way to go parada22 I will come back and recommend everyone go!
author: Courtney R.

description:
Hola! Parada 22 was my first foray into Puerto Rican food. I saw a deal on GrubHub for 50% off so I decided to finally try it out. It's a moderate small place, it was packed and we were lucky to find one small table in the corner.

There was one waitress serving everyone so she understandably took awhile get to us. Once she made it she was wonderful. 

Since it was our first time we asked for a recommendation which is what lead us to try the Pollo a la Criolla (12.00) and the Plato Vegetariano (11.00). The Plato Vegetariano was mine and came with a nice salad, Spanish rice, red beans, fried bananas, yuca & maduros. The yuca and maduros were probably the least impressive. The yucca was too starchy for my taste. The rice and the beans were fantastic and the salad had a nice dressing.   

The real winner of the meal, and the reason why I would come back to this place, was the Pollo a la Criolla. It had the same fried bananas, same Spanish rice, same salads but replaces the yucca with a sautéed chicken thighs covered in chunky sofrito sauce (which is like cooked fresh salsa with bell peppers and other goodies). The spice and flavor was fantastic!

It was F'ing goo! I would have personally wanted that whole meal wrapped up in a burrito and would want to order it at 2 in the morning right after I leave the clubs in a drunken hungry state. 

¡salud!
author: Nik B.

description:
I would give this place a 4-star if they didn't have horrible service.

My boyfriend and I went there at prime dinner time so the wait was expected. We left our names on the counter and went outside to wait because the restaurant is so very small and packed. We waited for about half an hour, finally a waitress comes out and acknowledges us and another couple and said "two tables will clear up in about 5 minutes." She sat the other couple first, we waited for another 15 minutes outside, no tables or whatever. Another couple just walked in and got seated. The couple that was seated earlier stood up and left because they were ignored, and we thought "oh, there's our table." But NOPE, the waitress moved another party of two that was sitting at the bar-like tables and sat them there. We finally figured that maybe she had forgotten about us, and it was confirmed with the look on her face when she saw us waiting inside instead. So, she made room at  the ends of the long table (that another party was occupying) to seat us.

Service aside, the food was pretty good. The Biftec Encebollado consists of very flavorful sautéed steak and onions, although the meat was a bit too chewy. The mofongo was all the hype that I read; savory flavors and large shrimps, but whatever that was under the shrimps and onions were very salty. We had the coconut flan to-go and that was very good as well. The texture was kind of like a hybrid of pudding and custard.

P.S. I personally liked (*gasp!* coming from a person who doesn't like beans) the white beans better, it had more flavor than the red beans.
author: Annie C.

description:
One of the best places I've been to for Puerto Rican food. The staff is friendly and welcoming. Although a bit on the small side, the restaurant is comfortable and the ambiance perfect with black and white films showing on a small flatscreen against the brick wall. Pictures and trinkets adorn the cabinets...

Oh yeah, the food, you ask? 

If you visit Parada 22, you will find yourself enamored with the food. There's just enough salt, pepper, and spice to provide you with a pleasurable taste sensations but there's hot sauce on the table if you need it. At first glance, when we received our food, I wondered if it would be enough because the presentation is clean and the food just looks too perfect. However, once you take a bite and start devouring the plantains, the Spanish rice, the mofongo, and guzzle all the delicious food down with a Citrus mint drink, you will be full for the rest of the day (and very content). Oh, and about the Citrus Mint, you'll just have to go there to experience it. ;)
author: Dorothy S.

description: My wife and I stopped by after having a photo shoot in the presidio (China beach) we usually go to sol in San Rafael. This place had a better feeling of authenticity of Puerto Rico and the staff was great and gave above and beyond service. Now the mofongo was delicious and the sampler platter was great also. The rice had (pegow) Puerto Ricans know about that. I was surprised because they don't even give it to you at a San Juan Puerto Rico restaurant. Anyway well be back!
author: Ruben S.

description: I definitely recommend this restaurant ! It was the first time I ate cuban food and love it . The atmosphere is also really cool .
author: Charles D.

description: This place is a hidden gem in the Haight. We brought the Moms here for mothers day as a surprise. It is definitely a small place, but that is the charm to this cute hidden gem. I ordered the  Chicharrones Pollo dish (crispy chicken bites, arroz, beans, plaintains) I love the spices that they used for this dish which made it unique. The special sauce on the table you use to drizzle on everything is just amazing! I noticed many people were walking in to pick up their call in orders, so if you do not feel like waiting, then call in your order. My family thoroughly enjoyed their meal and decided they were all fans of Puerto Rican food and will now stalk any Puerto Rican restaurants!
author: Jennifer A.

description:
Ever get tired of potato? Not ME!!!.....but  I've recently encountered some great alternatives-YUCA-Cassava AND PLANTAIN!! 

As a newbie for Puerto Rican food, I decided to give the sampler a shot. It came with little bit of everything I enjoy eating. The chicharon pollo tender was moist, crispy and deliciously seasoned, yuca was not starchy dry but very simple and tasty, maduros has just the right amount of sweetness, fried savory plantains hit the spot and the pernil asada was the ONLY slightly disappointing sample in the sampler, YUP, on the dry side. Hey, but if you dip it in their special sauce, VOILA, pork has been SAVED, giving it a nice kick!!! WOoHOO!!

Sangria and Cuban sandwich was also GREAT!!
Service: EXCELLENT, much kudos for our waitress who was very attentive--my paper water cup was always full! 

I'm already thinking of going back to try their other dishes!! =)
author: Leeseuh K.

description:
Mighty, mighty tasty, although perhaps not the greatest for vegetarians. They do have vegetarian options for sandwiches and plates, both of which are delicious, but the authenticity of the Puerto Rican food doesn't lend much to vegetarian dining. I think for meat-eaters, this place is probably heaven.

I will say that the flavors were very well balanced and enticing, and that a lot of care was put into making the food. As a vegetarian though, and for the sake of an honest review, I may not go back because the veggie plate I had was a bit forgettable.
author: Jen N.

description: This is some NEXT LEVEL Puerto Rican food. I am from LA area and am no stranger to maduros and Latin slow roasted pork, but this place was INCREDIBLE!
