I got the pernil asado and was amazed by the tender pork (served with a delicious salad!) and uniquely delicious red kidney beans. To top off the experience, All the entrees were under $12 and the atmosphere was adorable....I will be back!!!
author: Hana L.

description:
Had the Camarones a la Criolla. I really liked it though I don't believe I've had puerto rican food before. I really liked the Spanish rice esp mixed with the sauce from the shrimp. The red beans as a side is much better than the white because it's cooked with ham (or bacon?) where the white beans with vegetable stock. Even the salad was good!

Service was kinda slow because there was only 1 waitress and it started getting more busy as we ate.

Though I can't say the food would be something I'd crave normally.
author: Jenny C.

description: A very good Puerto Rican restaurant for this area. The portions are decent, friendly service and the prices are good. If they stepped up their beer offerings it would change the world.
author: haggeo r.

description:
The Haight has a pretty terrible assortment of restaurants, so it didn't take long for my partner and I to spot this gem amongst the dross of this thoroughfare. We've been here twice in less than a week and will be back soon.

We were greeted by everyone behind the counter with smiles and shouts above the dining noise--a touch reminiscent of home.  We snagged the high-top table in the nook by the window, which is easily the best seat in the house. The exposed brick and turquoise wall aesthetic is exuberant and inviting, and the island flair is fitting and authentic.  The servers are friendly and knowledgeable, and do not leave you hanging.

The sangria is served in a massive pitcher with NO ICE--an incredible delight at $22. Although only a minimal amount of additional alcohol, it is certainly worth the money. The entree portions are solid, and include a side salad, fried plantains, choice of rice and beans. The Spanish rice and red beans both hide succulent pork pieces--woohoo! We had the Pollo Encebollado, Pernil Asado, and Pastelon between our two visits, all of which were excellent. The pork was tender and juicy, the ground beef sweet and moist. 

Overall this place has a cozy and inviting atmosphere, the people put you at ease, and the food is priced well, plentiful and satisfying.  Go here soon and often.
author: Justin M.

description: Tried the pork with the white beans...quite tasty!  Looking forward to the chicken with the red beans next time.
author: Michael L.

description:
Mmmmmm!  Had lunch here with my girlfriend today.  I had Pastalon, which was layers of sweet plantains with ground beef - absolutely delish and everything was at a reasonable price.  My friend had a shrimp dish which she devoured.  We shared a pitcher of ice cold sangria.  

A good place for small groups, like 2 or 3.  There aren't a lot of tables, and I imagine on weekends the place is crowded.
author: Patricia K.

description: Great food and service. Wait was not that bad considering the location. I would definitely go back.  It's  a great spot with interesting random stuff on their walls, but it's quite small.
author: Derik D.

description: Really good. I ate here twice when they first opened up. The food was always good but the portions seemed small for the price. I'd get an entree and still be hungry. been back a few more times lately and the portions are bigger. I'm good with just an entree, not stuffed but good. The pork and chicken are both really good, the beans are great too.
author: DJ Madison H.

description: This is legit Puerto Rican food. Probably the best in San Francisco. Small interior but great stuff.
author: Rich M.

description:
So far, still my choice for the best cubano.  had one today with chorizo; so the style is different, but there is always much to enjoy in a good cubano. 

Friendly, fun staff. Definitely a good choice in the upper haight
author: Steve Obama L.

description:
This wonderful lil spot is so freakin' awesome.
I love the inside. I like the food. The service is a little more casual and a teensy weensy bit slow. And still 4 stars because the rice and beans and pernil were so yummy, especially with plantains. Yum.
The coconut flan was pretty delicious. Dreaming about it as I type.
My date, who was not on the menu, was pretty damn fine too. So it made it all extra dynamite, does anyone still say dynamite?!

Yeah, go. I mean do, because then it might become too over-run with everyone.
author: Violet J.

description:
So happy to have finally try this place after walking past it so many times.  My hubby and I arrived at 8pm on a Saturday night and were seated right away.  Shortly after we sat down,  the place filled up pretty quickly because it is small, they don't take reservation, and you just simply got to be there at right time to get seated as quickly as we did.   There's only one girl running the dining room and cash register who excelled at providing great friendly service even when it got really busy.

I ordered the Pollo a la Criolla with white beans and white rice.  Chicken was very moist and tender and had this wonderful chunky broth sauce on top.  I also really enjoyed the salad, beans, and rice that came with it.  So much food per dish!

He ordered the Pernil Asado with red beans and spanish rice.  This slow roasted pork dish was very tender and flavorful in most parts.  But there parts that were a bit less tender.  He enjoyed the red beans and spanish rice, although I thought the spanish rice was a bit bland. Overall, plenty of food for the cost. 

We ended our meal by splitting the rum cake.  For $3 bucks, we got a 3x3 square cake that was not over sweet or syrupy.  It was a tasty end!

Next time, I would love to try the Chicharron De Pollo (breaded/ fried chicken goodness) because it looked sooooo good as I watch the server bring it out to several tables in restaurant.  

Some improvements that could be made:
1. An updated online menu because the current one is a bit outdated.
2. Consider laminating your paper menus because there were some nasty ones that the server had to filter through so that we view clean copies of the menu.
3.  It would be nice if you'd offer free refills on sodas & sweet tea.
author: Aimey T.

description: This is one of my absolute favorite restaurants! My boyfriend and I love going here when we're in the city.  The food doesn't get much better than this. If you're not sure what to get and you want a little of everything, go with the sampler.  I order the sampler as my entree every time and it never disappoints.  Their sangria is quite nice too! When you're done with dinner, you can check out the many things around in the Haight.
author: Kim O.

description: i love this place so much. I tell all my friends about it and make a Parada 22 lover easily. Their dishes are all worth trying.
author: Carolina A.

description: Quaint, small, get crowded quickly, but worth it.  The food is basic, but seem authentic.  Fried plantain chips/patties are my favorite.  Although there was one or two large tables, most of the tables are small.  If you have a large group, you might have to come early and wait for the tables.  They have a small kitchen and small staff, so don't expect food to arrive quickly.
author: Duke D.

description:
First off, I just want to say THANKS to the awful date I went on. Had it not been for this douche, I'd never know about this place. What can I say, a tip on good food makes ANY bad date manageable.

This place has changed a bit since the first time I went here. They now take cards and it's a sit-down place with a slightly different menu. My partner and I went here on a Saturday night and it was packed. We ordered the mofongo and the combination appetizer. Both were fantastic. Ahem. Don't forget the coconut flan. It totally completes the meal!
author: Joanne R.

description: I'm from the Virgin Islands (basically next door to Puerto Rico), so I was thrilled to discover this spot. Chill ambience, and so many good vegetarian options! The berenjena (veggie) sandwich is out of this world; so hearty and flavorful! The tostones, maduros, and habichuelas blancas are all delicious. The sangria is potent and delicious, and I believe identical to that of Cha Cha Cha next door. The only dish that disappointed me was the yuca al mojo... very bland, extra disappointing since it takes up most of the vegetarian plate. For the meat eaters out there, my carnivorous brother and boyfriend both adore biftec (steak) sandwich.
author: Elizabeth N.

description:
Tried this place for the first time last night and i have to say , Yay! I'm a fan. I ordered the Cuban sandwich which was good with the well dressed salad. My girlfriend got the chicken with the carmalized onions, spanish rice , white beans and plantains.

  I would def come back to order the fried chicken with the Tostones and salsa rosa
dipping sauce !
author: Michael T.

description:
A solid 3.5 with some room for growth!

Being a major fan of Sol Food in Marin, it's hard not to compare the two, but Parada
does a good job at holding its ground. Dishes range between 8-$11, which is more
than reasonable for a combo plate of fresh food in the city. 
My Pollo a la Criolla was yummy, although the chicken was slightly crispy from the grilling,
and I wished it had been 2 thicker slices vs the 3 thinner ones that I got. No real complaints though,
just a personal preference. The tiny cup of pink beans were delicious and had really good
flavour.. perhaps spiced with some vinegar and olive juice. Also, the plantains were different
from the ones I've had before. They were neither sweet nor salty.. it seemed like they were simply grilled on a pan.
so the outside was a tiny bit hard/crisp and the inside was soft. Really liked that texture!
The salad had some light creamy dressing on it that I didn't particularly care for,
I feel like it would have been best with just some simple vinaigrette or lemon. 

Service was REALLY good for being run by one single lady during lunch hours.
Family-style seating always seems to throw people off, so it was nice to see some
2-person tables along the sides. Definitely a good lunch option and my friend's 
shrimp dish looked really good with all that sauce on it! Will come again!
author: Jade T.

description: Small place good food, good ambience = I am a fan
author: Milana R.

description: Came for a snack with my Puerto Rican GF. Decent PR food although slightly on the bland side. Had the sampler plate and a sweet tea/lemonade drink (see my tip). The marinated pork was tasty, chicken tenders were slightly on the dry side. I would give it a try again but unfortunately nothing to rave about. Great service and they did a cool job with the decor (turquoise cabinets give it a comforting feel). Next time I'll try a dinner meal but the sampler plate was so-so.
author: Nathan R.

description: One of my new favorite restaurants in the city. The food is fresh and delicious, the service is great, the staff is friendly and I've tried almost everything, and it's all great. Try the Biftec or the Pork. So good.Definitely one of the more underrated spots around.
author: J P.

description:
Water. They used a paper party cup for it lol. 

Pernil Asado. Roasted Pork marinated with Garlic and Oregano-based Sofrito. Served with Rice, Pinto Beans, Salad and Plantains. The rice, salad and beans were damn good. The beans reminded me of a vegetarian chili. OM NOM NOM NOM. The pork was alright, I guess I have a thing about not completely liking meat that's stringy. I mean I'll eat it but I prefer my protein picks to be silky smooth. The flavors of it were pretty damn good though.

Plantains. With Salad. OM NOM NOM NOM. I love me some plantains. And their salad was damn good too. Yummy, fresh veggies!

Pastalone. Sweet plantains layered with Beef. Served with Rice, Salad, Beans and Maduros. This was really similar to lasagna just without loads of cheese on it. It was pretty good though, very interesting and well seasoned. The beans my friend got, I can't remember what type of beans they were (I want to say white beans though) but it tasted more like tomato soup. 

They were pretty good. Me and my friend had a Scoutmob so our bill was 50% off and ended up only being around $9 each. It was worth it at that price, we were both so stuffed we couldn't finish everything.
author: Constance C.

description:
My family and I have been coming to this place since they opened. 
We have seen the evolution of their menu and have enjoyed the Boogaloo pop up they did for a while. 
The food has gone form good to ok and then back to good. 
The reason for a 2 star review:  the service. 
Most of the time we are treated with respect and are taken care of in a reasonable maner. This past Sunday however was a drastic failure in service. 
My sister, brother, 3 year old daughter, 7 week old son and I attempted to eat here.  I had the tandem stroller which is a bit long. 
I know this place is fairly small so i knew i would have to park the stroller in the most out of the way location. Keep in mind that this was NOT rush hour, it was mid afternoon (2pm) . The place had plenty of of open seating, there were only 7 people in the restaurant.  
So i proceeded to park the stroller in the corner, when the person behind the counter said no.  We then suggested to use the center table which had plenty of chairs, he said no. Then he asked us to sit at the table right in front of the cashier where there was already another family seated, with only 3 seats open, and park the stroller next to the table, so it left one person without a seat. 
We started to sit, and then saw that it would not work.  All this guy said was:  if you sit in the middle you will kill me....  meaning his service....  well his attitude killed the service.   
So at looking at this, we packed out stuff and left to have a much more pleasant lunch down the street. 

So if you got kids with you, STAY away from here.  I love supporting my local places, but won't do it when the service is this bad.
author: Rodrigo L.

description: OMG! That was amazing food bar none. I finished my plate and ate off others. Great hole in the wall atmosphere. Music. And good service. Loved! So glad we found it!
author: Melissa E.

description:
This place is just OK. Definitely not worth it at full price. 

The Yucca was very dry and hard inside. The plantains weren't cooked that well. The quality of the greens was not as bad as your typical fast food joint but not much better, either. The "vegetarian options" are incredibly bland. (white rice & white beans) 

I would not recommend this place to anybody because it's way overpriced for what you get. The service is not good, but it's not the servers fault. She has to tend to all the tables and she also seemed quite busy in the kitchen area at the same time. 

Expensive drinks on an expensive bill served in cheap paper cups? At least let me feel like I am getting something for my money...  

2 vegetarian plates, 1 citrus mint drink, 1 sweet tea came to $32 after tax & tip, before groupon. Have a scoutmob here as well, but I don't think we'll be back to use it.
author: aaron f.

description: Well, with this many reviews, no one really needs mine.  And yet, I persist.   Love it, love it , love it.  I am lucky enough to have a schedule where I can go for lunch on a weekday and always get a seat.  I have never been disappointed.  I was led to this place by vegetarians but I never go for the vegetarian options because the meaty stuff is so great.  I've had the pollo encebollado, camarones and the pork -- something  pernil -- Asado perni?  Whatever it is, it is so tender.  The portions are generous and I always have leftovers.  The decor is a walk down memory lane from when I lived in Hoboken and New York City in the late 80's.
author: Renee C.

description: Definitely a fan of this place!!! I had the Pollo Encebollado plate very good tasting and I really loved the Tostones there!!! I have already gone back a few times an will continue to do so!!! =0)
author: Anthoníí M.

description:
This place started out all bad. I rarely bad mouth the working joe cuz I used to work for tips and I know it can be tough, especially when its busy, but this time it got to me cuz it was really avoidable. 

My girl and I got there and all the tables were full. No problem. Hostess greeted us and said we would get the next table. We're the only ones waiting for a table at this point. Few minutes later another couple comes in, two chicks, not cute, at least nowhere as cute as me and my old lady. Hostess acknowledges them, tells them it will be a few. Table opens up and we are waiting for the hostess to clear it as the two non-cute girls ask if they can sit there and the hostess says yes. Strike one. I was annoyed but wasnt that bent out of shape cuz another table was opening up while this was going on. We get our table maybe 30 seconds later. So now were waiting to order. Another couple comes in, cuter than the girls but dressed like douche bags. They get a table. Now this is the part that finally made me decide to bad mouth the service, the hostess who is apparently the hostess /waitress /busboy /bartender, takes the two chicks orders, than the douchey couples orders, than after putting their food and drink orders in, comes to our table. Straight BS. Common courtesy and good customer service to take care of us first. Oh well. Food was awesome though, I had the pork and my girl had the steak. Pork was good but my girls steak was killer. Good food, good price. They just need more staff instead of making one person handle everything outside of the kitchen. Super cheap, $36 for sangria and dinner for both of us. Four stars even with the poor service.  

The Neighborhood- I'm comfortable walking in ANY part of the city, but these Haight St. Dorks really bring the neighborhood down. These motherf***ers are ridiculous. I do not fear or loathe entering and walking around any district in San Francisco.  I can, and have, carried a conversation or shared a laugh with every walk of life in this city. I've joked with drug dealers, dope fiends, socialites, hookers, politicians,  business owners, gangsters, the homeless,  blue collar workers and straight killers, for real. I get along with EVERYBODY, but these fools on Haight St. drive me crazy. Most of them are from out of state, most of them are white, most of them have homes/money/support and family that care about them back in whatever state they are from, but they choose to roam around Haight St. begging for money, talking sh*t about people that wont give them a handout, talking sh*t and yelling at people who actually work for their money. Towing around their dogs who I'm sure wish their owner wasnt some dirty out of state wanna be hippie love child. 

Random kid in Utah, "What's that Mom? You say I can live here at home and you'll help me out with college tuition while I work part time and go to school? No thanks, I'm going to San Francisco with my friend Lief, and we're going to grow blonde dreadlocks that hang to our knees, kidnap a dog, sleep in Golden Gate Park, bathe in Stow Lake, then wander up and down Haight St. all day, smoking weed and shooting heroin now and then. Tell Dad I appreciate the offer though! Bye Mom, I'll send you a picture of my staph infection in a few weeks, please forward my mail to the San Francisco Needle Exchange. Love Ya!"
author: Brian R.

description:
This is a great alternative to next door's ChaChaCha if you want a quick(er) meal and don't have that extra hour to wait for a table.  We thought it was smart for a similar restaurant to open up right next door to Cha x3 since they'd be sure to take some of their customers, but we were pleasantly surprised to find out that they're owned by the same owner.

We had a pitcher of sangria that was as fab as next door's.  Among our group, we were ordered the (1) pernil asado- (shredded roasted pork) pork was tasty but a bit dry, could have used some sort of sauce to accompany it, (2) chicharron de pollo (fried chicken)- this was regular ol' chicken strips, perhaps a little kick in the marinade could've spicened it up, and (3) Pastalon- a delicious ground beef dish with fried bananas and a yummy sauce on top-- this was my fave of all the dishes, the sauce was so tasty and the meat toppled with the bananas was perfect.  I will def get this next time, along with the spanish rice.

Overall we had a good experience-- we were hungry and didn't care to wait 45 min-1 hour at ChaChaCha.  Sure it doesn't have the same ambiance as next door, but with our Scoutmob discount of 50% we only paid $40 for our entire bill of 3 meals, sangria and sodas which was well worth it.  I'll def be back with or without the Scoutmob deal though!
author: Trixie B.

description:
I just wanted a taste of home! One of those Newyoricans over here, and I was missing my mom's rice and beans. My girlfriend first brought me here for Valentine's Day because she knew I wanted some Puerto Rican food. I usually opt for something other than a Spanish-influenced restaurant because a lot of the taquerias around have Rice-A-Roni type rice, y no me gusta eso!

Since that first visit, I have been back several times, bringing multiple friends and family members, including my parents who recently visited. 

I had the Pastelon, which, for me, is best described as a plantain lasagne. A delicious layer of platanos maduros (sweet) over a layer of seasoned meat, with another layer on top, and so on. With the white rice. So good!

Tostones (fried plantains) are awesome with the tangy sauce that comes with.

I tried my dad's penil (pork) - super flavorful! Definitely getting that next time. The steak with onions! The chicken! Everything is good. 

And the staff is always super friendly. The last time I was there, a wonderful waitress (with striking blue/green eyes) waited on us, spoke beautiful Spanish with my parents, and really showed us a great time. Thank you! See you soon!
author: Sheri V.

description:
A friend and I discovered this place by accident one day when we were just looking to grab dinner.  We went in not really expecting much, but we were completely blown away.  The space is small and cozy, the food is excellent, and the sangria is delicious.  It gets a bit crowded during the rushes, but the atmosphere is still comfortable.

I ended up organizing my friends and we descended on Parada 22 en masse one evening.  Although there was some concern about getting a table, we went early enough to grab 8 seats and had a really good time. The owner/waiter was great and kept us very happy.  Although, he did so by plying us with more Sangria, so that might be the real reason.  This is definitely a go-to place for me.
author: Wacey T.

description: Everything is GREAT but the "Pastelon" and their "Mogongo" is AMAZING and fingah linking!
author: Juan S.

description: My partner and I love this place! We are officially regulars now... The ambiance is great, the food is super delicious (highly recommend the tostones and the coconut flan is rediculous). The sangria is one of the best I've had and the service is superb! I would highly recommend that the owners look at getting Gaby some help during the weeknights. The place has gotten super popular, as expected and now she needs some help!! Regardless, no matter when you go you won't be disappointed. Can't wait to go back!!
author: Josh G.

description: Really good food if you are looking for puertorican food,we try the sampler and the Cuban sandwich both perfect
author: Celia B.

description:
Great place and much less crowded than cha cha cha next door. Discovered this place thanks to a groupon and now became a fan. 
One good place to eat in the upper haight. 

Last time I went, I took the CAMARONES A LA CRIOLLA with Mexican rice and mixed beans. It also comes with plantains and all of it is excellent.

The service is also great, quick, and friendly!

Good place for a casual diner with a couple of friends but no more than that as the place is very small.
author: Pascal P.

description: Best shrimp salad I've had in a while! Perfect size and not too heavy to where you're mad you ate so much! Also- the coconut flan is amazing; a must try! Can't wait to explore the menu next time.
author: Heidi H.

description:
¡Oye Cabrón! ¡It's time for some Boricua food, cabrón!

¡ñOOO! This place was good! I love the decor, which felt authentic and REALLY made me feel at home. The menu looks authentic, which is a great start. I wish someone would do this with a Cuban place somewhere because I have yet to see them with anything authentic. I had a steak sandwich, and it was great. They don't use the cuts of meat that one would normally use in a Cuban/Puerto Rican sandwich, but that's all right. Next time I'll try some other stuff on the menu.

They have mofongo on the menu, for crying out loud. They have the balls to put something like this on a menu with no notes, so the waitress/cashier has to explain it to 3,569,234 people a day. She was getting ready to explain what "muh-fon-goe" was to my friend and I, and we nodded. She interrupted herself, "--wait, you know what that is?"

"Yeah, it's the mashed plantains dish, isn't it?"
She then said something to the effect of "my god, I am so relieved I don't need to explain this to you, you get tired of trying to describe it all day to everyone."
author: A G.

description:
Finally came to the area and got to try out Parada 22.  Definitely was not disappointed!  Loved the food...especially the chicharron pollo!  Very tasty.  Red beans were so delicious...very flavorful and taste like the PR beans I grew up eating. 

I'll definitely come back to try more =)
author: Erica R.

description: Wow, what a great find! We stumbled on this place on our way to a Mexican place down the street. Great authentic Cuban food. I got the steak with onions dish with red beans and Mexican rice and it was SO delicious. My boyfriend got the chicken with ham dish and loved it. I tried a bit and the flavors were so different from my dish but equally as tasty.
author: Alexandra W.

description: Tostanes and muduros were my favorite part of the meal! Yummm! Salad was also very fresh and delicious; yuca was a bit too garlicky for me... Nice there is vegetarian options but I'd love to see some fish on the menu ;) menu prices were a bit higher than I thought but overall food was pretty good. Cute space. Friendly staff.
author: Coco J.

description:
First choice order: camarones a la criolla. Second choice order: pastelon. Both are delicious, both made everyone else at the table jealous of my order, both left me with cravings for a week.

Hip and trendy little place, won't fit a big party so don't bring one.
author: Lynn B.

description: Great service. Open kitchen that allows you to sit and watch your food be made (and they rock it out)... I had the biftec sandwich and cubano... cubano was amazing, nothing wrong with the biftec but the pork on the cubano was so perfectly braised! will def go back again when in San Fran.
author: Bernard K.

description:
We came here for lunch from ucsf and it's a decent walk...probably about 15 minutes taking the elevator.

Anyways the food is bomb. I got the pork with Spanish rice, black beans, and this grilled banana thing. Pork was absolutely wonderful and bigger portion than I thought I would get. Spanish rice is yummy. 

Service is nice. Price is around $10 a plate. My only complaint is that the food took forever. I swear it shouldn't have taken that long...at least 20 minutes. Maybe you should try calling in your order before coming here.
author: Nikkie P.

description:
Growing up in NYC, I was accustomed to Puerto Rican food especially being raised in Queens.  Parada 22 definitely comes close to home with their authentic dishes. Gotta eat my arroz and habichuelas.

Price is priced right for the wallet conscious folks.  It's most definitely a date spot. =)
author: Alexander H.

description: We had the most amazing food here. If you are looking for a home cooked meal, go to Parada 22. You won't regret it.
author: Lisa S.

description:
Casual atmosphere and really good food make for a great experience. Great Sangria! Really great food. Not one thing was off. We ordered the Classic Cubano, the sampler (our kids demolished it), Pernil Asado, habichuelas blancas and both the caramel and coconut flan. One dish came with your choice of Spanish (red) rice or white. We all wanted red except my daughter. Our server brought her a little side of white rice free of charge. It was very sweet of him. The service was really friendly, all smiles. I can't wait to go back without the kids and try the pitcher of sangria at happy hour.

Con: not in the best neighborhood after dark

Pros: perfectly cooked pork, great flavors (especially the red beans that came with the asado), amazing caramel flan, more wine than juice in the sangria, house made hot sauce at the table
author: Brandy M.

description: Finally found some delicious Puerto Rican food in SF. Now just put chuletas on the menu!
author: Josh E.

description: The sampler is perfect for sharing...everything was delicious except the yucca was kind of bland. The pork was tender but kinda blah. Surprising since both were cooked in garlic. The cilantro salad dressing is good dipping sauce to go with the tostones.
author: Eve C.

description:
Unbelievably delicious. I'm not a soup or bean eater but the white bean side was amazing. I could eat it daily. Authentic and cute atmosphere. Another table of six told me that everything at their table was delicious.
I wish the owner would read this and begin selling white bean side in quarts to go. We would stop by once or twice a week to take home the soup----healthful and delicious. Can't beat that.
author: Patricia B.

description: The food was amazing. I had the shrimp mofongo which was delicious. The service on the other wasn't all that great very slow we got sat and waited about 10 minutes to even be greeted. The restaurant itself isn't big at all so why it took that long was a little disappointing. Our waitress lagged on everything even bringing a coke to my boyfriend who had to ask a second time once the food was dropped. Overall I would definitely come again not the best service but the food was good. Don't get me wrong service is essential when dinning but it's a place worth trying
author: Jenefer R.

description: Delicious food! I love the mofongos and the yuca salad!
author: Pele T.

description: I've been to this place twice for brunch and am amazed that there isn't a line outside the door! The food is really delicious! Apart from being authentic it's got tasty vegetarian options. I got the boogaloo classic that comes with an finger-licking creamy gravy and much recommended home fries. My only criticism is that the service could be friendlier- the server wasn't unfriendly, but he just seemed bored and took time to take our order. So really a 4.5 rating for Parada 22!
author: Akire C.

description:
A couple of weeks ago, I decided that I really needed to fulfill my urge for some Puerto Rican food.  While being in the Bay for most of the last ten years, I was one of the lucky ones to enjoy Sofrito in Oakland while it existed; to this day, I truly miss their Puerto Rican food.  I'm the type that, when in NYC, I will stop by in Spanish Harlem for some of that real Puerto Rican food; I've also been lucky enough to attend some Puerto Rican quinceaneras where I had the most amazing pernil, arroz con gandules, and tostones.  Clearly, I love Puerto Rican food! 

After some friends recommended this place, I decided to give it a try.  I was still holding out hope that I could find some of that legit Puerto Rican cuisine here.  After having the pernil and arroz con gandules here, unfortunately, this place just doesn't measure up anywhere near the Puerto Rican food I've had.  I gave it three stars because, while I wouldn't classify the food as Puerto Rican (it's more Cuban I think), it was still decent.  The pernil was tasty and juicy and perfectly cooked, however, it didn't taste like any of the Puerto Rican pernil I have ever had; same w/ the rice.  It may have to do w/ the spices used, or lack thereof here.  If I wasn't going in expecting legit Puerto Rican food, my rating might have been higher.  However, they advertise themselves as Puerto Rican cuisine and, from my experience having Puerto Rican food around this country, it just didn't measure up.
author: Abraham E.

description: I came here wanting some good puertorican food and I was a little disappointed,food is great don't get me wrong but it needs more Puerto Rico taste more sazon y garlic.
author: Melanie W.

description: Came by for dinner one night after rave reviews from a Puerto Rican friend - maybe PR food just isn't my thing, but I thought the food tasted like Mexican food without the spiciness.  We tried a couple of the combo plates and thought most of the food tasted pretty standard.  The rice seemed rich not very flavorful, the shrimps had that chewy shrimpy texture you get after boiling shrimp, and the beans were pretty bland.  I did like the plantains and could see ordering a side of those to go.  Overall the restaurant was OK - definitely nothing objectionable or bad - but I don't think we will be headed back anytime soon.  I'm wonder if this means we should now cancel our one month trip to Puerto Rico...
author: Rosers M.

description:
Amazingly good. 

Me and 4 friends went to Parada 22 on a Saturday around 6pm. We were told there would be about a 10 minute wait. After checking with Cha Cha Cha next door, and learning the wait was 45 minutes, 10 minutes sounded great. 

We were seated at the "family-style" table right up near the kitchen. The place is very cozy, so if you have space issues, then you might have issues here. We all had no problems sitting at the table and eating.

We ordered the sample platter which comes with pork, fried chicken, plantains and some other goodies and a nice dipping sauce.

Our appetizer came out and we had 2 of the samplers, which we didn't order, but being as hungry as I was, insisted that we just keep them. 

We also ordered a pitcher of delicious Sangria(cha cha who?). 

For my dinner I order the Pork plate(PERNIL ASADO) and my girlfriend got the fried chicken (CHICHARRON DE POLLO). I forget what everybody else got in our group. Everything was very good. The fried stuff was nice and crispy. The plantains were cooked perfectly and all the rice was good and flavorful. 

I would definitely go here again, and constantly think about going there soon. Hooooooray
author: Mack L.

description:
Never disappoints.  Our go-to place for comfort food.  The menu is underpriced for the quality and freshness of their food AND.... now they are serving brunch!  Yumm!
It's a small place, but worth the wait (and you will because always a line during busy times).  Only thing is.... I wish they would serve espresso at dinner.
author: Raquel V.

description:
Got a $20 groupon for ten 

I grew up with Boriquas (spelling) in NYC and grew up more on Puerto Rican food then Mexican. I know that is hard for people out here to understand. This is home cooking folks, just less salty. I've never know the names of dishes that I ate at the homes of friends but at the restaurant I got the pernil asado. Pork. . . 

It was a healthy serving of meat (with beans which I didn't opt for), fried plantains, a side salad and finished off the meal with some white rice, a bottle of soda and in-house made flan (verses the rubbery stuff that comes out of .containers). Mmm. . . flan. 

The pork was well done and little on the bland side compared to what I'm used to. The plantain were perfect and hot. The rice was alittle overdone, the way it should be and the salad had a sweet dressing. I ate well for the value of the groupon and paid for some flan to go. Mmm...flan. 

The restaurant is small and filled with warm wooden furniture. The decorations are Latin, geared towards Puerto Rican culture. Not sure who the photos are of the people posted but kinda wished it depicted more of how Puerto Ricans look with the wide variations in hair, skin and eye color. The culture is as diverse as the people. 

Anyway, the food was good and plentiful. The hostess was nice. And you get to see the kitchen as the food is being prepared.
author: lily l.

description:
As a neighbor, I think Parada 22 is the neatest experience in Haight. I dig the narrow, cozy brick thing going on and the staff are super cool. 

The food is reasonably priced and exceptionally good. All the meats are great and the sides are delicious. The sangria should not be missed and makes a great way to unwind.
author: Ryan K.

description:
wow. absolutely delicious food. great portions. incredibly well cooked and seasoned meats.

great atmosphere for a date without being too pricey, and a family-owned feel to the place. did i mention the food was amazing?

my go-to: so good i have two 1) steak plate 2) pork plate

the fried plantains are also amazing, and come w/ all the dinner plates.
author: Aunik B.

description: My wife and I came here for a casual dinner and loved our dinner!  We shared the Tostones and we split the cubano and chicken sandwiches which were great.  The best cubano sandwich we've had since being in Key West 10 years ago.  The biggest disappointment was when our waitress was so nice to give us a taste sample of one o fthe other dishes we saw another diner had and we were sorry we hadnt ordered that dish.  But this means we will need to go back.  There are a few more things on the menu than their website shows, and it seems they are all deilicious.
author: Steven B.

description: Best Puerto Rican food in the Bay.  Love the mofongo con camarones with Spanish rice and kidney beans. Tostones here are crispy and tasty, the way they should be. Service is very cold and unfriendly. Pork is not good and nothing really close to Puerto Rican lechón asado.
author: Eddie M.

description:
The food is amazing and the staff is super sweet and attentive. As a "real" Puerto Rican, I can say that most of the food is very legit. This place was even loved by my traditional Mother who is very hard to please.

The best stuff to order is the pastelón de carne (which is a pretty much a plantain lasagna) with rice and beans (go for the white rice and red beans). Another great favorite are the chicharrones de pollo. I'd say that the pork is the least authentic of all their dishes, but everything else is on spot.

I've got a comment for all the angry vegans/vegetarians, seriously, as a Puerto Rican it offends me that you expect a Puerto Rican restaurant to have vegan options for you. First of all, this place is relatively cheap... it is not meant to cater to all of the different substitutions for your delicate diet.  Second of all, we Puerto Ricans don't eat things that aren't derivative of animals, we never even eat salads... we've never even seen gluton free things, or soy or alternative proteins. EVERYTHING we eat is filled with animal fat because of the way we cook things. So for you to be offended that the beans have pork in them seems like an absurdity to me, and of course... proof of your privileged first world entitlement. It is your job as someone with a strict diet to ask before you buy. The reason why those "ingredients" are not listed in the menu is because every single thing we cook has at least 20 ingredients in them and animal fat is as common as salt in your food. Learn before you buy, be careful of the things you say, don't expect the world to cater to you. If you don't like it, then chances are Puerto Rican food is not for you.

Again, best place ever. I lived too many years without good decent Caribbean food in this city until this restaurant came to be. Now I can have a piece of home with me in this great city :)
author: Alex P.

description:
Parada 22 is a must try. If you're tired of the same old traditional lunch options and are looking to spice things up then this is the place for you. 

The rustic decor combined with the friendly and genuine service promotes a relaxed and welcoming ambiance that makes for a perfect weekend lunch outing. The interior has pretty limited space but pulls off a nice cozy feel, especially on a foggy day. My favorite dish is the mofongo de camarones, and you can't go wrong with a glass of sangria. I'm such a fan of the mofongo that the first time the gf's family came to town we took them here and almost everyone got the mofongo and EVERYONE loved it. Packed with the diverse, rich flavors of Puerto Rico, Parada 22 stands out as a true SF gem.
author: Andrew T.

description:
I must say I have been waiting MONTHS to try this place.
I was finally soooo happy to get here.

To start my review off I need to say this.
I give this place a 5 star and would give it 6 star for food if I could!!!

The food was EXCELLENT!!!! In fact, EXCELLENT may be and understatement!!! I felt like I was in my family's kitchen eating authentic food.  This place definitely is AUTHENTIC PR food!!!

I ordered the vegetarian plate which consisted of salad, rice and beans (I decided to order spanish rice with red beans. They also have the option of white rice and white beans), platano maduro and yucca.  It was nothing short of FABULOUS!!!!  My friend ordered the bifstek plate which was the same except she had beef.  We also ordered an extra side of platano maduros because who could only eat a few :)

I came here on 10/1 for dinner.  My bday is on 10/4 and so my eating celebration was continuing :)  

The place had excellent decor with art work and family portraits all over.  They also had cool table ornaments of cans w/the utensils in them which I thought was totally cool.  It's in an excellent location in the heart of the height.  It's definitely a hole in the wall with not much seating at all but those are always the diamonds in the rough!!!

I bet you're wondering if everything was so great, why the one star!?!? I'll tell you why!!!  The owner or manager of the place was clearly not of the latin decent.  She did not not speak any Spanish.  She was the one managing the register as well as taking the orders and bring out the food.  After arriving at 8pm we were seated quickly but shortly after the rush came in!!!  There were 2 people in the back cooking.  An older heavy set Spanish woman and a Spanish male.  I guess with all craziness going on, the manager (for lack of better words) had her come to the front to pass out the beverages and wipe the table down.  As the older lady came to our table to refill our water, I asked her if she was the one who cooked the dinner.  She indicated to me that she did not speak English.  Being that I am Dominican, I instantly spoke to her in Spanish and she was much more at ease.  I told her the food was great and that she did a good job.  Once my friend and I finished our food, paid our bill, we began to leave the place and we said thank you to the manager (a Caucasian girl I would say in her late 20s to early 30s).  Both my friend and I said thank you and we were at complete shock that she did not even acknowledge us, yet rushed passed us to serve another patron.  We thought that was odd so we just continued to put on our jackets and in the middle of the restaurant she proceeded to call the spanish lady stupid and slow to the customer.  I was APPALLED!!!!!!! I looked at my friend and we were both at a loss of words because I could not believe she would utter those words to another customer and out loud for every one to hear.

For that ladies and gentlemen, I will NEVER go back to this place.  I will not support an environment who speaks to their workers like that.  The poor lady had no clue because she did not speak English.

Parada 22 my advice to you is:
***Either you find someone to man the floor who speaks Spanish and can converse with the workers or
***Hire a translator

Either way....that manager/person/who the hell that was, should be fired and no one should eat here!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Sandra S.

description:
Great food and atmosphere. I've had the biftec entree 2x. And it tasted even better on the 2nd visit. Ask for the Spanish rice instead of the white rice. Portions are good  Sangria and sweet tea are perfectly made.  

Service is good. Small, crowded place...not meant for groups larger than 4,  But the turnaround is pretty quick. 

Why only 4 stars? I wish they had a fish dish (besides the yummy shrimp entree).
author: Yinnie Q.

description: Yum! Pollo sandwich 5 stars and Classic Cubano 4. I went and got take out during Bay to Breakers (I know, I am idiot) and the staff seemed pleasant, despite the chaos. I feel like I need to try more and experience dining in before this can get a five star, but it's close!
author: Debbie L.

description:
The chicharrones de pollo are amazing!!! Fried chicken heaven...get it with the sampler platter or as an entree ($10.50). 

Another great meal at Parada.
author: Yee-Shing W.

description: Amazing food! I  am a puertorican born and raised in san juan. This restaurant trully brought some great memories! I ordered mofonfo con camarones and my boyfriend pastelon. We loved it! The right ingredients!
author: Ibelig V.

description: Extremely good. Great service. Chill atmosphere and it's always a good time.
author: Abhi M.

description: I love this place.  The food is fantastic!  I had the pernil asado,  thinking about it now makes my mouth water.  Had a taste of my friends biftec which was also yummy.  I loved the tostones and flan.  Can't wait for my next visit.
author: Carb Q.

description:
This place was my first time trying out Puerto Rican food and I am definitely a fan now.  

I ordered the roast pork (Pernil Asado) dish.  It was the first dish on the menu that caught my attention.  Since I am not a major fan of non-refried beans...I decided to substitute it with more mixed greens.  IT WAS THE BEST DECISION I HAVE EVER MADE!  The dressing in the mixed greens tasted AMAZING!  The Spanish rice was also DELICIOUS!  The roast pork however...did not have that garlic flavor that the menu said it's suppose to have so I was a tad disappointed there.

I plan to try the Mofongo dish when I return to this place since I have been recommended to make room for it next time around.

I also had their coconut flan as dessert here and it was ok.  The coconuty taste was definitely in there, but the middle part of the flan didn't taste completely done.  Nevertheless, it was still a tasty dessert.
author: Wendy T.

description: It was okay... The beans were salty both red and white.. Also the mofongo had toooooo much pepper it was almost unbearable. The amarillos were good. Sangria is good too.
author: Margarita G.

description:
San Francisco is missing out on one of the best types of cuisine in the world. I don't say this lightly nor because I am from PR. When I heard Parada 22 was opening my mouth started salivating thinking for once SF would bring some of the most traditional plates to a neighborhood near me. After my first visit, whether nostalgia or hunger, I was pleased. I had the Camarones a la Criolla, which I must admit is a delicious plate but not remotely close to anything you'll find in Puerto Rico.

I've been to Parada 22 at least 4 times. The Pernil Asado and Yuca al Mojo are about the most authentic things you will find in the menu. Amarillos are good too, but come on, it's nearly impossible to get those wrong. To be able to call yourself a Puertorican restaurant there are 2 main dishes you absolutely need: Mofongo and Tostones. This is my main disappointment with Parada 22. I came in expecting at least one of those 2, maybe even some Medalla. Instead I found an americanized or cuban/puertorican infusion menu with mexican beers.

If one goes in to eat good food without thinking of its region, then I definitely recommend it - it is delicious. To those familiar with Puertorican cuisine, there's a LOT of room for improvement.
author: Ruben R.

description:
Recently went back in. They've changed the set up a little bit, converting to a more 'sit down' type restaurant. I take this to mean they were tired of not getting any tips! Having worked in a similar environment, I sympathize.

SOOOO happy to see they take card now! I will be dining here much more often. It used to be like, "Oh, I want Parada 22.. oh wait, I don't have any cash, uggh..". Now there's no restriction!

Also, to all who were saying they don't have Mofongo, well.. they have it now! I had no idea what it was when I went in, the lady suggested it. The description sounded good, so I ordered it... MAN it was so delicious! Stomach is growling right now just thinking about it. I couldn't tell you how authentic it was since I have nothing to compare it to, but on flavor alone it gets 5 stars from me!
author: Rachel H.

description:
I really dig this spot! It's nice and intimate, meaning it ain't that big but I like it. The joint's got high ceilings and the walls are adorned with all kinds of memorabilia from Puerto Rico; food, photographs, decoration and such. There's even an old school, black and white television showing old Puerto Rican flix. Big plus for the interior. The waitress was really cool and helpful. In fact, the first time I went there we was chatting it up. That's always a plus for me.

I've been to Parada 22 twice already and both experiences have been quite enjoyable for my tummy. I really dig the Pernil Asado, roasted leg of pork marinated nicely in a garlic and oregano based sofrito. All the main dishes come with Puerto Rican rice, red OR white beans, maduros and some greens. Believe me, it hit's the spot coz the portion is perfect. Not too much and never too skimpy. I've also tried the Biftec Encebollado and the Chicken Encebollado which is steak or chicken with caramelized onions. Their sandwiches are hella good too. I had the Classic Cubano, roast pork, sweet ham, pickles, mustard and swiss cheese. Oooooh weeeee.

I always "big-up" the chef when I leave because, like I said, the food is real good and your order's usually come pretty quick. And if you're one of them particular types, you can actually see him cook because there isn't a wall separating the kitchen from the dining area.

I'm coming back to try dessert next time coz I never have room for it.
author: Ivan F.

description:
As a Puertorrican living in the Bay Area I was pleasantly surprised when I saw this restaurant for the first time. 
I was little skeptic at first, for Puertorrican food is all about the "sazón", or blend of spices used to cook and season the food, and I knew that if they were not done right I would be very disappointed. But Parada 22 captures the essential flavors that make Puertorrican food distinguishable and unique. Their food is surprisingly good!!

The place feels like a "colmadito" or small store back on the island. Old newspapers showing important moments in Puertorrican history and local products and brands decorate the walls, most of them you cant find outside the island.

Now, I only wish they sell Medalla...

The pernil asado and yuca is highly recommended.
author: Elvin R.

description: Very good and great sized portions. The food is authentic and the place has an awesome decor. I'd definitely come back.
author: Lennie S.

description:
I'm a gringo but lived in Puerto Rico long enough to claim a second identity as a boriqua.  The food here is authentic and delicious.  If you haven't tried this cuisine before it's similar to Cuban, though the Puerto Ricans would insist it is entirely different because Cubans use black beans and they use pinto beans! :)  If this is your first time, try the mofongo or the sampler plate.

The original restaurant is in the Haight but they have a "pop-up" at Boogalos in the Mission on Friday and Saturday nights.  Check it out!
author: Bill K.

description:
I was excited to try Puerto Rican food in SF, because my standards are pretty high (the only PR place I know in the Bay is Sol Food so far). So, I was hoping that Parada 22 would be able to satisfy my craving for maduros without me having to drive anywhere.

First, I have to say, that it was my mistake to assume Parada 22 was strictly Puerto Rican; they incorporate flavors and dishes from all over Latin America.

Secondly, I was weary because the place was completely empty when I walked in (granted, it was 4:30pm, and nobody really eats at that hour).

The decor is very colorful and bright, the walls are covered in Cuban and other Latin memorabilia. The vibrant shelves are lined with a wide variety of vintage products, reminding me of home (sigh). I was a bit confused though, under the assumption that it was more "street food" and that seating was not to be expected. I got a completely different experience, I asked the server if she takes our order at the table or if we're required to order up at the counter...she seemed confused about this too and replied "whatever you want to do..."

Must-try on the menu:
Citrus - mint beverage: an in-house concoction of citrus juices mixed with mint and ginger. Great refreshing drink (non-alcoholic) for what was definitely the hottest day of the year in SF!

Spanish rice - great flavors on it's own; BUT you should definitely follow my lead and pair with...

Habichuelas coloradas - homemade red beans that are spiced to perfection. You get a mean red beans and rice combo that satisfies anyone's comfort-food-button.

Yuca y Aguacate al mojo - a rather large salad with cassava and avocado that is lightly seasoned with salt and pepper, atop greens that have been tossed in a garlic and onion vinaigrette.
author: Alyssa G.

description:
Went to Parada 22 for dinner as an alternative to ChaChaCha next door on Haight. The facade stands out with its blue-green paint color.  The decor is pleasant, a two-story small dining room covered with memorabilia from Puerto Rico and Cuba on one side and an old rustic, red brick wall on the other. We were seated immediately.   Service was attentive and we didn't have to wait too long for our plates.

I tried the Pernil Asado main and my wife had the Berenja sandwich with extra avocado.  The Pernil Asado was delicious: a generous portion of very moist, flavorful roast pork accompanied with rice, beans, a small salad and maduros - ripe sweet plantains.  The Berenja was a nice veg sandwich with grilled eggplant.

We'll return to try some of the other Principales.
author: David E.

description: This place was awesome. Small, cute decor, and most importantly, quality food. I got the pork plate, and it was a perfect combination of tender meat, flavorful Spanish rice (you can also get white rice), a small bowl of beans, a small salad, and the perfect addition of fried plantains for that salty-sweet combo. Also got the fried green plantains, which were delish. Go.
author: Sarah Y.

description:
3.5 stars

A pretty small place for Cuban / Puerto Rican Food. I was actually expecting more on the menu. The bf and I settled for the Cubano sandwich and the biftec. Both came out pretty quickly with a small side of greens. Lunch cost us about $20 with no drinks. No frills, no thrills just solid food.
author: Julie F.

description:
Was meeting up with old college friends and I decided to try this place that my classmates had been raving about.  I'm glad that they take credit cards now, because the bill came out to be a little bit more than I would have expected from the place... but we did order a lot. I tried everything that we ordered: 

Wine- good, but I wouldn't get it again. Only got it because we all had a long day.

Yuca side- not fried, with sauteed onions and a creamy sauce. delicious

Camarones- great! the sides were really good and the shrimp was done really well too in a creampeppery sauce. The onions weren't as well done as I would have liked so they turned out to be kinda slimy type onions. 

Biftec-meat was done well. same sides as what I had.

Sides (spanish rice, beans)- I couldn't really taste the pork in the spanish rice or the red beans, but they are definitely really good.  Spanish rice was very moist. White beans are just as delicious.

Sandwhiches- eggplant and chicken were simple and done well. 

Rum Cake- good, but not fabulous. I feel like I could have gotten that in a store somewhere and wouldn't get it again.

Worth a visit!
author: Sirina K.

description: Hey all of you Cha Cha Cha people, if the line is too long, stop in at Parada 22 and you will not be dissapointed!  They offer some of the best Mofongo I have ever tried along with other great dishes!  My wife and I have eaten here 3 times and we have not been dissapointed.  The service is good, the staff is chill and relaxed but attentative.  The food is awesome!  We recently tried the Camarones a la Criolla- which is a sauteed shrimp in a fresh tomato, onions & sweet peppers cream sauce.  It was a hit, I know we will both have some serious cravings for this place in the future and we cannot wait to go back!  Well done Parada 22!
author: Drew H.

description:
It's indeed hard to find Caribbean food in this allegedly foodie-centric city... so finally having a spot on this side of the city rocks (Primo Patio Cafe in Soma is another great one) 

A smaller spot with a handful of tables, close seating not really good for groups over 5ish, but great for dates. 
 
Menu is smaller but everything they do they do it damn well. The sangria is a def must. Food is bright, colorful and nicely plated. We tried the steak and pork, both were off the dankometer eg: flavor that politely bareknuckle punches you in the mouth with explosions of spices and juices

Def worth trying, especially if puerto rican food is something you're not familiar with. Get there before dinner rush.
author: Jon S.

description:
Awesome place for tasty food.  The staff  are friendly and the food comes out quick.  I've been there a handful of time and tried a few things on the menu.  The platters come with a few sides, (beans, rice and plantains).  Definitely a good size portion to fill your appetite. 

I normally hate ordering salads at restaurants because I don't think you get enough bang for your buck.  However, the chicken salad at Parada 22 is awesome.  The chicken is tender and there's just enough dressing to coat the leaves.  

I'd recommend getting the citrus mint drink.
author: gareth l.

description: This is our favorite place on Haight, and possible the city. It's a cozy joint full of character, and the food is full-portioned and delicious! My wife describes the music as tropical and says when you're there it's easy to get lost and and feel like you're in Puerto Rico. Carlos is friendly and the service is excellent. We just love it here, plain and simple :)
author: Roy B.

description:
Yes, yes, and yes! This place is so yummy. I will get my cynicism out of the way and mention that I hate the paper plates and paper cups. With that said, the food is delicious and the vibe is so casual and fitting of the Haight. I'd totally take someone out here on a casual date but even I have to say that paper cups and paper plates is a little off-putting.

However, everyone should at least try this place once because their mofongo is so good! Their roasted pig is also delicious!
author: Rylan C.

description: I dont remember the last time I actually came on here and wrote a review.  I just got mafungo de camarones to go.  I took two bites and I want to shout this restaurants name from a mountain top.  Im flipping out right now.  they definitely just gained a new loyal customer.
author: Brandon H.

description: Love this little spot. The food is amazing, worth every single penny. I actually like their decor.
author: Nemesis J.

description:
Was buying gifts in the Haight for a friend's two year old and I started getting The Hunger!  From the abyss of my brain I remembered reading an article about a Puerto Rican restaurant in the Upper Haight, so I wandered amongst the bong stores and crowded sidewalks until I found Parada 22.  

I walk in and everything felt right, the music, the Goya Products on the wall, the Cafe Bustelo which spoke of mi abuela- and then I get ready to order. I am already salivating and happy to eat some good soul food; this Jew-Yorican knows that keeping my Borinquen half happy is hard in this city and any chance to eat some Puerto Rocking food is a chance taken.  I asked the woman behind the counter- "You don't happen to make mofongo do you?"  She looked at me like I had two heads.

"Mo, what?"

"Mofongo."

"Huh?"

"Mofo- ah, nevermind. You're not Puerto Rican are you...."

I ordered some pollo frito- which was passable, and some maduros (sweet plantains) which were not maduro enough, and some rice and beans- which were great.  

I will be the first to admit, that for Puerto Rican food, I am a hard judge- this would pretty much be the exact meal that I would eat if it were my last (made by moms of course)- so my standards are exacting.  What elevated the meal was the beans.  Seriously, they nailed the beans. Without the beans I would never go back, and the beans are the hardest part!

So, what I would say is if you just want to try some Puerto Rican food or are homesick- Parada can come through in the clutch, just don't expect mofongo, and take it for what it is.  Next time I am really jonesing for something vaguely resembling food I grew up eating, I will head to Parada 22; if I don't make it at home.
author: seth s.

description: Great food and atmosphere.  Nice authentic looking Puerto Rican theme decor.  Good attention to detail, including the rough, uneven, and cracked  concrete floor, which caused my table to wobble and made it next to impossible to move my chair.   Aside from that, my dinning experience was pretty good.  Food was excellent.  I had the Biftec Encebollado, the Appetizer Sampler, Raspberry tart, sweet tea, and Sangria.  Customer service was prompt and friendly.  They honored my Groupon.
author: Hiroshi K.

description: Way too good! Definitely will come back. Service is great. The place is small like most of the places in SF but I'm Puerto Rican and the food is definitely authentic. I had the sample of "pernil, chicharrones de pollo, tostones y yuca al mojo" and it was delicious.
author: Coral S.

description:
I've been wanting to check out Parada 22 since it opened but never found myself in the Haight area.  After I saw a Scoutmob for it, I took the opportunity to check it out with my brother.

The place is, indeed, quite small.  You sit wherever is open if you're dining in, which could be at a small counter or in the corner.  Luckily for us, the big table was clear so we snagged 2 seats at the end.

As always, my bro and I ordered 2 entrees to split.  He got the pernil asado and I got the mofongo.  The mofongo was the clear winner of the two, since the pernil was on the dry side.  The pork had great flavor, but couldn't quite make up for it being overcooked.

The mofongo dish, on the other hand, was fantastic!  The shrimp w/ the onion/tomato/pepper cream sauce (camarones a la criolla) was divine and not too too heavy despite the cream.  The mofongo itself was also flavorful.  I've never had mofongo before, but if this is what it's always like I'll make sure to order it every time I eat PR food!

My spanish rice was mushy and a bit bland, but the white rice was fluffy and tasty.  The red beans were ok but not great, perhaps a litttle heavy on the tomatoes?

Service was a little slow, but when there's one person running the cash register, grabbing drinks, clearing tables, serving the food, and taking phone orders, that's expected.  She was really friendly and it gave my bro and I a chance to catch up so we didn't have a problem with it.

Neither my brother nor I live particularly close to the Haight, but we'd both definitely go back!
author: Naoko M.

description: Flavor flavor flavor! The food here is amazing! Generous potions and reasonable prices. The mofongo, fried plantains and pork are to die for! Service is a little slow but worth the wait
author: James P.

description: Cute little place with great food. I had the veggie plate. They should do more on the plantains portion vs. the yuka fries/mash thing.. i felt i needed more plaintains when i was done. It was a nice experience here. i would go back one more time to get a different dish. Small space.
author: C A.

description: I have been looking for a great Puerto Rican food restaurant ever since I moved from PR to the states and I finally found it! Delicious food that tastes just like home!
author: Mairi V.

description:
Disregard Sandra's review. She's a bitter hater and is posing as a Latina. She doesn't habla Español or know of what she speaks in any language.

This is a great spot with delicious, authentic comida criolla. The service was also super, and the ambience couldn't have been warmer. Can't wait to go back  and hang with the cool manager y mi gente chevere. 

Sabor!
author: Will R.

description: The place is quaint with old family pictures and video of Puerto Rico. My wife and I had Chicherones de Pollo with fresh salad, Spanish rice with white or red beans, tostones and Sangria. It was fantastic authentic PR cuisine. Menu had many PR delights.
author: Joseph K.

description: Service is slow, even if it is not busy, even if there is nobody else in the restaurant. It could possibly be the waitress' fault, or just plain ol' negligence. I would not recommend this place; unless you enjoy waiting. Not good for groups either; unless you enjoy being crammed into a small space with no elbow room.
author: Iroquois S.

description:
This place is like some sort of Puerto Rican wet dream, but less messy (although crowded a lot).

The food.  Oh the food.  The pernil asado was so delicious - pork chunks with just the right amount of fat.  The chicken thighs with caramelized onions are also delicious.  I really liked all the sides that come with the meal as well.  Beans?  Awesome.  Rice?  Get the Spanish rice.

One small complaint though...the table service situation is really kind of awkward at the moment.  Its setup makes it look like it's a order-at-the-counter kind of restaurant, but then they also offer table service if you dine in, and then tipping is awkward - does the waitress bring you your check or do you pay at the counter after your meal?  Do you tip at the table or in the jar?  How many levels deep am I in this wet dream?  All very confusing questions that there are no good answers to (I'm looking at you, Christopher Nolan).
author: jon y.

description:
3.5 Stars

I've been to Puerto Rico twice, I dated a Puerto Rican for 2 years and have had home cooked meals too, but all that does not make me an expert on the cuisine.  I do have to say I know what I like and I know what I've had back in the homeland.

The tostones are excellent.  I've made them myself and have had mine compared to grandma's too so I know their tostones are yummy.  I ordered the mofongo because I have yet to find good mofongo here in the states.  This dish was definitely good but I miss the dome like shape it traditionally comes in.  It was just a bunch of mush on my plate topped with some shrimp and sauce.  (If you google mofongo images then you'll know what I'm talking about.)  My boyfriend got the pernil asado and boy was that a disappointment.  Dry and flavorless!  The portion size wasn't even that big and he stopped eating it since it was a waste of space in his stomach and polished off the spanish rice instead.  

The portion size is perfect.  I'm a petite 5'2 girl and I polished off my plate.  Other Yelpers mentioned on how the portion sizes are huge but you have to consider where you are.  We're not in at Gary Danko honey, this is Puerto Rican cuisine and they want to fatten you up!  

I loved the way they decorated though.  Very homey with the Goya cans surrounding you while you eat.  hehe
author: Rosalind S.

description: I was slightly worried after reading all negative service reviews; however, the positive food comments made me still want to check it out. It was DELICIOUS and the service was FANTASTIC! We had the pastelon, mixed plate, and of course the sangria. Everything was yummy! We can't wait to go back.
author: lura m.

description:
1. Located next to Chachacha on Haight (same owner)
2. Teal walls with huge pantry, paintings, portraits, and pictures, crayon drawings in the bathroom
3. TV on brick wall
4. Half pitcher of sangria-$12, more fruit than alcohol
5. 21st amendment watermelon wheat beer
6. Mofongo: mashed green plantains with sofrito and shrimp- interesting, hard to tell what you're eating since everything is mashed together, flavorless, does not look appetizing at all
     7. Spanish or white rice
     8. Sauteed sweet plantains
     9. Red beans with or without pork
   10. Mixed salad
11. Sampler platter: crispy fried chicharron de pollo- fried chicken, crispy skin, deliciously salty
   12. Fried plantains- can't go wrong with fried
   13. Yucca- like a potato, but bland
   14. Roasted pork- tough, hard to eat
15. Lots of leftovers- save it for 4th meal or lunch the next day or give it to a homeless on your way to the car, you won't miss em.
16. Lovely service, did not rush us out even after closing
17. Cozy and cute, only 10 tables
18. Accepts credit cards
19. 50% scoutmob special- holla.
20. Open: Tues-Sun 11:30am-10pm
21. Wish I had tried the rum cake
PARADA 22!!
author: Angela W.

description: I had been meaning to come to Parada 22 since it opened, and finally made it in today. The service was was receptive there, and the portions were perfect. The main entrées include a salad and beans (white or red). The food was very flavorful as well. I gave 4 rather than 5 stars because I thought there could have been more shrimp added to the dish ordered. The food was great, but more shrimp is always better! Overall, I will definitely be returning, especially for the sangria.
author: Ashley B.

description: Six words for Parada 22: Finally, a Cuban sandwich in SF.
author: Stephen Y.

description:
Charming.
Well put together.
Friendly.
Fun.
Delicious.

No, I'm not describing a date.  I'm discussing a recent lunch experience at Parada 22.  I was lured here by an article describing how the owners came up with their bean recipes, and let me say the beans are definitely as advertised.  So is most of the rest of the food at this tiny, comfortable little eatery.  It's casual (paper plates, picnic table seating, counter service, cash only) but that fits the food, which is deceptively simple.  The only off note was my pork dish, which was a little too dry, but everything else was delicious.  Parada 22 is most definitely worth several return visits.

Now, about that date...
author: Suzanne B.

description: My partner took me to this place and I was skeptical, but the food was great. it is a tiny restaurant with a feel of home and not to mention great food. I had camarones a la criola with tostones, and I almost immediately thanked my partner for taking me there. Friendly service as well. I will go back.
author: Daniel V.

description:
My blanco self I may not know authentic Puerto Rican food, but I know this place is good and reasonably priced. The pork is amazing, the chicken was decent. Get both if you're sharing, but highly recommend the chicken. The yucca salad is banging, as are the Habichuelas Coloradas. 

There's seating, but it's totally casual. I like the ambiance but it's not a restaurant where you get served...You go up to the counter and order.

Enjoy!
author: Melissa C.

description: Fun casual island food.  Great bold favors, and a good portion. The pepper sauce on the table is amazing as well, we polished off a whole bottle between the three of us. Great place!!
author: Spencer M.

description:
Holy moly this is some might tasty food! After getting the scoutmob email today, I stopped by with the Mr for a quick bite to eat. Cute little spot and we sat by the window to enjoy a little people watching in the haight (a highly enjoyable past-time).

Its definitely a supercasual place but for a late lunch on a friday, it was poi-fect!

The waitress was great, fast, efficient. friendly. The food came out quickly and wowza.

I had the Mofongo with spanish rice and black beans. An awesome plate was put in front of me with some yummy dressed salad, a ramekin of beans (such a good idea so it doesn't turn everything else on the plat to mush), the spanish rice was soooooo good, the fried plantains were delish and wa-wa-wee-wa. The mofongo. Its baked mashed plantains filled with a generous helping of grilled prawns. i love it when restaurants are generous with prawns (as so many aren't) and the smoky taste to the prawns definitely smacked of a charcoal grill.

He had the special of the day which was ground beef with layers of fried plantain. Kinda like that other layered dish with beef we like so much. Really good.

Can't wait to go back!
author: Leah O.

description:
I've been off the Yelp radar for some time now, not because I haven't been eating out but because I just wasn't inspired to write anything. I've been to some really good restaurants like Berreta, Incanto, and Pizza Delfina, and some really horrible ones like Nikko's.

But on to more important things; a review for one of my lists and the food of my people.

Parada 22 had only been open a week and a half when I went in but even so I don't think there are any kinks that need to be worked out. They had pernil (roasted pork shoulder) which Sol in San Rafael doesn't have. This gives them extra points in my book. It was a generous portion and it was moist and well seasoned with just the right amount of fat. The rice and beans were just like my dad makes and the maduros (ripe fried plantains) were delicious.

What they don't have just yet, and I'm sure that with some pressure they will get, are tostones (fried green plantain chips.) They decor is communal and cozy just like similar places in Puerto Rico. I wouldn't call it fine dining but it is more like picnic style.

In any case I will be going back often and maybe I'll try different things but I was so excited about the pernil that I didn't really read the rest of the menu.
author: Hunter G.

description:
There is nothing fancy going on at Parada 22. What you do get (aside from authentic Puerto Rican food, more on that in a second) is a ramshackle Latin street corner vibe (the place is named after a street in San Juan), complete with scattered photos from the old country, and a huge glass cabinet stocked with bags of coffee, cigars and assorted canned goods.

It's mainly a take-out spot, but there are some benches you can crowd over, and there's also a small drawing table (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/TlBFKt2N2eSEBpN-UZmDBw?select=8Z7Xrj3Va8G1aWV3TuK8gA) for the little people to doodle at while waiting for the order. 

I tried the Biftec Encebollado, which came with onions, white rice, a couple of plantains, and white beans. The Camarones were another hit at our table, served in a fresh tomato and pepper cream sauce. My friend Sig N (http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=ZrLjXdfDlmcTwhZ9zTryuQ) is partial to their sandwiches, for what that's worth! 
 
I hear there's a whole fried fish you can order -- not on the menu -- that you can only order for sit-down. Seems like a seriously good way to enjoy Puerto Rico without leaving San Francisco.
author: Nish N.

description:
This is the second time i've eaten here for dinner. It was fine. The first time I had the shrimp in tomato and this time I had the chicken with ham sauce....I must say that the shrimp really is delicious and full of flavour. The sides that went with it were great, however the chicken wasn't so good....far too salty, didn't add anything to the dining experience other than i gulped my water and a soda down a bit too quickly.

I don't think i'll go again because the food is kind of hit and miss. Next doors' Cha Cha Cha is probably a better option food-wise, but Parada 22 has a relaxed, intimate atmosphere that would be good for catching up with friends.
author: Rachel G.

description:
A good place for small groups, like 2 or 3.  There aren't a lot of tables, and I imagine on weekends the place is crowded. 

GOOD FOOD!
author: Francisco G.

description:
Hello there.

My GOAL: Great/Good Puerto Rican Cuisine & Experience.

MEAL ORDERED: (MAIN) CHICHARRONES DE POLLO 12.

RESULT: Three quarters into the meal, after cutting the fried chicken for a bite I noticed a fried hair follicle - possibly from the chef who certainly isn't wearing proper attire. Keeping my composure and not making too much of an ordeal, my girlfriend insisted on notifying the waitress about the issue. As I agreed to do just that, having shown the waitress the "fried-hair follicle" for validity she offered to compensate the meal less my order.

A few minutes pass, and a manager  - assuming - approached us with the bill and two Sangria drinks.

NOTE: The dinner invoice still had the meal I ordered as being charged, despite the noticeable "Fried-Hair-Follicle".

We left and I decided to pay plus tip, even though our first experience of this restaurant wasn't up to par.

I don't like writing bad reviews...as always CHECK B4 YOU BITE your next meal. 

GOOD LUCK!!!
author: Apollo J.

description: Top notch foooood! Now this is what we call real good consistent meal. Not these other fake chinese & thai places around. Here you really get the value of the $$ you spend. They are not so pricey and I really hope they dont try to make it any higher because then they'll lose quite a number of clientele. I ordered to go and got home and devoured that plate. Was too full, had to take a nap!
author: DeesQue N.

description:
I went here last night with my roommate.  It was nice to do something different than Mexican, pizza or Thai (all of which are way too abundant in the Upper Haight).  The decor was warm and inviting.  The place isn't too big which gave it a nice, cozy feeling.

We ordered a small pitcher of sangria ($12) which seemed a bit watered down and light on fruit.  Cha Cha Cha next door has much better sangria in my opinion.

I ordered the sautéed shrimp in a fresh tomato, onion and pepper cream sauce ($11.50).  It came with red beans, spanish rice and fried plantains.  My favorite part of the dish had to be the plantains.   I will definitely be back just to get a side order of plantains.  The red beans were pretty good too.  They were a bit spicy and very flavorful.  I wasn't in love with the shrimp or spanish rice though.  They were ok, but pretty bland.  Also, the rice was a little over cooked and there were only 5 small shrimp in my dish.
author: Lara O.

description: Wow.  I didn't know I would like Puerto Rican food this much.  We ordered the sampler appetizer and the Mofongo (shrimp dish).  I didn't have it but the cuban sandwich looked awesome.  This is probably one of the best restaurants I've tried in the last month.  It would be 5 stars except that 1) the sangria was too sweet and served in a small glass and 2) the service on a Friday night was very slow (they only had one server working the entire restaurant).  I will be back and hope they fix both of the issues above.
author: Toby C.

description: East Coast/New York city style puerto rican food in the haight next to golden gate park.  Heck yeah.
author: Daniel Y.

description:
Place is a bit small (what isn't on the Haight) but the atmosphere was nice.  We came a bit late (8-9pm) on a Sunday so it wasn't too bad in terms of the wait.
