Food portions were huge.  We wanted the spanish rice, but it ran out, which is really the only downside of the night.  I got the biftec enbecellado, which was steak and it was good.  Came with plantains, rice and beans and a salad.  All good stuff.  My girlfriend got the citrus mint drink, which was a bit sweet/syrup-y but not bad after watering it down.

Waitress was nice as well.
author: Ken L.

description:
Was not sure at first when  we saw this small, narrow but intriguing-looking place on the Haight, next to Cha Cha Cha's but with the later having a long line out the door and noise to follow~ we slipped into Parada 22 to take a chance. While I was able to wheel in (I use a wheelchair) and was able to be seated comfortably in this small place - the toilets are def. NOT handicapped friendly - know that and be prepared if you use a wheelchair or have mobility  issues .
     Having said all this- the food did NOT disappoint!!  We had;
Biftec Encebollado~ sauteed steak with caramelized onions with Spanish rice, white beans, maduros and greens  and the Camarones(prawns marinated in creamy garlic sauce) On A Bed Of Organic Greens With Vinaigrette salad. Prawns were fresh and sweet, perfectly cooked! I can't wait to go back and try more on the menu!
     I do hope they will add cuban coffee in future to menu - it would really be appreciated  and not go amiss!
author: M M.

description: First time trying Puerto Rican food, and it was amazing! I am a huge fan of plantains, so that's what drew me in. I ordered the Pastelon and my girlfriend had the Camarones a La Criolla. Both of our dishes were amazing! We asked the waitress about the Yuca Al Mojo, and she offered us a taste. Neither of us ended up liking it, but it was fun trying. I don't know that we'll ever be back, just because The Haight neighborhood is so rough, but we would certainly recommend the food to anyone who is in the area.
author: Vince A.

description:
My gf brought me take out after her and a friend eating in the restaurant and it was so damn good we decided to go back and eat there again for dinner the very next day! I've never been compelled to do that before, but it was so freaking yummy that I couldn't resist. 

The take home meal was the pork dinner. Mind blowing. 

Second meal I got the fried chicken and yucca. The sauces were incredible. The quality of the food was evident in every bite. And to really top it off, our waiter, Wilson, was super kind, and made us feel right at home. 

Kick ass food. Kick ass service. Kick ass location. I can't recomend this place enough.
author: John B.

description:
Everything my brother and I ordered was so good. Even though I was full, I kept on eating because I just couldn't stop. I'm not from SF, but when I found out there was a Puerto RIcan food place near my brother's place, I decided to come here to check it out.

Why not 5 stars? Because of the paper plates and cups.
author: Rhoi C.

description: Unique and tasty food combined with reasonable prices, pleasant service and a cozy quaint atmosphere. I recommend the appetizer sampler.
author: Chris S.

description:
I was introduced to Puerto Rican food via Sol Food up in San Rafael. Luckily I work up in Marin, so Sol Food for lunch isn't an uncommon occurrence. But I live in the city, and sometimes you don't want to drive 40 minutes each way for some beans and rice.

So I was overjoyed to stumble across Parada 22 today on my way to Amoeba Records. The restaurant looks just like Sol Food! The guy at the counter has a hard-to-understand accent (authenticity!) And it doesn't taste the SAME as Sol Food, but just as good.

I had the vegetariano plate. Everything was delicious-- the beans, the Spanish rice, the potato-and-onion stuff, the fried sweet plantains. I also tried my girlfriend's veggie Cubano sandwich and it was equally as good as my plate, if not better.

Price ain't bad. Highly recommended for Sol Food lovers in the city.
author: Steve g.

description:
Not yet as advertised, but huge potential, lively vibe, electric interior and tasty food. I kept reading that everything would be served in takeout containers, but we got a mix of paper plates and ceramic, and the touted beer selection must not be brewed yet, because they only had Bud and Corona bottles, and there was no Cha Cha Cha sangria. By the time we got there, around 7, they were sold out of all of the main dishes, which was disappointing, but understandable for the first day open.

The food was great!  I had the Cuban Sandwich which was fantastic, but I'll order it with extra pickles next time.  My sidekick had the chicken salad, which she loved, and we agreed that the greens which came with everything were superbly well dressed.  It says something when you order a large salad, finish it off and proceed to pick at the greens on the side plates.  The plantains and yuca were both well made and well seasoned, and I think I will go back to sample the rest of the menu soon.  

Parada 22 is a welcome addition to my neighborhood!
author: Quinn S.

description:
Thank god for local deals! While I'm glad that local deals mean we get to try out new places like this that we otherwise would have missed, am not sure if I'll go back to Parada. 

The place itself is quite cool, a high ceiling  and brick walled place with *cozy* seating, the food I thought was OK.. nothing out of this world. I'm glad that they give their mains with salad, sweet plantains (or savory for some), salsa and rice - it enables Puerto Rican food novices like me to try a few diff things in one go. THe plantains were fine and so was the salad. Me n hubby both got chicken dishes - mine was pan-fried chicken thigh with caramelised onions while hubby's was a breaded,deep-fried chicken thighs. The issue with mine was the chicken was -not-tender, the flavor was so so (plain pan-fried flavor, nothing more) resulting in me eating like a quarter of it :( Hubby's on the other hand was extremely oily, he was dripping oil cutting into it :(  

We both finished our salads though and the spanish rice was delish too .. Oh and I got the citrus mint drink (homemade orange & lemon juice topped off with some ginger ale) which was nice :)
author: Orchids P.

description: The restaurant is overrated, it's too small..capacity says 49 ppl and looks like it can fit only 40. The food has no savor (flavor)!! I'm 100% boriqua n that's not authentic rican food.. Service was not up to par, another patrons were literally waiting behind u to be seated while you dine..
author: Gloria F.

description: I've been eating Puerto Rican food since I could chew; Parada 22 is like eating at my abuela's house. It can get cramped at times, by that gives thw whole place a cozy/homey feeling.
author: Cecilia R.

description:
Let's face it, The Haight aint great (for food)!

Parada 22 is a much needed yummy oasis. This place will be a great afternoon spot for tourists checking out the neighborhood, and for hipsters to grab a lunch and people watch too. 

I had the classic cubano sandwich, lemonade, and a small fresh greens side salad. The sandwich was a masterpiece; fresh bread, warm meat and spicy sweet dressing. 

The service was great, the cute guy behind the counter was very helpful and excited for our patronage. The set up is adorable! Lots of PR culture on the walls and picnic tables for dining in.
author: Halley B.

description:
Great food, great service.  More subtle than ChaChaCha next door with a smaller menu - but a much better bang for your buck at lunch time.  The sandwiches come on very good bread and come with a small side salad (real greens, not that iceberg shyte).  As neighborhood locals we are prone to avoiding that edge of Haight street - but after eating there once or twice it has become a potential regular on our list! Neighbors and tourists both will not be disappointed - we have tried both the Cuban and Chicken sandwich and both were great (if greasy)(but not too greasy). 

And we hear they are about to get Sangria!

YUM!!!!
author: Eric B.

description: Not many vegetarian options, but they are very good! The tostones are spectacular. And the meat dishes are very good also, according to those who ate with me. The space is cozy and charming, the walls covered with photos and Puerto Rican memorabilia. Friendly, attentive, child-friendly service. Large groups may have trouble seating.
author: Max P.

description: Reminded me of being at one of cuban/puerto rican places I frequent. It's a little smaller than most places in SFO, but the food reminds me of being in the east coast. It's a short walk to the park and the bus station is right at the corner so you can get to downtown easily. It's a good place to visit.
author: Edward I.

description: The food at Parada 22 is mediocre, but I suppose does the trick if you really crave Latin food. The food was good, but portions were not really big for the price. We paid $13 for the Mofongo with Shrimp but the sauce was quite bland. My wife got the Pibil (pork) which was sized well, but was not well seasoned, slightly bland to taste. The problem is that the taste is quite bland, and we needed to add a lot of salsa. Value for worth was just okay.
author: Varun B.

description: The food here seems pretty good everytime I have been here, even though a few times I've been here a portion sizes have seemed a little small
author: Rachel N.

description:
I live 2 blocks away, so of course I was stoked when I heard that a Puerto Rican place was opening up! (There aren't that many in the city if you haven't already noticed.) 

Apparently they brought in someone from Puerto Rico to make sure the place had a sense of authenticity. Man, I love me some exposed brick!! The restaurant is eclectic and vibrant with a great turquoise wall, plants, old photographs, and did I mention exposed brick?

The menu is varied and it was hard to choose what to order. We went with pernil asado (roasted leg of pork) which came with beans and rice, pollo emparedado (sandwich on french baguette) served with salad, and a side order of the maduros (sweet plantains). 

I was disappointed in the number of plantains that came with the side dish - literally 5 (and it's $4.50). If there had been a couple more I wouldn't be complaining. Everything else was excellent. The leg of pork was moist and flavorful, although there were a couple fatty pieces. The sandwich was the best - very savory - but be warned: it's no Ike's. The sandwich is on the flat side and doesn't have many toppings, but it's delicious!!

Overall, I'm excited about this is a new addition to the 'hood. There's a rumor going around about them serving sangria (possibly from Cha Cha Cha's next door!?)...I'll definitely be back to check it out!

Full menu here: http://www.thrillist.com/popup/120739/120740_popup.jpg Note: there are a few funny spelling errors on the menu (my boyfriend thought "cornona" beer was the best)
author: Hannah L.

description: Love this Place! I am obsessed with the camerones. Every time I go into the city I try to make it here.
author: Lor B.

description: If you know anything about authentic Puerto Rican food, then you will know that this food DOES NOT COME ANYWHERE near the flavor that it should have. This place is a very poor example of what authentic Puerto Rican food should taste like. Don't waste your time or money!!! The only good thing there is the cuban sandwich. The decor is casual and trendy and a complete copy of Sol Food in the North Bay. If you want to delicious Puerto Rican food, then it's better to make the drive to SOL because at least there, you will not be disappointed!
author: Christina N.

description:
a quiet little joint with lots of character, this place has good food and friendly service. I got the cubano that comes with a tasty, but simple salad the fried plantains with a yummy dipping sauce. The sangria was great too! my only "complaint" if you you could even call it one is the fact that it's a little on the pricey side.....i get it. it's a hip little joint on trendy haight street. 

check out the oddball staircase to what I assume is storage that drops down from the ceiling near the kitchen. It hella tripped me out!
author: Caddy M.

description: Went here with some friends and the food is worth the trip. Our particular experience was brought down by sub par service. The place wasn't even very busy and we had to ask for menus, flag the waiter down for drinks, ask a second time for our drinks, ask for the bill a couple times...you get the point. The waiter just didn't seem to be with it. All this being said we all agreed that we would definitely go back again as each of us enjoyed our meals. Try the Puerto Rican sauce on the table is spicy with a great flavor.
author: Jeff O.

description: Never had puerto rican food before, but a friend brought me here one night and showed me what i'd been missing out on. the first time, we ordered the pollo a la criolla and some kind of pork thing, and we shared some sangria and tostones.  The chicken was absolutely fantastic.  Really tender and well cooked with some tasty veggies and spices.  But my favorite part of the meal was definitely the tostones.  Those things are like crispy little morsels of deliciousness.  the perfect amount of sweet and savory, and the sauce they give you to dip it in is tangy and matches the tostones perfectly.  No complaints about service either, I thought they were all very friendly and responsive.  Really nice little place to grab dinner, and the neighborhood is.. interesting as well.  Overall always a great experience here.
author: Evelyn T.

description:
Inside is small and can be cramped, feels homey like a mom pop shop and you can see the cooks at work.

Totally dug the Eggplant sandwich! Will come back for more for sure!!

Pernil asado is good too. But I really liked the sandwich more ;)
author: Brad L.

description: Today was my husband & I first time at Parada 22. I had the pernil asado. From a culinary standpoint and very familiar with Latin Cuisine's I have found that the pork was very salty barely edible,the fried plantains was garnished with black pepper on them which I find that's not traditional,the yellow rice and beans was not fresh tasted like a day old. The service was hectic where they lacked waiters or waitress's.
author: Tanya G.

description:
I think that the best food moments are when they're spontaneous. Don't ya think? Like you and your friend are hungry but aren't craving anything, so you just go to a random restaurant. Well, that is what happened to me last night! I've never been to Parada 22 before and my friend suggested we go there. Boy am i glad he picked this gem of a place. It's right next to Cha Cha Cha's and i hear that they're both owned by the same person? Anyways, hella bomb ass Puerto Rican food :)
I got the Pollo Encebollado and by golly it was SO GOOOOOD. I highly recommend it...major nomnomz.
author: Suzan L.

description: We were looking for a last-minute place for dinner and we were told by a local that we wouldn't be disappointed. It was true! The food is Puerto Rican, which is similar to Mexican, but with fried plantains instead of tortillas. Had the steak and the pork entrees --- both were delicious. The sangria was also excellent. The food has a nice home-cooked feel to it, and the staff were super nice. Well-priced too. I would definitely eat here often if I lived in the area.
author: Laurent L.

description: Red bean (meat) and white bean (vegan) sides rock. Mofongo wonderful. Neighborhood historically important but sketchy. Our first experience was 5 stars.  Ohh yeah... We will be back soon!
author: Thomas B.

description:
Funky Porto Rican decor, decent food.
The only disapointment is that it is owned by Cha Cha Cha.
author: Marcel C.

description: The most amazing food of this types have ever had.  Everything was really great.  I was really disappointed when I finished my food and had none left to eat.  The restaurant like many places on haight is a little bit crowded, but the server still managed to be very attentive.  I got to sit in the corner with the crayons and had fun drawing while I waited for my food.  I would highly recommend if you want something to eat that will make you happy to be alive.
author: Peter G.

description: Parada 22 has some amazing food! The prices are impeccable and service is to a "T." I came here on a whim while shopping on Haight St. I really wasn't expecting much, but to my surprise, the food was mouth-watering! Everyone who works at the restaurant welcomes all patrons with open arms and is more than willing to suggest an array of delectable dishes off their menu. As someone from LA, with no known Puerto Rican restaurants around, this place takes the CAKE!
author: Victoria S.

description: I have been in this place 3 times. 1) Sandwich Cubano, 2) Pastelon,  and 3)Mofongo Relleno de camarones. Everything was delicious. The flavor, portion size, cleanness, price, and ambiance are really good. It is not a big place (SF space), but comfortable, It is worth to come here.
author: Jax R.

description: Eggplant sandwich was great, the salad wasn't soggy with dressing, it was perfectly coated.  Latin music and ambiance.  Dirty bathrooms.
author: D M.

description:
Craving Puerto Rican food after getting a taste outside of the city, a friend and I found Parada 22 via Yelp.

The verdict:  delicious!  I tasted the pernil asado and the cuban sandwich.  Both were not fatty at all, which is always my fear with pork.  The salad was light and tasty, the maduros were at the perfect stage of ripeness, the rice was simple yet tasty and the red beans were very flavorful with a great balance of spice.  

Further, the staff was friendly and the space has a great feel.  I'll definitely be back!
author: Michelle M.

description:
Went here today and it was one of those "need to go home and Yelp this place" moments.  Cash only...let's just get that out of the way first since this city is kinda 50/50 on that. 

After raving about the food in SF last night to some folks from Texas I decided to try Parada 22 out for lunch today. Was assuming that someone in SF would know how to make pretty good Puerto Rican food. I'm pretty glad that I rarely work from home because I would probably have that pork plate more than twice a week if I did. 

So the pork plate was great. I got the red beans and rice on the side,  a little salad with the perfect amount of vinaigrette, and some delicious fried plantains - $9.50. Everything was delicious. Don't expect fried carnitas though, (I love how spell check wants me to say "carnival" instead of "carnitas") cause you might be disappointed. A few pieces of the pork were a tiny bit dry, but that's only if I'm being really really picky, and trying to find something to complain about. 

Liz ordered the chicken salad - $8. It was also amazing, but again....if I'm trying to set expectations for you like the carnitas comment....it was all dark meat (which we love), so don't expect some all white meat TGIFriday's chicken salad. Again, the salad had the perfect amount of vinaigrette. 

The small touches make all of the difference, and the fact that they had two pitchers of water (one with limes and one with lemons) was awesome. We did order drinks though, which were also AMAZING. The sweet tea was the perfect amount of sweet (unlike the ultra sweet tea at Baby Blues), and the lemonade was incredibly satisfying - $2 each.

This might be one of the longer reviews that I've written, but Parada 22 was pretty f'ing amazing, so it was well deserved. I haven't even touched on the ultra sweet interior, but you'll love that too. Unless you're like, a big fat jerk or something :)
author: Mike M.

description: Blown away by the vintage decor and perfectly cooked & seasoned food.  We eat at many cuban/pr/dominican restaurants in NYC, and to be amazed in SF we were so happy.  The steak was juicy, tostones perfectly toasted and the sangria strong.  Highly recommended!!!!!!!!
author: Chris V.

description: First of all.. I want to make this clear: Parada 22 serves PUERTO RICAN FOOD! Por favor, honey, get that right. Sorry, I had to go there because a previous reviewer had said it's Cuban food. Um no, there is a difference and it gets on my damn nerve. I have family in Puerto Rico and my some of my family members are Puerto Rican (I am Asian) so I do know a thing or two about Puerto Rican food. As soon as I stepped in (with Puerto Rican music on full blast) I nearly balled like a baby as it made me miss Puerto Rico so much. But let's be real here... our reviews our based on food not decorations. We went for lunch on a Wednesday afternoon so it was quiet as we were the first ones there. Our waitress was super friendly. My boyfriend ordered their mofungo with chicken instead (i'm allergic to shrimp) and I ordered the grilled chicken with onions (pollo encebollado). We were surprised at how big their lunch portions were. It  came with a side of beans, salad, rice and plantains. Their plantains were cooked a lot better and even tasted better than Cha Cha Cha's. Both are of our lunches were good; my chicken was made just right and the caramelized onions really added some kick to it. My boyfriend said his mofungo was "everything he dreamed and more." Their prices are very decent ($9 for the chicken and $12 for mofungo) considering how big their lunch portions are. We noticed that the table next to our devoured their food in a matter of minutes (which to me is a good sign). I am def. coming back next time and will be trying their desserts.
author: selina n.

description: Im gonna go with 4 just because Sol Food is still the best. However, for SF this is the place to go for Puerto Rican for sure. I like the old photos and furniture laid back vibe and the food is awesome. The fried chicken, yucca, and flan were perfect.
author: Lilia D.

description: Ate at Nopa this past Saturday. Parada kicks it's butt. The hype and prices at Nopa are undeserved. The food at Parada is beautiful. From the Pernil Asado, Biftec, and Habichuelas Blancas to the incredible habanaro and carrot sauce at every table. The sauce is so good they had to put it in squeeze bottles because when it was in glass bottles with screw tops people were stealing it. Go there now before word gets out and lines form.
author: Vincent K.

description:
If you love Latin food (Cuban, Domincan, Brazilian etc.) believe me when I say you MUST try this place! 

Its EXTREMELY small inside (max capacity is like 49 I think), but the food is just...no words for it lol.

The BF and I went here on a Sunday Evening after visiting Vista Point and brought our A-Game appetites (we were starving).

Their menu selection is small, perfect for those indecisive eaters (like me!).

I ordered the steak w/ maduros (fried plaintains), spanish rice, and spinach salad, and white beans.

The BF ordered the shrimp and it came with the same sides.

Both dishes were so yummy! I also ordered a glass of the Sangria (alcoholic) cuase I never had it before...it was very good. A lil on the sweet side, but still a great compliment to the food. 

Def coming back when were in SF again!!!!
author: M S.

description:
So... in keeping with only writing positive reviews... I was thrilled when at lunch today I was reminded how much I enjoy Parada 22.  

Yaaaaaaaaaye!!!!  Another review to write!!!!  We live in the neighborhood, it's one of our neighborhood faves.  When we go: the service is always warm and friendly and the food is always delish. It's a cozy little place where you can get great food without busting the bank. 

What you can count on:
Cane sugar coke in the bottle
Maduros (plantains, nom, nom, nom)
Cubano Sandwich ((nom, nom, nom)
Camarones A la Criolla (it's the perfect meal, spanish rice, white beans, salad, and shrimp is this divine sauce)
author: Lani N.

description: I was amazed at the quality and mouth watering flavour of my Cuban sandwich, and I loved the comfy and interesting decor.  Would love to eat here again.  I was visiting San Francisco and this was easily the best lunch I had the entire time I was there!!
author: Amy S.

description: I am addicted to the Bistec Salad with either creamy cilantro sauce or vinaigrette. For an extra $3, I get more meat!! so mouthwatering. They cook that steak so perfectly and season it so well. A must try. I have yet to try the coconut flan.
author: Shayenne G.

description:
I thought this place was just ok, nothing special. It's small, cute with all the decor and wall of canned/pkgd goods and clean. 

The Biftec Encebollado was tough, and way too difficult to cut with just a butter knife on the table. The onions were nicely caramelized, but the meat lacked any substantial flavor. The spanish rice was good, I'd recommend getting that with your meal, and the salad was lightly dressed.

The cuban sandwich was just alright. The bread wasn't pressed down like a panini and the slices of pork were kinda dry and not thinly sliced, so that made it tough to bite without the sandwich falling apart on you. I've originally had a Cubano in Miami and that was off the hook!! I'm still chasing that high and haven't found one close yet. 

Customer service was friendly and good, she checked in on us a couple of times, but granted the place was empty at the time.
author: Ly T.

description: Sabrosisimo! Best Tostones of my life, and I'm old! :-) Spanish Rice is crazy good and the Red Bean were from another dimension in sophisticated flavor layering. Do not miss out if you're in the neighborhood.
author: antonio w.

description:
This place is one more jewel of a restaurant that makes me think ---  thank the heavens I live in San Fran (and not Podunk), where super tasty food abounds!

My friends and I set-out to go to Cha Cha Cha Sat. evening but when we heard about the 1.5 hr wait we decided F$#k that and went to  Parada 22 right next store. Wow were we glad that we did. 

The food here is truly stunning (and super vegetarian friendly). We had the eggplant sandwich and the vegi plate and both were over the top, the yucca is going to be one of those things I fantasize about at night...The portions were very generous and I thought the service was pretty stellar too.

The space itself is cute and hip, though a bit loud and seating limited. Overall thought I highly recommend you pop into this new joint and give it a try -I doubt you'll be disappointed. Happy eating
author: alana d.

description: Very good Puerto Rican food. I had the pork on rice and it was phenomenal. The pork was so tender. The Spanish rice and the ripe plantains were delicious. The place itself is a small restaurant decorated with family pictures of Puerto Rico. Note: this place is like 20 times better than Sol food in marin.
author: Suhaila S.

description:
This place appears to be Puerto Rican, they have all these random Puerto Rican corn flake boxes on the wall, though my roomie is convinced it is Cuban. In his defense, the food is pretty similar to Cuban food and I can see his misunderstanding (i.e. if you serve me plantains, I think Cuban food).

I've only had the pork entree here so far, but it was delicious, and I definitely plan to come back and try one of their sandwiches.  It is definitely nice to see a good quality restaurant open up in the Upper Haight.

My biggest complaint is that the seating in the restaurant is minimalistic and not super comfortable - they basically have rows of lunch benches.  I guess the lunch benches are acceptable, if you come to the restaurant expecting lunch benches, but I can definitely see getting take-out instead.
author: E-dough R.

description:
I'm by no means an expert on Puerto Rican food, so I'm not going to evaluate the authenticity of these dishes.  All I can say is that the style seems very similar to Cuban food with the heavy use of beans, rice, plantains, yucca, and sauces throughout their dishes.  Overall, it was very tasty and flavorful!  The pork dish was succulent and prepared just right, not too dry and not too moist.  My GF had the vegetarian yucca dish which had an incredible amount of flavor for a dish that sounded so boring on paper.

Good beer selection for such a small place plus homemade desserts seal the deal for another return in the near future.
author: Mike B.

description:
The place was a little seedy in terms of seating.  We were seated on stool chairs in the corner by the entrance at a makeshift table that was literally two connected two by fours protruding out of the wall.  There wasn't much of an assortment on the menu either.  There were no pasteles or arroz con gandules for starters.  Puerto Rican food is more than just a few entrees.  They more than likely do this to cut cost and promote efficiency, at the expense of an unknowing consumer.  It's apparent that the owner gets away with it in light of the mindset of those in the area that just don't know what good Puerto Rican food is really about. 

I won't return.  Instead, I'll give my business to Nueva Frutilandia, a place in the Mission district that is by far better in every respect and the complete opposite of the above stated.

One more thing:  The bistec encebollado was really tough and the beans looked more like lentils than the real pink beans used by Puerto Ricans.  The rice was acceptably so so.  The dishes overall were cold and there were no refills on the sweet tea.  The malta India was good, but then again what can one expect from something that's already bottled elsewhere.
author: John Q.

description: I had the Pernil with red beans and extra side of plaintains (maduros/amarillos) and yucca. The beans were a little to thick for me, but still very good (I think this may simply be a preference as some in my family like it this way but my mother always made them a little thinner). The pernil had all the right flavors but I would have appreciated some of the roasted skin mixed in there (called cueritos) to give it that extra bit of fatty moisture. The yucca was outstanding. I hope to see some green plantain dishes such as mofongo and tostones being served in the future here as well.
author: Alexis G.

description: The food was authentic and taste good, and A+ service. The sangria was great and the decor excelente!  I would definitely go back very soon...
author: Jared M.

description: Came to parada at 2:40 pm and finally got seated at 3:06 pm. The bottomless mimosas end at 3 pm I asked if I could get the bottomless mimosas since I had been waiting over 20minutes for a table and was informed from the waitress "no, not at all." Am a constant customer and will not be returning because every time have had an issue with the service and the small restaurant. Will be telling all my friends about this. Hopefully they will rectify the situation but because I know they won't I would state the food is good but the service and size are horrible. Do not go here!!! Order out if you must but do not tip they do not deserve it!!! Horrible staff and horrible space!!!
author: Jaimie M.

description:
I haven't had too much Puerto Rican food in my lifetime, aside from arroz con gandules.  So I can't say how "authentic" the food is.  But I can speak on the deliciousness of the food at Parada 22.  

I had the grilled chicken sandwich, and my BF had the classic cuban.  Both came with side salads, and both were amazing!  I couldnt get enough of my own sandwich which was slathered with jack cheese and grilled onions on top of juicy chicken.  And OH MAN, the cuban! OH MAN!  I wanted to steal it from my boyfriend, seriously!  The flavors were on point and so savory.  You know, the salad is very simple with a light dressing but its refreshing against the flavorful sandwiches.

We definitely want to come back and try the plate dishes.  They look and smell so good.  

Water is self-serve towards the register.
author: Lesliegh H.

description: Okay, so it's been a while since I visited but had to write a review because I loved this place.  Parada 22 is a cute little place; with minimal seating. Came here on a weekend for a late lunch with friends.  We all ordered different "main" items and everyone really enjoyed their food.  I can only recall my order which was the camarones (shrimp) a la criolla. It was served with salad, rice and beans, and plantains.  I finished everything on my plate; felt satisfied but not super full.  The food is light and fresh and tastes home made.  Order the sangria; you must!  Can't wait to go back! :-)
author: NEHA G.

description:
So happy to finally have a Puerto Rican restaurant in the city! I'm half Puerto Rican and grew up eating many homemade dishes and I think this place measures up. It's great that they have a sampler; I especially liked their amarillos, chicharron, and pernil asado. For my main dish I had chicken which was pretty good but not great (it is not on their main menu because it was a daily special but it was my first time ever having this PR dish so I don't know the name). I was very bummed out not to see arroz con gandules, pastelillos, or asopao on the menu, but hopefully they make it on there sometime. 

The restaurant is small so I would not recommend for large groups but I did like the decor a lot and the service was great. 

Overall I think the food and ambiance were good but not quite great. But I am still very happy that there is a Puerto Rican restaurant in the city since they are extremely rare in the west coast! I will definitely be returning to try more of their dishes, I am very curious to taste their mofongo.
author: Christine S.

description:
Boricuas put your hands up, there's finally a place to get homestyle PR food. Platano, arroz, habichuelas, you know the deal. So why not a 5 star?

It's the prices/portion size. When I get Puerto Rican food, I'm expecting a boatload of food, enough to share with my amigos down in the handball courts. At least the manager was pretty cool, definitely a gringo. 

I had the chicken thighs, not sure if it was super boricua. Going with the pork next time.
author: Kenny H.

description:
So delicious! First time here, went with a group of four. I've never had Puerto Rican food before, but after coming here, it might not be the last time! I ordered the shrimp dish and it was DELICIOUS! My friends got the roasted pork, chicken thighs, and a sandwich... all of which were amazing! 

Everything had such good flavor, so well-seasoned, and decently priced. It has a nice intimate feel to it, and we were sat quickly as there was no wait. I will definitely be coming here again!
author: Jackie M.

description: Best platanos maduros i've ever had in my life...
author: Leah P.

description:
This not got 5 stars just because I'm not sure it's worth the price.
It's not expensive, but 9$ for a sandwich can be considered a little bit too much maybe. Also plates are very very good.
But the Cubano Sandwich was just delicious, one of the best sandwiches in the city I've ever tried. Sangria was really good too!
We found a spot in 9 of us after a waiting of about 20 minutes. Definitely not for big group, the place is tiny but very cozy.
author: Luca D.

description: This place is legitimately amazing, what a gem. I loved trying this new cuisine. Order the pastelon if you love sweet/savory dishes, it will blow your mind.
author: Erin W.

description: We came here for an early Sunday dinner.  Stopped off at Cha Cha Cha and it was already full, so we decided to check out Parada 22.  Very impressed with the quality of food for the price.  I had the Biftec, which was a steak sandwich with carmelized onions, jack cheese and garlic. Steak was tender and the sandwich was a messy one you dive into.  We also shared arroz blanco and the tostones which had a nice crunch with a soft center. Small dining room and it got busy quickly.  Will definitely be back.
author: Ryan O.

description: Finally!! Tasty, legitimate Caribbean flavors. I got the steak with caramelized onions and red beans with white rice. The rice and beans were my hook, they tasted just like my P. Rican step mom used to make. Just so flavorful with little pieces of ham. Mmmm...next time I'm getting just a bowl of white rice and beans. My hubby got the shrimp mofongo and it was also very flavorful, just not authentic per what we had on the island. It's worth repeating though. We also shared a sample platter and everything on it was fantastic. I'm looking forward to more rice and beans, they were this pregnant lady's dream!
author: Maria Valentina B.

description: big portions, good food, cute restaurant. Great stop if you're in the haight!
author: Caroline D.

description:
We've now been to this place twice.  The place is small, but I like the decor (old PR memorabilia and stuff).  The food is very tasty and the flavors are close to home.  I was, however, disappointed by the mofongo.  Not enough plantain; too much sauce made it mushy...  Still, good flavors.  

We were told the sangria is the same from next door's Cha-Cha-Cha.  I tried it, but it is a little too sweet for my taste and nowhere near close to Fido's in the Island.  (But, seriously, what is?  ;) )

Good rice and beans; the tostones were crispy; the pernil was well cooked and seasoned.  I saw other dishes that looked yummy, which means I'll have to go back to try them.  Rum cake and flan looked interesting, but after our big meal, we were too full to consider dessert.  Next time? :)

Wait staff was friendly and efficient, in spite of being extremely busy.  

Yes, I plan to go back.  :)
author: M M.

description:
Very good lunch time decision for me today! They have shifted from an "order at the counter" restaurant to wait service which is nice since several of the previous reviewers had commented on the lack of this service for the money spent on a meal. 

I tried the pollo sandwich (bread, chicken, sauce (yum), cheese, and carmelized onions) which comes with a small side salad. My two other friends tried other sandwiches and we ordered the Maduros to share between the three of us. My total of the meal (with tax and tip) came out to about $13.50 which I don't think is too bad in the City and the sandwich was fantastic (my friends had similar good experiences)!

CASH only FYI!! I always like to know this in advance!
author: Amber E.

description:
Hands down, one of my favorite restaurants in the city, or maybe even anywhere. Delicious. So good. Yum. Drooooooool... OK OK OK, back to the review. 

I've tried almost everything on the menu. Never been disapppointed with any dish. I usually do a kind of gamble or blindfolded point and pick when I don't know what I feel like and can't decide. Even the greens that come with the entrees and appetizers is on point. Delicious and fresh dressing, crisp fresh lettuce, dressed just right. My man says the tostones are exactly like the ones his Ecuadorian father makes. The bistec reminds me of the bistec encebollado that my host mom used to make me when I lived in Mexico. (yes, I know, Ecuadorian and Mexican are different than Puerto Rican, but still) The yuca is the best I've ever had anywhere, and yeah, I lived in Mexico for over a year. 

To boot, the wait staff/service is on point. They are kind, attentive, and give the place a laid back, welcoming atmosphere. 

Not sure if they are still doing the brunch thing, but I did make it out to their brunch once and it was delish, too. Honestly, no surprise. 

Parada 22, gracias por su comida deliciosa! Que rica!
author: Alison W.

description:
Note on edit:  Totally consistent each time.  Just earned the 5th star.

One of our favorites.

Only had one bad experience here and it had to do more with the attitude of the guy behind the counter than the quality of the food.  I haven't seen that guy since so, hopefully, he quit.

Went last night and had the mofongo and the pastelon.  Just really good stuff.  Filling and worth it.  The rice and beans on the side were gone first if that says anything.  I think the side salad is fantastic.  There's a variety of greens that are just dressed so as not to obscure the flavor of the leaves.  Just right.

The restaurant itself is interesting.  The walls are covered with the owner's family pictures and other historical and other interesting things like newspapers and old-timey advertisements.  My favorite is the vintage videos playing on a small screen in a wood box on one side of the restaurant.

No pretense and well worth the money.
author: Steve F.

description: OMG...after a graduation at USF my family and I stopped at this incredible Puerto Rican cuisine restaurant.  My brother and I are Puerto Rican and craved our mom's home cooking.  This place surpassed our expectations everything was outstanding. The pernil rocked...the mofongo with shrimp was incredible, the rice and beans to die for. Service was great...I just can't wait to go back...
author: Lucy S.

description: The food in this place was really tasty and with a lot of flavor. The service was great. Thank you for giving me a little piece of PR.
author: Bren R.

description: Great food and tasty sangria!  Cute restaurant, relaxed ambiance and to top off our experience, we had a friendly and attentive waiter.  I'll definitely be back.
author: Zanne S.

description: Deslish!  I had the first thing on the menu, a lasagna dish with fried plantanes instead of pasta.  WHA!?, you might be thinking.  Yeah, it sounds totally weird, but it made my taste buds do a sexy dance.  Super sweet server lady.  Really yummy Sangria!
author: Audrey K.

description: This review is specifically about the brunch they now serve at Parada 22. Yes, they're now serving brunch and it's seriously awesome! I selfishly don't want to tell people about it, because right now there's no wait. But they deserve the praise. From their biscuits and gravy (YUM!) and Eggs Desayuno to their French Toast and sausage, everything I've had there has simply been tastier than the other breakfasts I've had in the area.
author: Steven A.

description: Parada 22 reminds of my trips to PR.  Oh how I miss you Puerto Rico with your rich history, amazing blue skies, endless beaches and men who are made like gods.  But I digress.  The food here is reminiscent of Puerto Rican homestyle cooking minus the lechonera, the food amazing!  Thanks to ScoutMob I was able to find out about Parada 22.  Stop by and eat there already!!
author: ismael d.

description: Being Puerto Rican, New York born and raised,  I like this place because it's hard to get carribean food here in the Bay area. This place is better than Cha cha Chas but it's diluted and Americanized. Pernil or roast pork is very good as are the tostones. But any PR restaurant knows that rice and beans are the staple dish not sides and mofongo is fried with bits of pork in it, not boiled. Also many of the traditional dishes such as morcilla, mondongo, arroz con gandules etc are not available. Portions are small but filling.ambiance is nice and cozy. Its a nice place but most of the dishes I make better myself.
author: sal m.

description: Hidden gem! Delicious food & sangria, great prices, and no line on a Saturday night? Um, yep, we'll be back. New neighborhood favorite!
author: Emily A.

description: Parada 22 was my first introduction to Puerto Rican food -- and what an introduction it was. Everything here was amazing from the camarones to the fried bananas. I will DEFINITELY be coming back for the camarones a la criolla. As a South Indian, this type of food reminds me a LOT of my native South Indian Food. Great, Great place to eat!
author: Anjali M.

description: What a find! Had dinner there with friends two nights ago and I was charmed by Parada 22 right off the bat. The owner was gracious and helped us find our best options on the menu. I had the chicken with onions which was great - light and cooked/seasoned properly, just like I had hoped for. A girlfriend ordered the fried chicken dish and I was a little jealous I didn't do the same. I had a bite, it was amazing! The ambiance couldn't have been cuter, it's a small spot though so plan accordingly! Love to see great restaurants flourish, go Parada 22, go!
author: Alexandra S.

description: I was so excited when this restaurant opened. The vibe in there is just amazing. I always feel like family when I go there. The food is great too. It would be unfair to compare Parada 22 to another Puerto Rican restaurant up north which is 'to die for' so I won't do it. Both restaurants are pretty different but they offer similar dishes. Both are great in their own way. The menu is pretty extensive and everything always tastes fresh and flavorful. I met a Puerto Rican tourist on the street recently and she told me that the place up north wasn't as authentic as Parada 22.
author: L. L.

description: Seriously good Puerta Rican/Cuban on the Haight.  Cubano Clasico sandwich was THE BOMB.  "Two types of pork and a pickle" you cannot go wrong here.  Ordered some fried plantaines on the side which were crispy and great for dipping in their salsa.  Great find thanks to Yelp!
author: Daniel C.

description: I will never eat here again! First of all, the food isn't even that great. Secondly, after my boyfriend ate most of his meal, he found a short black hair in his chicharron. We really didn't want to make a big deal of it but I thought they should know. I noticed the cook wasn't wearing a hair net or anything. I told the waitress and she told us that they would not charge us for that meal. We weren't even expecting that but thought that would make up for it. Next thing I know, the other guy working, (I am assuming he's the manager or owner) came with the check, two small glasses of sangrias, and apologized for the hair in our food. I thought in addition to not charging us for the meal that he was going above and beyond by doing that gesture. Then I noticed that he did charg us for the meal that had the hair in it! I was shocked after being told we were not going to be charged for it. Needless to say, that was gross! I wanted to throw up for my boyfriend. I wondered if I had hair in my food too but just didn't see it. I hope that's not the case. The cook needs to wear a hair net! If you want hair in your food and have to pay for it, then this is the place for you. I will continue to search for yummy Puerto Rican food but will never come back to this place. Oh, btw, they do not have pasteles or arroz con gondule which is what I really wanted and the sweet plantains portion was  very small. Definitely not worth the money. The restaurant is small and you will feel crowded there. I suggest you go somewhere else.
author: Rochelle J.

description: The odd hybrid of Southern girl/pseudo-Hipster in me loves the occasional no-frills homestyle meal, which is what lead to take Scoutmob up on their offer to try Parada 22 at a great discount. Unfortunately, even with the deal I was left unimpressed. I could excuse the minute-maid lemonade served in paper cups and food served cafeteria-style...food cooked cafeteria style, however, not so much. Given the prices (lower mid-range) my dishes lacked necessary character and an authentic Puerto Rican kick. Unless Scoutmob decides to present me with an even better offer I can't resist I'm not sure if it's worth a second shot.
author: Mahsa K.

description:
Rave rave rave. loved the platter of so many delicious items on one plate. Get the yellow rice. get it. with red beans. and you get a salad and maduros (plantains). for me, the pernil asado was a bit too much meat to other components, but it was a delicious mix of sweet, sour, and savory.

next time i'm trying the yucca platter.
author: Jade L.

description:
So my mom, my friend, his son and I walked in to this mediocre place, just because we never had Puertorican food before...

Tables were dirty and nobody was there, 2 cooks and 2 servers, probably "too busy" to keep a restaurant in a decent way right?

Only 1 revolting restroom for women and men, you actually have to walk through the kitchen to get there, so you can see all the dirt on the floor, and the poor conditions that they work and cook.

Food and service were mediocre, but the worst part was when I wanted to pay the bill and I realized that someone had stolen my purse from my chair!!!!!!
I know this could happen anywhere, but not a manager was present, only my very nervous waitress who called the police, but nobody took my info in case they found something that could help me to get some information about my personal belongings, nothing!!!!!
My opinion is that YOU SHOULD NOT EAT HERE, it is not worthy!!
The neighborhood is horrible and you probably do not want to take the risk to be around!!
Do not go to this place!!!
author: Maria Loreto R.

description: We had a simple meal at Parada 22 before the Earthquakes-Sounders game at Kezar.  We had never had puerto rican food before, so can't judge authenticity, but we were very happy with our restaurant choice.  One of the closest restaurants to Kezar, it only seats about 20. The service was friendly, the decor cute, and the restroom very clean.  I had the vegetarian platter, which included yellow rice, white beans, yucca, salad, and plantains.  While yummy, it was kind of carb-heavy (I'm pre-diabetic), as yucca, it turns out, is like potato.  My buddy found the salad with chicken excellent.  Portions were good-sized.  Prices were very reasonable.
author: MJ L.

description:
I have been here twice and have plans to keep coming back! The food is great, reasonably priced, and the staff is friendly. Yaay! It's a good place to eat. They have COCONUT FLAN, which can only be properly eaten with a big a$$ spoon ;)

I have tried the following: Biftec Encebollado, Mofongo, Maduros, the sampler, Pastelon, rum cake and coconut flan. All are pretty good. My favorite so far would have to be the Pastalon, which is like a lasagna with the pasta replaced with strips of fried plantain (I know what you may be thinking, I wouldn't have thought so too, but it's REALLY good). When you get the choice between the white rice and spanish rice take the spanish rice it's very flavorful. Also red beans over white beans (white beans are like listening to jazz whereas the red beans are a little bit rock and roll). The red beans have a little kick to them. A lot of the plates are prepared with plantains so keep that in mind if you're considering the maduros it would be redundant to order them and a dish prepared with plantains. For dessert go ahead try the coconut flan, it's sweet not eggy like other types of flan. Do it, do it, do it!!!

Finally, the place itself is pretty interesting, lots of pictures on the walls, and drawings from kids that have visited. There are only a handful of tables and some seating on the side facing the wall. Sitting facing the wall turns out be a better move if you're on a date since you're less likely to be affected by the staff moving around while tending to the other tables which are crowded together.

Great place for a great meal under 30 bucks :)
author: Jose U.

description:
I've been to Parada 22 about once a month at least for the past 6 months and have yet to be disappointed. I like the space (nice blue color, open kitchen, comfortable seating), I like the service (friendly and attentive), and I love the food. Just the beans -- white or red -- really good. I've had the shrimp, the trout (whatta deal), braised chicken thigh -- all good. My husband loves the roast pork and the steak (eat it with the hot sauce provided). Very affordable. 
Also like to mix their sweet tea and lemonade. Yum. 
Keep fearing the place will get too packed, but so far it's busy but not overwhelmed. Whew. 
Went today for lunch and discovered they now have full service instead of counter-ordering. I miss their old communal tables -- the space seemed more open before, but the change didn't ruin it.
author: Lola X.

description:
OK, so here's the deal.  I live right around the corner from this place so you can imagine how bad I wanted to love it!  Unfortunately, that was not the case, BUT the place has potential and I feel that after a few months it can be great.  

Here's what I did not like:
Very small portions.  I got the plato vegetariano and I swear it wasn't enough food for a kid.  It had two pieces of maduros and 1 piece of yucca and seriously like 3 lettuce leafs, but there were plenty of white beans, which were yummy!  My bf had the pollo dish and while he liked it just fine, it was also very small and there was only 1 small chicken thigh. 
Lastly, their only dessert was rum cake was decent, but it was definitely not homemade.

THE GOOD 
I loved the decor, the whole place was visually stimulating and fresh. the food was tasty, but its certainly not a go to dinner place.  Its good for a light lunch or order a lot of sides and add to something you've already cooked at home.
I'll give it a couple of months to get settled and make some improvements then try it again.
author: Molly M.

description:
Good, honest Latin American food. Tremendous value.  Diamante gives it FIVE stars!  

Try the Pernil Asado w/ extra platanos maduros.
author: Edward S.

description: Comida de Puerto Ricano!!! MMmmm,  Im definetly a fan now. We went for dinner last night. We ordered a platter of everything on the menu. Penil, Camarones, platanos maduros, spanish rice, red beans, white beans.Mofongo, CocoRico and a raspberry torte for dessert. Everything was delicioso! Were definetly going back.
author: Raquel Q.

description: Being that I'm Puerto Rican and love the food this place is a nice alternative to doing it yourself.  I really liked the decor and obviously they went out of their way to make it look authentic.  I understand the limited menu and would give them 5 stars if they every now and then served other dishes like pasteles or served up lechon (whole roasted pig).
author: Pete P.

description:
This place has it all! 
Deliciously tender meats, fresh seafoods, SHAMAZING rice and other hearty starchy things. TVs in little wall-mounted boxes playing Ring-like loops of old timey things (not as creepy as it sounds; quaint. And the service staff is spot on, uber friendly and knowledgable staff without being too cutesy. 

Super tasty all around, highly recommended. Reasonable prices, definitely. Oh, and get the sweet tea. YUM.
 
Dinner? What?
No idea. I try not to talk about the Haight after dark.
author: Jacob B.

description:
Good basic yums.  Steak is great.  Beans in sauce are just spicy enough to go from plain to delish.  Everything but dessert was great.  The rumcake was generic/store-bought, feel free to skip.  Also, no matter what they say, the homemade hot sauce isn't that hot.  Feel free to apply liberally. 

The only downside is getting accosted by 7 guys trying to sell you 'bud' or 'nuggets' when you walk out.  C'est le Haight.
author: San B.

description: Parada 22, the cute little restaurant in the Haight, where lemons and limes are used as napkin-weights.  Based on reviews, I ordered the pernil asado with red beans.  Hubby ordered the Cubano classico sandwich.  The pork leg fell right off the bone.  I dowsed my rice in the red beans mix.  The plate was a good mix--salad, meat, beans, rice, and plantains.  I would have definitely preferred some juices/sauce on the pork leg.  The plantains tasted a little bland.  The Cubano classico was pretty tasty, particularly with the melted swiss cheese.  Again, the pork could've used some sauce/juices.   I kind of regret sticking with the pernil asado and going against the smell of fried chicken.  If I ever return, I will try the fried chicken...
author: Steph W.

description:
Yum! I got the vegetarian platter with yellow rice and white beans. Hubby got the Biftec with red beans...both were super yummy. The yuca didn't look super appetizing, but it was delicious. Everything was very flavorful, and I liked that there was a little green on the plate! 

Downer that they only accept cash, but there's an ATM pretty close. We'll be back!
author: Shari Z.

description:
Folks ,

Parada 22 is as  Authentic as it gets and delicious to boot. Best Biftec I've had off the island itself. I highly recommend stopping into this friendly spot and sit for a bit and enjoy some delicious eats.
author: Jamie K.

description:
My husband and I are truly stupefied by the good reviews given to Parada 22.  My husband is Puerto Rican, well Neworican (Puerto Rican born and raised in Brooklyn, NY), and if you've been to NY, they're are many Boricua who have moved there from PR.  His, mother, born and raised in PR cooked for us every Sunday when we lived there just a few years ago.  In fact, we go home often just for her food.
Parada may offer Puerto Rican food, but it is NOT AUTHENTIC.  I wonder if they even use Goya products in their food???  We ordered the rice and beans, which was a 2 out 5; the pernil asado - not Pernil they way Mom cooks it!! it was a 1 out of 5; it just didn't have the taste right; pernil is not supposed to be soggy!!
Please!!!  If those of you who find this place great, get a chance, go to Brooklyn, to an authentic Puerto Rican food joint, or go to PR, and you will never go back to Parada again!!! 
In fact, El Nuevo is a better, and we even find that place not the great.
SOL is okay, but still just not quite authentic.
author: Gigi T.

description:
This place has bad food.

No me gusta.  La comida es como basura, preperado sin amor.

I can be a food snob at times, but for $18 I expect something more than sugar water ("homemade lemonade with mint") and cafeteria style entrees (Pernil Asado).... Prison cafeteria that is.  I left totally unsatisfied, and the Veggie Platter made my girlfriend throw up 20 minutes after the meal (not kidding).

One star because the waitress was really friendly.
author: Leon S.

description:
Husband got the classic Cubano sandwich, I got the chicken thigh dish, my friend got the roast pork dish, we shared the sangria and flan.  We were all happy with our meals.  Seems like a couple reviewers have mentioned that it's not quite authentic Puerto Rican, but  for Puerto Rican *inspired* food, it was quite delicious.  Rice and beans were yummy, I could go and just get a big order of those and be happy.  They had 2 types of rice and beans to chose from.  I thought the maduras were very well cooked and perfectly flavored and ripe.  We did use a Groupon, so that helped with the cost a little.  The flan was excellent, I would recommend it if you're a flan fan.  

Overall, really liked this place, would probably go back if I was in the area, glad we checked it out.
author: Ana B.

description:
Let me start by saying I am Puerto Rican.  I love Puerto Rican food because it is like home to me. My grandfather was the cook in our family and when he past he took those secrets with him to the grave. My grandmother is a good cook too, but is older and a little forgetful, so when I am craving Puerto Rican food I ask my mom, but she doesn't cook it that often so sometimes I'm SOL.  

So today I wanted Puerto Rican food was close to the Haight and thought I'd give it a try, and sorry to say it was Blah!  I had the Pernil Adoba with white rice and beans. Pernil (pork shoulder) is suppose to be so soft that you can cut it with a fork and it is suppose to have the cracklin on top. This was a tough piece of meat. I could taste the seasoning and that was good, if the meat had been a little softer it would have been great. My favorite part of the meal was the sweet tea and the boiled yucca and avocado salad.  That was fantastic. All the salad needed was a few more tomatoes and salted cod (bacalao).  That is how my grandpa made it and it is to die for.  

If I was in the neighborhood I might go for the tea and salad.  But would make the trip from SSF to here for the food.  Not that great.

The waitress was friendly though....
author: Cindy M.

description:
Intended on going to Cha Cha Cha but it was packed - some things happen for a reason! We passed on the hour + wait and stumbled on Parada 22 - so glad we did! Ordered a half pitcher of sangria (delish!), sample appetizers (maduros, tostones, pernil [pork], salad, ~ fried chicken, and yucca) and the mofongo (mashed plantains, pork, and shrimp) with rice & beans and salad. Everything was delicious and authentic!! My mom continued to comment that it reminded her of her ex-mother-in-law's cooking (Puerto Rican). Delicious!!  

Quiet restaurant, and SO reasonably priced! Would definitely recommend it if you're in the Haight-Ashbury area and looking for some good/Latin food.
author: Danielle G.

description:
Of course I discover this place on my last night of living in the Haight! I ordered the Biftec with red beans and was amazed!!
Make sure to order Spanish rice - very flavorful!
author: Marina S.

description:
As someone who has lived in Puerto Rico and has eaten more food there than I care to tell, I have to say that Parada 22 is like a little piece of Carribean heaven!  I had the Camarones a la Criolla and the Habichuelas Coloradas.  The shrimps were succulent, the rice was perfect, and the red beans were amazing!  After eating that meal, I was ready to have a post-coital cigarette!  LOL

There isn't much room in the restaurant--it's pretty narrow--but if you've ever lived outside of the US, you'd know that it's really not *that* bad.

I will definitely be back here!
author: Keilani L.

description: Came here yesterday for the first time. I like the way this place is decorated. I had the Chicharron De Pollo and it was delicious! I definitely will be going back again.
author: LaShea R.

description:
Came in for a late lunch.  Dirty dishes were left on all the two tops and the four top in the corner was occupied, so I sat alone at the communal table.  Looked around for service, but there was no one at the register.  A few minutes later, packages of paper cups rained down from the loft - the manager was tossing them down onto the kitchen floor from above.  I should have left then.

Waitress slapped down a menu in front of me, then set about ripping open the bags of paper cups with her teeth.  Charming.  I selected the Pastelon, plantains layered with spiced beef.  Waitress winked, "That's my favorite."

While I waited, a young guy in a business suit came in.  He chatted with the waitress and indicated the 'consultation' wouldn't take long.  So maybe she was more of a manager.  At this point, she called from behind the counter to me, "Oh honey, we don't have the pastelon today."  Okay...

So I order the classic cuban.  Crunchy bread, tasty pork, good sauce.  Tiny side salad.  And a cup of water in a weird paper cup.

While I eat, the waitress clears just ONE pile of dirty dishes from a two top, and sits there in front of me with the consultant.  He wants to know what online marketing she's tried in the past.  She tells him about Scoutmob and Groupon - but says she just wishes they could build a regular return customer base.

How about giving a damn about your regular customers, honey?
author: Sarah E.

description:
oh boy. hold on to your hat. This place is an amazing find. It almost feels wrong to write about it to have more people find it, but I just have to. 

I found out about this place from a friend. I've been there twice and I love the cassava salad and the mint fruit drink. Both times I went it wasn't busy at all and great service. The decor and the music are impeccable (makes you want to get up and dance). Although I've never been to Puerto Rico, it makes me feel like this is what it should be like. I love the low key authentic feel of the place. Reasonably priced. (two people $30 w/tip)
author: Butch B.

description:
great addition to Haight Street.  I had the pork which was really delicious.  This came with rice and beans which were good,  not mind blowing - but still good.  I was disappointed by the plantains and I was left wishing for a delicious vinegar based salsa type sauce to slather on top of everything.   

i'll go back, it's casual and tasty, and i'll keep hoping for a hot sauce upgrade - cholula just doesnt cut it.
author: Millie A.

description: They were out of the dish I wanted to order :(, so I settled on the sampler platter, which was pretty good. Maybe my lack of enthusiasm is for the type of food itself and not for how it was executed. I'm pretty confident I might enjoy some of their other dishes more. The decor is very cute.
author: Olivia P.

description:
Parada 22 is great!  Seriously, I love this place.  It's cozy, comfortable, inviting and full of delicious food.

The trout is excellent, the beef sandwich tender and juicy, the drinks cold and refreshing.  It's the perfect place to drop in on a sunny afternoon and get a well priced, super filling and overall satisfying meal.

I highly recommend that you check this place out next time you are up in the Haight.
author: Boone S.

description: We accidentally ended up here on Bay to Breakers in the afternoon.  A friend recommended the place next door but I'm glad they refused to seat us!  It was de-lish!  I had the Biftec Encebollado or sautéed steak with caramelized onions.  My friend had the Pernil Asado or roasted pork, marinated with garlic, oregano base sofrito.  We both ordered the wonderful Spanish rice.  I wish there were more fried plantains on the plate (my favorite) but next time I know to order an extra side.  We both loved our food and the atmosphere took us out of the chaos on Haight and into a Puerto Rican cafe!
author: Meli B.

description: We're Puerto Rican and were so excited to find this little gem in the city!!! SUPER yummy food and great music!
author: Aborigen A.

description: Disappointing. The dish I got (the beef/plantain) did not taste right to me, it was a little off-putting. Needless to say, I didn't finish it. I also think the ambiance would be nicer if they played some Puerto Rican music (at least that's not what I heard while I was there). I wouldn't recommend this place. :-\
author: J.D. Q.

description: I thought I was in Miami for a minute while eating my Cuban Sandwich.  It was really tasty.  I randomly happened upon this place while walking down Haight Street and was pleasantly surprised.  Latin American fare (they said they were Puerto Rican) but many of the dishes seemed Cuban as well.   Cool decorations too, with all the Latin import packages and simple homey feel.
author: Avi S.

description:
I love this place. Prompt service, great food and moderately priced. I love the shrimp With Red beans and Spanish rice here! The ambiance is also really appropriate. 

I've read a review here that states that maybe having a white woman as the manager is not the best choice for this place. I was actually there at the time in question. The place was shortstaffed and there were clearly issues that I couldn't see. When I asked, I received an explanation. It had nothing to do with skin color and everything to do with employee performance. Yelp is not the place for racism so I felt the need to say something.
author: Sean M.

description: We really loved this place. Good golly, the habichuelas blancos, just get them. I usually don't wax poetic about beans, but... The pernil asado was succulent and beautiful. It's all I can say. Just go.
author: H. M.

description: Another delicious meal here!  Tried the Pernil Asado (pork) and Pollo Encebollado (chicken with sauteed onions) this time, and both were great!  I love the Red Beans and Spanish Rice too.  Maduros were a little dry tonight, but this place is still on my list!  Only thing that's missing is some homemade hot sauce like they have at Sol Food in San Rafael.  Otherwise, this place is a much closer way to get my Puerto Rican food fix.
author: Lindsay B.

description: I came here for an early dinner on Friday. It wasn't too crowded, but the place is tiny so there were defiantly people waiting after I was seated. The decor is pretty unique but not as loud as Cha Cha Cha next door. The waitress was friendly and accommodating. I had a glass of sangria,which was pretty perfect. Potent yet sweet and tangy. I was tory between the Mofongo and the Pernil Asado, and the waitress recommended the mofongo, as it is something that you can;t find hardly anywhere. I decided to get the Mofongo plate and just add some of the pork on the side. She was right, the mofongo was amazing!. I liked the pork, but it was only juicy the first couple minutes I had it, then it dried out pretty quick. The Mofongo, on the other hand was awesome! There was a nice amount of shrimp and the flavor was really unique. I loved the plantains that came with it!. The prices were pretty standard for dinner, the mofongo was $12, I think? Glass of sangria was $4.50, save some money by getting a pitcher :D
author: Shannon H.

description: Very satisfying Latin fare. Various plantain iterations along with the typical bean and rice dishes. Had chicharrones de pollo  which was very tasty but  the my RECOMMENDED ITEMS are : PASTELON (sweet plantains layered with ground beef) and the regular FLAN.
author: aj s.

description: My husband and I popped in before a show at the Fillmore last Fri and had a wonderful experience. Parada was buzzing with a welcoming and relaxed atmosphere. We grabbed some stools by the window which provided a great view of passerbys and the entire restaurant. As always, the waitstaff were great. Really attentive, helpful, but never pushy. Even though my husband had to pop out for a work call they were very understanding and patient. Once he returned he ordered the Pollo encebollado (marinated chicken with caramelized onions) and I had the Pernil  asado (roast pork). I definitely recommend choosing the red beans and spanish rice, it adds a ton of flavor! Another must-have is the sangria - delicious and very well priced. The food was absolutely perfect and we took our time chatting and enjoying our meal. To top off the great experience, our waiter presented us with two free glasses of sangria at the end of the evening - such an unexpected and thoughtful surprise!
author: Stephanie B.

description: Pretty good food, though a little bland. I got the pork shoulder dish with yuca (didn't like the olives in the mojo sauce), plantains (amazing), and Spanish rice (delicious) + kidney beans (overseasoned). Kind of a weird ambiance. Definitely got overcharged, but also had leftovers (and I went ridiculously hungry). I've had really amazing Cuban food before and this did not satisfy, but it might be tasty for someone who hasn't tried it.
author: Gina C.

description:
i came here with a friend because he had a groupon; but i would definitely come back--with or without a discount. prices arent that bad either way; bout 10$ avg for a plate & they fill you up just right! it was my first time but sure gave a great impression. i got the mofongo (she wrote MOFO on our check haha) and it was amazinggggg. thats all i gotta say. just order that. shrimps with this chunky stuffing type deal drenched in this delicious creamy sauce, paired with rice, beans, and a salad.

so damn good. cleaned my plate with ease.
author: Mitch N.

description:
Yummmmmy! Been keeping an eye out for a good Puerto Rican spot in the city. Thank you Yelpers!! I enjoy Sol Food in San Rafael, but by the time we get over and pay the toll, we could have had a whole meal at Parada 22.

Now I am not Puerto Rican and admittedly I have only had about 5 experiences with the food in my life. My hubby is, but my in-laws have yet to send me any recipes or the Sofrito I was promised. All that being said, I enjoyed!

 I had the Pollo Encebollada (2 boneless chicken thighs w/ caramelized onions) and the Mr had Pernil Asado (roasted pork). These both came w/ rice and beans and sweet plantains. Love those maduros! Both meats were cooked nicely. My chicken wouldn't have had much flavor if it weren't for the lovely caramelized onions. Me and the hubby disagreed about the rice and red beans. I say perfect, he says bland (this from the man who salts almost everything before he tastes it). Let him write his own review! : P The sweet tea could have been sweeter, but that's irrelevant. 

Very cute place. The guy behind the counter was very nice and welcomed my husband's bean criticism. We will be back. Looking forward to an expanded menu in the coming months...maybe some empanadias, mmmmm
author: Sharma R.

description: Great service, and the food is phenomenal. I mean, ridiculously fantastic. Their limeade-minty concoction is also tasty and not at all overpowering. The atmosphere is great!
author: Rachel S.

description: Get the fried chicken or shrimp entree, w/ white beans, w/ spanish rice, and you are golden. DELISH.
author: Connie N.

description:
Decent sangria, my shrimp dish was good, but on the menu they should state that the red beans have pork in them as not everyone (including me) eats pork. The waitress was very friendly and quickly traded my red beans for white beans. 
The restaurants itself is cute, bright and fun, but very small; I'd definitely not recommend it for a group of four or more. 
I came here because I received a scoutmob deal and yet I was still charged full price because the waitress who took note of my deal wasn't the same one who ran my card...annoying. Still, once I brought it to their attention the waitress who ran my card was apologetic and showed me proof that she had voided the transaction. However, 5 days have passed and the full amount is still posted on my account (I'll be following up with my bank shortly) In addition, my card was swiped again after I was charged the correct price factoring in my 50% off. 
Overall, my experience was decent and I might go back, but I'm not in a hurry to do so.
author: Natalie M.

description: My kind of place. Delicious pernil asado, rice and beans, small salad, and maduros for $10. Is that the best deal in town? Nice atmosphere as well.
author: William S.

description: Yummy gluten-free food!  Second time I've eaten there and the food was just as delicious as the first time:)
author: Liz K.

description:
Great find. I don't know anything about Puerto Rican food but my friend took us here and it was great. The Biftek and the Pollo are good (on the dry side though). The beans are way better than other places I've been to. The Mofongo is just delicioso. Let's not forget the Tostones. I could have ordered more of those. 
The place is very, very small, and was packed when we got there. It took us almost an hour to get seated. The superbly done wall decor and the seemingly mismatched tables gives you the feeling you're in a roadside diner in Puerto Rico even if just for the little time you were there. It's in Haight so parking may be a challenge.
author: Jai R.

description:
We started coming to P-22 on a Groupon deal and have never looked back.  The food is a gustatory gem -- simple fare based on quality ingredients prepared skillfully and with respect for the products.

A few favourites have developed for us:

- The beef salad -- great greens, well marinated beef thinly sliced and cooked perfectly.  This could be a complete dinner by itself.

- The Cubano classico sandwich is a real mouth-pleaser in both taste and texture.

- The marinated chicken sandwich with fried onions -- add the avocado... total creamy goodness.

- The braised white beans -- so good they've displaced the also-good maduros as our favourite side dish.

- The other half reports that the sangria is very good (sangria of any kind is not one of my favourites).

The price of this particular feast was (before tip) less than two twenties.
author: Bruce B.

description: We were looking for a casual place to get some really good food, and we found just that at Parada 22.  The atmosphere was cozy and welcoming, and the service was good.  The food was excellent, both dishes were very well seasoned, and the many sides that came with them were tasty too.  I had thought from previous reviews that we should order additional sides, but one meal each is more than enough food, although the other side item we got was very flavorful and a nice addition.  The sangria is very good too.  Overall an excellent experience.
author: Eric H.

description: we have been here a few times, and what can i say, puerto rican food in SF! I have ordered the pernil a few times, and it was great. reminds me of the pernil in PR. and the Pernil at our house and our restaurant. We have also had the biftec, the pollo criolla, the mofongo, tostones, and every thing seems to come with a side of amarillos. Yes Mofongo relleno in SF! is there anywhere else that even serves mofongo in nor cal? and the last time I went i had a Malta! I am a tough critic and i would actually give this place a five star if they served Medalla.
author: Daniel J.

description: A block away from my house and probably the best place to eat at around the Haight, which is seriously lacking in good food. I blame this on the fake hippies bums that like to poop on the streets ugh specifically in the bushes in front of my house. Anyway, I always order the pernil (roast pork) with their yellow rice and white beans. My bf prefers the red beans but I think the white is more flavorful. Along with this comes a nice mixed greens salad with a simple tangy dressing. I also order the avocado, yuca salad which is soooo freaking good. I love yuca and avocado and they have their amazing dressing over it so it just works out really well. My bf gets the steak plate which is also good but I'm just a pork lover so I never sway. It's similar to Sol food in San Rafael, except Sol food is a lot better. Thats not saying that parada is bad its just that Sol food is AMAZING. Anyway, my one complaint is that since its a small place and we literally live a block away their take home portions have been getting pretty skimp. My bf said something so they started hooking us up more but other than that a a really solid place.
author: Mila A.

description:
Wow, the service here REALLY sucked for me. I had lunch on a Friday.

The waitress seemed to not be paying attention anything even though the restaurant was almost half full (still not many people). I had to get up to order my food because she never came over. I had to get up to ask for my bill because she never came over to clear our table. She never asked if our meal was ok.

Food was just ok, especially for the higher cost. I had the Pernil dish. A little dry and non-flavored, but it looked good. You get a few chunks of pork, a few spring green leaves as salad, two pieces of plantains, and a tiny cup of beans. $13 plus tax and tip.

The cuban sandwich was tasty and it's hard to get a good cuban sandwich in SF.

At least they have mexican coke in a bottle.

I can't see why anyone would come here except if the wait at Cha Cha Cha was too long.
author: D L.

description: Loved the atmosphere created by the decorations, memorabilia and friendly staff. Food was Excellent, totally affordable. My compliments to the Chef!
author: Michael L.

description: Probably one of our new top 5 favorite spots in the city. This place is perfect, from the atmosphere to the excellent and friendly service, to the fact that have lots of deal offers, to the absolutely delicious food at a reasonable price. I'm sad to not have discovered this place earlier. I think it's because the name threw me a bit - maybe I was guessing that it was the 22nd location of a crappy bay area Mexican food franchise.
author: M L.

description:
There are food angels in SF!  This may be an understatement, as we were indeed blessed by these food angels to discover Parada 22 - the palace of delicious Puerto Rican cuisine, only because the Host with the Leastest at ChaChaCha was so darn rude when we ventured there first.
