Aha! I exclaimed, I am taking this rude "host" situation as a sign to see what other restaurant is closeby. 

Immediately I yelped - lo and behold Parada 22 was right next door and though we saw they were crowded, with only 1 very busy waitress and 1 busier chef,  we entered.  We, 3,  shared one of the long tables with a family of 6, who were quite friendly.  We ordered two entrees of pastalone... because it seemed so different and we, 3, adventurous.  Wow! Pastalone is, in a nutshell, a puerto rican lasagna, the unusual combination of bananas, ground beef, olives, raisins... and more - i'll get the recipe perhaps later.  Even BF who is the most picky of eaters, wolfed it down with PR rice and beans!  Also ordered - yucca with onions - good!  We topped off our meals with flan - they were out of the coconut, so we got the plain - which we all decided was the best flan ever!  The busy waitress was friendly and accommodating throughout the evening, she took orders, bussed tables, served tables, delivered menus and checks, and took money, with a smile and efficiency.  The chef only looked up long enough to acknowledge his waitress and the thanks of the many happy patrons.   We were grateful to have been angelically guided away from the restaurant next door over to Parada 22!
author: janet b.

description: Best home style Puerto Rican I've had, you can't go wrong with the pork or Spanish rice.
author: James C.

description: Pretty darn tasty Puerto Rican food. Really good vegetarian options and good-sized portions. They have plantains! And yucca! I've been happy with all my meals here.
author: Lucy M.

description: Recommend the Mofongo... not as good as Puerto Rico, but not bad for being on Haight. The food is much better then its neighbor ChaChaCha. I've also tried the Biftec and the Chicharrones de Pollo both were tasty meals. I'm also a sucker for fried plantains.
author: Steve K.

description: Authentic, delicious Latin American food. In a word... Bomb. If your in the neighborhood, stop by for some awesome grub and friendly service. My recommendation: the shrimp
author: yosef k.

description: Yum!!!  People are tired of hearing how good my lunch was...I had the pollo criolloa and my son had the Cuban sammy...YUM!  The sweet plantains with salsa rosa were delish too.  Tiny place - good music - great food.
author: Maryellen C.

description:
Based on food and service (clearly the most important features of a restaurant) I'd give Parada 22 a 4/5 but I'm unfortunately reviewing their customer service which up to this point I thought only applied to businesses selling goods and services.

My gripe has to do with a strange experience I had a few weeks ago when I dined there with my boyfriend.  After we left I discovered that I had left my hat and glasses ($200.00 prescription) behind and ran back to the restaurant to retrieve them.  The manager, however, claimed she did not have them so we left and decided to check back with the restaurant in a few days to see if anyone returned them.  Lo and behold somebody did and the manager told me she'd leave them for me under the counter by the cash register.  A few days went by and I finally had a chance to swing by to pick the items up but decided to call first to make sure they hadn't been put away in a secure area for safe keeping.  The person who I spoke to informed me that the glasses and hat were not there and after checking with the manager informed me that "I should have come by the day they were returned".  I asked her if they had perhaps been put away in a secure area, maybe the cleaning people had moved them etc.. but was instead told that "maybe I should check back again in a few days"??? 
The manager did call me back the following day and was told that she would check around and get back to me but I never heard back.  I asked her if it was common for people to steal things from behind the counter and she stated she didn't think so....
I've dealt with a lot of flakes in my life but the management of this restaurant took the cake.  So I should have returned back to the restaurant the same night my hat and glasses were returned to ensure they didn't disappear again?
Very bizarre experience indeed.
author: Shaki S.

description:
great prices.
great food. 
I only wish i lived closer to the place.
author: Chris T.

description: Spectacular food! We first encountered this restaurant through a Groupon certificate and we've been hooked since! The camarones is out of this world! I highly recommend Parada 22. We bring all our visiting friends to this wonderful place.
author: Darrel B.

description: best place in sf for PR food. i love the cajun shrimp. perfect portions, great prices. its small but intimate.
author: Chucky B.

description: Parada 22 is delicious, fresh, quick, and has great atmosphere and staff.
author: Alex M.

description: The mofongo de camarones was delicious. Overall, the food is very affordable given the generous servings (and, in fact, affordable even if servings were not as generous). The owner of the place is super friendly and makes you feel like you're a guest at his home. I highly recommend this place to anyone who wants to experience Puerto Rican cuisine.
author: Ryan G.

description: Good slow pork. Sangrias.  Close to the park.  Good atmosphere.
author: Jim T.

description: Amazing food and great service. What more can you ask for. An absolute must try if you're into latin american food.
author: Peter C.

description: Why would you open a Latin American restaurant right next door to a Latin American restaurant? You have a fantastic business strategy, that's why. If you have ever tried to get into Cha Cha Cha only to be tortured with the aspect of a 90 minute wait, you can drown your sorrows next door at Parada 22 with a glass of sangria that you don't have to stand up to drink. And while you're there, might as well have something to eat. You were in the mood for Latin food anyway you say? Genius.
author: Shannon M.

description: Food is good, my favorite is CAMARONES A LA CRIOLLA - sautéed shrimp in a fresh tomato, onion and pepper cream sauce...mmmm love the sauce and rice. But food proportion to price is way 2 expensive. Price for the platter is 11.50. If you really want to come here wait for the online deals, I got mine at buywithme.com $12.50 for $25 worth of food. Another thing was service was shi**y. When I ordered the food the waitress face looked like she was thinking, "Sh*t why am I here on a glorious weekend." When I gave her the online coupon her face gave a, "Sh"t, another Asian with coupon." When I asked for a to go box and the bill, there was another, "Sh*t more work to do look." I think Cha Cha Chas service is way better, but it's more of a full service meal while Parada 22 is a quick and dirty meal.
author: Erica B.

description:
Definitely not the best Puerto Rican food by a long shot, but given we're in California where there just aren't that many Puerto Ricans.  I'm Puerto Rican by the way.  And I'll start by saying most people should find something to enjoy here since it is different than the usual and not bad tasting food.  

It's basic and as simple as it gets.  I had the Pernil with white rice and red beans and maduros (sweet plantains) and it was average.  Pernil should be a juicy, stripped, and full of taste.  Mine was in huge chunks, dry and pretty bland.  The rice was fine but it's white so can't go wrong and the beans were good.  Maduros were also good but that's also hard to mess up.  Could've been less soggy and more crispy but they're made a lot of diff ways.  

No traditional Puerto Rican drinks or sodas which kind of sucks.  I had a bit of the Pollo encebollado and it was also average.  Just chicken and onions.  Didn't have the hint of specific Puerto Rican spices but it was fine. 

The menus is limited and didn't even have Arroz con Gandules, which is arguably THE most popular Puerto Rican dish.  Hard to make right though.  Kind of like paella.  

2 stars just because they didn't have a key dish or any traditional drinks.  Sangria is a generic cheap cop out for any latin restaurant if you ask me.  But I do think people can enjoy it as a cool little change up to the abundance of mexican/asian restaurants in the SF.   El Nuevo Frutilandia is better I think.  Not as cute in decoration but more authentic in taste.  Can't wait to find a PR restaurant in the bay that makes me wanna come back for more.
author: Isamarie P.

description: Waitresses are so friendly! The food is bomb! the sangria is dedlicious! Thumbs up Parada 22, you rock!
author: Alex V.

description:
I went to this restaurant to try something new, I was surprised that it had good reviews, because let's face it, it does not have a good look at all.

I tried the biftec sandwich to go with avocado, and I paid around 10.75 which is a little pricey for a sandwich, but ok. 

The sandwich was really good, not too big, not too small. The meat was hot, cheese melted and delicious bread (and I am french, I am really picky on breads). 

The only downside to this meal was that the salad was ok, but not perfect. I would have preferred to choose between a salad and something else, or at least choose the dressing for it. 

The inside of the restaurant looks unfinished, but there is a good atmosphere. 

This place has potential, definitely !
author: Thibault S.

description: Love this place, absolutely delicious and a really nice spot to eat! The mofongo de camarones was so good!
author: J M.

description: I've been here four times since it opened. The food tastes homemade and it feels like you're eating in PR. The ambiance is cool and unique. My favorite dish is the shrimp.
author: M R.

description: Their pulled pork is amazing! I've said enough.
author: Dean I.

description:
Puerto Ricans living in the Bay Area all know how rare it is to find an authentic Puerto Rican Restaurant. So when we hear that one has opened up we RUN!!! to it in hopes of savoring some real down home cooking. So it was a little disappointing when I went to Parada 22 for my birthday Dinner with friends. There was absolutely no Puerto Ricans running or working in this restaurant and the decor although primarily Puerto Rican Themed had Yerba Mate on display & an old newspaper framed with headlines of Cuba, Cholula Hot Sauce & Mexican beer. One of the bigger disappointments was that they did not serve Tostones or Malta, which is as basic traditional everyday Puerto Rican Cuisine as you can get. Don't get me wrong, the service was good, food was OK, and it's not bad for a quick inexpensive meal, the place was clean and green in many ways. But Puerto Rican Cuisine ... not really 

The Rum Cake was absolutely DELICIOUS, the Cubano Sandwich was alright & although the Pernil was fall apart soft ,it lacked the flavor of traditional seasonings. It was kind-of down hill after that. Yes rice can be difficult to master, but you had to search for the gandules & flavor in this rice, and granted the habichuelas had pieces of ham & potatoes, they also were missing something. The yucca tasted minty rather than garlicky and was over cooked, more like mashed potatoes. The chicharon de pollo was not, it was basically just a quartered fried chicken. The Bifstek Encebollado was delicious, but again not the taste of Puerto Rican cuisine, it lacked the Puerto Rican trademark vinegar marinade and the onions were really carmelized(not how we cook them).
author: I R.

description: I came here with a group of friends and my food was extremely good but theirs wasn't. My one star rating is for the food. As for the service, it was absolutely terrible. I have never experienced such horrible service. Don't even bother coming here unless you have a reservation. I don't know if it was just an off night but I had a really bad experience. Hit up cha cha cha's next door, it's worth the wait and they care about their customers and their sangria is ten times better.
author: Larissa S.

description: Did not know what to expect when hubby got the Groupon for this place but my favorite food is the Maduros (fried sweet plaintains (bananas)) and they had them so he bought the groupon.  On a cold blustery day in the Haight we were treated to great service, delicious Maduros, yucca, Spainish rice and wonderfully prepared pork.   It is right next to another favorite Cha Cha Cha.  I hope this place thrives on those not willing to wait at Cha Cha Cha and the fellow Groupon users.  We will definetly be back to try the Sangria and more Maduros!
author: April M.

description: Had to change my review NOW THAT THEY TAKE CREDIT CARDS!!!!!!!!!!!! And have a more legit website. let the feasting begin.
author: Amaranta C.

description: Just went back and had their biftec sandwich this time. YUM. Definitely going back to try to rest of their sandwiches!
author: Leilani H.

description:
Mofongo with shrimp--absolutely delicious.
Tostones--really really good, rivals Puerto Rico itself!
White Beans--yum.
Sauteed shrimp--also really good, although mofongo was better.
Maduros--mmmmm good.
Spanish rice--perfect (I'm vegetarian so just picked out the ham)
Even the salad was delicious!
And the coconut flan was the best I've ever had.
Sangria was strong.
Service was great (granted it was 7:30pm on a Sunday night, not busy, but still our server was prompt and pleasant).

So glad Living Social did a deal here so I could be introduced to a great little place.  I've loved Sol Food for years now, but now I'd also go to Parada 22 anytime!
author: Traunza A.

description:
Let me start by saying I am of Puerto Rican decent and a recent transplant to the Bay Area so decided I should check out this place.  With that said, the "Puerto Rican" food at Parada 22 isn't bad but by no means authentic. Bistec Encebollado was dry which is so not how that dish is prepared. The beans are good but again not authentic as in Puerto Rico they use pink beans not kidney beans. There are also a serious lack of key dishes like arroz con gandules to be authentic. 

So although the food is tasty by no means does this Puerto Rican girl give it a thumbs up for authenticity.
author: Brenda C.

description: This was my girlfriend and I's first time having Puerto Rican food and we were both satisfied and would definitely come back to this restaurant. I had the Pernil Asado which was very tasty. Meat was tender and full of flavor. The dressing for the salad was so good (honey vinaigrette). The spanish rice was also full of flavor. Overall the food was delicious and reasonable in price. The server was also friendly which is an important factor for us.
author: Raciel A.

description: Came here for dinner on a Monday night and really enjoyed the vegetarian plate -- everything was well-seasoned and tasty. Portion size was also very generous for the price. Service was excellent. I'll definitely be back!
author: Elizabeth R.

description:
the food here is simply incredible - way better than cha cha cha's next door, so much care is put into the dishes, and each one comes with 3-5 separate dishes on the plate. the portions are huge and the flavours are unlike anything i've had in latin cuisine before. 

i reccomend the chicharon de pollo and the camarones a la criolla - so so good, i'll be back soon.
author: Ben B.

description: Love Parada 22. We found it through Scoutmob - smart move on the restaurant's part to promote it w/ a deal because we'll be back for sure. I had the steak, my husband had the chicken special, and my son had the chicken sandwich and all three were a hit. Our waitress was a doll - sweet and fast. The decor is colorful, fun, and upbeat.  Our only suggestion for improvement would be to add a kids plate (rice, beans, and a small portion of chicken). Maybe they're not after the family market, but even if it was just offered from 5-6:30 would be great since that's when most families eat and most restaurants need a little push for more business. Other than that, our experience far exceeded expectations.
author: Kristin S.

description:
I always said that I'd only write positive reviews on Yelp.  This place disappointed me SO much that I changed my mind.

First of all, let me state that the place is ADORABLE.  Bright colors, a glass hutch with cans and boxes of Puerto Rican food products, and exposed brick made this place look very appealing to me.  Also, it's around the corner from my house.  It had a lot going for it....

Here's the rub:  the food was TERRIBLE.  A friend and I went for dinner about a month ago on a weeknight and we arrived around 9:00 pm.  I had the vegetarian combo. platter.  First of all, they were OUT of rice.  HOW can a Puerto Rican establishment be OUT of rice?  Isn't that a staple?  The platanos were very greasy and the yucca was gummy and congealed in a gelatinous-like substance that I presume to be the sauce.  I didn't want one of the items on the platter, and the folks had kindly agreed to substitute avocado, but instead they put extra platanos on the plate instead of just telling me they were out of avocado as well.  Finally, the beans just weren't good - the sauce was not particularly flavorful and the consistency was not right.  My friend, who had one of the meat dishes, concurred about the terrible quality of her food as well.  To enhance the experience even more, the waitress was downright surly, and she was obviously counting down the minutes until her shift was over.  She was neither helpful nor polite.  

I am not one of those people who lives to write negative reviews nor am I a very harsh critic.  I can overlook a lot of issues.  However, I'm so bummed out by the fact that a place with such amazing potential turned out to be such a SEVERE letdown.  I will definitely not be returning to Parada 22.
author: Brooke N.

description: This place is great all around. Good Service, delicious food and reasonably priced. It truly fits the 5 star yelp description "as good as it gets"  dont hesitate to make a stop here!
author: Joe D.

description: this place is so awesome. we are a family of 4 and you get a generous amount of food for a good price with GREAT taste. i love love the shrimp. the staff is very friendly and they even remembered our order. i would recommend the sangria, flann and Chicharrones de Pollo. i also like the decor. i always try to bring anyone one who has not been to see their face when they have the great food. we also like walking off the food on haight st after. enjoy!!!
author: Alexandra M.

description: Yum! When I first saw it I was skeptical. I am Puerto Rican came here from Chicago with GREAT PR food. Never could really find a good PR cuisine place in the bay that measured up. UNTIL NOW! ALL THE FOOD IS GOOD and when I say ALL the food I MEAN ALL THE FOOD! Biftec was amazing! Mofongo was amazing! Flan was incredible! Tell your friends.
author: Father O.

description: This place was amazing!! We tried the pollo asado and the vegetarian plate and everything I tried was delicious. The hot sauce they have at the table is this little habanero concoction and was really tasty. The salad dressing on the greens was quite good too. The server was really sweet and even offered up how they make the dressing and sauce. I would definitely go back and have some more of that sangria too :)
author: Morgan R.

description:
This place is absolutely amazing. It has a very authentic feel to it while having the tastiest food ever. There are very few (if any) Puerto Rican restaurants in the Bay Area. It was nice and cozy, and the woman ( Puerto Rican) was very quick, sharp, funny and well versed in the culture. We had the bistec and rice. Which was served in just the right time. Sangrias were excellent. 

Very much worth the time to investigate!

JR
author: Joe R.

description: Parada 22 is extremely tasty. I have had the cubano sandwich which was fantastic, and I also have had a chicken special which was superb. The place serves nice size portions for the plates and are around 12 bucks. Its has nice decor and is definitely a nice place to bring a date.
author: Ethan S.

description: I bought a groupon not knowing anything about Parada 22. My partner and I took a friend. One of us had the trout, the other had the camarones and I had the pork. As a special of the day they had mafongo, the meal was AWESOME. great price, excellent service and all three of us walked away full and happy!!!! and best of all......I've got another groupon to spend. I will definitely be back.
author: Troy H.

description: The best food in San Francisco! If you are craving for some Puertorican food this is the place to go. I tried the Biftec Encebollado which is one of my favorites, also the Lechón asado and the Mofongo. All of it was really good! The sangria is also awesome! Lots of alcohol and no ice for the pincher!
author: Anuardi J.

description: Had the veggie plate. which was lovely!  Best sangria I've had!  Reasonable prices, lovely service!
author: Loretta C.

description:
YUCK! This food is awful! The meats were dry and overcooked and poor quality. 
Sol Food in San Rafael uses good quality meats and still manages to keep their prices low. Even the platanos were dry and flovorless. 
The wait staff was friendly, but you can't eat them. I won't be back.
author: Lisa R.

description: I dig this place a lot! But the shitty service knocks it down to two stars. Every time I go, I always feel that I'm getting a waitress who has had a bad day or something. Once, my boyfriend and I waited 10 minutes until the waitress and her friend would stop chatting and actually take our order. The same waitress also left for smoke breaks...because everyone loves the lingering smell of nicotine while you eat. Although there are other incidents of not so great wait service, I will probably painfully drag myself back to order more delicious food...to go.
author: Kitty K.

description: I was very excited to hear there was a Caribbean/Puerto Rican place because there is nothing in the city that replicates the authentic recipes. The only place that is decent is Sol Food in Marin. I am originally from Miami and this is not a good example of the food.  Even the sides lacked flavor and we're extremely dry, which is pretty hard to do with maduros and tostones. A little mojo wouldn't hurt the pastelón either. I can only hope they revisit and get a chef that is authentic! On the bright side, staff was extremely friendly and very professional.
author: Kristina O.

description: Parada in Puerto Rico is the term for bus stops along Ponce de Leon Avenue and Fernandez Juncos Avenue in San Juan. Parada 22 is in the Santurce area close to the Plaza del Mercado which at night is a local hangout. The sandwich cubano was tasty but not as good as in Miami or San Juan. However the other dishes are good and tasty.  My puertorrican wife enjoyed her chicken and kidney beans although she likes the one from Sol Food in San Rafael better.
author: Frank B.

description: I've been here a few times and it's always been tasty food, I mean really good, and nice service.  I'm happy to have this as an option after hitting Amoeba.  Last time I got the bitfec sandwich w/ avocado, awesome!
author: Jason D.

description: My daughter ordered Mofongo. It was pretty good. My wife and I ordered a simpler since we had our lunch earlier. The sampler was okay. Overall I'll say Parada 22 has authentic Peurto Rican food. Service was good, just the plate the provided wasn't so clean. They should be more careful. I'll come back someday to try something different.
author: Henry H.

description: Oh it brought me back to the Plaza del Mercado in Puerto Rico.  The rice was plump and moist. (Hey instant rice fans, this will be an epiphany!)  I ordered Pernil, roasted pork, and the plate came with a salad, fried sweet banana, rice, and beans.  So tender and comforting.  My husband had the Bistek and it was equally delicious.  I say run, dont walk!
author: kitty p.

description: The service was excellent. The server was very attentive and always came to us, to see how we were doing. The plates were excellent, and I really enjoyed the ambiance. Brick walls are key! It suits the area well. I'm so happy they've opened in my neighborhood. It's perfect for a delightful vegetarian meal. I had the Vegetariano Plato, and the plantains were great. I love the salad, and everything was tasty. My friend had the Eggplant sandwich which he said was good too. The prices are very reasonable.
author: Mei F.

description: Delicioso!! Seriously a must have. The camarones are my favorite, but I won't leave without some if those plantains....no matter how full I am!!!!
author: AlwaysHonest R.

description: One of the few spots in the neighborhood where I can walk to for something delicious (sorry, Magnolia). Very reasonable prices, absolutely tasty fare, I haven't been disappointed in the few meals I've had there, nor have anyone who has been there with me. The meats are delish and sandwiches are fine. I enjoy the cheerful decor in there, with all the pantry goods and cans along the wall, it's like being in someone's kitchen. Great for a quick, good bite to eat. Duck into Parada 22 instead of that loud restaurant next door...
author: Lisa K.

description:
I really wanted to give Parada 22 five stars, but you know in movies how you always hear the saying, "There's good news and there's bad news... Which one do you want to hear first?" Well let's begin with the good news...

I absolutely loved the food. I've watched a whole lot of Anthony Bourdain, Andrew Zimmerman and Adam Richman and every time one of those hosts visited Puerto Rico, I always heard them speak of "mofongo"-- some mashed plantain dish mixed with garlic, shrimp and more. I was sold the moment I got a glimpse of this mofongo on television and since then, I've been on a mofongo hunt. Sadly, I don't have any Puerto Rican friends who know how to whip up some mofongo (as a matter fact, I asked my Puerto Rican friend once and he gave me the raised eyebrow) and sadly I never even heard of a Puerto Rican restaurant in the city, despite the many times I've searched it on Yelp. The nearest I'd always get was one in San Rafael and I just couldn't seem to bring myself that far to try the long awaited mofongo.

Anyway, long story short, my friend told me about Parada 22 and I was there ASAP. I ordered the mofongo and almost cried at the sight of such a beautiful dish. Everything about it was DIVINE. I don't even remember what else was served with it... some sort of shrimp, rice, beans... a whole platter to feed a fat little man like me! So I was happy. Probably the happiest I'd been all week until....

Here's the bad news. And I'm talking about super bad news. The only thing in this world that can make a happy camper like me go sour over food would be... THE SIGHT OF A HAIR IN MY FOOD. Yes, sadly there was a black hair in my mofongo (I just did the gag reflex as I remembered that very moment) I know it wasn't my hair because it was buried deep in my mofongo. I'm talmbout I saw the tip peeking from the corner and when I pulled it out, it disrupted the beautiful mofogan hill and exposed the entire body of hair upon that pile of disrupted plantain. I tossed the hair on the floor and gag reflexed over and over. I didn't tell my two friends what I had seen only because... I just couldn't, but they knew something was wrong by the reaction on my face. You know how they say love is blind? Well I suppose hunger is blind, too. The food was so damn good, but it doesn't excuse me from complaining. I regret not complaining. I ended up eating more of my food, but did not touch the rest of my mofongo for the rest of my sitting.

I'm really disappointed that had to happen to me, but some things like that aren't controllable. I plan on eating here sometime again, but I'm still slightly traumatized from that last time....
author: Ally C.

description:
Yay!  New blood on Haight St!!  I'm always looking for new places to eat because, to be brutally honest, I feel like the restaurants in the upper Haight lack a certain level of "excellence" so to speak.

This place was pretty good, I have to say.  My husband has been there a few times and always gotten one of the cuban sandwiches.  He likes them a lot, so we thought we'd try the place out for dinner.  He went with his tried and true "classic cubano" and was quite happy.  I got the roasted pork main dish and it was........good.......
My pork was only luke-warm so I asked the waitress if it was suppose to be that way.  She really didn't answer me, but offered to bring me another order of pork so I thought, well, hell yeah, giddy up!
It was still only luke-wark so, I'm guessing its the way it is suppose to be??
The white beans were out of this world good and the spanish rice was pretty good.  The plaintains were great!  I dont know puerto rican food well, but I liked the spices and overall flavor.
So besides the luke-warm pork (twice) I was pretty happy with my meal.  I'll go back, but I think I will order something different next time.
author: Claudia M.

description: This place is authentic and delicious. Everything I have tried here is tasty, well balanced and nutritious. The camarones (shrimp) platter is the bomb! Love this place!
author: Brittany T.

description: Small, cozy ambiance. Food nothing out of the ordinary. The server was very nice, in spite of his being the first day at work. I wouldn't go back again.
author: Lindsay K.

description: This is a must!!!! Try to go once a week for the fried chicken or the shrimps but most food on the menu is so good and cheap.
author: Mikkel J.

description: We found this nice cozy little latin american place at the end of Haight near the park.  I liked all the pictures and paintings on the walls.  It added to the concept of the restaurant.  I had a pretty good Cubano sandwich.  It wasn't extraordinary though.  They did have good flan, but the service was way too slow.  Our quick lunch turned out to be over an hour.  We were seated right away, but there were long intervals of time where we had no contact with our waitress.  I'd come back, but I won't be going out of my way to eat there again.
author: Andy Z.

description: Being from Puerto Rico I am very picky about eating  puertorrican food. This place is fantastic and is as authentic as it comes. Whenever I feel like I want a taste of Puerto Rico, this is where I go. EXCELLENT food and great Service. Enjoy and come hungry, you will leave satisfied.
author: Andres N.

description: I've only been here once and I am already in love. The cubano sandwich will definitely keep me coming back for more. My friend's steak was succulent goodness. The mango and guava drinks were light and refreshing and perfect for the sunny day. I especially like the fun casualness of the place. We sat at a table that I thought was a children's table because of the crayons and paper. But at second glance,  the drawings on the wall depicted a much more adult humor. Loooooove It!!
author: Sophia C.

description: This is my favorite place to order from for our office lunches. the whole staff agrees. I love the food, but I specifically created this review in hopes of giving constructive feedback to the folks at Parada 22. On a couple of occasions over the last couple months the food has been much saltier than it normally is. Please - don't ruin a delicious thing by dumping too much salt into it. Thanks, and I will certainly order more and stop in again next time I'm in the Haight.
author: Joseph O.

description: Small little place that I really wanted to like.  It was an off night for them because they had just been slammed by Groupon, so they were pretty much out of everything.  We tried the biftec and biftec sandwich, shrimp, and the chicken.  They had just run out of the trout, it looked AWESOME.  I was disappointed at how little steak was in the sandwich and steak plate.  The shrimp was just ehhh, the sauce was good though.  The chicken on the other hand was surprisingly good, not over cooked, but just right.  The salad I really did enjoy, a nice light dressing was ultra flavorful and very crisp.  We had only tried the white rice, it was very buttery.  The red and white beans were good, but I think the white were much better.  3 stars as of now, but I'm willing to give it another shot.
author: Danny T.

description: Small eclectic Puerto Rican joint with great service & really good food. Low key & feel free to where flip flops, you'll feel like you're on the island. Some of the locals look a little scary but they won't bite.  A must!
author: Kimberly S.

description: the food wasn't 100 % authentic... but tasteful. the best part was the service. esteban was great, friendly, polite, and trying to please us as much as he could.
author: Linda B.

description: I purchased a Groupon for this place about a month ago. Went with the bf the other night and had a great experience. Super cute little place in the Haight, friendly attentive waitress, and great food! We both got the sampler plate so we could try a little of everything. A ton of food for only $10! That's a deal in my book. Looking forward to coming back soon!
author: Trisha A.

description: Happened across this place as my boyfriend and I were attempting to not look like tourists while navigating the streets of SF completely aimlessly. I did get the most innocuous items on the menu ,the pollo ensalada and the fried plantains. Both were good but my bpyfriend's cubano was superior. Very good and a great sauce too. I feel as though the food tastes so good because it was a gorgeous perfect day outside and the food complemented it well. I probably would not be a regular If I lived in SF but I would recommend anyone to try it at least once.
author: Emily J.

description: The food was okay. I had the puerco asada combo. I enjoyed the ambiance but the food was very basic. Don't know if I'd patron again . . . I like food that makes my tongue wag for more!
author: D M.

description: Awesome and authentic Puerto Rican food. You can take my word for it, I'm Puerto Rican... Try the Pastelón if they have it as the week's special!
author: Eric S.

description: Outstanding flavorful puertorican/cuban (which one is it?) fare that is affordable and fast.  Service is always great, the place is usually full, but never a wait, what more could you want?  I love that it is small and feels homey, and the decor transports you somewhere warm and near the ocean.  My go-to when going out with the beau or guests in town.
author: Crystal M.

description: This place has potential.  I like the concept, and I like that when I walked in I no longer felt like I was in the Haight. The service was very friendly.  They serve REAL coke.  Their beans and rice were delicious.  But unfortunately the pork was pretty dry and had large chunks of fat on it.  My boyfriend almost choked on a bay leaf that was hidden under some of his beans.  I think with a little more attention to detail this could be a really good place.
author: Gami G.

description: Parada 22 is a great addition to the restaurants of Haight Street. I got the pulled pork with red beans and rice. The pork was juicy and flavorful, but they FORGOT to add the beans to my to-go order! I got a side of the Yuka potatoes which were delicious. The Entrees come with a small side salad (simple greens), rice & choice or red or white beans. Unfortunately again they forgot my red beans. Pretty disappointing. Next time I go I'll request a free side. The place was empty, so I don't see why they would forget. Anyways the food was great. Highly recommended. Double check your to-go order before you leave.
author: Rodney D.

description: Excellent food at great prices.  Quaint little place with good service.
author: Tracy H.

description: Checked out this spot initially because of ScoutMob and was so impressed with the food, I went back a couple more times within the next week. If you're in the 'hood, definitely give it a shot for some quality Puerto Rican food. My fave is the Mofongo Plate which was so savory I almost licked my plate clean. The sangria is the same as neighboring Cha Cha Cha's. It has just enough sweetness to fool you thinking you're drinking punch and causes you to order more because it makes you feel so good. Packed in between exposed brick and aqua blue walls, the ambiance is a great place to go on a chill date or to kick back with small group of friends.
author: Bryant T.

description: For some reason, I can't stop thinking about the steak sandwich. It had a taste that sort of just lingers on in your mouth and your mind after you finish the thing. I could eat two, not only because of its deliciouness, but sadly due to its small size :(. I'e knocked it down a star because of the price and quantity of the food, but the quality I would say makes up for it. I've only ever had the steak sandwich there and my friends have eaten the other sandwiches and left the place satisfied. I spied on the other dishes the other guests were eating and everyone seemed to be satisfied. My first puerto rican food experience was very positive and I'd definitely open up the door to this quaint and cute little restaurant a second time. It fits the neighborhood well, it's a cute, romantic, hipster hole in the wall. The restaurant probably won't do a good job of accommodating a large group, but will do great for intimate settings. It has about 8 tables and 1 long table that could probably fit about 8 people comfortably. I'd recommend this place as a quick bite with friends before heading out to the haight or a casual yet adorable date place.
author: Christine B.

description:
what we ordered...pernil asado, sampler

pernil asado was a disappointment maybe because i was expecting more flavor but it came out to be just an ok roasted pork, and same with the yucca and plantain chip...now, talking about the fried ripened plantain, spanish rice and breaded fried chicken we're talking a different story... plantain was at it's ripest and fried slightly, spanish rice was like a very good paella without the meaty fillings and the chicarron de pollo is the one to go for at this place, flavorful, crispy on the outside and soft and juicy inside....
 
ambiance... good (homey, vintage and very small)
service... ok (just ask me twice if we want anything else but that's about it)
cost... $$
author: Gors P.

description: I went here last night with my bf, brother and sister-n-law. Solid 4-stars.  If you like Cha Cha Cha but hate the wait, come next door to Parada 22.  I especially liked their main pork entree.   Great value!
author: Karina P.

description: Went here the first time last week and have gone twice since.  Great food, reasonably priced.  The beans are great, would suggest the white beans.  I've gotten the pork dish twice, excellent.  My girlfriend got the whole deep fried trout, great! Tough to mess up anything fried though.  The service is excellent.  Food comes out quick and the waitresses are really nice.
author: Darren A.

description: delicious cubano sandwiches. very friendly service and a great ambience. what's not to like?
author: Spiferina P.

description: A friend & I went in here for the first time and it was the worst. Service took a long time and the girl kept saying sorry to everybody. They had one cook, no lemonade & ice tea (I had the last tea and the girl said they didn't have time to make more). The Cubano sandwich I ordered was okay but, not worth the (almost) 30 minute wait. Other people around us had a bad look as well on them about the service. Hope they work on it before a lot of people find out and not go there.
author: Rob G.

description: The food was like in Puerto Rico. I ordered white rice and beans. THe beans had calabaza and jamon de cocinar. The mofong was good. They did not have empanadillas. THey did not have Malta India but they had another brand.  The cooks are not puertoricans but the owners are.
author: Mw C.

description: This review is on behalf of my boyfriend- We came here for lunch today, and the food was incredibly delicious!!!  My boyfriend was raised in Brazil and has missed yucca (cooked properly), Parada 22 had the best tasting yucca ever!  He also loved the beans and spanish rice, saying it is very authentic (I liked it too!).  I had a shrimp dish that was full of flavor.  The restaurant decor is unique, it's casual but nice, I enjoyed the ambiance.  I would give this place five starts if it was in a better location and just a little less expensive, the prices aren't terrible though~  We will be back.
author: Liz Y.

description: Reallllyyy good food. Salad rice and beans comes with every meal. It's a casual atmosphere but it was enjoyable with the colorful decor and Latin music. Also very reasonable!
author: Co W.

description: Great place to grab a reasonably Cuban (or so it seems) food. Where I'm from there's nowhere to get any kind of quality latin cuisine, so the unique experience was refreshing to me. Definitely order their plantains, don't miss out on that. Cozy place, good vibe, somewhat open kitchen. Overall, very satisfied with the food and the portions are filling.
author: Adam C.

description: The roasted pork dish is outstanding! Tender plentiful pork, spanish rice, sofrito-infused beans, nice serving of salad and some tasty fried plantains to boot- all for $10! this is totally how Iike to eat. Cute decor and *great* service! I will be coming back.
author: Monty L.

description: Nice vibe and decor, nicer Cubano, and even nicer platanos. A nice place to unwind after a long day of record shopping at Amoeba next door.
author: Maximillian M.

description: My husband and I finally made it to Parada 22. Overall, we were very pleasantly surprised. I am Dominican and I felt the food was very authentically Puerto Rican. The pollo encebollado was very good, and so were the Spanish rice, white and red beans, and of course, the plantains were to die for. But... I was rather disappointed with the pernil. The pernil I grew up with is not made with white pork meat, and it is juicy, and slow cooked. Otherwise, I would highly recommend  Parada 22. We are planning to go back and try more dishes soon!
author: Digna R.

description: I'm so glad this place exists near my neighborhood.  It's a rare occasion when I don't have an appetite for some juicy chicken, spanish rice, plantains, salad, and beans.  Though the chicken here is not as awesome as Sol Food in San Rafael, I have to say I really love their white beans and spanish rice.  And the convenience of having an alternative to driving across the bridge is awesome.  I'd like to try the watermelon beer sometime.
author: Diana C.

description:
This place is pretty good, plus it gets points for proximity to my apartment. Parada 22 and Cha3 definitely gentrify (I mean that in the best way) this otherwise nasty block of Haight. 

Let's be honest here, Parada 22 is a poor man's Sol Food in SR. The decor and menu are pretty similar, though the taste is a little different. I mean, you can't blame them, Sol Food's definitely got a great business model that is really working for them: simple, delicious food that's reasonable in a fun and colorful environment. Parada 22 is no different. It's amazing how delicious even their simple dishes, like rice and beans, are! 

I got the shrimp, they were wonderful. I would definitely get them again, though I'm excited to try the other offerings on their menu. They also have help yourself pitchers of lemon AND lime water, which was nice. This is a solid 4 star restaurant. I came here with my dad, so it was a low key meal, but I would like to come back with friends and enjoy a beer and hang out at one of their indoor picnic tables.
author: Em G.

description: For people not acquainted with Puerto Rican food, it's going to taste divine, that's why I rated it 4 stars. I was expecting more flavor from those beloved dishes though. My pernil plato was $12. The portion was respectable, but dare I say it, they were a little cheap on the arroz con gandules. They only offered flan for dessert, so I died a little inside at the absence of some classic PR sweets. The service was very very slow, even though it wasn't too busy. I would go back again to try their cubano sammich, but probably just do take-out.
author: Janet R.

description:
I'm pretty stingy with my five star reviews, so I would probably give this a 4.5 star rating if I could, but I can't think of anything I didn't like about my dinner, so I went for the big 5 stars! 
My hubby and I went for dinner with a Groupon deal and were pleasantly surprised at how much we liked it. 
We order the sampler platter- highly recommend! A little bit of everything and all so delicious! Between two people, this would almost qualify as a full meal because the serving is quite large, and at $11, this can't be beat! 
We also ordered the cuban sandwich and a plantain and beef "lasagna" that I don't remember the name of...fabulous. All the food was great, even the side salad! We agreed that it tastes like a Puerto Rican Grandma is cooking up the food.
The serving sizes were generous and the prices great, the waitress super friendly. Nice atmosphere too. 
We will definitely be back, I'm liking it!
author: Emily R.

description: And this Puerto Rican...approves!  I love the decor of the space and the shelving with Puerto Rican products.  Oh, memories.  For the important stuff:  The flavors are on target.  Rice and beans reminded me of school lunch back home; yes, that is what kids got in school.  Jealous much? The pernil could have been a little juicier, but the flavors were great, plus they were on their 2nd day, so no biggie.  The plantain was perfect, and the yucca was yummy.  Now, because I want it all, I look forward to them expanding their menu, and add some tostones, mofongo, etc.  Service is friendly too.
author: Vivian P.

description: stopped by for lunch had the chicharron de pollo which was delicious, spanish rice , beans, twice fried plantains and a spring salad yummy, service was supper nice and attentive. my gf got the cubano sandwich also very tasty, next time we'll have to try the appetizer sampler plate.
author: Wei W.

description: I used my SF Weekly Deal coupon for Parada 22--- my friend and I walked from the Sunset to the Haight-Ashbury and it's a good thing for that long walk to and fro because our authentic Puerto Rican meals weighed us down pretty well for a while! I mean it's 4 hours since I left and I am still full.  My friend had the Mofongo de Camarones and I had the Chicharrones de Pollo. Both were yummy and the portions were big with salad, plantains, your choice of  white or red beans (the secret behind J. Lo's badonkadonk maybe?) and rice (white or Spanish)! Charming decor abounds in this cozy and warm establishment, the kid sister restaurant of Cha Cha Cha just 8 paces down the block. Give Parada 22 a try--- it's a great place for meeting a friend, a cute date after a walk in the park, or a family dinner. Build a good appetite before coming because you get your fill. The 30 block walk back to the outer Sunset was my saving grace that delayed the impending food coma.
author: Patricia M.

description: It's great to actually find a GOOD Puerto Rican restaurant in the city. Usually, I have to go to San Rafael to get my fix, so I was very excited to find out that there was one right in my neighborhood (I live down in the Lower Haight). So far I've only had the cubano sandwich, which was perfectly assembled and tasty. The sauce on it wasn't the plain old yellow mustard that they usually put in the sandwich, but it was garlicky and flavorful. I have yet to try the plantains and I talked to the cashier and he told me very soon they will have tostones and mofongo. Good call! I am Puerto Rican from the island so it made me very happy to learn that Parada 22 is expanding their menu.  Next on my list to try: red beans and rice of course!
author: Gina R.

description:
the pernil asado was my favorite thing.  maybe i'm partial to pork because everyone else preferred the fried trout.  each entree came with red or white beans (choose the red), a couple maduros and a small bit of salad.  we also ordered a side of maduros.  i love maduros!

tips: 
order a corona instead of the other mexican honey beer ($3).
the brick walls mess with cell phone reception.
author: jane d.

description: A good addition to the Haight.  Fast, friendly service served on compostable plates.  Bring a few friends and split a few dishes.  The Cuban pork is delicious and don't forget the plantains...
author: Kra C.

description: I love this place. It is delicious and close to my house, which is all I can ask for in a restaurant. Slightly annoying that they don't take credit card. Who carries cash these days? Blah.
author: Lara C.

description: This Place Has Really Tasty Food The Deep Fried Trout... My Gawd it was Good!!!!! It Could Have Been Fried Harder But Nevertheless it was Very Good I had that and also a Cuban Sandwich My Partner Did not care for his But i Enjoyed mine It could  have been hotter But her for a First time i would go back. Make sure you get a seat when u get in Because the place fills Up Quickly.....
author: kim c.

description: Parada 22 is great. Very authentic Puerto Rican food. Very reasonable prices - The vegetarian dish was only $8, beers $3-$4. You can eat an awesome dinner there for $12! It is cash only.
author: Heather M.

description: chicarrones de pollo!!! best fried chicken in san francisco.
author: Art V.

description: We stopped here after seeing all the great review on yelp and looking for a new place in the neighborhood.  Loved the charming ambiance of this place, we were seated fairly quickly, but we did go in around 8 pm so a lot of people were finishing up.  We had the shrimp dish and an eggplant sandwich.  They were both delicious but the shrimp dish was especially memorable.  I would definitely go back for it!  The service was good and the food came quickly.  I would definitely recommend this place.
author: J. Marie N.

description: This spot has been vacant for so long, I have to say that I'm so glad this great little restaurant moved in to the spot. Yummy Puerto Rican food for a good price. This is a great addition to the Upper Haight.
author: Sabrina L.

description: Coming from a person who grew up eating Puerto Rican all of her life this place is okay. I've never been to a PR restaurant that doesn't serve Arroz con gandules (staple in PR). The pernil was not pernil, it was cut up pork chops with a little bit of seasoning and I mean a little. I had bistec encebollado, which was good but not enough on my plate.
author: Debby O.

description: so good.  the chicharron de pollo was so tasty...finger-lickin' good ya'll, if you know what i mean.  the camarones over the salad was really good, and they have great sandwiches too.  they have this sampler side platter that is a huge mound of stuff....good to get if you have a group of people (and by "group" i mean more than 1 person)....go ahead, pig out...you only live once (or so i'm told).
author: Miss P.

description: My better half and I did a stroll through the Haight this afternoon for a little bargain shopping and some sun on our faces. Putting off lunch far too long we decided to go to CHA CHA CHA's for some tapas and what not. There was a twenty+ min wait for a table and being 3:00pm and starving we moved on. Just next door we came across this Puerto Rican place that looked inviting. We looked over the posted menu and agreed to go on in. Glad we did. I had the Biftec Sandwich (sliced sauteed steak with cheese onions and garlic) and my partner had the Pernil Asado (Roasted Pork marinated with garlic and oregano based surfrito).. Both were delicious and with his came a small ramekins of Puerto Rican beans. Now I'm not usually a bean guy but these were out of this world. My other half is a serious bean guy and said these were some of the best he ever tasted. I went as far to ask if they sold them in larger quantities to go but was unfortunately declined. We split some flan for dessert and that was also over the top good.  We came to find out later that it is owned by the same people as CHA CHA CHA's.
author: John W.

description: The shrimp was fantastic, and the Cuban sandwich very worthwhile. I like the substance and variety to the plates.  This is a nice local place I will go to often. Great for a very casual experience, rather than a more formal "dining out" one.
author: Jeremy R.

description: I don't think Puerto Rican food will ever be one of my favorite cuisines, but what they do, they do extremely well!
author: Michael S.

description:
I stopped in for a weekday lunch.  Festive latin music was fun.  The place seats maybe only 25 people, and we grabbed one of only a few tables fit for more than 2 people.  The place was empty and we got quick, kind service.  

Classic cuban sandwich is one of my favorite lunches, and this one was solid.  Sweet tea to drink - love it.  The girlfriend had a roast pork entree with plantains, green salad, red beans and spanish rice.  All so tasty.
author: Matt S.

description: This place is terrific and a great addition to the neighborhood.  My mom is Puerto Rican and I can vouch for the authenticity of the flavors of this place.  Pernil is a pork dish that we have in our family only at Christmastime, because it is so labor intensive to season the meat.  So it is a delight to have it available here all the time.  Their spicy sauce on the counter is extremely hot and looks and tastes just like the one my grandfather used to make and pour on all his food.  We enjoyed everything we ordered, as did both of our kids (5 and 2).
author: Victor O.

description: Food is amazing!!  The roast pork leg dish, the cuban sandwich, the shrimp... all amazing!   Love the space as well.  A great spot to grab some great authentic Puerto Rican food.
author: Adam S.

description: La Boricua sez, this place is de pelicula!!!
author: Miss N.

description: Yum!  One of my favorite places to eat in SF!  Always friendly and delicious food!
author: Vanessa L.

description:
This place was almost a 4-star, but there is room for improvement. First, I have to say that - being a 28-year resident of the upper Haight and very underwhelmed with the restaurant selection and quality - I was very, very pleased to see this new restaurant open. Welcome to the Haight - live long and prosper, PLEASE! 

I ordered the chicken thigh plate with the white (veggie) beans and rice (sorry, I can't remember the names of the dishes). The portion size was good, the rice and beans were delicious. The chicken, however, was overspiced or too salty - I couldn't decide which. I couldn't finish it. My partner had the pork, which was better than the chicken. We also ordered an extra salad, because I wanted to try the dressing, but I think it was the same salad that was on my plate. 

We will definitely go back - but I might just order rice and beans and a salad next time (I don't eat red meat or cheese and there are not a whole lot of other options there, such as alternate chicken dishes), and I think it would be more than enough. 

Thanks Parada 22 for opening in the Haight!
author: Mara K.

description:
One star off for no spicy vinegar sauce.
One star off for no tostones.
One star off for bad service.
One star off for unevenly cooked, bland food.
One star off for obvious cost-cutting measures including two teensy weensy pieces of sweet plantains. 
Ok, I will add a star for the pleasant interior. 

My main reason for yelping Parada 22 is that it has decent ratings, but I don't want perfectly decent people to waste their money on an inauthentic and flavorless meal. Go to Sol Food.
author: Lina C.

description: This place has a great menu and serves food that keeps them coming back.  Truly a great neighborhood restaurant.  I am surprised that Yelp allows a racist rants in the reviews however.
author: Richard M.

description: We had a great meal, a wonderful time.  The place was spic and span when we came in.   My only regret was that I did not get the waitresses name.  She was great, friendly, professional, and was around when we needed anything.  She did not roll her eyes when we pulled out a coupon, or when I asked her what the Parada 22 meant.  My son asked her a million questions, and she gave him all the time he wanted.  Fortunately, most of the time we were there, we were the only diners. I had the Pernil Asado, which was tender and yummy.  This dish came with white or Spanish rice and white or black beans, salad, and plantains.  I loved the white beans, flavorful, and nicely spiced.   The plantains were sort of mushy, but OK.  Water is served in paper cups, weird, but it was nicely flavored with lemon.
author: Carol K.

description: I am digging this place a little more every time I go there. Great food, great atmosphere and a great alternative to jetting up to San Rafael for Sol Food. And, it's in my hood so- yo gusto. But they have to make tostones!
author: Dave B.

description: Got the yucca and avocado salad.  Simple, super yummy and a generous portion.  Very filling.  Don't know if it's totally authentic or not as I haven't eaten much Puerto Rican cuisine but it tasted great and I thought it was reasonably priced.  Good enough to make me return for sure.  Super friendly service, too.
author: BJ F.

description: Went to Parada 22 for lunch. I'm a New York Rican and cook my own PR food, but have been searching for someplace to go eat when I don't want to cook...this is not the place. The food was served on horribly chipped plates... I mean just plain nasty. Drinks were in paper cups...WTF?  They had tostones and no mojito to dip it in (contrary to popular belief, mojito is NOT just a drink, it originally is a garlic dipping sauce). No one knew what I was talking about, but served up the minced garlic that you get in a jar from the supermarket..not a true mojito at all. Instead they served a mayonnaise/ketchup mixture that's supposed to be very puerto rican. NOT SO MUCH, My abuela would've slapped me had I served that! My friend asked for mofongo and it was made with shrimp..not the usual mofongo made with pork or beef..we didn't like it at all. For puerto-rican food, this was not good at all, and there wasn't a puerto rican in sight in the kitchen. Evidently the chef lives in PR and comes to train the cooks.  The only thing I liked were the beans. The roast pork (pernil) was not seasoned enough, the salad was limp. Ay Dios, don't waste your money. It's a tacky little restaurant that needs some decent plates and flatware..and glasses, and needs a real puerto-rican trained chef who knows our food and not just horrible imitations of it.
author: Arlene J.

description: nom nom nom. this place is soooooo yummy! scored a sweet livingsocial coupon for this place which worked out well because i've been wanting to check out this restaurant for awhile now. super chill vibe. our waitress was cool. my sis and i took her recommendation on what to order and boy was she spot on. we ordered the mofongo ( mashed green plantains served with sauteed shrimp) and the pastelon (sweet plantains layered with picadillo). soooo good. lots of flavor. good portion size. not too much, not too little. it was so good that my sister literally cleaned her plate. this was my first time trying puerto rican food and now i can't wait to come back! =)
author: Linda N.

description:
Heard about this place the other day and thought I would give it a try. Been in SF for about 8 years and am always looking for Puerto Rican food being a NY Rican myself. First I would like to say I know this place is new, so given that, I will go back in a year to see how they improve. 

Food is edible but please don't walk away thinking you ate Puerto Rican food. Portions are on the small side and they still need time to work out the ingredients. The pork was actually tasty but again if you are looking for pernil this is not it. I tried the yucca and was very disappointed. The white rice dish was not good and what they call Spanish rice taste like rice out the box that you find at the grocery store. 

I see that most of the reviews are very positive but I didn't see or experience anything that was mentioned. There was no service with a smile and the place is still kind of empty no real feel to it.. clean and all but no aroma of puerto rican food that takes you back (for those puerto ricans out there) 

Ive tried all the Puerto Rican food in the bay area and I suggest for good PR food go to NYC or PR.
author: Chase T.

description: This place is great. The food is authentic and the atmosphere is quite pleasant. A wonderful addition to the Haight.
author: Mark H.

description:
I ate at Parada 22 last night.  Good news and bad news.  The room is fine, but probably functions best as a place to pick up food-to-go, because it's small, loud, and offers only a few picnic tables for seating. The food is served on paper plates with the cheapest, flimsiest plastic utensils I've ever seen;  I've never understood how restaurant owners think they can cut corners that way without turning off the customers they need to make it in a tough business.  How much would it cost to provide real silverware to people who are eating in the shop?  The plastic junk they expect you to use to cut through not-inconsiderable chunks of pork seemed designed to frustrate would-be terrorists in the event of a hijacking.

That said, the food was delicious.  We tried the Cubano sandwich and the pernil, a roasted pork dish, along with orders of both red and white beans.  The sandwich was sublime -- smoky, sweet, and perfectly balanced, with slices of roast pork, ham, and Swiss cheese along with piquant mustard and pickles on a warm, sublimely textured, slightly crispy white bun.  It's instantly one of the best sandwiches in the city.  The pernil, in thick slices with a few shreds of caramelized onion, was slightly less impressive, being somewhat dry, a little stingy of portion, and not quite singing with garlic flavor. But it was good home-cooking style, and I would order it again.  It came with a couple of slices of fried maduro plantains, slightly crispy and caramelized, which were wonderful -- it might be worth ordering a whole side of those.

The highlight of the meal was the beans.  The red ones were cooked with pork, the white beans with a vegetable/oregano sofrito, and both were exquisite: soft, savory, comforting, smoky-tasting.  Vegetarians should be very happy with an order of white beans, rice, and maduros (along with several other vegetable dishes we didn't order.)  Next time I'd like to try the whole fried fish, which was an Oregon trout last night.

There will be a next time.
author: Steve S.

description: Cute place, but food was average. And by average i mean i can probably cook better Puerto Rican food than they can despite my asian american upbringing.
author: LT B.

description:
Once a year I get together with 5 of my cousins we do a "sister's weekend" the theater and dinner.  This year we went to West Side Story and to Parada to carry on the Puerto Rican theme.  Also, Groupon had a coupon $10 for $20 worth of food. Our lucky day.  No way!  Some of us ordered the steak sandwich (BIFTEC) they should call it an onion sandwiche..maybe two very thin slices of beef..rip off.  The Cubano sandwiche was not any better.  But the killer is that when our check came it did not have any of the prices only the grand total which seemed high.  I had to look at a menu and spend time adding up the bill.
I felt embarassed and felt bad for my guest.  Finally, our waitress asked if I wanted to see the prices..I said yes/she looked on the cash register and sure enough they had charged me an extra $20 plus dollars.  I'm sure they thought we were tourist (since my silly cousins were taking pictures) and they wanted to get the $20 back from the groupon!  What a scam!!  The food is not worth it and make sure you check your bill/I'm pretty sure they've done this before.  Oh, by the way we all grew up in the Mission so we know good latin food..not to mention PR in the family..
author: May L.

description: Food is just ok.  Tostones were not crunchy, pork was tough, salad drenched in dressing.  Saving grace was the flavorful beans.  The waitress was friendly which earned them an extra star.
author: Lili C.

description: Yummy distinctive dishes. Prices reasonable with friendly pro service. Parking can be rough, neighborhood is well, either interesting and cool or sketchy.
author: w l.

description: four of us were really hungry for being stuck in traffic & finding parking for hours so we can shop on haight, luckily we bumped into Parada 22 right away & everything was so amazingly good that i thought it was so worth it. we were two adults, one child & a teenager, we all agreed that this place is delicious A++. we didn't have to wait at all & was greeted by the hostess/waitress at the door, she was really sweet & friendly, it was a happy time we had in there. we basically ordered every meat dish there were, everything on my plate was sooo good, from the rice to beans to plantains & i loved their salad too, all of these things were part of the dish. i'm going back next time to try their seafood dishes. ok, writing this makes me really hungry.
author: zoelle C.

description: I was walking to another restaurant on Haight and saw this restaurant.  I like to explore the variety of restaurants the city offers so I decided to stop in and ordered the sampler plate.  The Maduros & Tostones are to die for.
author: Louis T.

description: I was disappointed.  I am Puerto Rican and really wanted to like this place, but didn't unfortunately.  After reading what people were saying about the Camarones I was excited to try them. Nothing special at all.  The pernil was also a disappointment.  Instead of roasted pork shoulder, what they served us had the texture of pork loin.
author: Noel S.

description: the pastelon and pernil asado were very good .. it was my first taste of puerto rican food and quite impressed.  i enjoyed every bite.  christy was a very sweet host, making this experience quite memorable.  oh, and that sangia .. yummy! -- definitely would like to try other menu items the next time i'm in town =)
author: Arlene D.

description: Watermelon wheat beer, and the special - something the waitress described as "kind of like lasagna" with sweet plantains and ground beef - completely rocked my world. This little old-school charmer is so tiny that you literally walk through the kitchen to get to the bathroom (but you can see your food being made!), so it's very intimate (read: don't come with a group of more than four people - but a nice place for a casual date!)  They have 50% off on scoutmob.com (which means that you can order more for the same price; believe me you will want to!).  Also tried the fried plantains (good, as fried often is) , and the rum cake - which was so mouthwatering and authentic I almost didn't want to split it with my counterpart. Overall, this place gets a 4/5 - they could improve the seating arrangements so that we weren't practically locked into our table by the guests flanking our front and back -  but the food we tried was delicious, the place itself was kitschy, casual and intimate, and it set the tone for a great meal!
author: Lindsay B.

description: This place is small, but the food is really really good, especially for lunch.  The Cubano sandwich is great as well as the shrimp salad.  We overheard the lady working say that the recipes are from the owners grandmother.  Very authentic cuban.  Highly recommended for lunch, especially if Cha Cha Cha (next door) is over crowded.
author: Justin G.

description: The decor is lovely, but they are clearly still working out a lot of kinks.  Price is about 30% higher than it should be for what is, ultimately, very basic, homestyle Puerto Rican food without much adornment, of the type you can get for $5 a plate at any number of places in Miami.  With the exception of the bizcoche de ron (cake with a rum custard layer), it was nothing memorable.  Our server was extraordinarily friendly, and the place is beautifully decorated -- a lot of thought clearly went into the design -- but they are clearly having a lot of trouble drawing business and for the moment I presume they are relying on a trickle of people who get fed up waiting in line at Cha Cha Cha next door (same ownership group, I believe).  A place this nice deserves a better and more inventive menu; if they're going to stick with very simple comfort food and sandwiches, it needs a serious rethink.  For instance, I would *love* to see this place reincarnated as a late-night $4 sandwich shop.  In its present configuration, though, it just doesn't work.  I'd give it 3 stars if I had faith that it would get better and I thought I might go back, but I don't, so it gets 2.
author: Tee Jay R.

description: if you craving a cubano sandwhich you now have a place. good location on h8 st, so you can wonder around after eating. if you like garlic Yuca al moja is very good.
author: dee s.

description: Love the decor in this small place.  Very creative. Food is solid too. but it's owned by cha cha cha so was a little disappointed. Still I'm happy to have found this place.
author: Ellie C.

description: Great service from nice waitress with blonde hair this past Saturday night, and delicious food to boot. I did take out and tried the shrimp (sometimes risky to take out seafood) dinner and was blown away. The sauce with the dish was incredible, and accompanying rice and beans were unlike any I have had in latin cuisines. Bottom line, this was a delicious meal and was pleasantly surprised by the two pieces of maduros with our dinner - soooo good, highly recommended! Price range is technically $$, but most expensive dinner runs $12. Do it, Try IT!
author: Scott C.

description: The Puerto Rican food here is very good!  Nice portions for a nice price.  Don't skip on the dessert - the flan is delicioso!  The staff was friendly and the place was quaint.  It is a small restaurant with big flavors.  Definitely worth going back.
author: Noemi M.

description: New local fave!  Delicious, quick, inexpensive and they do takeout!  The grilled pollo is divine, tender, crispy, and well-seasoned.  And my friend loved the camarones a la croilla, shrimp peeled and cooked in a creamy sauce.  All mains are generous portions, served with beans, rice, plaintains and a small green salad (no iceberg lettuce!).  If you want lighter fare, they have a long list of salads and the housemade vinaigrette is yummy.  I've heard that the eggplant sandwich is also highly recommended.  Don't be surprised if I become a regular.
author: Rochelle E.

description: I chose this place because it was my boyfriends birthday and he had his heart set on Caribbean food in the city. I love puerto rican food so i was already expecting to enjoy what they had. The pictures on yelp let me know it wasn't gonna be super fancy but nice. The food was great! Only problemas for the birthday boy and his mom were they were out of pork, so they instead for the shrimp dish and beef. The menu is small but considering had a good variety. The place is kinda small we got there around six on a sunday and it wasn't to crowded but the place was filled by the time we left.  I got the Yucca salad which was bigger than i expected and EXCELLENT. We shared a plate of sweet plantains which was our dessert. The other thing that I recommend is to not to sit by the door if you are at all sensitive to cigarette (or weed) smoke we had to ask them to close the door (it is Haight street, and there is a bar right next door) Once they closed the door it was all good. I would say its a slightly Americanized Puerto Rican good eat spot if your willing to spend a little extra cash.
author: W R.

description: This place is awesome. Food is excellent, prices are very reasonable and they give huge portions.  I had the bistec and carmelized onions with the Spanish rice and red beans.  Definitely recommend this dish.  We also shared the sampler platter, everything was delicious, especially the yucca.  Try the flan it melts in your mouth.  The service was good too, very attentive.  Can't wait to go back.
author: Mariel G.

description: Wish we came here more often when we were in the neighborhood.  This is a nice, casual spot with great food.  Had the pernil asado which could feed 2.  The plantains were prepared well, golden color.  Also had the plantain chips (YUM!) and yuca (tasty garlic sauce).  Very affordable.  Want to come back for the chicken wings.
author: win c.

description: We went there twice, For lunch I had the cubano sandwich which was very tasty. Also went there in the evening and had the biftek. It was like a homecooked meal! The sangria was very good, too. It is tiny so you need to be patient about close quarters.
author: Kathleen S.

description: love the food and the pics on the wall.  i had the plantains and that ish went great with a beer!  def. going back.  bench seating good for a quick bite and priced reasonable
author: Jerry Lee F.

description: I visited on a Saturday night and for starters, the service was the epitome of first class.  The food was delicious and I loved the warm welcoming atmosphere.  I'll be back!
author: Lauri R.

description: Great addition to the hood. Reasonably priced food with lots of flavour. What they do, they do very well.
author: Jeff B.

description: Really, really good food that is slightly different than you'd normally find. Of course, it's Puerto Rican food but not exactly knowing what that means, I went in with excitement at eating something new and refreshing. We shared our meals which is always my favorite way to go! The Pernil Asado, roasted pork, was tender and tasty, not spicy at all. Came with baked plantains, red beans and yellow rice. I'm not always a big fan of beans as they just seem so "beanie" but these were wonderful. Very tender, tasty, and larger than pinto or black beans. The plaintains were like dessert.  We shared the Berenjena, grill eggplant sandwich with a cream cilanto-garlic jack cheese. It was like a pannini and very tasty. Sorry to keep using with word tasty but my mind is rather tired and not able to branch out much these days! We ordered the Yuca Al Mojo, the cassava or juka root, which came out like mashed potatos. They were yummy (tried to avoid tasty), giving you that little bit of starch but in a way that made you feel like you were eating healthy and natural. What a fun place to go. Not real big in terms of seating but we sure saw lots of people coming in and getting food to go. Will definitely go back here!!
author: P G.
